On Wed, 7 Aug 1996 blkadder@value.net wrote:

> You know, I for one get real tired of this "I can't believe a *raver* 
> would say XXXX." Who are you to tell me, or anyone else what they should 
> believe to be a "raver?" Do I get kicked out of the "raver" club if I 
> don't agree?

well you know, i just allowed myself to wonder a bit. no need to get upset.
nobody kicks you out of the club if you don't do it yourself.
but if i keep reading on this list that money is not the thing to 
make you happy, but, all and forever, PLUR, and if i keep reading posts 
that have people contemplating about the evils of mc donalds and 
advertising campaigns, and if i keep reading posts that show people are 
aware of environmental problems, poverty in the third world and the connection
between these puppies and capitalist economy, and if i keep reading that 
people are reflecting what they, obligated by their special quality of being 
*ravers* could possibly do about and against that, then i start drawing 
conclusions about those californian ravers nature.

and if then, all of a sudden, posts emerge, virtually written by the same 
people, that recommend 'move yer butt and get yerself a job at mc donalds', 
or in advertising, posts that express not only disapproval, but hate against 
people that don't work and produce 'litters of children', dear black adder,
and if i see these people being all concerned somebody could steel 
their money from them and have a good time (not concerned, of course, 
about those oh so necessary spendings for defence), then i can't help 
being a little puzzled.

me:
> > normally you don't earn money by making the world a nice place for 
> > everybody, but by producing needless stuff, talking people into buying 
> > needless stuff, do research in the name of progress (a concept that is 
> > totally questionable nowadays), generally by contributing to the 
> > limitless growth that is a consequence of capitalist economy and 
> > inevitably fucks the world up. i mean, hey, how many of you actually 
> > bake bread or teach children (or other sweet things to think of) to make 
> > a living. *i don't*. 

> Well then try to find a job in a field you feel good about. I feel good 
> about what I do, and rather it meets your definition of usefulness is 
> unimportant. 

yeah sure you don't care the fuck wether i consider it useful what you do.
i got that.
but wether your job provider considers what you would like to 
do, or what you're good at, or what you think would be of advantage for 
mankind as a whole being useful (for his business), this *is* important. 
is it not? for he won't pay you a penny for something he *feels bad about*.
but thats ok. i understand.

about me, i like my job. i'm only aware of the fact that what i do 
(theoretical biophysics) is completely unnecessary in the sense that it 
doesn't do any good for anybody. they could as well pay me for doing nothing. 
but, at least it doesn't cause any damage, a thing that can't be said about 
too many jobs that are out there. i imagine you would agree with me when i 
say that maybe some solid 50% of the goods that are produced/services offered
are sheer luxury, if not completely needless and are just produced/offered to 
keep the circle of economy moving, all on the cost of nature.

me:
> > i think somebody who doesn't work might actually cause less overall damage 
> > than somebody who does. 
> 
> Yes, and our race would have been extinct several million years ago had 
> we embodied this philosophy.   

this is why i called the belief that one had to work to justify ones 
existence **oldfashioned**.  this is something that used to be true when the 
means of production weren't so high developed as they are today. today, 
everything that is really needed can be produced by a fraction of the 
population with the help of all those machines.

happy,funny communist-beating!
ulrike

Saw this in Time Magazine.  In a poll, 12% of the respondants said that they
"use E-mail or the internet", and their astrological signs break down as
follows: 
 
Taurus:         18%
Libra:          11%
Sagittarius:    10% 
Scorpio:        10%     
Aries:           8%
Capricorn:       8%
Gemini:          8%
Aquarius:        7%
Cancer:          6%
Leo:             6%
Pisces:          4%
Virgo:           4%

Somewhat interesting.  The 4 most frequently reported signs on sfr (Aq, Gem, 
Can, Pis w/ 11, 10, 9, 9, making up ~39%), are in the bottom half of all
e-mail/Inet users, comprising only 25%.  Then again, only 97 people on this
list responded, and who knows what cross-section Time polled?  Oh, well, it
amuses my mostly-asleep brain. 

-mike

Firstly, you need to read "the New republlic" by Plato and anything by 
John Paul Sarte and then re-think your definition of the words, socialism,
government and democracy.
Secondly, when a person recieves a welfare cheque he is not benefitting
from Government generiousity or stealing from fellow tax payers.  He/she
is recieving a bribe so that he/she will just go home and keep quiet.
Remember: no moniterist Government can afford to have 100% employment so
each unemployed person actually keeps five people in work.  If there weere
not welfare recipiants you, Wowser, would not even to be able to afford
your computer or anything so stop complaining and be thankful for small
mercies.  In short, capitalism can not function without unemployment and
welfare so the very thing that you crtizise is the very thing that keeps
the system that you tradgically believe in.
And finaly. socialism, democracy etc are all words that are used to pull
the wool over our eyes and, in practise, they mean nothing.  These ideals
can only be truely achieved in a society where there are no laws, no
governemnt or elections, no police and everyone is paid the same
regaurdless of what they do because each individual understands the fact
that they are just as an important as everybody else.  This system is
called Anachism and it is the only way that man can carry on living in
large societies and survive. 
Tristan.

Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Thu, 8 Aug 1996 08:06:28 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: leftjab@well.com (leftjab)
Subject: social security -- the regressive tax (NRR)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>    Social Security                $352   21.8%
>    Welfare                        $ 75    4.6%
>      (but not food stamps or
>      unemployment)
>    Food stamps                    $ 27    1.7%
>    Unemployment                   $ 24    1.5%


according to the stat posted, social security is the biggest chunk of our
budget -- and is paid for by a regressive tax.  The percentage is flat up
to a certain level of income (I forget what, sorry) and after that income
is social-security-tax-free.

yet, basically everyone gets equal social security, tax-free, even rich
people who paid proportionately less than poor people for social security,
and who ostensibly need social security less (yeah, i know, it's supposed
to be a deal based on what you pay into the system . . . in which case we
should all stop if we're sure it's going to go bust).

maybe that's why social security taxes are untouchable . . . whatever one
thinks of welfare + food stamps + unemployment, we pay almost 3 times as
much in social security.

the big shift in income by decade in the 80's wasn't just from poor to
rich, it was from young to old.  According to Geoffrey T. Holtz's amazing
book "Welcome to the Jungle," using U.S. Census figures, from 1973-91, the
median income of 15-24 year-olds and 25-34 year-olds fell by more than 27%,
while the income for all other age groups has risen, particularly for those
over 65.  In 1970, the median 20-24 year-old male had an income 67% of a
median 45-54 year-old; in 1990 the 20-24 year-old made 34% as much (for
25-34 year-olds, the decline is from 92% to 69%).

food for thought,

leftjab

Good day,

>Well what kind of oils do you use? I know lotion sucks, if you get crappy lotion, you'll be 
>wishing there was a shower near by. Wouldn't your oils make you all oily??? Lotion is 
>just cool for hand rubs. Anything else and it just isn't too cool.

Brian mentioned using hybrid oils, of one or more of the types listed.  Almond oil can often be 
found rather inexpensively.  These do not have the slimey feel of lotion and, with a simple
hand towel or paper towel do not leave a staining (clothes) oily residue behind.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Aug  8 09:34:55 1996

Received: from tgrigsby (tgrigsby.us.dhl.com [199.41.137.104]) by shellx.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id JAA10326 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 8 Aug 1996 09:34:26 -0700
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 1996 09:34:26 -0700
Message-Id: <199608081634.JAA10326@shellx.best.com>
X-Sender: tgrigsby@best.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: Re: NRR: Welfare (was "Socialism")
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

David Lowe wrote:

>It does make me sad that many of these people, liberated from the bullshit
>working lifestyle,

I don't see the working lifestyle as bullshit.  I see it as selling my 
services.  I'm not a slave.  I'm a contractor.  We all are.  We contract 
with our employers, selling our services.  The minute you don't like the 
arrangement, you can begin marketing your services to other bidders.  I am 
contracting my services to a company.  I have an agreement with them to 
perform certain duties, produce certain items, and in return for the hours I 
spend I am reimbursed in the agreed upon currency.  And then you want me to 
turn around and give part of my money to some mystery person, someone who 
has given me no guarantee that they're making an effort to get off the dole, 
to support themselves?  No, I don't buy it.

We live in a capitalist society.  I don't think anyone that's had to buy 
food, pay rent, an spend money at the gas pump is going to argue this point. 
 If you wish to live in a communal society where everything you gain is 
pooled so that others can use it without question, you need to go find that 
society.  Putting a person that has no money and doesn't want to earn any in 
a society based on money is like throwing an animal that can't swim into the 
ocean.  That's the reality of life.  Another reality is that people 
generally don't like to see that which they've worked hard to earn given to 
someone who has made a living off government subsidies for doing nothing.

>  Okay, very nice.  In the real world, however, there are people who can't
>find jobs.

And in this program they could get training for a different job.

>How do you deal with the fact that we live in a bigoted society, where
>someone who is black, or female, or ugly (by society's standards) may have
>a hard time or find it impossible to find work.

I say bullshit.  People of every race, color, creed, personal hygiene, and 
Vogue/GQ factor manage every day to find gainful employment and support 
themselves.  I know -- I'm a systems engineer, and I occasionally have to 
work with some of the ugliest, smelliest people in the world...  ;)

>  Also, there are people who don't want to work.  I'm all for that.

And I'm not.  Fine, you don't want to work for someone else?  No problem.  
Write a book.  Paint.  Do something that produces something that is 
marketable.  Or move out to the country and start farming to support 
yourself.  I don't care, but don't put your hand in my pocket like you've 
got the right.  If you want my help, you're going to have to start by 
helping yourself, and the program I propose gives people the chance to do 
just that.

>  And
>there are people who are not willing to work below their skill levels, who
>demand that a job meet their needs.  And I'm all for that too.  Nobody
>should *have* to work in a miserable environment.

Again, I don't care what they're willing to do, this becomes a question of 
what I'm willing to do, and I'm not willing to wipe someone's ass just 
because it's 
beneath him to do it himself.  He'd better swallow a little of that pride 
and get busy.  What I propose gives a person a chance to determine for 
themselves what kind of job they want, to obtain the skill sets they need, 
and gives them time to apply themselves in the pursuit of finding gainful 
employment in their selected field.

>> "Give a man a fish, and you feed him for a day.  Teach him to fish, and you 
>> feed him for a lifetime."
>
>  Unless he doesn't like fish... 

Don't be disingenuous.  If he doesn't like fish, then he better learn to 
hunt or farm.  Or starve.  And if someone isn't *intelligent enough* to do 
that, then so be it.

S

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Aug  8 11:23:26 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id LAA16708; Thu, 8 Aug 1996 11:23:26 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from arl-img-4.compuserve.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id LAA16695; Thu, 8 Aug 1996 11:23:22 -0700 (PDT)
Received: by arl-img-4.compuserve.com (8.6.10/5.950515)
	id OAA28305; Thu, 8 Aug 1996 14:22:50 -0400
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 1996 14:18:39 -0400
From: "Jason C. Lundy" <104242.1233@compuserve.com>
Subject: Work ethic
To: Wowser <tuskluv@lewiston.com>
Cc: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <199608081422_MC1-854-6527@compuserve.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Good day,

I have been trying to stay out of this one for a while, but this message has touched a 
nerve.  I had probably on of the *best* work ethics an employer could hope for.  In Jan.
95, I injured my knee on the job and continued to work while going to physical therapy.
Before this injury, I was working 45-60 hours a week at my job in an attempt to pay off
debt that I had incurred several years earlier.  Two months into P.T. I reinjured my knee
lifting weights.  To make a long story short, it became progressively harder to continue
with my duties at work by Feb. of 96.  My injury had become a permanent disability.
Despite my 7 years of experience and skill, this employer became upset over how my
weekly trips to the therapist, for this condition, was inconveniencing him. (he couldn't
seem to keep the times straight and would schedule work in these slots anyway, or
would over book the schedule and have a FIT when I reminded him that the doctor's orders 
were to not have me standing more than 40min of every hour)  This still caused some 
pain, but I felt that I was making some progress with the condition.  They *asked* if
I could do anything about the doctors orders.  When I said that they were in place to
make sure the condition didn't worsen, I was sent home.  It seems the alternate 
desk job that I was most qualified for, was the technical service duties that were a small
part of my boss' duties.  Unfortunately, these were his most cushy duties and he was 
quoted as saying "what! You want to give him your job", to a felllow employee, after I had 
been sent home.  This man was quite incompetentwhen it came to tech service, and had 
a hard time remembering a conversation you might have had with him yesterday.  When 
he was out of town and I would take over tech, upon his return, he would find that everyone 
was interested in talking to me because I was courtious and knew what the hell I was talking 
about (he often didn't, and customers picked up on this)  So what did this great work ethic 
get me?  A hellish trip through a Worker's Comp. program, where I  have yet to collect the 
training that is due me.  By the way,  pro-businness legislators have restructured this 
program with a cap of $16,000 for schooling, money to live off of, ($700 a month less than 
I was making without O.T.) counselors fees (up to $4500) and any other expenses.  I am 
fighting with the insurance company to get part of a disability settlement that is mine, as a 
lump sum, for the sole purpose of extending my training from a 2 mo. CNA  to a 5 mo. CNE 
program.  They have cut off my income, without even contacting me, when the claims 
examiner was fired and had not turned in any on the required paperwork to my employer 
etc. etc. This alone cost me 45 days of crucial time, where my money to retrain is limited.  
Not to mention, causing even more friction between the employer and myself; we both 
thought the other was dragging their feet.  They haven't even taken me off of the payroll, so 
I can get my hands on the profit sharing money that I earned while in their employ (working 
on this).  These are the same people who want to enact sweeping welfare cuts.  I say cuts 
and not reform, because THEY would like nothing better than for NONE of THEIR money 
to go to these FREELOADERS.  Do you really feel that $13,000 in disability payments will 
make up for not being able to spend more than minutes dancing; nix on mountain biking, 
free climbing, hiking or just standing for long periods of time.  And I am trying to spend
$6000 of this to train myself to a level that would have been taken care of before "reforms"
were enacted.

Please think about the people who use these safety nets in earnest, before you gut them 
due to the abuse of some.  Without help from my friends and family, both emotionally and 
monetarily, I would be livivg in absolute depression right now.  The very orange 286 relic 
I am typing on right now, was donated by a good friend of mine.  When the my WC checks 
stopped temporarily, without help, I would have been out on my ass, with legal costs due 
to breach of lease, unable to get a afford deposits for a new apt.  Some people for various 
reasons, do not have any of these internal safety networks and should not be punished for 
lack of them.

I realize that drawing a parallel between WC and welfare is stretching a bit.  But, my point is 
that any "reforms" that are enacted aren't going to help society or recipients in any way if they 
don't include such things as education and child care for those you are trying to get out of the 
system.  Who is going to watch "welfare mom's" kids while she's flippin' burgers for $4.25 
an hour?  What do care worker's get for this on average?   $7-8 dollars an hour.  This means 
we must train those that are willing to work into at least $10 an hour jobs if you expect to get 
anywhere.  I haven't even seen any education guarantees from those who are proposing
reform, because this cost with child care is often more expensive than Welfare alone, in the
short term.  And our representatives are concerned primarily with the short term, quarterly
earnings of their big business pals.  

This will probably be my only public post on the subject of socialism, wefare etc.

Thank you for your time.

Take care,
                    Jason
  

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Aug  8 11:27:33 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id LAA17118; Thu, 8 Aug 1996 11:27:33 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from netcom15.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id LAA17102; Thu, 8 Aug 1996 11:27:29 -0700 (PDT)
Received: (from branka@localhost) by netcom15.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id LAA18269; Thu, 8 Aug 1996 11:27:22 -0700

From: Branka Cehic <branka@netcom.com>
Subject: Re: Intolerance for Hippie Crack (LONG)
To: "E. Nygma" <enigma@best.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <199608080256.TAA01380@dns1.noc.best.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9608081029.A14712-0100000@netcom15>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

You wrote:

Compare this to the legal scene, where alcohol, a depressant that
often leads to irrational and violent behavior, not to mention auto
accidents, and tobacco, a sedative with addictive effects comparable
to heroin, are the legal drugs today. This comparison is best observed
at venues such as Wicked, when the scene changes from club land to
rave land at 2:00am.

Hmmm.....  I am not sure if I completely agree with your statements in 
the above paragraph.  Maybe I should start with smoking - I quit 3 1/2 
weeks ago after 10-11 years of smoking.  The only times I crave a smoke 
is early in the morning after partying all night (going to after party 
and watching other people smoke).  Maybe I am different than other 
people, maybe I just didn't get addicted to nicotin (I could not imagine 
wearing a patch or chewing Nicoret because that's just nasty - I enjoyed 
the ritual of smoking).  Maybe getting off heroin (if I was addicted to 
it) or any other drug would be as easy for me as getting off cigaretts, 
but I can't tell (considering that I wasn't addicted to anything except 
for chocolate at one point :P).  But, I know many people would not agree 
with me - I am sharing my personal (as well as 2 of my roommates 
expereinces because we all quit smoking).

The other statement that I didn't like was that alcohol leads to auto 
accidents...  I agree with you, but it just sounded like other 
recreational drugs (I just love that term :)) don't.  I have seen people 
so messed up on E, acid or whatever that they can hardly walk.  I can't 
even imagine one of them trying to drive a car.  Don't you think that 
auto accidents would be caused as well?  I think the reason there are not 
as many accidents like those is because there are less people using those 
drugs vs. alcohol. 

I have never been to Wicked (maybe I will go one day), but I am sure it 
can compare to 1015 with the cluby/bary atmosphere.  I am sure alcohol 
has some affects on that, but I think that more problems are caused by 
the general attitude of the bar/club sceene (this is speaking from 
personal experience because I just stared raving 6 months ago and I used 
to be one of those people).  When you are part of that sceene there are 
certain rules to follow if you want to be accepted (at least I felt that 
way).  You have to be serious (smiling too much *will* get you in 
trouble), can't talk to just anybody and pretend you are a small step 
from God (I feel flames coming my way - I just want to say that this is 
how I felt as part of the club sceene for years.  I am also not saying 
that all clubby ppl are like that and ravers are not.)  You have to 
pretend you *don't* care otherwise you will get hurt.

The reason I love raves is people who make it.  I can walk around with a 
smile and I won't get shit for it - I can talk to people because I just 
think they are neat, not because I want to go to bed with them and I can 
be myself and not pretend I don't care.  I can give hugs and be silly and 
most people won't care.  If I need help from somebody, I can ask one of 
my friends that I met at the rave and they will help me (hey Tim).....

But, if you know me I am sure you heard me in early morning hours say "I 
wish I had a beer right now."  There is no better way to end a party than 
with a nice, cold beer :).  Some people jokingly said that maybe I was an 
alcoholic (maybe I am I just don't know it), but I love the taste of 
beer after 
partying all night.  Also, because I don't drink that often as I used to 
I get messed up on alcohol fairly quickly.  I don't think that my 
attitude becomes like it used to few months ago, because I know the 
environment that I hang out in does not require me to be a snotty bitch.

Anyway, this is getting too long, I am at work, but I just had to get 
some things of my chest.  SOrry to get so sidetracked, but I guess I 
really don't feel like working right now :))).

Hope to see some of you soon,
hugz & smiles
Branka

Precedence: bulk

I'm very glad that Jason shared his experiences.  I am enjoying the
current debate over sociliasm, jobs, welfare, etc., but it's been very
theoretical and abstract.  I think that the best way to learn about these
topics is to talk about them in general, and also talk about them as
they relate to specific people.

I hope to see more posts like this one!

See you,

Ann

> On Wed, 7 Aug 1996, Wowser wrote:
> 
> > Well guys and gals, I spent a couple of hours trying to track down some
> > honest, simplified bar graphs or pie-charts as to the spending of the
> > Federal Government (in response to the recent flood of our political posts).  
> > What do they do with our money?  I searched the web in vain, and found that
> > all the sites were far too complicated to present a whole, simple picture.
> > There are a bunch of people throwing statistics around, and I think it would
> > benefit us all if we found a .gov site or similar that explained 'simply'
> > how our money is spent.  Does anyone have any suggestions or know of any
> > sites where this type of information can be found?  If you do, please post
> > the site so we can all become more aware.  Thanks!!!

for those of you who pay taxes, every year in the tax booklet
that includes your 1040 tax form they include some very simple pie
charts that show where the money comes from and where it goes.
it's even simpler than the table that was posted earlier
(which looked accurate, btw).  don't tell me you've thrown those
old tax booklets away!! :) for more detailed information, check out
"the american almanac" available at your local crown books.
it has lots and lots of great statistics on any and every topic
to argue over.

expenditure information is definitely not a state secret, in fact there
is probably no information that is (or should be) more public.
--

eric.pederson@airtouch.com                                      510-279-6185

> 
> Hmmm.....  I am not sure if I completely agree with your statements in 
> the above paragraph.  Maybe I should start with smoking - I quit 3 1/2 
> weeks ago after 10-11 years of smoking.  The only times I crave a smoke 
> is early in the morning after partying all night (going to after party 
> and watching other people smoke).  Maybe I am different than other 
> people, maybe I just didn't get addicted to nicotin (I could not imagine 
> wearing a patch or chewing Nicoret because that's just nasty - I enjoyed 
> the ritual of smoking).  Maybe getting off heroin (if I was addicted to 
> it) or any other drug would be as easy for me as getting off cigaretts,

Congratulations!  I'm not a smoker myself but lotsa family (asians and
the smoking thang, don't you know) and friends do, and from what I've seen
it's pretty damn hard to quit.  I think I've only known about three people
that have successfully quit, six counting you and your roomies.  I don't
know if you are genetically blessed or have a better mental approach to it
or both, but I still suspect that nicotine is REALLY addictive.  Most of
my friends from high school that just wanted to "try it" are still smoking
today.  

> The other statement that I didn't like was that alcohol leads to auto 
> accidents...  I agree with you, but it just sounded like other 
> recreational drugs (I just love that term :)) don't.  I have seen people 
> so messed up on E, acid or whatever that they can hardly walk.  I can't 
> even imagine one of them trying to drive a car.  Don't you think that 
> auto accidents would be caused as well?  I think the reason there are not 
> as many accidents like those is because there are less people using those 
> drugs vs. alcohol. 

Hmm...  Well, it seems to me like the alcohol "scene" seems to encourage
driving under the influence, as well.  I mean, you go to a bar/club, get 
loaded, the place closes, what are you gonna do?  In an ideal world, the
driver's been sobering up for a couple of hours, but it doesn't always
happen, and as you say, there's a lot of folks drinking out there.  At
raves there seems to be more recognition of the fact that, yes, you're
going to have to go home at some point.

Although, maybe it has less to do with the "scene" than with the pacing
of the drug.  Booze is an "incremental" drug where you can drink another
beer, get a bit more loaded.  Repeat at relatively short intervals of
time for added fun :)  With  pills it seems more "all or nothing," pop
something and you know you're committed for x number of hours.  So maybe
you're more psychologically prepared that way, "Okay, for the next x
hours I'm not even going to THINK about driving, then after that I should
be okay."

Or maybe I'm just looking at the world through rose colored glasses and
there are a lot more people driving high than I think?

From: Andrew Knutsen <andrewk@sco.COM>

Subject: Re: Statistics!!???!!??
Cc: pounce@vcn.bc.ca, tuskluv@lewiston.com
X-Mailer: ScoMail 3.0.Bd
MIME-Version: 1.0
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 1996 12:02:53 -0700 (PDT)
Message-ID:  <9608081202.aa16281@andrewk.pdev.sco.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> a government site that says "simply" how tax dollars are spent?  goos 
> luk.  it's not in the government's best interest to allow the average 
> person access to that sort of info.  you might find out just HOW out of 
> proportion the military and Pentagon budgets are.

	Well it isn't simple.  You can't just look at federal spending...  I 
seem to recall the federal gov't was initially charged with very little *but* 
military spending, with the states and municipalities handling the rest.  The 
balance has changed a bit this century, but still to figure out how the money 
taken from a citizen by legal force of arms is spent you have to add up:

	Federal taxes
	State taxes
	Property tax
	Federal, State and Local Sales tax (inc. gas, liquor, cigs, etc).
	Tolls for public roads/bridges, incl. parking
	...

	Basically anything collected by someone with a gov't badge when you 
haven't committed a crime.  Then you have to do a calculation where you figure 
out that citizens contibution in each area (defense, infrastructure, education, 
research, welfare, retirement, etc), which means estimating the total amount 
collected from that person by each tax, taking the percentages, classifying, 
adding them together, and dividing by the total to get the total percentages.

	Enough info is public to do a pretty good job of this (I think), but 
since it varies from individual to individual its hard to calculate.  I'd love 
to see a web site that took some basic info -- zip code, homeowner status, and 
income, for instance -- and made a pie chart.

	Then to be really interesting you could subtract out the benefits that 
individual receives -- health care, road use, education, gov't salary, welfare, 
etc (don't forget "protection") -- and find out which end of the stick they're 
holding...  Of course, handling intangibles like "liberty" and "security" is 
difficult (how much more should they cost you the more you make?  What if you 
don't want them, or like the kind you get for your money?).

Andrew

Andrew Knutsen            andrewk@sco.com
Santa Cruz Operation      (408) 427-7538

Well I went 2 Wish last night and I'd like to thank all of the SFR familily
that helped make it a success.  I must admit, without US the vibe just
wouldn't be there. It felt like what I'd assume ComeUnity was when it first
started.  And I realley enjoyed the non-club feel, bumping into each other
(and getting bumped into) w/o any negative 'tudes being thrown around...

Hope to see some of you again @ F-8, dancing like CrAzY (& how my feet will
feel it...).

BTW: For thoses who dont know me, I was the one dancing shirtless for most of
the night (when I had the t-shirt on, it was black)...


"Dance with me.."

--Adam

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Aug  8 13:19:50 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id NAA01438; Thu, 8 Aug 1996 13:19:50 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from bolero.rahul.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id NAA01412; Thu, 8 Aug 1996 13:19:46 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from [206.61.226.222] (c222.rahul.net) by bolero.rahul.net with SMTP id AA00691
  (5.67b8/IDA-1.5 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>); Thu, 8 Aug 1996 13:19:41 -0700
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 1996 13:19:41 -0700
Message-Id: <199608082019.AA00691@bolero.rahul.net>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: wolfe@rahul.net (Nancy W. Wolfe)
Subject: Astral Matrix Rocks!!!!!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



I'm not really into the Come-Unity scene at all but I went last night in
support of Andrew aka Astral Matrix.  Garth was on when I got there playing
some pretty good funky stuff but then got more into the "Can you feel it"
kind of housey stuff that drives me crazy.  I went outside and talked to
some friends paying close attention to my watch waiting for the clock to
strike two.  Just before two I went into the ladies room to make sure I
wouldn't have to leave in the middle of his performance and realized once
again why I don't really like Come-Unity.  I'm not going to get into it.
Now on with the review.  He started off with what I think was Pink Floyd's
Dark Side of the Moon.  Whatever it was it was wonderful. Then he brought
in the beats.  That unmistakable Astral Matrix acid sound was pounding
against the walls and back to him.  People were very excited and pushing
their way to the front to see who was responsible.  Played some slamming
stuff that I haven't heard before.  It has been a long time since I have
heard Andrew play anything.  The last song he ended with was probably my
favorite of the night as I have only recently started appreciating all that
jungle has to offer.  It was a slamming drum n' bass track but had a
soothing melodic kind of sound over top to give it an extremely well
produced sound.  I had a fabulous time and couldn't help but think about
seeing him in the desert at Burning Man.  There are going to be so many
things to do, see, and take, but I must say that by far I'm looking forward
to hearing Andrew yet again but this time out on the playa in the middle of
the desert.  See you there!!!!

-Nancy Wolfe

> From: Ulrike Laitko <laitko@hpbio1.biologie.hu-berlin.de>

> On Wed, 7 Aug 1996, Andrew Knutsen wrote:

> > > From: David Lowe <dlowe@best.com>
> > >   Also, there are people who don't want to work.  I'm all for that.  And
> > > there are people who are not willing to work below their skill levels, who
> > > demand that a job meet their needs.  And I'm all for that too.  Nobody
> > > should *have* to work in a miserable environment.
> > 
> > 	So, You're Elected to hold the gun to each person's head who wants to 
> > make their life better, but does not want to pay for those who don't.
> > 
> > 	Just make sure you don't make us miserable doing it, or we'll all 
> > starve...  and you'll run out of bullets.
> > 
> > 	It makes me feel so warm and fuzzy thinking how nice the world will be 
> > once we're all happily under your gun.  I'm sure we can all trust someone 
with 
> > your confidence.
> > 
> 
> WHO IS HOLDING A GUN HERE?
> BABY YOU MUST HAVE TOTALLY LOST IT.
> it's funny how some of these ravers start phantasizing about people 
> with guns when it comes to the topic of *possibly maybe* sharing their 
> *hard earned money* with bums and lazybones, just like every ridiculous old 
> redneck. 
> ulrike

	Umm, I guess you've never heard of the US government, or heard of people 
who didn't pay their taxes.  What happens in Germany if you don't pay?  I'm 
pretty sure you will eventually see some guns.  We here in the US have some nice 
folks called the IRS.  They have an enforcement arm.  These are some very 
special police. Debtors prison doesn't work, so other methods of coersion must 
be used.

	I'm not against taxes, but assuming that everyone will gladly pay for 
people who don't feel like working is the real fantasy.  And if not everyone 
pays, those who do will slowly pay more and more as more and more people start 
to get tired of paying.  Isn't there something called the "tragedy of the 
commons"?

	Nor am I denying that the main objective of collecting taxes (at the 
US federal level) is to buy more guns.

Andrew

PS lets start our own country... theres lots of room in Idaho...  we can be Free 
Men (and women, of course).
AK

E. Nygma wrote:
> Is there anyone out there in raveland who feels the way I do about the
> 'burbs? 

Yep. Hate 'em for exactly the reasons you put forward. The happiest
time of my recent life was the year or so after i moved from
Wollongong, a soulless suburban satellite city of Sydney, into Sydney's
old inner suburbs.

> What can I do to regain my sanity, and have everyone be happy
> (especially myself)?

Maybe explain to your beloved just how much you're uncomfortable with
the situation, and see if you can come to some compromise.  Maybe she's
got an unrealistic idea of what living in the city is like. The media
image of inner cities isn't exactly balanced.

Good luck!

Jeremy, who's really thrilled because he's just got accepted for a
beautiful old appartment in downtown San Jose.

for those interested in the topic of suburbs and especially mass transit =
versus cars, you should check out the documentary "Taken For a Ride". =
more info at:
http://www.pbs.org/pov/press/910.html

and an interesting article by Tom Vanderbuilt entitled "Why You Drive =
Where You Live: From Streetcar Suburb to Subsidized Sprawl" is available =
at:
http://www.word.com/machine/vanderbilt/

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning 3am-6am - "Aural Fixation"
       experimental sounds of ambient and trip hop with a splash of hi
       nrg, from trance to jungle. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" Beats and
       atmospherics w/DJ Seth. KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Tristan, have you ever read "Atlas Shrugged" by Ayn Rand?  I'm more of an
objectivist than anything.  I do not agree with you about me not being able
to afford my computer (or whatever) should their be no welfare recipiants.
Where ever did you get that?  Also in an anarchy, everyone would not be paid
the same. That is text book socialism.  We could do well in an anarchy
provided everyone would leave everyone else alone.  But there is too much
hatred, fear, crime, LIES and GREED for this to happen.  

I like most of the other stuff you wrote.  I doubt seriously if the New
Republic, which was written a very, very, very long time ago could even
begin to address pointedly the issues we are facing today.  I do think,
however, it is a wonderful book and a valuable tool.  Capitolism = freedom.
There is no other formula because of the nature of human beings.

Troy J.

At 07:35 AM 8/8/96 -0700, you wrote:
>Firstly, you need to read "the New republlic" by Plato and anything by 
>John Paul Sarte and then re-think your definition of the words, socialism,
>government and democracy.
>Secondly, when a person recieves a welfare cheque he is not benefitting
>from Government generiousity or stealing from fellow tax payers.  He/she
>is recieving a bribe so that he/she will just go home and keep quiet.
>Remember: no moniterist Government can afford to have 100% employment so
>each unemployed person actually keeps five people in work.  If there weere
>not welfare recipiants you, Wowser, would not even to be able to afford
>your computer or anything so stop complaining and be thankful for small
>mercies.  In short, capitalism can not function without unemployment and
>welfare so the very thing that you crtizise is the very thing that keeps
>the system that you tradgically believe in.
>And finaly. socialism, democracy etc are all words that are used to pull
>the wool over our eyes and, in practise, they mean nothing.  These ideals
>can only be truely achieved in a society where there are no laws, no
>governemnt or elections, no police and everyone is paid the same
>regaurdless of what they do because each individual understands the fact
>that they are just as an important as everybody else.  This system is
>called Anachism and it is the only way that man can carry on living in
>large societies and survive. 
>Tristan.

From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: WARNING: NRR!!! Work ethic
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Jason Lundy wrote:

>I have been trying to stay out of this one for a while, but this 
>message has touched a nerve.

Thanks so much for relating your story!  I really feel for you and the 
trouble you're going through.  YOU are the kind of person that support 
programs were originally put in place for.  The problem as I see it is that 
the assumption was made that people had the integrity to use only as much as 
they needed to get back on their feet.

I absolutely agree with you about education and daycare.  I honestly feel 
that reform of support services should come in three parts: 

1. Strict limits.  The number of years a person capable of gainful 
employment can collect the services, primarily.

2. Expansion of services to include college and training funding and daycare.

3. Incentives to businesses to hire people in the program and keep them on 
for a minimum of 2 years.

The expanded services would require a LARGE up front investment, but the 
payoff would be more and more people permanently off the dole with real 
skills, real jobs, and real experience.

I know this doesn't really apply much to your situation.  It sounds like 
your private hell is being created by Worker's Comp. problems.

is early in the morning after partying all night (going to after party 
and watching other people smoke).  Maybe I am different than other 
people, maybe I just didn't get addicted to nicotin (I could not imagine 
wearing a patch or chewing Nicoret because that's just nasty - I enjoyed 
the ritual of smoking).  Maybe getting off heroin (if I was addicted to 
it) or any other drug would be as easy for me as getting off cigaretts, 
but I can't tell (considering that I wasn't addicted to anything except 
for chocolate at one point :P).  But, I know many people would not agree 
with me - I am sharing my personal (as well as 2 of my roommates 
expereinces because we all quit smoking).
(SNIP)
It's called self control.  I have it as well.  In the ongoing course of
raving (Wow, almost 7 yrs. now) I've been introduced to almost every known
"Recreational Drug" and binged on them from time to time... But I choose not
to contenue usage.   To this day, I smoke non-tobacco products about once
every 4 months (If not longer).  Anything else stronger is consumed more on
an anuall basis.  I don't smoke cigaretts, & only drink alcohol in social
situations(ie. offered a drink, and it would be rude to refuse).  

The other statement that I didn't like was that alcohol leads to auto 
accidents...  I agree with you, but it just sounded like other 
recreational drugs (I just love that term :)) don't.  I have seen people 
so messed up on E, acid or whatever that they can hardly walk.  I can't 
even imagine one of them trying to drive a car.  Don't you think that 
auto accidents would be caused as well?  I think the reason there are not 
as many accidents like those is because there are less people using those 
drugs vs. alcohol. 
Ive driven on Alcohol, pot, LSD,ketamaine (Boy was THAT hard)..    And
although im not ness. PROUD of my accompishments , it's mostly control (& a
bit of luck)that kept me from being caught.


Spins, 

Adam

The topic on forum this morning (kqed 88.5 fm, 9-11am) was the recent CBC
bust and proposition 215. They usualy repeat the first hour of the
broadcast at 10:00 pm.  I reccomend anyone who's interested to tune in
tonight. Here's the description from their web site (www.kqed.org/FM):

9:00 LIVE Forum with Michael Krasny Forum looks at the issues surrounding
Proposition 215, the initiative to legalize marijuana for medical use. 
Guests include Terence Hallinan, District Attorney for the City of San
Francisco;  Steve Telliano, Press Secretary for Attorney General Dan
Lungren's office;  Dennis Peron, founder of the Cannibus Buyers Club; Don
McNeil, executive board member of Citizens for a Drug Free California; and
Dr. Michael Myers, who specializes in addiction medicine.

Well, I can tell you a little breakdown of Bukem's name.  

1) "LTJ" = DJ in Italy
2) Bukem = Book'em (from the expression "Book'em Dano")

I just hope people dance, instead of mostly standing around watching as
happens a lot in the BA (at least at parties where jungle is not the
primary genre). I thought it was interesting how in the basement
of 1015 last night, they had thin drapes partially covering the dance area 
around the dj (Jonah, the time I checked), who was spinning jungle and
more downtempo breakbeat.  Any spectating that was done was of dancers'
silhouettes -- silhouettes that were purposefully projected onto one of
the drapes to absolutely beautiful effect.  This was one time I didn't
mind just sitting around and watching.  The broad daylight might deter
the timid... but who knows?  Maybe these visiting dj's will help bring
jungle to a new light.    

Rok.

Fellow Groovers...just wanted to let those of you who were not able to
attend Reggae on the River '96 that it was a BLAST! I had soooo much fun
just hangin' out in the sun, feelin' IRIE and listnin' to Reggae.  We
happened to get one of the BEST (IMHO) campsites on the river (for those of
you who went, we were right at the entrance to the main swimming area). 

Just some time to relax and chill out with good people and good vibes.
could it get better???

 YES!!! ...just so happened that 3 campsites down was the "funky-futuristic"
but "retro" Wicked bus with the crew. So after the reggae show let out on
Saturday night, the luggage doors on the side of bus came up to reveal Phat
speakers and rekkids, the turntables came out, and we had GARTH on the
river! It was so much fun! Me and my buddies grabbed our glowsticks and
busted the groove until about 4am Sunday morning when they finally made them
shut down because of noise...

Then after the last show Sunday night, they busted out with the beats again!
This time it was a different DJ that I didn't recognize. He busted out the
house grooves mixed with some niiiice reggae beats...till about 4am. Does
anyone know who that DJ was???
If anyone was there, I was the one with the black "hemp" hat on with the big
checkered jacked and Big Happy-Ass-Perma-Grin on... =P

Woke up the next morning sitting upright in a lawn chair...feeling great...
it's a beautiful thing =)

And so as we're driving back towards the bay area, I'm thinking..
"Awwwwwwwwww Yeah! This is just what I needed..A little time away from the
hectic-ism of working and responsibilities....as well as a booster shot of
house music to rekindle the internal flame o' funk...Yeeeeeeeeeeeaaaaaaah!
=) =) =)

Lookin' forward to groovin' wit ch'all soon,

Morgan

ps. If anyone from the Wicked crew monitors this list, I just wanted to say
thanks! You guys multiplied the fun factor bigtime!


*** Put your head back, reach up as FAR as you can, and smile as BIG as you
can. Now do you see?! The Perma-Grin will be with you...always. ;) ***

Seinfeld-isms
>From the Washington Post:

What's with the people who put carpeting on the lid of their toilet
seat?  What are they thinking -- "Gosh, if we have a party there may not
be enough standing room; I'd better carpet the toilet too."

What's with this weird hotel custom of leaving a peice of chocolate on
the pillow?  I awoke thinking my brain had hemorrhaged some sort of
fecal matter.

Have you ever noticed that the waiter who takes your order is not the
one who brings your food anymore? What is THAT about?  And which waiter
are you tipping, anyway? I think next time I go to a restaurant I'll
just say, "Oh, sorry, I only eat the food.  The guy who pays the bill
will be along shortly."

Whould somebody please explain to me those signs that say, "No animals
allowed except for Seeing Eye Dogs?" Who is that sign for?  Is it for
the dog, or the blind person?

Why do people give each other flowers? To celebrate various important
occasions, they're killing living creatures? Why restrict it to plants?
"Sweetheart, let's make up.  Have this deceased squirrel."

Can't we just get rid of wine lists? Do we really have to be reminded
every time we go out to a nice restaurant that we have no idea what we
are doing? Why don't they just give us a trigonometry quiz with the
menu?

If airline seat cushions are such great flotation devices, why don't you
ever see anyone take one to the beach?

Why do they call it a "building"? It looks like they're finished.  Why
isn't it a "built"?

Why is it when you turn on the TV you see ads for telephone companies,
and when you turn on the radio you hear ads for TV shows, and when you
get put on hold on the phone you hear a radio station?

Why is it illegal to park in a handicapped parking space but okay to go
the bathroom in a handicapped stall?

How come you have to pay someone to rotate your tires?  Isn't that the
basic idea behind the wheel?  Don't they rotate on their own?

All the king's HORSES and all the king's men? Are you kidding me?  No
wonder they couldn't put Humpty together again. Just what did those
idiots expect the horses to do, anyway?

Did you ever notice, when you are sitting at a red light, that when the
person in front of you pulls up a couple of inches, you are compelled to
move up too? Do we really think we are making progress toward our
destination? "Whew, I thought we would be late, but now that I am nine
inches closer, I can stop for coffee and a danish!"

Isn't it weird that we drink milk, stuff designed to nourish baby cows?
How did THAT happen?  Did some cattleman once say, "Oh, man, I can't
wait till them calves are done so I can get ME a hit of that stuff."

Have you ever noticed how they keep improving your laundry detergent,
but they still can't get those blue flakes out?  Why do we trust them to
get our clothes clean?  These guys can't even get the DETERGENT white!

Did you see these new minivan ads?  All they talk about are cup holders,
kiddie seats and doors.  What kind of advertising is that?  When you see
an ad for a suit, do they say, "And look at the zipper!  Carefully
hidden, but easily accessible when you need it!" I think not.

Who is this guy Louis Freeh who is head of the FBI? People keep calling
him Louie, like he was the king of France or something. And what's this
with his last name?  What does this mean, that he gives away the letter
H?

Sometimes suburbs can be nice.

El Cerrito, where I live 'cause the rents are cheap and it's got TWO whole
BART stations, started out kind of as a suburb.

Now it's just about as urban as you can get and still have lots of trees,
room for kids to play, and places for taking long walks.

Did I mention the rents are cheap?  $650 for a 2-bedroom fourplex apt.  

Any more El Cerrito ravers out there?

-Ann

"Little boxes, on the hillside, and they're all made out of ticky-tacky,
little boxes, little boxes, and they all look just the same

There's a green one, and a blue one, and a red one and a yellow one, and
they're all made out of ticky-tacky and they all look just the same

And there's doctors, and there's lawyers, and there's buisness executives and
they all have pretty children and they all go to pretty schools.

And they all meet, at the golf course, and they all drink their martinis dry,
and they're all made out of ticky-tacky and they all look just the same..."

This is an excerpt from a song my mom taught me as a child.  It was written
by a woman who was locally famous in the berkeley area in the late 50's-early
60's.  My mom was always a little out of it [for a non-drug using,
semi-but-not-realy-hippy:)], so she can't remember who it was, or just how
famous this wise woman was.  Anyone out there ever heard it?  It really stuck
in my head.

Since the 50's, housing has grown in a way different than ever before.  It
used to be that a town would grow slowly out of need for one in an area (a
factory site, a mine operation, etc.), and people would move there and build
houses on plots of land on a street/road in the rural area.  Now, they build
all the houses, streets and mini malls first, with 5' inbetween each one, and
then move in the people.  This causes a severe lack of community, which IMHO
retards respect between people in the area.  This is in part why people are
so uptight and unfriendly these days.  If a community were allowed to _build_
instead of being pre-fab, then I think it would promote individuality which
is the healthy human condition, again IMHO. Just my .02

-Juhstyn

From: "Mark Camp*" <Mark_Camp*@quickmail.apple.com>
Subject: Re: TB303
To: "Sami Khoury" <khoury@hyperreal.com>,
        "Steve Simitzis" <simitzis@netcom.com>

X-Mailer: Mail*Link SMTP-QM 4.0.0 FC1
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

         Reply to:   RE>>TB303

>You might also look at Roland's MC-303 -- it's supposed to clone
>a few of the popular x0x's in one easy-to-tote box

I had a chance to check out the MC303 recently and it is really cool!  Although, It doesnt sound anything like a TB303.  At least the sounds that I heard, I didnt get too deep into it.  It has all your basic generic techno sounds, preset patterns that you can copy into user patterns and edit, or you can create your own patterns.  Its basiclly an 'Insta-Techno' Box.  You dont need to know anything about writting music to use the thing.  Its got a Tap Tempo button on it for the DJ's so you can easily sync it up to your records.  The downside is the sounds are not editable, other than Filter Cutoff and Resonance, which sounds really cool on the drums.  Its deffinatly worth picking up.  Its cheap ($895 retail, I've been quoted $550 street price).  Its  a great tool for getting idea's down and then sending the sequence to your computer and adding better sounds or whatever.  

.02,

 /-M-\
!E.A.C!    

--------------------------------------
Date: 8/7/96 6:11 PM

You might also look at Roland's MC-303 -- it's supposed to clone
a few of the popular x0x's in one easy-to-tote box.

My mother taught me that as a kid too - in Dunedin, New Zealand. There
was quite a strong beat-generation thing happening in that little
university town in the late 50's - early 60's (right down to sit-ins at
the university), and suburban blight is no respecter of international
borders and thousands of miles of ocean. :)

While i'm in reminiscing-about-my-home-town mode: I was back there in
late June (I've lived outside NZ for nearly 6 years, and outside
Dunedin for nearly 9) and found one of the best underground Goa parties
i've ever been to: especially amazing, considering the population is
only 100,000.

Jeremy

I KNOW THAT SONG!!!! I forget who it's by too.... if you remember let me

---------------------
Forwarded message:
From:	Juhstyn@aol.com
Sender:	owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
To:	enigma@best.com
CC:	sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: 96-08-08 19:46:18 EDT

"Little boxes, on the hillside, and they're all made out of ticky-tacky,
little boxes, little boxes, and they all look just the same

There's a green one, and a blue one, and a red one and a yellow one, and
they're all made out of ticky-tacky and they all look just the same

And there's doctors, and there's lawyers, and there's buisness executives and
they all have pretty children and they all go to pretty schools.

And they all meet, at the golf course, and they all drink their martinis dry,
and they're all made out of ticky-tacky and they all look just the same..."

This is an excerpt from a song my mom taught me as a child.  It was written
by a woman who was locally famous in the berkeley area in the late 50's-early
60's.  My mom was always a little out of it [for a non-drug using,
semi-but-not-realy-hippy:)], so she can't remember who it was, or just how
famous this wise woman was.  Anyone out there ever heard it?  It really stuck
in my head.

Since the 50's, housing has grown in a way different than ever before.  It
used to be that a town would grow slowly out of need for one in an area (a
factory site, a mine operation, etc.), and people would move there and build
houses on plots of land on a street/road in the rural area.  Now, they build
all the houses, streets and mini malls first, with 5' inbetween each one, and
then move in the people.  This causes a severe lack of community, which IMHO
retards respect between people in the area.  This is in part why people are
so uptight and unfriendly these days.  If a community were allowed to _build_
instead of being pre-fab, then I think it would promote individuality which
is the healthy human condition, again IMHO. Just my .02

-Juhstyn

released or acted upon. In other places, people either are not brought up

problem is not one that other people have to deal with, it is something

Subject: NRR netscape security...
In-Reply-To: <Pine.ULT.3.93.960806133645.11085C-100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>

ReSent-Date: Thu, 8 Aug 1996 19:35:27 -0700 (PDT)
ReSent-From: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>
ReSent-To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
ReSent-Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.93.960808193527.975A@taz.hyperreal.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

 > ok...I have been browsing my netscape security preferences...and it says
 > that I have accepted site certificates, including att research, mci
 > mall and a bunch of others,...what are these things?

   Basically, it means that you made an SSL connection to their
site.  These certificates are most commonly issued by VeriSign (for
Netscape Commerce Server) or possibly by some other CA if it's an
Apache-SSL server.  The signature from a "trusted" CA helps prevent
against man-in-the-middle attacks against RSA.

-jon

X-Received: from mercury.Sun.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id PAA20118; Tue, 6 Aug 1996 15:52:03 -0700 (PDT)
X-Received: by mercury.Sun.COM (Sun.COM)

Message-Id: <199608062251.PAA02535@ultramarine.eng.sun.com>
From: Jon Cooper <Jon.Cooper@Eng.Sun.COM>
To: Paul Anthony Rose <trose@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
Cc: Andrew Knutsen <andrewk@sco.COM>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: NRR netscape security...
In-Reply-To: <Pine.ULT.3.93.960806153241.9490A-100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
References: <9608061456.aa27715@andrewk.pdev.sco.com>
	<Pine.ULT.3.93.960806153241.9490A-100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
ReSent-Date: Thu, 8 Aug 1996 19:36:04 -0700 (PDT)
ReSent-From: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>
ReSent-To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
ReSent-Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.93.960808193604.975C@taz.hyperreal.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

 > OK...I am getting some idea...but what does it mean that i "trust" these
 > people? Do yhey have a site certificate to my site(computer), if so, what
 > access do they get with this?

   No, they don't have a site certificate for you.  It means that you
trust that their SSL-speaking server (in this case HTTPS) is who it
says it is as opposed to a man in the middle.  I'll illustrate:

   One possible attack against public-key cryptosystems w/o
certificates like this is as follows.

	a. You want to encrypt something to Eve.  You contact Eve's
	   host, and ask for her public key.
        b. An interceptor catches that request, masquerading as Eve's
	   host.  Since TCP/IP doesn't have real connection-level
	   authentication, you don't know this.  The intruder sends 
	   you a public key that it controls the private key for, and
	   catches Eve's public key from the real Eve.
	c. You encrypt using this (fake) public key from the
	   interceptor.  It decrypts the message, using its private
	   key, then reencrypts it with Eve's public key and sends it
	   to her, keeping a copy of the plaintext.

    The certificate is a signed document from a
Netscape-binary-trusted source, like VeriSign, that says "this public
key really does belong to the site it claims to."

    This doesn't grant them any special access to your machine.

Regards,  

-jon

have found some microbes that may have existed on a meteorite that may

earth or even picked them up while hurtling through space???

or maybe we'll find out more when we spend all this money to launch probes in a 
couple months.

necessary for people to live and to keep living right now...if we don't 
start curbing population growth and the ills befalling our environment 
and so many other things there won't be any life left on earth either in a 
couple hundred years...and perhaps in a couple billion years someone on 
some other planet will find out that there once was microbes living on earth 
too, yahooo...

Maybe we will find some new chemical form that cures AIDS and cancer by 
exploring space but if we just explored our planet more and spent some 
more money on research here then we could find those cures here on our 
planet.

Getting off the soapbox now...geez I need to get off work and go have

>> I've decided it's finally time to break down and add a TB303 to my
>> arsenal... Unfortunately, they are of course hard to find, so I've
>> been looking at clones. The Fatman seems nice, as does the Syntecno
>> "TeeBee" TB303. Also, it seems that it would be nice to have MIDI to
>> ease some of the sync/timing issues.
>
>> real thing, I'd love to know :)
>
>I can't tell you about the TB303, but the Fatman is cool as hell. First
>of all, you get to build it yourself :) A very good project to start out
>on, and you can patch and mod the Fatman and when you get good you can
>start building your own instruments. I guess this message doesn't tell
>you what you should get, since i've never used the tb303, but if you get
>the fatman, and you like building stuff, you'll be very happy :)

Gonna have to second this statement. I just built a FatMan last week. Very
cheap(170), very easy(takes around 30-35 hours to build). Easily emulates a
303, not to mention longer drone sounds and other creative synth uses. With
the FatMan you get more than a little bass station. Midi implementation
includes pitch bend only, but CVs are included for gate,pitch,velocity, so
you can actual sync certain aspects of the sound to an analog rhythmer.

Electronics aspect is basically just like following model instructions.
Very easy. Modifications can be easily performed based on your need(LFO,
Subharmonic Generator). As you determine what you want you can also come up
with your own. This is a great introduction to electonics for muscial
purposes. PAiA also has lots of cool little kits like phase shifters, ring
modulators and other good experiments.

This is not a self contained acid box though. It is more and less. No
sequencer, no on the fly grooves. Just cool analog sounds made in 1994 =)+)

Hope this helps.

syncr@earthlink.net

On Wed, 7 Aug 1996, Lee Fogel wrote:

> blkaddr:
> > 100% correct. There *are* cliques, things going on behind the scenes, 
> > stupid "power" struggles, etc. Because anyone chooses a scene to identify 
> > with, this does not change the fact that they are human beings and 
> > subject to all the strengths and weaknesses that being human entails.
> 
> Yes, but it seemed that there were certain things about raves (music,
> ecstatic dancing, openness, vibe) that attracted certain kinds of people
> and perpetuated certain kinds of attitudes, despite all of our
> differences.  And it seemed that many ravers had similar outlooks about
> life because of this.  That's why you sometimes hear people say "I
> wouldn't expect a raver to feel that way."  For some, it felt
> like more of a cultural phenonemon instead of just another scene.

I agree with the first part, but the second I have problems with. It is not 
up to me to decide what political philosophies others must adhere to be 
considered a "raver." Doing that would be judgemental, and in my opinion, 
incorrect. When you become entrenched in socioeconomic/political/religious
dogma and offer that as the "official" party line, you begin to turn 
away people that you once would have welcomed with open arms. People 
have to find their own truths. Far too often people are spoon-fed their 
truths by their government, their religious leaders, their political 
party, etc. Invite people in. Allow them find their own truths.  

> 
> > I am not judging at all. I don't care what people who chose to function 
> > outside the strictures of society do. Again I am just saying I do not 
> > want to be financially responsible if that is their choice. How is that 
> > judgemental?  
> 
> I have to assume by this that you are also against NEA grants that
> help support all those freeloading artists.  I guess what I found
> judgemental about your statements is the presumption that many people on
> welfare are doing it as a choice for freedom or some kind of preferred
> lifestyle.  I suppose this is true in some cases, but I think it unfairly
> stereotypes and oversimplifies a complex social problem.

You assume incorrectly, and one has little to do with the other. 
Comparing NEA funded artists, who are offering something back to society 
in the form of their art vs. those who are doing nothing, are two 
different things entirely. Furthermore, I never made a presumption that 
people on welfare were doing this as an expression of freedom. I was 
addressing the subject of those individuals that David Lowe chooses to 
support because they wish to live as subversives. I have stereotyped no 
one, and have oversimplified nothing. All I have said is that I do not 
wish to support those that choose to live outside of society, offering 
nothing, and taking much.


> 
> > > > Well then try to find a job in a field you feel good about. I feel good 
> > > > about what I do, and rather it meets your definition of usefulness is 
> > > > unimportant.
> > > 
> > > To me, this egocentric attitude of I-know-what's-good-for-me-so-fuck-
> > > everyone-else is a bigger problem in our society than a few people
> > > taking advantage of the welfare system.
> > 
> > Thanks for being so unjudgmental Lee. I can see you really live by your 
> > words.
> 
> Well, I do try, but often fail.

And this is what I have a hard time reconciling: Your caution against 
rushing to judgement, and then doing that very thing. 

                                       Black Adder

On Wed, 7 Aug 1996, Jeremy Lawrence wrote:

> Black Adder wrote:
> > On Wed, 7 Aug 1996, Jeremy Lawrence wrote:
> > 
> > > Sure, these things are bad.  What i was trying to say was that reducing
> > > welfare could well make the crime situation go downhill faster, with
> > > even more crime-related costs.
> > 
> > Things are not only bad, but they have been getting progressively 
> > worse. So should we continue the downward spiral? 
> 
> Not if we can help it. But what evidence is there that the costs caused
> by reducing welfare won't accelerate the downward spiral? 

What evidence is there that the current system is not functioning as 
designed? Volumes. Which necessitates change. Which is happening. 

> 
> Is there any evidence that the downward spiral has anything to do with
> welfare at all? For example, the "war on drugs" has swallowed up far
> more tax dollars than welfare in the last few years, and has arguably
> caused more problems.

As a drain on the economy, most certainly. And I wholeheartedly agree 
that the "war on drugs" is costing more than welfare, and is a serious 
waste of revenue. The problem with these type of arguments however, is 
that they divert attention from the issue at hand. These tactics are used 
within the government all the time, and in my opinion is why nothing ever 
gets done. Want to talk about welfare? Let's talk about welfare. Want to 
talk about the bloated war machine the U.S. maintains? Let's talk about 
that. But when you are discussing one issue, stick to it.

> > Saying that the crime-rate is going to increase if we cut people off 
> > after five years is unlikely at best. Please read the following. It can 
> > be found at http://www.newsarchives.com/archive/dec1495/rgd.htm/
> 
> Ok, lets take a look at it. (By the way, welfare is also going to be
> denied to recent legal immigrants.)
> 
> > Report: Welfare Recipients Seeking Work in Wake of Benefit Cuts 
> >
> >    HARTFORD, Conn. (AP) -  A change in the state's welfare system that cut 
> >    benefits to encourge recipients to seek jobs apparenlty is working, 
> >    according to state officials.
> > 
> >    Figures released Wednesday shows that the number of welfare parents who are
> >    employed has gone up 30 percent since cash benefits were cut in July.
> >
> > [snip]
> >
> >    State statistics show that only 12.7 percent of welfare recipients reported
> >    that they were working in June 1995, the month before the cuts in cash 
> >    benefits were enacted.
> >
> >    The number of recipients working has increased every month since then, and 
> >    reached 16.5 percent in November. [snip]
> 
> Ok, so some people made extra effort to find work when welfare was cut,
> and about 4% of those on welfare found work. How many of the 80% or so
> who weren't working and didn't find work made extra effort to steal?
> It seems likely that at least some extra crime would result from the
> measure.  (I'm not suggesting that the crime is justified, only that it
> is likely.)

By all means, I made the effort to find some statistics to validate my 
feelings, if you are going to make claims based on your feelings, find the 
numbers to substantiate them. 

I have provided you with some indication that an alternate approach may 
help slow or alter the deteroration, and you counter with conjecture. 

> Lets look at other aspects. The extra 4% of those on welfare who did
> find jobs, took them out of the available pool. This will reduce other
> peoples' incomes to some extent (there must have been more than 1 or 2
> applicants for at least some of those jobs). It may, after some time
> lag, cause other people to go on welfare.

This article was based on a study done over several months, and by the 
fact that it was done over a period of several months, refutes your 
assertation.


> It doesn't appear that the measure provides child care. There will
> almost certainly be downstream costs in crime (again), reduced
> educational performance and hence welfare. Forcing parents out to work
> without providing adequately for their children is a wonderful way of
> sustaining the "welfare trap".


I have never stated that this is the absolute solution to the problem. 
There are several things that need to be done, including adequate 
day-care for the working poor, vocational training, and a host of other 
items. But handing people money in perpetuity for nothing, as is being 
done now is not the answer.

> There seems to be no substantual evidence that, taking into account all
> the costs, this measure actually saves money. Sure, the state's costs
> went down in the short term, but how much will police, court and prison
> costs, public health costs, property insurance bills, and welfare costs
> go up in the future?

Do you know? Please provide any data that you have to this effect.

> Cutting welfare is false economy IMHO, and i haven't seen any strong
> evidence to the contrary.
> 
> The newspaper story is a good example of how to put a slant on a story
> by selectively quoting statistics and by ignoring the wider picture.
> "Limbaughing, n.: lying by selectively choosing data to confirm
> a desired result."

And your statement is a good example of how to avoid the subject by invoking 
the name of a pompous jackass because you have no solid repudiation of 
data presented.

> > But can't you see that the way things are being done now isn't working? 
> 
> That's a wildly sweeping statement. A proportion of the people on
> welfare couldn't possibly support themselves in any way. They're being
> cared for. Some proportion of the people on welfare genuinely can't
> find work despite extensive searching. They're being looked after. That
> bit of the system seems to be working ok.

Then by all means, if they can't find jobs, let's put them to work. 
The re-introduction of public work projects would be a great starting 
point. If they can't find work, and are willing to work making our 
country a better place in whatever capacity, by all means let's allow 
them to stay on welfare. But do not continue to allow people to sit on 
their asses collecting money for nothing. 

> Sure, there are problems with the welfare system, but there is no
> substantual evidence that cutting welfare will make things "work"
> better. As i suggested above, if you want to blame something for things
> not working, take a close look at bigger-budget items like the "war on
> drugs". Welfare spending is a relatively small part of the budget,
> although our political masters want us to think differently.

Who said cutting the system? Not I. Altering, absolutely. 

It is rather silly to attempt to give "substantial evidence" of the results 
of a proposal before putting it to in effect. 

It also would be nice if we could stick to the issue at hand. All these 
problems are big enough to be dealt with one at a time. 

> Personally i think that the welfare system needs to be tweaked and
> experimented with to get it to achieve better results. This is being
> done in various States. What i don't support is the Federal goverment
> cutting a 12 billion dollar chunk out of welfare. That seems to be a
> rash populist move, with potentially disastrous consequences.

Well, at least that is a start. 


                                     Black Adder

On Wed, 7 Aug 1996, Anarch wrote:

> blkadder@value.net wrote:
> >Ponder this: The U.S. currently offers most favored nation trading status to
> >             a country that is one of the biggest perpetrators of human 
> >             rights violations in the world, practices infanticide, and 
> >             and violates any copyright they feel like. Is this the
> >             action of a country that doesn't have anything to fear?
> 
> The US has actively encouraged and supported, through means far more 
> direct than favorable trade relations, numerous governments whose respect 
> for human rights, democratic values, etc, can easily compete with China's 
> in the "most horrendous" sweepstakes.  Guatemala comes to mind.  Not to 
> mention South Vietnam.  In all the cases, it's not a matter of pacifying 
> a hostile nation, but rather of: a) maintaining alliances and lines of 
> influence that support the exercise of American power in the geopolitical 
> realm; and b) maintaining favorable conditions for American economic 
> growth, i.e. efficient access to resources (including labor) and markets. 

Agreed. I did fail to recognize this and it is a most valid point. 

>  (The two categories intersect and overlap in many ways, of course).  Any 
> fear of China is not fear of blood in the streets and the red flag over 
> Washington, but fear of a closed Asian market, or, to a lesser extent, of 
> an Asian political bloc not necessarily aligned with American interests.

And what exactly does "an Asian political bloc not necessarily aligned 
with American interests" equate to? Sounds rather like an uncomfortable 
situation to me.

I just heard on the 10 o'clock news that there is a 1/100 chance that if
you are caucasian, male or female, you could possibly have a natural
resistance to the HIV virus.  They have been watching and studying two gay
males who have repeatedly had unsafe sex with numerous partners not knowing
whether these men they were having sex with had the virus or not.  The
study is going to be published in the upcoming Journal of Science and
Medicine.  That was all the info. I got on the news although, Dennis
Richmond did also mention that this gene or whatever it is, I can't
remember, must be passed on from both the father and the mother.   Do you
know how many caucasian people there are on this earth?  1/100 is alot of
people with chances of not picking up the virus even when engaging in
unsafe sex or needle use.  I'm sure it will be in the papers so keep your
eyes peeled for it.

-Nancy
