> between these puppies and capitalist economy, and if i keep reading that 
> people are reflecting what they, obligated by their special quality of being 
> *ravers* could possibly do about and against that, then i start drawing 
> conclusions about those californian ravers nature.

Drawing conclusions is little different than sterotyping in this senario. 

> 
> and if then, all of a sudden, posts emerge, virtually written by the same 
> people, that recommend 'move yer butt and get yerself a job at mc donalds', 
> or in advertising, posts that express not only disapproval, but hate against 
> people that don't work and produce 'litters of children', dear black adder,
> and if i see these people being all concerned somebody could steel 
> their money from them and have a good time (not concerned, of course, 
> about those oh so necessary spendings for defence), then i can't help 
> being a little puzzled.

I think we have gone through this before: TALK TO *ME* 

I never posted anything good or bad about McDonalds, or working in 
advertising. You make sweeping generalizations, putting all "California 
ravers" into a specific category, and do not seem to be able to 
differenciate statements made by various *individuals* Verstehen Sie?

I challenge you to show where I have ever expressed *hatred* towards people 
that do not work and produce "litters of children." I have said the 
following two things:

1) The current system supports women having litters of children.
2) I do not wish to pay for those who choose not to work and want me to 
   support them.

Now, you could probably reasonably say that I hold a certain level of 
disdain for both groups, however hatred is a very powerful and draining 
emotion, and one I would not invest. 

> me:
> > > normally you don't earn money by making the world a nice place for 
> > > everybody, but by producing needless stuff, talking people into buying 
> > > needless stuff, do research in the name of progress (a concept that is 
> > > totally questionable nowadays), generally by contributing to the 
> > > limitless growth that is a consequence of capitalist economy and 
> > > inevitably fucks the world up. i mean, hey, how many of you actually 
> > > bake bread or teach children (or other sweet things to think of) to make 
> > > a living. *i don't*. 
> 
> > Well then try to find a job in a field you feel good about. I feel good 
> > about what I do, and rather it meets your definition of usefulness is 
> > unimportant. 
> 
> yeah sure you don't care the fuck wether i consider it useful what you do.
> i got that.

Because by your statements, have already decided what is "useful." You 
can judge my job as "good" or "bad" but when everything is said and done 
how *I* feel about myself and what I am doing is what matters.

> but wether your job provider considers what you would like to 
> do, or what you're good at, or what you think would be of advantage for 
> mankind as a whole being useful (for his business), this *is* important. 
> is it not? for he won't pay you a penny for something he *feels bad about*.
> but thats ok. i understand.

To them it may very well be. All one can ever attempt to do in this 
regard is work at a job that you feel good about.

> about me, i like my job. i'm only aware of the fact that what i do 
> (theoretical biophysics) is completely unnecessary in the sense that it 
> doesn't do any good for anybody. they could as well pay me for doing nothing. 

Your field doesn't do any good for anyone? No one in your field has ever 
proposed something, postulated something, or made any positve 
contribution to the field of science?

> too many jobs that are out there. i imagine you would agree with me when i 
> say that maybe some solid 50% of the goods that are produced/services offered
> are sheer luxury, if not completely needless and are just produced/offered to 
> keep the circle of economy moving, all on the cost of nature.

Is luxury valueless? Personally, I prefer wiping my butt with soft tissue 
rather than leaves, running water is a delight, and hey, four walls and a 
roof beat a drafty cave any day of the week.  

> me:
> > > i think somebody who doesn't work might actually cause less overall damage 
> > > than somebody who does. 
> > 
> > Yes, and our race would have been extinct several million years ago had 
> > we embodied this philosophy.   
> 
> this is why i called the belief that one had to work to justify ones 
> existence **oldfashioned**.  this is something that used to be true when the 
> means of production weren't so high developed as they are today. today, 
> everything that is really needed can be produced by a fraction of the 
> population with the help of all those machines.

Define "really needed."

                                      Black Adder

I need to clarify my position:

My statement about alcohol and auto accidents was meant to point out
that it is a very dangerous drug, and yet it is legal. It wasn't meant
to say that driving under the influence of other drugs is any
safer. Alcohol makes one tired, and lose sense of judgement and
awareness. Often times one doesn't feel inebriated, and it lends
towards irrational behavior. On the other hand, ravers who partake in 
alternative substances tend to be more aware of their condition, and 
are less likely to drive under the influence (my personal opinion, 
based on the experiences of friends). So why should alcohol be any 
more legal than marijuana, MDMA, psylocybin (SP?) mushrooms, GBH,
or LSD, among others?

Our government's stance on drugs is purely arbitrary. It could be 
argued that our drug laws violate our constitutional right to freedom 
of expression. Until very recently, no one in office has dared step 
forward, and speak out against the so-called "war on drugs", and 
propose reforming our laws. Even now, it is still very much a grass 
roots effort (and a feeble one at that). 

Actually, I think that ravers who partake in such alternative 
substances instead of alcohol tend to be more aware of their 
condition, anyway, and are less likely to drive under the influence. 
By the time the party is over, the effects have worn off.  

BTW, I knew a couple of classmates from my high school who got into a
car accident after smoking pot. One of them is paralyzed from the
waist down for the rest of his life. The other was in physical rehab
for six months. It was not a pretty sight.

E.N.

  I received a call last night from a friend telling me that Nation lost the 
  site for their gig (at Pier 45).  There's been alot of planning and for 
  the plug to be pulled at the last minute, it's very upsetting and 
  difficult to find a new venue.  Evidentally, Enrique (sp?) is getting alot 
  of run around from the city and no answers as to why they lost the site.  
  My friend, Ramiro (who's pretty political) mentioned that this was really 
  a case of discrimination of the type of party more than anything else.  He 
  asked that as many people call to complain to the Mayor's ofc.  The phone 
  number is 415.554.6490.
  
  I called the number this morning, and per Mayor Brown's spokesman, da 
  mayor is very cautious to release a statement until he receives all the 
  facts.  The spokesman said he's received calls from as far as Seattle and 
  Chicago, so I guess things are already underway.  In any case, I thought 
  I'd pass this on in case you want to voice your opinion.  And if you feel 
  compelled to, please pass this onto anyone else who might be affected by 
  this or understands the situation--after all...isn't it time we really let 
  the city of SF, much less the Bay Area know how many raving voters 
  contribute to the economy and overall city scene affirming the diversity 
  and positive energy shared?
  
  Have a great Friday and I hope to see some of you out there dancing this 
  weekend!
  
  Lotsa love 'n hugs,
  Diane

As I guess everyone knows, the Bay Guardian has a couple articles about 
SF's underground scene.  The articles are good, but I think it is kind of 
ironic that they are brining above ground the "underground."  It saddens 
me in a way.  I'm not sad that the "scene" is more popular.  I'm glad 
that there are lots of wonderful people with whom to share it.  I'm just 
worried a bit about this "outing" of the scene.  What if some of us don't 
want it outed?  But, maybe that's selfish.  I just really admire and love 
the way information is disseminated by word of mouth and phones and 
computers.  I'd hate to see this disappear.  But, I guess as long as 
there are dedicated people, there will be a dedicated "scene."

-sensless musings-

KaySEE

got it off the burning man mailing list....

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 8 Aug 1996 19:26:51 PDT
From: Eric Pouyoul <eric@Chorus.COM>
To: doits <dotis@mgvgroup.com>, burnman-list@Chorus.COM
Subject: Re: tickets to the burn

|I'm a little confused about what i've been hearing about the situation
|regarding the actual burning of the man. Is it true that this year there
|will be tickets sold to the burning event, seperate from the $35 i sent
|in for my BM registration?

Yes, and the big news is that since I wasn't so happy to not be able to
get a seat on the front row (because *someone* have took all of them to
resale them with profit probably on the Playa... ;-( ), I called Larry
and convice to add 3 more rows. Those seat will be free, EXCEPT, you
will have to be naked and painted with some satanic drawings (the painters
will provided by HELCO for a small fee, or you can do it ourself).
To register for this "program", get to the HELCO campsite as soon as
you arrive on the Playa, naked (because they will either to check your
painting or they'll  paint you). Don't forget to bring your id, because
they will have to take your name (if you're under 21, forget it, the TV
will be there, and the Project doesn't want any problems with the justice).
BTW, the small fee (I don't know how much) for the painting job is just
to cover the cost of the paint... No profit made.

|Being 4 stories high, wouldnt the burn be
|visible for quite some distance? I'm not just driving 12 hours to
|hang out, party, and then leave... I WANNA SEE IT THE MAN BURRRRRN!

The bad news is that it will be fences around the reserved seats and the
main public. Larry says that's the only way to keep the large crowd to
bother the people on the reserve area, and to let the various TV crews
to operate as they need to (you don't want the burn to look bad when
you'll watch it on MTV or CNN, do you ?).

For additional questions, I suggest you ask Stuart.

BTW... I've got my tickets today by mail...heheheheh... I can start

Good day,

>Maybe I should start with smoking - I quit 3 1/2  weeks ago after 10-11 years of smoking.  
>The only times I crave a smoke  is early in the morning after partying all night (going to after 
>party  and watching other people smoke).

Congratulations!  I was able to give it up almost 6 years ago.  It feels so good not to 
smoke.  Parties were also the hardest part of the equation for me to resolve.  I could easily
smoke a second pack, being up most of the night at a party; normally a 1 pack-a-day
person.  

>I have seen people  so messed up on E, acid or whatever that they can hardly walk.  I can't  
>even imagine one of them trying to drive a car.  

Luckily, most of them can't imagine it either and have enough raver sense not to try.  My
perceptions can get extremely skewed, but logic tends to prevail in the realm of psychs.

>You have to  pretend you *don't* care otherwise you will get hurt.

I was never much of a clubber because I could pick up on this.  It was easier for me to just
avoid the scene altogether, not being very good at being dishonest. ( I considered this a 
flaw at some point? )


>The reason I love raves is people who make it.  I can walk around with a  smile and I won't 
>get shit for it - I can talk to people because I just  think they are neat, not because I want to 
>go to bed with them and I can  be myself and not pretend I don't care.  I can give hugs and 
>be silly and  most people won't care.  If I need help from somebody, I can ask one of  my 
>friends that I met at the rave and they will help me (hey Tim).....

YEEESSS!  I am a much more outgoing person in this scene because I feel accepted for
who I am and don't feel threatened about expressing myself. 

>But, if you know me I am sure you heard me in early morning hours say "I  wish I had a beer 
>right now."  There is no better way to end a party than  with a nice, cold beer :)

If you go to Burning Man this year, I'll have to take you up on this.  Beer is one of my favorite 
foods in the post party afterglow.  Jeff gave me a Pyramid Apricot Ale last Sunday moring,
when he wen't back onto the decks.  Time + 1 beer =  temporary energy source.  I had 
fogotten this axiom.  Two to three is good to mellow the crash, and an excuse to keep your
friends up conversing for a few more hours.  (  "Wou ja like anutha pint, mate?" )   

Take care,
                    Jason

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Aug  9 12:08:05 1996

From: "Ronald Knegtel" <knegtel@horatio.ucsf.EDU>
Message-Id: <9608091207.ZM3735@horatio.ucsf.edu>
Date: Fri, 9 Aug 1996 12:07:51 -0700

On Aug 9, 12:43am, E. Nygma wrote:
> Subject: Re: Re: Intolerance for Hippie Crack
> I need to clarify my position:
>
> My statement about alcohol and auto accidents was meant to point out
> that it is a very dangerous drug, and yet it is legal. It wasn't meant
> to say that driving under the influence of other drugs is any
> safer. Alcohol makes one tired, and lose sense of judgement and
> awareness. Often times one doesn't feel inebriated, and it lends
> towards irrational behavior. On the other hand, ravers who partake in
> alternative substances tend to be more aware of their condition, and
> are less likely to drive under the influence (my personal opinion,
> based on the experiences of friends). So why should alcohol be any
> more legal than marijuana, MDMA, psylocybin (SP?) mushrooms, GBH,
> or LSD, among others?

The problem is that driving under the influence is not very well defined
when it comes to drugs, so people rely on their own gut feeling. Which
seems just as unreliable as with alcohol to me. I've seen plenty people
driving while they had taken drugs (usually quite some time after the
actual intake) and still find it hard to say if they are save drivers.
Taking the average time of action of for instance LSD and the overall
tiredness that comes into play I wouldn't say recreational drug users
make safer or more aware drivers than drinkers.

In one sentence: it's not the drugs, it's the people.
A bottle of beer will not kill anybody, a drunk driver will/could.
{One of the beautiful things of raving in Holland for instance is
that the country has a working public transportation system, you
just take a train or a bus home (you may have to wait until 7 am,
but you just sit in the park watching the birds and the grass).}
If the responsibility that people today show with drinking and
driving is an example, I wonder what traffic would become like if
LSD was freely available to anybody... ;-)
>
> Our government's stance on drugs is purely arbitrary. It could be
> argued that our drug laws violate our constitutional right to freedom
> of expression. Until very recently, no one in office has dared step
> forward, and speak out against the so-called "war on drugs", and
> propose reforming our laws. Even now, it is still very much a grass
> roots effort (and a feeble one at that).

I fully agree that the policy in this country regarding drugs makes no
sense. But perhaps it's smartest to to start small, legalize marihuana first.
It will keep kids from sniffing glue to get high and is generally
pretty innocent. The harder drugs I would be more careful with, 95%
of the people is not ready for them I would say. A start would be
to stop harrassing the users.

> Actually, I think that ravers who partake in such alternative
> substances instead of alcohol tend to be more aware of their
> condition, anyway, and are less likely to drive under the influence.
> By the time the party is over, the effects have worn off.

Have they? Ever inspected your pupils the next morning? Ever seen
trails after moving objects weeks after LSD use? And they're still
very tired I would say. People believe what they like to believe,
I would be _very_ reluctant to drive after using any mind altering
substance, the risk of hurting the people you love isn't worth it
to me. And there are still people passing out on alcohol-free parties.
Several people have given me rides home after raves, being under
some sort of influence, and I trust them with my live in that sense
but one still takes a risk doing so.

> BTW, I knew a couple of classmates from my high school who got into a
> car accident after smoking pot. One of them is paralyzed from the
> waist down for the rest of his life. The other was in physical rehab
> for six months. It was not a pretty sight.

I'm sorry to hear that.

The Frying Dutchman

Hope everyone has a great weekend even though Nation was cancelled at
pier 45...supposedly it's still gonna happen just not at pier 45? Call
their infoline 415.764.2922 for more info.

I called the Mayor's office to voice my polite concern saying that his
decision could adversely affect the support from a growing registered
young adult generation in his current and future political aspirations.
Eventhough I was not planning on going to Nation this action against
Nation affects our entire underground scene and I believe we should
voice our concern to the mayor in a polite, responsible, and informed
manner. Here's his number again:

415.554.6490

On a lighter note here's some funny translations to get your weekend
off on the right foot!

Peace and Love Always,
John
----
The name Coca-Cola in China was first rendered as Ke-kou-ke-la.
Unfortunately, the Coke company did not discover until after thousands
of signs had been printed that the phrase means "bite the wax tadpole"
or "female horse stuffed with wax" depending on the dialect. Coke then
researched 40,000 Chinese characters and found a close phonetic
equivalent, "ko-kou-ko-le," which can be loosely translated as
"happiness in the mouth."

In Taiwan, the translation of the Pepsi slogan "Come alive with the
Pepsi Generation" came out as "Pepsi will bring your ancestors back
from
the dead."

Also in Chinese, the Kentucky Fried Chicken slogan "finger- lickin'
good" came out as "eat your fingers off."

Scandinavian vacuum manufacturer Electrolux used the following in an
American ad campaign: "Nothing sucks like an Electrolux."

The American slogan for Salem cigarettes, "Salem - Feeling Free," got
translated in the Japanese market into "When smoking Salem, you feel so
refreshed that your mind seems to be free and empty."

When General Motors introduced the Chevy Nova in South America, it
apparently unaware that "no va" means "it won't go." After the company
figured out why it wasn't selling any cars, it renamed the car in its
Spanish markets as the Caribe.

Ford had a similar problem in Brazil when the Pinto flopped. The company
found out that Pinto was Brazilian slang for "tiny male genitals". Ford
pried all the nameplates off and substituted Corcel, which means horse.

When Parker Pen marketed a ballpoint pen in Mexico, its ads were
supposed to say "It won't leak in your pocket and embarrass you."
However, the company mistakenly thought the spanish word "embarazar"
meant embarrass. Instead the ads said that "It wont leak in your pocket
and make you pregnant."

An American t-shirt maker in Miami printed shirts for the spanish market
which promoted the Pope's visit.  Instead of the desired "I Saw the
Pope" in Spanish, the shirts proclaimed "I Saw the Potato."

Chicken-man Frank Perdue's slogan, "It takes a tough man to make a
tender chicken," got terribly mangled in another Spanish translation. A
photo of Perdue with one of his birds appeared on billboards all over
Mexico with a caption that explained "It takes a hard man to make a
chicken aroused."

Hunt-Wesson introduced its Big John products in French Canada as Gr Jos
before finding out that the phrase, in slang, means "big breasts." In
this case, however, the name problem did not have a noticeable effect on
sales.

Colgate introduced a toothpaste in France called Cue, the name of a
notorious porno mag.

In Italy, a campaign for Schweppes Tonic Water translated the name
into Schweppes Toilet Water.

Japan's second-largest tourist agency was mystified when it entered
English-speaking markets and began receiving requests for unusual sex
tours. Upon finding out why, the owners of Kinki Nippon Tourist
Company changed its name.

Dear All;

        Regarding the quitting of smoking of tobacco. I successfully quit
smoking cigs in 1982 and have never ever gone back. How did I do it, by
smoking pot when I just couldn't stand it anymore. Yes, I would roll and
light up a joint and it would take care of the craving for me, and in
addition it got me high; giving me some positive affirming feedback that I
was doing the right thing.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Aug  9 12:52:04 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id MAA16144; Fri, 9 Aug 1996 12:52:04 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from nak.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with ESMTP id MAA16132; Fri, 9 Aug 1996 12:52:00 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from ucdata.Berkeley.EDU.ucdt (ucdata.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.165.25]) by nak.berkeley.edu (8.7.3/8.6.10) with SMTP id MAA20686 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Fri, 9 Aug 1996 12:51:55 -0700 (PDT)
Received: by ucdata.Berkeley.EDU.ucdt (SMI-8.6/SMI-SVR4)
	id MAA11910; Fri, 9 Aug 1996 12:46:18 -0700
Date: Fri, 9 Aug 1996 12:46:17 -0700 (PDT)
From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Arrest of a Child (NRR)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9608091200.A11480-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I go for my daily ritual of morning coffee on Telegraph.  (Ah, gotta love 
Noah's Bagels!!)  Telegraph is usually an assaultive experience, but at 
this hour it is calm, almost beautiful.  But outside the store a crowd 
begins to gather: three cops are arresting a child.

I know this child.  I've seen him many times on the street.  Tiny, maybe 
eleven years old, with huge baggy clothes, huge baggy Afro, and 
skateboard that he gets lost in.  Always a cigarette dangling from his 
baby mouth, stoned eyes dully taking in the mayhem that surrounds him.  
He appeared in my house one day, slyly pretending to be "looking for a 
friend."  Later we discovered several items missing: a cable box, a 
portable stereo.  A few days later the alarm came from the other co-ops 
(student housing): look out for a little black kid - he's robbing all the 
houses.  Alert the police if you see him anywhere.

I've seen him since, but I didn't call the cops.  And finally today they 
caught up with him.  The crowd is hovering on the edge of hostility, 
unsure whether rage is the appropriate response.  Three large white men 
are handcuffing and harassing a small black boy - it's quite a 
spectacle.  Pigs!  Street punk!  Which is right?  Who is to blame?

I think of all the articles I've read recently about the explosion in 
crime of young teenagers.  Fastest growing segment of youth violence - 
more violent, less repentant than older teenagers.  I read that if 
someone is 16, 17 committing crimes, there is a chance at 
rehabilitation.  They may have had some different values implanted 
somewhere.  But the most dangerous are those 11, 12, 13.  They are lost.  
They had nothing else to begin with.  The statistics for these children 
are, basically, hopeless.       

Whenever I saw this boy earlier, I always had the impulse to go up to 
him.  To grab the cigarette from his mouth and ask him what he's doing to his body??  To 
tell him that he's a worthy, valuable person, who deserves to develop his 
mind in school, and deserves a loving home.  To guide him towards 
agencies or somewhere that may offer him hope.

But did he ever have a chance at that?  And now that no-one has 
intervened in a constructive way, arrest at 11 may have sealed his fate.  
The development today of juevenile hall over school and family is like an 
irrevocable path...someone, parents, society, the police, has robbed 
this boy of his possible future.

I walked quickly past the scene, silent.

On Aug 9, 12:43pm, THX1138 wrote:
> Subject: Re: Substances:Ravin' at random
> Dear All;
>
>         Regarding the quitting of smoking of tobacco. I successfully quit
> smoking cigs in 1982 and have never ever gone back. How did I do it, by
> smoking pot when I just couldn't stand it anymore. Yes, I would roll and
> light up a joint and it would take care of the craving for me, and in
> addition it got me high; giving me some positive affirming feedback that I
> was doing the right thing.
>
> Peace
> Brian
>
Well, I'm still smoking and don't really care. See it as my little contribution
to the overpopulation ;-) I always find it funny that so many official people
are paranoia about smoking _here_, while nobody seems to mind _exporting_
smokes all over the world. And I can't help but chuckle when I see the
sign asking people not to smoke in front of the air-vents here at UCSF.
While they are located at street level with all the busses, cars and trucks
going by everyday, producing more nasty hydrocarbons than I ever can
in a day. Oh and on the subject of cancer, as a chemist I found it very
interesting to learn that some of the chemicals involved in some of the
synthesis routes of our beloved party snacks are carcinogens. I hope the
chemists really purify their merchandise...
And finally, I've always wondered if the nicotine is the real problem,
I've heard that is solved in about 6 days or so. I feel it's more the
social aspect, or the killing-time aspect that drives people crazy in
the end. I can do without smoking for hours when I'm real busy, but when
I'm relaxing I smoke much more.

The Frying Dutchman

Your message came through.... but also reminded me yet again that
our current world view has moved away from responsibility of self
to the view point that we ( or in this case the boy) are what others
make us.... Not responsible for ourselves... R. A. Davis murderer
because of what his parents and society did....  M. brothers murderers
because of what their parents did.... small unknown boy arrested
because of parents etc... see a thread here?

same as people on wellfare because of what society did to them....

Unlike John  Bradshaw I don't buy it.... but it seems lots of others do...
I'm not saying others don't influence but utimately the choice (lady or
the tiger?) is up to the individual.... but then 20 years ago I was
lucky enough to have been influenced by a master who taught me the MOST
important gift a human has is their dynamic will power... and that will
power self directed (yes with help from others) can accomplish anything
so NEVER turn that over to others without great care. This is why
Tony Robbin's motivation seminars work for so many... lack of this 
will power is why so many stay oppressed and on wellfare... and when
we find ourselves saying:  " They" caused me to.... we have given that
will power away.... and the battle for self-worth and self-motivation is
lost... from there on we believe whatever we get comes from others -
even if we steal it....

just a comment,

Mike

I completely agree that we should get the facts before protesting.
When I called I just asked for what the reason was why Nation wasn't
being allowed to use the Pier 45 space. The secretary's response was
that the mayor has no response at this time...it's not clear whether
or not the mayor himself made the decision or not but the secretary did
say that the police department had a role in the matter. One would 
think however that the city, mayor and police, have known that this 
event was going to happen for quite sometime and thus if possible 
should have notified the Nation promoters that they were not going to
be able to use the pier in order to give Nation adequate time to make
alternate plans.

Communist or Socialist.

places like many of our European counterparts. They have a much better
global understanding of the planet that we could ever imagine. Even in this
day and age we are still the isolated and clueless America.

> Subject: Re: Bay Guardian Re: come/unity
> Dear All;
>
>         Is commercialism so bad? When Europe has 50k people at a May Day
> celebration, or large rave is it commercial. We tend to envy raves like
> that, yet when a promoter here in the bay does one, they are trashed, go
figure.
>
>         So, Ulrike(or anyone else who has lived in Europe or has spent some
> time on the scene there) are events like the May Day celebration considered
> commercial, and is that considered a bad thing. Please respond publicly hon,
> thanks.
>
> Peace
> Brian

Although I haven't been to MayDay myself, I have attended a few similar events
in the Netherlands. I'd say many of them are commercial, just because it takes
such a large amount of money to throw them (reflected in tickets price,
the same bunch of DJ's at every party, stands with "rave mechandise" etc.).
To say they're seen as bad depends on your perspective. If you are into
gabber/hardcore, chances are (in Holland) you prefer huge parties, the
bigger the better with state of the art lighting/sounds/visuals etc.
But then again gabber is in the hitparades back home and probably already
pretty commercial in itself. Many people (including myself) with broader
interests etc. prefer smaller raves. The music is more adventurous,
the atmosphere more intimate and friendly, and the locations more fun.
The larger events (and some clubs) attract nowadays every dimwit who
got his/her hands on pills and are now "really into the house thing",
the small scale parties are more spread by word of mouth rather than
huge flyers and more difficult to get to if you don't were to ask
(similar to here in SF I would say).
The scene is so big there, that there is something for every one, which
(unfortunately) results in quite seperated groups ravers going only to
their kind of events...

My $0.02

The Frying Dutchman

>
> At 08:17 PM 8/9/96 GMT, you wrote:
> >The underground will always stay underground...  Just because an article
talks
> >about a few events dosen't mean the scene has become commericalized.  I've
> >been to parties where when someone sees an SFR laminate they say,
> > "oh, boy I guess were commercal now..." (sad, but true..)
> >
> >You just have to go "deeper" to find it @ times (Ie: CCC, SPAZ, Down to
> >Earth, Blessed ect...).
>-- End of excerpt from THX1138

On Fri, 9 Aug 1996, TEMPoNAUT wrote:

> if you dont have any skills what are you going to do? of course you're 
> going to flip burgers. if people didnt treat high school like shit, get 
> an education, and then apply to colleges (and if the schools took people 
> based on grades, not "who's a minority") then they wouldnt be flipping 
> burgers for 4.25 an hour. "oh but there's no money to go to college." 
> fine then, take out a loan. graduate. get a job, pay the loan back. if 
> people put some effort into things, they wouldnt have to be on welfare. 

	Whoa, what do you think college is good for?! Teaching skills? 
There you have something quite wrong. From what I have seen, college
either pampers you (like stanford) or teaches you how to deal with
complete beuacratic shit (Berkeley). I have yet to meet someone coming out
of college that has the skills needed to do the most important things in a
job like working with other people.  College isn't aimed at giving you the
skills needed to make things better for anybody except your future CEO,
but instead breeds, or at least allows to perpetuate, some type of narrow
vision of how one is SUPPOSED to live. College has destroyed the visions
of some of the brightest people I have ever met because the delusion that
an American university was supposed to be about learning and investigating
an academic field, and not about handing homework in, competing with other
people for spots and the like, simply turned them away from participating.
	And then let's take a look at this loan thing. Take out a loan? 
On what credit basis? Who is going to give you this loan? What if you 
want to study an art and not a tech field which might someday get you a 
job which can pay back the loan... If you are in a low economic class, 
who is going to make getting a loan an easy enough process to leave one 
with enough energy to keep going through the education assembly line? No 
where is there any type of plateau for someone to take a break and build 
confidence back up; if one's confidence is ever broken, who is going to 
slacken the avalanche of shit to allow that person a quick break because 
that person from a low economic class has already busted their ass far 
harder to get to that point then little suburn daddy bought you a car to 
take to college person... Granted, each person has a different load of 
shit to deal with and each person will have their own rock bottom as 
their beliefs are twisted and stretched, but it seems that colleges are 
set up with functions that are aimed more toward a certain lifestyle of 
comfort and politeness and shallowness...
	And finally, what if you don't know what you want to do with your
life but you know you don't want to controbute to the wanton destruction
of everything around you? What if you don't want to perpetuate this chain
of go to school, get a job, have job become your life - not of your own
free will, but because your potential is so great that your manager keeps
dymping stuff on you til you end up working 60+ hour weeks. Going to
school and getting a job is NOT what many people's life is about. Why
should it be?  When going to school, getting a job and "advancing" society
means moving resources around at a rate the local ecosystems cannot adjust
to the point where all the moving we do creates a tidal wave that
eventually crashes over us.... Maybe schools should teach people to think
a little about what they are doing out there in the world in addition to
the competition and the like that they are currently so good at
amplifying... Our economic system is not divised for this many people. To 
keep it going, it has to keep coming up with more bullshit things that 
people don't need and for many, just should not have because they are 
really beginning to interfere with other people's lives with them. In the 
process of providing these things, we are moving resources far more 
quickily than anything has been forced to adapt to before including 
ourselves. 

> and for those who just cant do it, fine then. there are still jobs out 
> there for people with almost no education. UPS. pays 8.35 an hour. part 
> time. full medical/dental/vision. stock options. .50 raise every year, 
> 1.00 raise on the 4th year. union protection.
> 
> thats just loading/unloading trucks. 

	And they are looking for certain people who can lift 80 lbs packages 
and work with dust that is known to cause cancer in constant exposure. 
Both these will limit your life span and probably give you problems over 
the rest of the course of your existence. Why should someone want to do 
that? To profit UPS? To make us, the people who bought into the fucking 
system, not have to take care of those who didn't want it anyway? Telling 
people to go get a shitty job to make their life even shittier so that I 
can go out and spend the money I am entitled to in my comfy job on drugs, 
parties, travel or the like doesn't seem quite right when they don't get 
to do the same...
	Yelling about how other people need to get off their butts does 
not help. It doesn't go anywhere. What I see from this anger is more 
resentment that the yeller cannot let go of things to go and live in then 
way he or she wants to because he or she is scared and because of that, 
he or she is pissed off. Granted, I am making assumptions but so be it. 
No one is going to be able to fix things on their own, but you can make 
an effort to help those around you and yourself.

dave

...  -listen: there's a hell
of a good universe next door; let's go

		- e.e. cummings

>>
>>vis a vis all my smart-alec friends...
>>
>>>HOW TO ARGUE EFFECTIVELY
>>>>>
>>>>>     I argue very well.  Ask any of my remaining friends.  I can win
>>>>>an argument on any topic, against any opponent.  People know this and
>>>>>steer clear of me at parties.  Often, as a sign of their great respect,
>>>>>they don't even invite me.  You too can win arguments.  Simply follow
>>>>>these rules:
>>>>>
>>>>>     *Drink liquor.
>>>>>
>>>>>Suppose you are at a party and some hotshot intellectual is expounding
>>>>>on the economy of Peru, a subject you know nothing about.  If you're
>>>>>drinking some health-fanatic drink like grapefruit juice, you'll hang
>>>>>back, afraid to display your ignorance, while the hotshot enthralls your
>>>>>date.  But if you drink several large martinis, you'll discover you
>>>>>have STRONG VIEWS about the Peruvian economy.  You'll be a WEALTH of
>>>>>information.  You'll argue forcefully, offering searing insights and
>>>>>possibly upsetting furniture.  People will be impressed.  Some may leave
>>>>>the room.
>>>>>
>>>>>     *Make things up.
>>>>>
>>>>>Suppose, in the Peruvian economy argument, you are trying to prove
>>>>>that Peruvians are underpaid, a position you base solely on the fact
>>>>>that YOU are underpaid, and you'll be damned if you're going to let a
>>>>>bunch of Peruvians be better off.  DON'T say: "I think Peruvians are
>>>>>underpaid."  Say instead:  "The average Peruvian's salary in 1981
>>>>>dollars adjusted for the revised tax base is $1,452.81 per annum,
>>>>>which is $836.07 before the mean gross poverty level."
>>>>>
>>>>>     NOTE:  Always make up exact figures.
>>>>>
>>>>>If an opponent asks you where you got your information, make THAT
>>>>>up too.  Say:  "This information comes from Dr. Hovel T. Moon's study
>>>>>for the Buford Commission published on May 9, 1982. Didn't you read
>>>>>it?"  Say this in the same tone of voice you would use to say, "You
>>>>>left your soiled underwear in my bathroom."
>>>>>
>>>>>     *Use meaningless but weighty-sounding words and phrases.
>>>>>
>>>>>Memorize this list:
>>>>>
>>>>>     Let me put it this way
>>>>>     In terms of
>>>>>     Vis-a-vis
>>>>>     Per se
>>>>>     As it were
>>>>>     Qua
>>>>>     Ipso facto
>>>>>     Ergo
>>>>>     So to speak
>>>>>
>>>>>You should also memorize some Latin abbreviations such as "Q.E.D.",
>>>>>"e.g.", and "i.e."  These are all short for "I speak Latin, and you
>>>>>don't." Here's how to use these words and phrases.  Suppose you want to
>>>>>say, "Peruvians would like to order appetizers more often, but they
>>>>>don't
>>>>>have enough money."
>>>>>
>>>>>You never win arguments talking like that.  But you WILL win if you
>>>>>say, "Let me put it this way.  In terms of appetizers vis-a-vis
>>>>>Peruvians qua Peruvians, they would like to order them more often,
>>>>>so to speak, but they do not have enough money per se, as it were.
>>>>>Ergo, ipso facto, case closed. Q.E.D."
>>>>>
>>>>>Only a fool would challenge that statement.
>>>>>
>>>>>     *Use snappy and irrelevant comebacks.
>>>>>
>>>>>You need an arsenal of all-purpose irrelevant phrases to fire back at
>>>>>your opponents when they make valid points.  The best are:
>>>>>
>>>>>     You're begging the question.
>>>>>     You're being defensive.
>>>>>     Don't compare apples to oranges.
>>>>>     What are your parameters?
>>>>>
>>>>>This last one is especially valuable.  Nobody (other than engineers
>>>>>and policy wonks) has the vaguest idea what "parameters" means.
>>>>>
>>>>>Don't forget the classic: YOU'RE SO LINEAR.
>>>>>
>>>>>Here's how to use your comebacks:
>>>>>
>>>>>     You say:            As Abraham Lincoln said in 1873...
>>>>>     Your opponent says: Lincoln died in 1865.
>>>>>     You say:            You're begging the question.
>>>>>
>>>>>     You say:            Liberians, like most Asians...
>>>>>     Your opponent says: Liberia is in Africa.
>>>>>     You say:            You're being defensive.
>>>>>
>>>>>     You say:            Since the discovery of the incandescent light
>>>>>bulb...
>>>>>     Your opponent says: The light bulb is an invention.
>>>>>     You say:            Well DUH!
>>>>>
>>>>>     *Compare your opponent to Adolf Hitler.
>>>>>
>>>>>This is your heavy artillery, for when your opponent is obviously
>>>>>right and you are spectacularly wrong.  Bring Hitler up subtly.  Say,
>>>>>"That sounds suspiciously like something Adolf Hitler might say," or
>>>>>"You certainly do remind me of Adolf Hitler."
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>
>> -------------------------------
>>
>>
>>        Because e-mail can be altered electronically,
>>        the integrity of this communication cannot be guaranteed.
>>
>>
>>
>>
>

On Fri, 9 Aug 1996, David L. Bayer wrote:

> 	Whoa, what do you think college is good for?! Teaching skills? 
> There you have something quite wrong. From what I have seen, college
> either pampers you (like stanford) or teaches you how to deal with
> complete beuacratic shit (Berkeley). I have yet to meet someone coming out
> of college that has the skills needed to do the most important things in a
> job like working with other people.  College isn't aimed at giving you the
> skills needed to make things better for anybody except your future CEO,
> but instead breeds, or at least allows to perpetuate, some type of narrow
> vision of how one is SUPPOSED to live. College has destroyed the visions
> of some of the brightest people I have ever met because the delusion that
> an American university was supposed to be about learning and investigating
> an academic field, and not about handing homework in, competing with other
> people for spots and the like, simply turned them away from participating.

You know, I found something very relative to this subject laying on a 
desk today(coincedence? I think not...):

"If the colleges were better, if they really had it, you would need to 
get the police at the gates to keep order in the inrushing multitude.
See in clooge how we thwart the natural love of learning by leaving
the natural method of teaching what each wishes to learn, and insisting
that you shall learn what you have no taste or capacity for. The 
college, which should be a place of delightful labor, is made odious
and unhealthy,  and the young men are tempted to frivolous amusements to 
rally their jaded spirits. I would have studies elective.
Scholarship is to be created not by compulsion, but by awakening a pure
interest in knowledge. The wise instructor accomplishes this by
opening to his pupils precisely the attractions the study has for 
himself.The marking is a system for schools, not for the college; for
boys, and not for men; and it is an ungracious work to put on a professor."


        --Ralph Waldo Emerson


                                           Black Adder

	(1.37.109.18/16.2) id AA039427555; Fri, 9 Aug 1996 17:39:15 -0700
From: Thomas Schwarz <tschwarz@scudc.scu.edu>
Subject: Re: Bay Guardian Re: come/unity
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 9 Aug 1996 17:39:15 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi All,

I totally agree with our Frying Dutchman.
I have been to some big events in Germany, and I consider these events 
as commercial. You cannot throw such big parties without help from the
commercial side. The German techno scene became really big over the last
years and a lot of companies (from the music business, as well as from 
other areas: fashion, tabacco, drinks) saw their chance to make profit. For 
them, the techno scene is a market, and they saw the potential of this 
growing market. Youth people in general represent good, solvent consumers. 
Companies like Camel, Adidas, etc. tried to catch trends, were successful, 
and also helped to accelerate the growing of the scene.

Is it a bad thing? 

On one side, there are events you couldn't realize 
without help from the commercial side (sponsoring, advertisements, 
publicity like TV broadcasts, magazines, ...).
Like the Frying Dutchman said: the big events often have amazing light, 
sounds, visuals, dj line-ups, ... Some of the events I went were really 
awesome. 

On the other side, it also has its drawbacks. Same as here, commercial/
big events tend to have a bad vibe sometimes. Sometimes there are 
a lot of people who just come because it's a big event and everybody is 
going. They don't know what techno is about. All they think is that
people go there and do drugs, and that's all they wanna do there.
Or some big events are just rip offs: announced djs don't show up,
bad organisation, ... I was also disappointed by some of the big 
events in Germany.

I wouldn't say every big, commercial event is bad. 
You just don't know how the party gonna be. If it's a bad
party, the disappointment is bigger because of your bigger
expectations and higher costs.


In my hometown Munich, the growing scene and partial commercialization
showed some interesting effects. Here are 2 examples:

We had (I think 2 years ago) a rave combined with the so-called
'Camel awards' for best dj, best live-act, best event... in town. 
These awards were voted by readers of a techno magazine and was 
sponsored by Camel. The space was awesome. I've never seen such a light
system and visual effects again. It took place in a film studio and
only invited guests (maybe 1.000 or 2.000 ?) got tickets (I was working
there). After the winners got their awards, the rave started.
The funny thing was, when they started the party, the room became 
more and more empty. DJs and location were really awesome, but the 
'guests' rather stormed into the VIP lounge...

Another example is the 'Kulturstation' in Munich. It's a location
sponsored by the city where young people can through their parties.
The rent is quite cheap comparing to other locations. It's also the 
place were techno started in Munich. There were the first techno 
parties in town.
Over the years the parties moved to clubs and bigger locations.
But after a while, people started to throw their own small parties
again at the 'Kulturstation'. And these parties are usually pretty
good, no matter what kind of big rave is in town the same night.

Like Frying Dutchman said, a big scene has something for everyone:
All kind of music styles and all kind of events.
Some are good, and some are bad.



Thomas

PS
I'm going to see Carl Cox at Nikita tonight.
Hope to see a lot sfravers.

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I just read "DJ roundtable" article in the Bay Guardian.  

I was soo impressed!  

I especially liked Graham's DIY attitude:  

"We don't need to rely on big studieos and major labels anymore to make
music."  

Right on bro.

"When punk came along it took control of the music out of the hands of the
majors and put in the hands of the people who really made the music.  And
it's happening again now. Majors look at our music and they don't
understand what we do or how to promote it, and they stay away.  So it's
quite exciting.  It really is in our hands at the moment."

Just like the parties where the music is played is in all of our hands at
the moment.  We create the space, the vibe, the setting, the social
experiment.  

I especially like the fact that Rave can't be packaged for a mass
audience.  It loses its magic, and the magic is what makes the rave.

Have an awesome weekend!

Ann

ELEMENT: man
SYMBOL: Xy
ATOMIC WEIGHT: not a pound more than when it was younger
PHYSICAL PROPERTIES: solid at room temperature but eats gets bent out  
of

to
rust, more difficult to get a charge out of aging samples compared to

CHEMICAL PROPERTIES: attempts to bond with Wo any chance it gets;  
however,
it is easily neutralized by saturating with alcohol, or television.
USAGE: none, come to think of it.

ELEMENT: woman
SYMBOL: Wo
ATOMIC WEIGHT: none of your business
PHYSICAL PROPERTIES: generally round in form. Boils at nothing and  
may
freeze anytime. Melts whenever treated properly. Very bitter if not  
handled
well.
CHEMICAL PROPERTIES: very reactive. Possesses strong affinity to  
gold,
silver, platinum, and carbon (diamond).  Violent when left alone.  
Able to
absorb great amounts of exotic food. Turns green when placed near a  
better
specimen. Ages ungraciously.
USAGE:  primarily ornamental. An extremely good catalyst for  
disintegration
of wealth.  Probably the most powerful income reducing agent known to  
man.
CAUTION: highly explosive in inexperienced hands.

ATOMIC WEIGHT: not a pound more than when it was younger
PHYSICAL PROPERTIES: solid at room temperature but eats gets bent out  
of
shape.  Fairly dense and flaky. Difficult to find a pure sample. Due  
to
rust, more difficult to get a charge out of aging samples compared to
young, fresh, ones.
CHEMICAL PROPERTIES: attempts to bond with Wo any chance it gets;  
however,
it is easily neutralized by saturating with alcohol, or television.
USAGE: none, come to think of it.
CAUTION: in the absence of Wo, this element rapidly decomposes and  
begins
to smell.

>BTW, I knew a couple of classmates from my high school who got into a car accident after 
>smoking pot. One of them is paralyzed from the waist down for the rest of his life. The other 
>was in physical rehab for six months. It was not a pretty sight.

I am curious as to whether they were at fault in this accident.  Also, if they were, did they
feel that being under the influence had any effect on the situation.  I am not condoning
any actions here.  I am just curious.  Also, if someone falls asleep at the wheel or 
is not at fault in an accident and is under the influence of marijuana, they will be prosecuted
for being so, regardless as to whether it had any bearing on the events that transpired.
Is this really fair?  From past experience, marijuana does not have nearly the impairing
affects that the legal drug alcohol does.  It does impair, just not to the same degree.  

Take care,
                    Jason

> Good day,
> 
> >BTW, I knew a couple of classmates from my high school who got into a car accident after 
> >smoking pot. One of them is paralyzed from the waist down for the rest of his life. The other 
> >was in physical rehab for six months. It was not a pretty sight.
> 
> I am curious as to whether they were at fault in this accident.  Also, if they were, did they
> feel that being under the influence had any effect on the situation.  I am not condoning
> any actions here.  I am just curious.  Also, if someone falls asleep at the wheel or 
> is not at fault in an accident and is under the influence of marijuana, they will be prosecuted
> for being so, regardless as to whether it had any bearing on the events that transpired.
> Is this really fair?  From past experience, marijuana does not have nearly the impairing
> affects that the legal drug alcohol does.  It does impair, just not to the same degree.  

Falling asleep at the wheel while smoking marijuana!  No way!

I for one can be made quite sleepy by this particular stimulant.  As far
as fair goes, should a person who drives a car knowing they're very tired
be `let off the hook' because they fell asleep and couldn't help it?
In other words, perhaps falling asleep should be considered more neglegant
rather than being under the incluence being considered less so.

I have fallen asleep at the wheel when I knew I shouldn't drive and can
only be grateful I did no damage to anyone or anything (except my car!)

A car is a dangerous weapon which most people aren't trained well enough
to handle.

As far as making generalizations about drugs in relation to EVERYBODY ...
keep in mind that all substances (drugs or not, legal or not) have
different effects on different people and different effects on the same
person under different circumstances.  Legalize it all, educate the
people and let us kill ourselves if we want to but provide thorough public
transportation to avoid our killing others on the way.

Tim

Just got back from the Greek in Berkeley. DCD put on an incredible
vibe in the open air of the night. 

The scene was quite perfect: sunset glowing above the horizon before
fading into dusk, the twinkle of headlights on the bridge, a warm and
friendly crowd, an awesome mix of acoustics...and not to mention an
intense performance by Lisa and Brendon, backed by many
percussionists. What a scene! The light show consisted of a perfect
blend of white, yellow, orange, cyan, blue, green, and violet,
reflecting off the big columns, and onto the stage.

It was an incredible way to kick off the weekend. I'm really 
looking forward to Nation tomorrow, wherever it will be!

For those of you attending Hunny: I'm sending a mellow, happy, thread 
of turquoise energy towards your way. Hope you felt it!

PLUR,
E. Nygma

I wrote:
> >BTW, I knew a couple of classmates from my high school who got into a car accident after 
> >smoking pot...

and you responded: 
> I am curious as to whether they were at fault in this accident. 
> Also, if they were, did they feel that being under the influence
> had any effect on the situation.  I am not condoning any actions
> here.  I am just curious. 

It was a one-car accident. Excessive speed through an S-turn on a
windy 2-lane country road. Most certainly the driver was at fault.

> Also, if someone falls asleep at the wheel or is not at fault in
> an accident and is under the influence of marijuana, they will be
> prosecuted for being so, regardless as to whether it had any
> bearing on the events that transpired. Is this really fair? 

As far as I'm concerned, anyone who cannot control the wheel for any
reason -- DUI, excessive tiredness, recklessness, or just plain
incompetence -- is responsible for their actions. I think it is fair
enough to subject them to the appropriate consequences, regardless
of whether they hurt anyone else or not. I want to personally feel
safe driving on the highways and streets, and not have to fear being
hit, and possibly killed, by someone operating their vehicle in an
irresponsible manner.

> From past experience, marijuana does not have nearly the impairing
> affects that the legal drug alcohol does.  It does impair, just not
> to the same degree.  

Every drug (including prescription ones) has a certain
responsibility the user must accept when taking it. I do not care
what substance a person chooses to imbibe, so long as it doesn't put
any danger on myself, my friends, or others.

As the ads would suggest, "Be high responsibly."

E. Nygma
playing the role of Dante in Suburbia

The Hills are alive.
--Head for the Valleys!

Davis so if anyone is up for the trip it should be fun.  If anybody hasn't
made plans yet and wants to come out e-mail me and I will get back to you at
about 7pm (work).  

Hope some of you folks make it out!

On Sat, 10 Aug 1996, E. Nygma wrote:

> Just got back from the Greek in Berkeley. DCD put on an incredible
> vibe in the open air of the night. 
> 
> The scene was quite perfect: sunset glowing above the horizon before
> fading into dusk, the twinkle of headlights on the bridge, a warm and
> friendly crowd, an awesome mix of acoustics...and not to mention an
> intense performance by Lisa and Brendon, backed by many
> percussionists. What a scene! The light show consisted of a perfect
> blend of white, yellow, orange, cyan, blue, green, and violet,
> reflecting off the big columns, and onto the stage.
> 
> It was an incredible way to kick off the weekend. I'm really 
> looking forward to Nation tomorrow, wherever it will be!
> 
> For those of you attending Hunny: I'm sending a mellow, happy, thread 
> of turquoise energy towards your way. Hope you felt it!
> 
> PLUR,

On Fri, 9 Aug 1996, Jason C. Lundy wrote:

> Good day,
> 
> >BTW, I knew a couple of classmates from my high school who got into a car accident after 
> >smoking pot. One of them is paralyzed from the waist down for the rest of his life. The other 
> >was in physical rehab for six months. It was not a pretty sight.
> 
> I am curious as to whether they were at fault in this accident.  Also, if they were, did they
> feel that being under the influence had any effect on the situation.  I am not condoning
> any actions here.  I am just curious.  Also, if someone falls asleep at the wheel or 
> is not at fault in an accident and is under the influence of marijuana, they will be prosecuted
> for being so, regardless as to whether it had any bearing on the events that transpired.
> Is this really fair?  From past experience, marijuana does not have nearly the impairing
> affects that the legal drug alcohol does.  It does impair, just not to the same degree.  

Yes it is fair. Just because one is not at fault in an accident does not 
alter the fact that they were driving under the influence, which is a 
really STUPID(and yes I am being very judgemental) thing to do. It is 
also something I see far too many people do. If you want to risk your own 
life, fine. But don't risk mine or my loved ones, or anyone elses for 
that matter, because someone can't be bothered to behave responsibly and wait 
before wrapping themselves in a few thousand pounds of metal and heading down 
the road.

As far as your past experiences, they are entirely subjective, and I am 
sure their are unbiased studies that have been done that refute your 
"feelings." Hell, I would go dig them up if you like, but I doubt that would 
make a difference, right?  

                                       Black Adder

Really?  My 19951040ez tax booklet totaly disproves this(on the fed level).
First, on page 8, it states that you must file if single and your income was
__$6,400__ or more.  BIG $3,600 difference there.  Then, the tax table on
page 29 states that a full time min. wage income is taxed $1226, about 15%.
(full-time employment is 40 hours a week, this = 1920hrs/year. @ 4.25/hr,
that = $8160/year)   This makes the actual wage about $3.61 an hour (85% of
4.25) 3.61 X 40= $144/week, or $579/month after taxes.  Rent = -+$350/month,
food, at 6.00$ a day ( $2 average per meal... a megar sustainance) 180= $ a
month.  Bills (pg+e, water, phone, etc.)=  + - 40$ a month.  The balance is
___9$___ .  Oh yah, there are state income taxes, too, so that is gone
anyway...How will you get to work?  What will you do if you need
medical/dental help?  How will you get new clothes(they wear out)?  How will
you wash your clothes? How will you buy toothpaste and deoderant?  How will
you ever do anything for fun except go to the park near your house on your 2
days off a week?  I call this barely existing, not living.  

Something's still got to give... 

-Juhstyn

Unfortunately about 3 years ago I fell asleep on the way home from a Wacky
Citrus.  That's what I get huh?  Anyway I was about 2 exits away from my
house and I fell asleep going about 80 and careened into a bus.  If that
bus had not been there I would have gone off a cliff and plunged to my
death(along with two of my friends).  That was a serious wake up call. I
stopped partying for almost a year.  I learned one thing that day.  I have
control over my own life.  I can decide before it is too late that I will
not get behind the wheel of a car if I'm not feeling like a am capable of
it.  Please people, you must be careful.  I wasn't even on drugs.  I hadn't
taken them and that was why I fell asleep.  My trick now is to smoke a
doobie, roll down the window, and listen to extremely loud country music.
Works every time.

-Nancy

intoxicated...oh wait.  You might like that :)!  The problem is that
chemicals often effect your _ability_to_know_ if you are ok to drive or not.
 You think you can do it cuz you're high, but your body is not up to dealing
with emergencies quickly enough.  It's even true when you're sober much of
the time, that by the time those breaklights come on in front of you, it is
too late for your body's reaction time to do a thing about it!  This is why
tailgaiting is so stupid.  By the laws of physics, you simply will not be
able to stop in time when you are that close.  Please don't endanger yourself
or others if you don't have to.  Be responsible for yourself by planning to
not have to drive.  If the situation comes about where you want to/must drive
when you planned not to (part gets broken up, you now want to leave beacuse
your ex showed up, etc.) you must continue that responsibility and stick it
out.  Drive to a close safe parking are and chill for a few hours...or better
yet, always have a sober person in your troop.  Then you can get as fucked up
as you please and still get somewhere in safety.  Plus, they can talk to cops
and stuff...

on important issues.  (: (: (: (:Keep your negative's in check!:) :) :) :) :)

Friends, as you know Roger Kumar's summer of pleasure has come to an end, 
and it is back to the frozen tundra of Missouri for him.  While he was 
here he certainly added to our scene with his generous posting on the Web 
of his many party pictures.  I just wanted to say a hearty thank-you!

Just yesterday he and I discovered that we are next-door neighbors!!  All 
summer and didn't even know it...the rave world is small and our virtual 
community is but a village, but sometimes someone is, literally, right 
next door and we still may not know!  How closely we all orbit each 
other, sometimes meeting by chance and then discovering the person was 
practically right next to you the whole time....

Tripping,
N.

From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Techno in "Trainspotting" (SRR)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9608101845.A16470-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



"Trainspotting" was awesome.  Imagine an American film dealing honestly 
and humorously with drug use and youth culture?  No, what we get from our 
mainstream studios is mainstream, homogenized crap...but that is a 
different thread.

Marginally rave-related:
Super-cool was the inspired use of techno as a soundtrack!!  The 
throbbing beats of the club scene (with familiar faces high on e and the 
intoxicating music), the plaintive tones of Underworld, jarring techno at 
the end...Here is a film that presents the emotional range of techno, 
that actually _respects_ the music.  The ONLY time I have heard it in 
American films, tv, etc. is as a joke, the stock portrayal of clanging 
noise with no redemptive musical worth...

Must be because the film's European, where techno is actually mainstream and 
popular.  But any other music for this subject would have been glaringly 
discordant...new, exciting sounds to accompany the trip to the edge, the 
life of young heroin addicts in Scotland.  Like the character says, 
"everything is changing...music is changing..."

But mainstream American entertainment will not acknowledge that.  Even 
major recording studios still think electronic music is a fad that will 
blow over, rather than seeing it as the beginnings of future music... Our 
big-budget studios, our mainstream culture, is decrepid, plodding along 
mired in the past and what will safely sell to the under-stimulated 
masses....

N

Well,

It turns out that the hacker war against me has excelated to a whole new
level,  and I'm asking for any UNIX guru's out there to please help me.

I didn't even know it was possible,  but these hackers have "subscribed"
me to over 4000 mailing lists,  thus completly cutting off all incoming
mail to me.    This afternoon,  I had over 4000 messages,  ALL of which
were to "Majordomo's" subscribing me.    As far as I know,  it's still
going on,   so for the time being,   I've switched over to a new account
on another system.   But I have a feeling that soon THIS account will
be spammed as well.

I find this outright harrassment,  and want to know if I have any
legal recourse.

For instance,  if an email request comes into a Majordomo account,  is
there a way to identify the source?

Anyway,   I could use some help from any UNIX hacker to help me out...

Crunchman

.......I agree!  You should be spanked soundly for even trying to drive
intoxicated...oh wait.  You might like that :)!  The problem is that
chemicals often effect your _ability_to_know_ if you are ok to drive or not.
 You think you can do it cuz you're high, but your body is not up to dealing
with emergencies quickly enough.  It's even true when you're sober much of
the time, that by the time those breaklights come on in front of you, it is
too late for your body's reaction time to do a thing about it!  This is why
tailgaiting is so stupid.  By the laws of physics, you simply will not be
able to stop in time when you are that close.  Please don't endanger yourself
or others if you don't have to.  Be responsible for yourself by planning to
not have to drive.  If the situation comes about where you want to/must drive
when you planned not to (part gets broken up, you now want to leave beacuse
your ex showed up, etc.) you must continue that responsibility and stick it
out.  Drive to a close safe parking are and chill for a few hours...or better
yet, always have a sober person in your troop.  Then you can get as fucked up
as you please and still get somewhere in safety.  Plus, they can talk to cops
and stuff...
Oh, and I don't mean to rag on you, it's just that I don't like to be silent
on important issues.  (: (: (: (:Keep your negative's in check!:) :) :) :) :)
}}}}}}}}}}}}}Juhstyn@aol.com{{{{{{{{

On Sat, 10 Aug 1996, Nancy W. Wolfe wrote:

> Unfortunately about 3 years ago I fell asleep on the way home from a Wacky
> Citrus.  That's what I get huh?  Anyway I was about 2 exits away from my
> house and I fell asleep going about 80 and careened into a bus.  If that
> bus had not been there I would have gone off a cliff and plunged to my
> death(along with two of my friends).  That was a serious wake up call. I
> stopped partying for almost a year.  I learned one thing that day.  I have
> control over my own life.  I can decide before it is too late that I will
> not get behind the wheel of a car if I'm not feeling like a am capable of
> it.  Please people, you must be careful.  I wasn't even on drugs.  I hadn't
> taken them and that was why I fell asleep.  My trick now is to smoke a
> doobie, roll down the window, and listen to extremely loud country music.
> Works every time.

So lets get this straight: You ran into a bus after falling asleep, while 
sober. And now, your solution to this is to ingest a CNS depressant before 
driving? Yup sounds like real sound reasoning to me. Please, anyone out 
there, please let me know if you see Nancy anywhere near a party that I 
am attending, so I can leave before she gets on the road. 

                                         Black Adder

...I was already gonna post this but I figured now would even be a more 
appropriate time with all this rave shutting down...

		...we should have the right to rave
		...we only want to spread SM:)ES and happiness, and dance

(off of flyer I was handed @ HUNNY)

	Why are you at this event? The rave scene is not just about techno.  
	This scene is not just about drugs this scene is no just about fashion.
	It is something special about unity and happiness.

	It is about being yourself and being loved for it.  
	It should be a harbor from our society.

	BUT our scene right now is disintegrating!!!!!!!
	Old style ravers -- remeber when everybody HUGGED all the time 
	-- not just to say hello and goodbyes?
	Remember when people just said hi to be your FRIEND?
	Remembver how good that felt?
	Why don't we do it anymore?
	New comers -- you are wanted and you should know that this scene 
	is about openess.
	
	We all share a bond -- the desire to groove to a good beat ALL 
	night long -- and no one is an island.
	Everyone needs friends and the OUTSIDE WORLD is tough enough.
	We don't need fronts and attitudes in our scene.
	Open your hearts and let the good feelings flow =)
	Look around you, pick a person, ask them their name, and make a FRIEND,
	eliminate boundaries.
	
	OPEN your hearts and minds, RAVERS UNITE and keep our scene alive!!!


				
					take care my dear fellow ravers,
			
					      	-={ MHg }=-

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Aug 11 02:24:36 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id CAA03863; Sun, 11 Aug 1996 02:24:36 -0700 (PDT)

From: Sfraver@aol.com
Received: by emout18.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id FAA21822 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Sun, 11 Aug 1996 05:23:07 -0400
Date: Sun, 11 Aug 1996 05:23:07 -0400
Message-ID: <960811052305_176242120@emout18.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: why did Nation get busted?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I was listening with frustration to tonight's reports that Nation had been
shut down (before it even started) by the SFPD, complete with riot gear and
barricades down at 18th & Illinois, also known as Pier 70.  This was the
second SF location that the Sundae crew tried to have this party at, after
being stonewalled out of their legit Pier 45 location earlier this week. This
certainly seems like overkill by our local government, given the most
always-peaceful nature of raves and ravers. It's a shame to see San Francisco
join the ranks of other cities (London and Los Angeles, to name a few) that
make a show of shutting down raves, rather than observing things on a
case-by-case basis, and only responding to complains from neighbors or unsafe
situations.

The folks in charge of Nation also promote Nikita and Spundae,at 1015 Folsom
and Club DV8 respectively, which means that the bulk of their experience is
with throwing parties in legitimate clubs where promoting both the specific
event and the location is not an issue. In the big club scene, that makes
lots of sense--everyone gets to see how exciting the location is, and plan to
meet their friends there, etc.  In the rave scene, announcing the location
for a party ahead of time gives the neighbors plenty of time to complain to
the police and the mayor, who then, to please the taxpayers, have a big stake
in seeing the party not happen.  This can lead to the "barricades and riot
gear" situation we saw tonight, where the police are not just busting a
party; they're making a statement over busting the party, to show the
neighborhood that they're responding actively to everyone's complaints.

That started me thinking about all of the very small undergrounds that I've
been to in San Francisco, and how, for the most part, these go off without
difficultly, even if/when the police do visit. As a case in point, I was at a
small underground last weekend, and the cops visited this party in the wee
hours, noted that "everything seems well under control", and left without
further difficulty.

The small undergrounds seem like mostly groups of friends who want to play
records for their friends. That's different from trying to re-create the
"superclub" atmosphere at an underground.  Underground parties are all about
"vibe", and superclubs are mostly about the venues and their world-famous
DJs. If you think of the rave scene as a little microcosm, it's interesting
to see the way in which the scene is self-regulating, even when the police
count as part of the microcosm. 

I'm feel bad that Nation didn't get to happen tonight; I imagine that they
lost a lot of money, and there will be a lot of disappointed folks
(especially under 18 and out of town) that miss Sasha and the rest of the
crew.  Kudos go to the folks at Nation for arranging a makeup party on
Sunday, and offering to refund tickets not used--they're really acting
responsibly in the face of adversity and police harrassment.

Sign me...
    ...a thoughtful sfraver

As I'm writing this message, I realize how much I appreciate having my
computer and other gadgets back after a most powerless day...
certainly I was powerless in both senses of the word. I also had a
chance to reflect upon how unprepared I am for a major earthquake, as
I stood in an endless line at Safeway, clutching my D batteries and
canned vegetables.

But I'm glad it happened today and not yesterday, because I would
not have been able to experience Hunny :) :) Dutch spun a wonderful
set; I think I danced the hardest at that point. I had never heard
DJ Dan before, and he played some rilly tripped-out crazy stuff;
fully enjoyed it; I'll look for him again. Unfortunately, I wasn't
able to pay too much attention to the other sets because I was tired
from a long day's work :(

The voicemail sort of was apologetic about the space (Jerrold Ave
Deli); I didn't think it was that bad except for the super-slippery
dance floor...

There was a very special feeling there last night; of course, I can't
describe it, but I'm sure you know what I'm talking about :) I stayed
until the end; enjoyed all of the group hugs, meeting random people,
and the total vibe. I was exhausted, but I couldn't bear to leave. The
party ended with everyone joining hands and dancing in a circle.

It was a beautiful night; I drove home with a stupid grin on my face
as I pondered how odd it is that we move our bodies to sound...

Steve

Good day,

Actually this was someone else's story that I was curious about.  I don't condone
cruising while high.  But I think the laws as current, could unfairly punish someone
who had, in the recent past (last night for instance), smoked and been involved in an accident
that no fault of his own.  Does this person really deserve this kind of aggrevation considering
the hypothetical circumstance?  It would be the same as having zero tolerance for alcohol; 
also stupid if you are responsible, count drinks and bide your time.

Take care,
                    Jason

From: "Jason C. Lundy" <104242.1233@compuserve.com>
Subject: (NRR): Impairment
To: "INTERNET:blkadder@value.net" <blkadder@value.net>
Cc: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <199608110739_MC1-858-F5F0@compuserve.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Good day,

I was trying to make the point that people who may use marijuana and drive at some later
point are not given the same chance to prove sobriety.  There is no easy way way to test
someone's level of exposure or time there of.  I have done some biased tests contrasting
marijuana, alcohol, and sleep deprivation related to reaction times, using a device
that was designed to improve drag racer's reaction times.  Alcohol, even at levels considered
legal, slowed rt's at almost double the rate of marijuana.  After 4 beers in one hour, I had to 
stop. It had become ridiculous, having trouble hitting the small button while making an 
attempt to react fast.  Marijuana faired better, but I would consider quite dangerous soon
after exposure.  I say soon, because, it depended on the level of exposure and time spent
chillin' .  Somewhere between 45-75 minutes after last exposure, rt's had returned to a
level that would be considered normal (95%).  This simply was not the case 1 hour after 
consuming 4 beers, or even 2 hours for that matter.  Sleep deprivation suprisingly had the best 
reaction times, though carries the possibility of missing whole events due to lack of 
awareness.  Judgement is subjective.  Though an attempt to test motor, reaction, and
reaction based judgement was done using a combination of video games (driving based) and a 
law enforcement hogan's alley (no real guns for this one folks!  paint guns).  The object with
the particular video game was not to be hit by or in turn hit any other vehicles (speed was
to be as constant as possible) and stay in between the lines.  Alcohol bombed.  Marijuana
ran into nothing but was occasionally hit by another car.  Sleep deprivation narrowly
avoided several accidents but regularly veered into another lane.  Alcohol killed several
innocents, missed many targets and cause fatal delays in reaction times.  Marijuana 
also caused fatal delays, but only one innocent was shot in all of the testing, target aquisition
was suprisingly good.  Sleep deprivation killed one innocent, caused fatal delays close to
sober, but was the only source of a target not noticed.  It popped up with another from a different 
angle and was not noticed until after several others had come up.  These WERE not 
100% flaw free tests; done by three high school students with a project due and alot of
time on their hands.  Two of the three participants scored their highest hogan's alley
scores after a good lunch, about 1.5 hours after smokin' a standard joint. (white paper, brown bud)

BTW:  We didn't have the balls to turn in the test stats for pot.  This was a HS science class 
after all.  The project recieved a B+ grade on its comparison of sobriety, alcohol, and sleep
deprivation.

Make what you will of this.  I will stand by some of the generalizations that can be made using 
this info.  Driving while high is always sketchy.  Driving while nodding, can be worse in 
some cases, as you might not be awake to even attempt a reaction.  

Be careful and responsible ravers so I can see your smiling faces time and time again.

Take care, 
                   Jason

Okay, here's the scoop.....
It's all conected to the Canibis Buyers club raid and that is connected to
the fact that we are having an election this year.  The DA of California
(I can't remember his name) is a right-wing arsehole and he wants to be
Wilsons (yes, I did say Willson) Running mate in 2000.  The best place to
make his presence felt is
at the Republican convention which is now going on in San Diego.  Now, as
we all know, Republicans like there people to be seen to be tough on crime
in the same way a pervert likes to watch porn: it turns them on.  And, as
far as every Republican is concerned, San Francisco represents everything
that they say is wrong with the US as a whole so if they are seen to be
tough on crime here they can say that they are winning it on a national level.
Hence raiding the Canibus club (because, as far as
they are concerned, those pesky AIDS people deserve everything coming to
them anyway) and stopping and making the SFPD raid Nation because Nation
was a major come together type party in a very prominent part of town in
what is the biggest single
underground movement in San Francisco (ie. rave culture)(because, as far
as they are concerned, Drug taking party goers are only one step above
project living gang bangers).  Which puts our Mayor and DA in a very
awkward position legally because you know if it was left up to my man
Mayor Willy Brown he'd just say no.  But his hands are tied because he has
to answer to the (supposidly) higher power of the Stae or he would loose
his job. But our DA has already said that he won't be prosucuting anyone
from the Cannibus Buyers club raid and you can bet your life that he won't
be prosecuting anyone for the Nation raid either.  I'm afraid that until
the election is over we are going to see a lot of this sort of thing going
on.  At least we can be thankful in the small mercy that we have such a
cool DA; they must be having kittens in Republican party headquarters down
south.  Just my $0.02!
Tristan.

stage amidst some strange electronic equipment and lots of wires.  A 
throbbing, droning noise commenced.  It was funny to see a nightclub

beanbags.  EAR is playing again tonight at the Kilowatt(21+) across from
