                          CT

Subject: Re: Spammed BIG TIME
In-Reply-To: <199608110247.WAA14018@fellini.syr.vcomm.net>

On Sat, 10 Aug 1996, John Draper wrote:

> I didn't even know it was possible,  but these hackers have "subscribed"
> me to over 4000 mailing lists,  thus completly cutting off all incoming
> mail to me.    This afternoon,  I had over 4000 messages,  ALL of which
> were to "Majordomo's" subscribing me.    As far as I know,  it's still
> going on,   so for the time being,   I've switched over to a new account
> on another system.   But I have a feeling that soon THIS account will
> be spammed as well.
> I find this outright harrassment,  and want to know if I have any
> legal recourse.

  Unfortunately, you probaly can't do a thing about it.  Majordomo mailing
list managers allow third party subscriptions without verification (i.e.
anyone can subscribe anyone else), and there is no legal policy against
that.  It's poorly designed software, and everyone knows it.
 
> For instance,  if an email request comes into a Majordomo account,  is
> there a way to identify the source?

  Since it is 99% certain they would be using a hacked account or an
anonymous remailer, no.  Unfortunately.

  I do hope that the situation improves in short order.  Meantime, perhaps
you could build a mail filter of some sort to handle the problem.
Something that scanned for messages from <majordomo@*> containing the text
"successfully subscribed" (or whatever it is) and trashing that message to
/dev/null, as well as sending a reply back saying "unsubscribe
[myaddress]". This would not eliminate the problem entirely, because it
usually takes a few minutes to unsubscribe you, during which time you
still get messages from the list.  But then, even if they have automated
the subscribing process, you will at least be continually unsubbed
automatically.

  Good luck.

: : J. David Lowe :: dlowe@best.com :: http://www.best.com/~dlowe/ : :

:  founded.  We are not now & never have been slaves to the past or  :
:       hostages to the future."         -Hakim Bey, /T.A.Z./        :

>Actually this was someone else's story that I was curious about.  I don't
condone
>cruising while high.  But I think the laws as current, could unfairly
punish someone
>who had, in the recent past (last night for instance), smoked and been
involved in an accident
>that no fault of his own.  Does this person really deserve this kind of
aggrevation considering
>the hypothetical circumstance?  It would be the same as having zero
tolerance for alcohol; 
>also stupid if you are responsible, count drinks and bide your time.



But again, it does bring up the issue that, even tho it may not have been
the stoned person's fault, could the accident have been prevented if the
person were not impaired?  Defensive driving really does include knowing how
to best handle it when somebody else on the road is being a moron, cuz
really the primary issue should not be "who's fault was the accident" but
"how do you prevent an accident to begin with".  Cuz if there's an accident
which is one person's fault but could have been entirely prevented if the
other person hadn't been impaired, to me both people are really at fault in
that situation.  


Love,
Shawna

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Aug 11 19:01:00 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id TAA02529; Sun, 11 Aug 1996 19:01:00 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from nak.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with ESMTP id TAA02523; Sun, 11 Aug 1996 19:00:57 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from ucdata.Berkeley.EDU.ucdt (ucdata.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.165.25]) by nak.berkeley.edu (8.7.3/8.6.10) with SMTP id TAA29150 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sun, 11 Aug 1996 19:02:45 -0700 (PDT)
Received: by ucdata.Berkeley.EDU.ucdt (SMI-8.6/SMI-SVR4)
	id SAA19625; Sun, 11 Aug 1996 18:57:03 -0700
Date: Sun, 11 Aug 1996 18:57:03 -0700 (PDT)
From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Saturday Night Follies (NRR?)  
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9608111814.A19445-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Saturday night is here.  It's 11:00.  The promising Goa Trance party 
turns out to be 23 miles south of Half Moon Bay - an immense distance to 
someone who can rarely be motivated to even get on the Bay Bridge. 
_Nation_ is emitting bizarre vibes, and besides, I promised myself I wouldn't go 
unless I got a pre-sale.  (Luckily for me, I did not!).
 
So, where does one go on a Saturday night if one wants to dance?  One 
stupidly listens to one's non-raver friends and goes to the place that 
they praise: Nickie's on Haight.  Ah, the bar scene.  Does it ever 
change?  Does it ever get any cooler?  Or is it just what it is, accept 
it or leave?  70's funk/disco night (how old is THAT?!).  Packed.  
Pick-up energy rampant.  I clutch my boyfriend for protection.  We pound 
beers in the desperate race to find fun.  We scream along with the 
others, "ring my belllllll! ring my bell!"  Amazingly, the room is 
getting even more crowded.  We are intimately squished with 100 drunk 
strangers.  We go outside for some air.

Some pulsing beats come wafting through the air, and we follow them down 
Haight to their source.  A few doors down from Nickie's, there's Joe Rice 
spinning at the Top!  We gleefully enter (for FREE!).  He is spinning a 
beautiful set - on the mellow tip, but with the underlying beats that can take you 
away.  The Top is a haven after the crush of Nick's.  Not too many 
people, places to sit, mellow vibe, bobbing heads to the groove.  But no 
dancing.  The Top has no dance floor!!  Joe tells me it was a pool table 
or room for dancing...(swoosh! go the balls into pockets, the pool cues 
glow a trippy red under the colored lights).

2AM too soon - we are still frustrated in our attempt to dance tonight.  
After-hours clubs, after-hours clubs - fuck, I've been raving too long!  
I don't know any!  We head down to Club Universe (pounding house for the 
gay crowd).  But we stupidly go to the back of the building, and enter 
(unbeknownest to us) an entirely different club.  House sounds good, and 
we delve into a crowd of several hundred beautiful, dark-haired men (I am 
the _only_ woman in the room - it would be a dream come true if only any 
of these gods were interested, but alas...).  We are happy, but suddenly 
the music changes.  "Hola, Mi Familia!" the dj booms, and we realize we 
are at _Futura_, a bi-monthly for gay Latin men.  Salsa and slow 
Mexican-flava softhouse drags the tempo down loooowww, _for the rest of 
the night_ :(,  and we slowly sway with the rest of the crowd. 

So at 4 we surrendered to the inevitableness of the night: no hardass 
crazy dancin for us this night.  But we had quite an adventure trying to 
find it! ;)

Nancy

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Aug 11 19:48:57 1996

August brings my busiest summer ever to a close and I was wondering if any of
you wonderful people out there have any idea of how to make the summer go out
with a *bang*!  Lot's to do... but unfortunately I have no transportation
anywhere and live in the snooze capitol of the Bay Area (Fremont).  For such
a large city there are few parties or clubs here that I'm aware of.  If
anyone is interested in hosting an end of summer bash on our side of the
water before school starts back up, please do so and let me in on the goods.
 Yah... it'll be pretty hard to find a location, but even harder for me to
find a ride across the bridge.  The void that is the bay once again keeps me
from my higher purpose.  Just think how many east bay ravers would worship
your good vibe efforts forever.  Me especially.  Thanx, and if anyone else
has an easier solution PLEASE let me know!!

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sun, 11 Aug 1996 21:57:39 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: leftjab@well.com (leftjab)
Subject: raving for papa bear at Hunny
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

August 9 -- a dilemma for this Deadhead.  On the anniversary of his death,
do I mourn Jerry with the Deadheads at many of the small gatherings
organized in the area?  Or do I celebrate my current life and new family at
Hunny?

A t-shirt an old deadhead friend gave me (he had scores extra at the end of
a tour) told me the answer:  the whole Winnie-the-Pooh crew is on their way
to a Dead show, Tigger with floor tickets, the hare with taping equipment,
Kanga and Roo holding a peace flag, Winnie with a big pot of Hunny and
shades, piglet resplendent in tie-dye riding on Eeyore, who is smoking a
big fatty . . . the quoted line is "Goin' on a Feeling" from the Dead song
"Saint of Circumstance."

So, I was drawn to living in the now, and know I had a better time at Hunny
than I would have had anywhere else that night.  Although the owners at
Jerrold always put out their non-scene vibe (and i'm sorry to hear of the
$$ problems for the organizers), the Beautiful People party a couple months
back and Hunny have worked for me.  There weren't that many people, but
those who were there were dancin' and smilin' up a storm.  With the crowd
not overwhelming for the space, it was easy to sit and talk and connect
with folks, and I ran into a number of people I had only a seen a couple of
times and wanted to see again.

As for the music, I guess I'm starting to lean towards trancier stuff, as
Dutch and Greg's sets had me movin'.  The Fnf/Gateway
4-speakers-in-the-round set-up has been spoiling me (I love going to the
middle of the 4 speakers and spinning around), but with the small floor 2
were more than enough.  The decorations and lights were great, with the
appropriate depictions of pooh characters.

Altho 6 o'clock now seems early for me for an end to an evening, the
sunrise over the east bay was beautiful, and I got a good morning's sleep
before hanging out in the sun with friends.  All in all, a positive
evening, even after two impossible weekends to top in fnf and chrysalis.
But, when am i going to rest before Burning Man . . . I know I'll be out
again next weekend, and I guess i'll have to rest the weekend of the
24th-25th . . .

leftjab

> Hey Hey there SF/LA Kidds--
> 
> Red Dog Dave here.
> 
> Just thought I'd pass on an excerpt from July/August Psychology Today.
> 
> CAPITAL words are my little emphases.
> 
> "Psychadelics: The Second COming" by Eugene Taylor PhD
> 
> "...Perhaps the most overt example of the psychadelic revival can be
> found at 'raves'.  High-tech, high-decibel, computer-generated music, and
> marathon dancing swirl continuously for as much as three to four DAYS.
> On a TYPICAL weekend in the San Francisco Bay area, there may be 20,000
> to 30,000 TEENAGERS dancing around the clock, 80 percent of them under
> the influece of drugs.
>         Another sign of the times is the a surge in use of MDMA, a
> laboratory-synthesized variant of a hallucinogen that naturally occurs in
> the body.  It's the new drug of choice among those who formerly ingested
> LSD, snd went on to pursue chemical-free spiritual awareness.  Also known
> as Ecstasy, it's a cross between a psychadelic and an amphetamine; in the
> majority of users creates a sense of loving presence and an improved
> reorientation toward intimate relationships.  And it deepend meditative
> calmness.
>         A 1987 survey of Stanford University students showed that 39
> percent had taken MDMA at least once.  By the end of the 1980s, an
> estimated 10,000 doses per month were in circulation in the US; by 1993,
> six million doses a year were being manufactured in home-based
> laboratories..."
> 
> 
> 
> Well, thats the cheese.  It's actually a really really good article.
> But, funny, when I raved in SF at Freedom, I think there were what,
> 4,000?  Where were the other 16-26,000?? Oh, teenagers, of course.  Also,
> I'm not sure how he got his statistics as far as MDMA manufacturing.  It
> seems almost seems impossible to gauge something so underground, well,
> maybe not THAT underground!!
> 
> Great article too, talks about MDMA, LSD, Psilocybin (shrooms), Pot, and
> Ibogaine.  They talk about psychadelics and their effects on brain, and
> how these drugs are used in some treatments of psychological disorders!

To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>

SWEET!  =)

Hi folks!

 Yes Hunny was very good! The sound was very good (a trifle loud but that's 
what ear plugs are for). The music just ripped!!!! As I was working the 
slide show I didn't catch everyone's set(s) but here is a quick run thru; 
 
DJ Dan: 	really good with a lot of variety- really enjoyed it.

Jon Williams:	interesting acid/house sounding set- very danceable.

Dutch:		hard trance that drove me insane!! :)

Greg Sandler:	folks you really have to check Greg out!! He is the SHIT 
		(IMHO). Large variety of sounds and styles blended 
		together in a hypnotically seamless fashion. All his 
		songs were fresh (no overdone remixed samples here!). I 
		danced so hard to his set despite my exhaution. Also 
		possible that Greg may be the worlds most humble DJ. An 
		hour after his set he was seen sweeping the main dance floor.

 The deli was nicely decorated with all sorts of lighting; intelligant 
lights, disco lights, fog, video screen, laser, black lights galore and of 
course my slide show. I felt that the fire alarm strobes someone left on 
were a bit much (6 hours worth) but it was interesting to drive home with 
no lights blinking. :)

 Personally I felt the management at the Deli sucked big wazoo's. They 
couldn't turn off the strobes while we were cleaning, couldn't reset a 
breaker that blew, would not turn on the air conditioning (the dance 
floor was nice but it was hot upstairs), they forced us to schlep 
equipment around while we were trying to clean up and of course 
they ripped off the promoters. Another BIG problem I experienced was 
having some of my equipment packed into someone else's truck. I really 
wish folks would ASK before touching equipment that you do not know for 
certain who it belongs to.

 Met all kinds of nice people there. The only one whose name I remember is 
left jab and of course Janelle and her boyfriend (Rob?). Ran into other 
folks that I've just met in the past few weeks (HI EVERYONE!!!) The vibe 
was outstanding and the circle at the end of the evening a very nice cap 
to a delightful party. Good work folks!!!

Hugz and such,


Ran

                           -=*=-
                             ~

Precedence: bulk

Due to the unusually large number of Seth's in the Bay Area scene, I've
decided to adopt a new dj pseudonym.  My last name just doesn't have
the flashiness or simplicity of say, a Joe Rice or a John Carel :), so I
had to figure out something else. The name Seth, when translated from
Egyptian, can be spelled a number of different ways, and one of them is 
"Sutekh".

My first use of this new name is on the MAD flier for this Monday night
(8/12).  So, in case you saw a flier and wondered "who the hell is that?",
now you know.  Or maybe you're still wondering "who the hell is that?"??
Either way, I hope to see some of you there.  Introduce yourself to me if
you get the chance.

In case you've never met me, I'm a member of Consciousness Lab, and have
played in chill rooms at a bunch of Gateway parties and a few others.  I
also do a radio show on KALX every Thursday night.  My gigs playing dance
music have been limited, but I'm hoping that'll change soon.

Hope to see you at Mad,
			Seth

sorry, i will try to make this my last one on the subject.
(this would be much easier if you could just stop upsetting 
me... :)

On Thu, 8 Aug 1996 blkadder@value.net wrote:
 
> I think we have gone through this before: TALK TO *ME* 
> 
> I never posted anything good or bad about McDonalds, or working in 
> advertising. You make sweeping generalizations, putting all "California 
> ravers" into a specific category, and do not seem to be able to 
> differenciate statements made by various *individuals* Verstehen Sie?
> 

OK. although it's funny again. normally people complain about bad 
generalisations. you don't want to be called a nice person here.

a) there were some posts saying 'holla, black adder, couldn't have 
said it better. thanks for making these points so elegantly.' 
i think i remember amy r., i'm not sure, but there were more.

b) to treat you as the individual you crave to be treated as:
if it really is the case that you think mc donalds is a bless for 
mankind and advertising industry makes the world a nicer place to live in
(i *know* you never said that, but if you suggest people to work in 
these fields better than doing nothing, and if you call work in these 
fields a contribution to society, i must assume 
that you, to a certain extend, support these statements), 
*then* i must say YOU, as an individual, are no doubt a good friend and 
a darling with your loved ones, but i disagree with your opinions to such 
a degree that i would call them, uhem uhem, quite dangerous. but, i know, who 
am i to do this and that, and you no doubt won't spend a single sleepless 
hour for the reason of what i just said,
so everything is just fine.

> I challenge you to show where I have ever expressed *hatred* towards people 
> that do not work and produce "litters of children."
> ... you could probably reasonably say that I hold a certain level of 
> disdain for both groups, however hatred is a very powerful and draining 
> emotion, and one I would not invest.  

yeah you are probably right.
there is a certain attitude in the way you say things like 'litters of 
children' (it's hard to explain though, maybe i'm not getting it right  
because i'm no native speaker), i think i mistook that for hate. excuse me.

> >                         i imagine you would agree with me when i 
> > say that maybe some solid 50% of the goods that are produced/services offered
> > are sheer luxury, if not completely needless and are just produced/offered to 
> > keep the circle of economy moving, all on the cost of nature.
> 
> Is luxury valueless? Personally, I prefer wiping my butt with soft tissue 
> rather than leaves, running water is a delight, and hey, four walls and a 
> roof beat a drafty cave any day of the week.  
> 

it seems like you are deliberately misunderstanding me here.

> > this is why i called the belief that one had to work to justify ones 
> > existence **oldfashioned**.  this is something that used to be true when the 
> > means of production weren't so high developed as they are today. today, 
> > everything that is really needed can be produced by a fraction of the 
> > population with the help of all those machines.
> 
> Define "really needed."

everything that is really needed means everything that is really needed 
included your tissue toilet paper and most everything a person could 
dream of, as far as material goods go.
don't you *see* that your supermarkets and shopping malls and sax 5th 
avenue department stores are stuffed, you sometimes can't help asking youself 
*gosh, who needs all that crap*, and they are so *without* the work of all 
the unemployed and welfare people. 
it lies in the nature of technical progress that a decreasing number of 
people is able to produce an increasing number of goods. 

as if that lack of work wasn't a bless, your working ethics demand that 
these obsolete people do something. so what do you want them to do?
of course, you can have them clean doggy poop off peoples backyards 
(excellent business idea!). if they are a bit educated, you 
can have them program, so that every stupid text processing software 
comes kicked out in a new release every ten minutes.
no problem, as long as somebody wants to buy it.
point being: i wouldn't really call this a contribution to society.
this is mostly a contribution to *economy*. 
(what gets us to the subject that *some people* think capitalist society 
can be seen as nothing more than the hunting ground of capitalist economy.)

a *good* contribution to society would be if you took care for hiv 
positives; or if you put up a nice playground for children where they 
could roam around and build wooden shacks and paint on walls or whatever, 
and you would be there to watch that nobody gets hurt and give them advice; or
if you organized some kind of neighbor-exchange-help-babysitting-stuff, god, 
whatever,i don't know. just something nice.
like i said, normally you don't get paid for that.
you can tar and feather me, i will never call frying hamburger patties at 
mc donalds a contribution to society, with the positive emphasis that 
statement apparently has for you 
(a *good* contribution to society nonetheless might be if mom in her little 
corner cafe does so. i think there's a visible difference.) 

*my* working ethics (yes even me has some...) demands that i do my job ok.
it doesn't demand that i and everybody else do *some* job on every cost.
this society is so damn rich, just milk those capitalists a bit more 
instead of letting them enjoy all the profits and the working people pay 
for all the expenses of the economy. 
i totally agree with you in the point that somebody who lives on welfare 
and watches tv all day long is not necessarily a morally outstanding person.
to drive the agreement to an almost painful threshold, i also think that 
those people, au contraire, sometimes tend to be a bit more on the down side, 
fucking lazy drugdealing punks and litterbugs that they are.
but, for me, things wouldn't get any better if all these people suddenly 
started to appear in late night commercials trying to sell me some 
patented device to mop the kitchen floor. (apart from the fact that i'm 
pretty convinced that *there are just not enough jobs*)
maybe this would work out for them, because some of them seem to have major 
problems killing their time now, but i wouldn't feel better and, IMO, the 
state of the world wouldn't be a bit better if they did. worser, if you 
ask me.
but anyway.
have a nice day everybody.
ulrike

On Sun, 11 Aug 1996, Nancy Shaw wrote:

> 
> Saturday night is here.  It's 11:00.  The promising Goa Trance party 
> turns out to be 23 miles south of Half Moon Bay - an immense distance to 
> someone who can rarely be motivated to even get on the Bay Bridge. 
> _Nation_ is emitting bizarre vibes, and besides, I promised myself I wouldn't go 
> unless I got a pre-sale.  (Luckily for me, I did not!).
>  
> So, where does one go on a Saturday night if one wants to dance?  One 
> stupidly listens to one's non-raver friends and goes to the place that 
> they praise: Nickie's on Haight.  Ah, the bar scene.  Does it ever 
> change?  Does it ever get any cooler?  Or is it just what it is, accept 
> it or leave?  70's funk/disco night (how old is THAT?!).  Packed.  
> Pick-up energy rampant.  I clutch my boyfriend for protection.  We pound 
> beers in the desperate race to find fun.  We scream along with the 
> others, "ring my belllllll! ring my bell!"  Amazingly, the room is 
> getting even more crowded.  We are intimately squished with 100 drunk 
> strangers.  We go outside for some air.
> 
> Some pulsing beats come wafting through the air, and we follow them down 
> Haight to their source.  A few doors down from Nickie's, there's Joe Rice 
> spinning at the Top!  We gleefully enter (for FREE!).  He is spinning a 
> beautiful set - on the mellow tip, but with the underlying beats that can take you 
> away.  The Top is a haven after the crush of Nick's.  Not too many 
> people, places to sit, mellow vibe, bobbing heads to the groove.  But no 
> dancing.  The Top has no dance floor!!  Joe tells me it was a pool table 
> or room for dancing...(swoosh! go the balls into pockets, the pool cues 
> glow a trippy red under the colored lights).
> 
> 2AM too soon - we are still frustrated in our attempt to dance tonight.  
> After-hours clubs, after-hours clubs - fuck, I've been raving too long!  
> I don't know any!  We head down to Club Universe (pounding house for the 
> gay crowd).  But we stupidly go to the back of the building, and enter 
> (unbeknownest to us) an entirely different club.  House sounds good, and 
> we delve into a crowd of several hundred beautiful, dark-haired men (I am 
> the _only_ woman in the room - it would be a dream come true if only any 
> of these gods were interested, but alas...).  We are happy, but suddenly 
> the music changes.  "Hola, Mi Familia!" the dj booms, and we realize we 
> are at _Futura_, a bi-monthly for gay Latin men.  Salsa and slow 
> Mexican-flava softhouse drags the tempo down loooowww, _for the rest of 
> the night_ :(,  and we slowly sway with the rest of the crowd. 
> 
> So at 4 we surrendered to the inevitableness of the night: no hardass 
> crazy dancin for us this night.  But we had quite an adventure trying to 
> find it! ;)
> 
> Nancy
>

On Fri, 9 Aug 1996, THX1138 wrote:

>         So, Ulrike(or anyone else who has lived in Europe or has spent some
> time on the scene there) are events like the May Day celebration considered
> commercial, and is that considered a bad thing. 

mayday (~80K? people) is super super commercial. and it is no way for free, 
but something like 50$ or so if i'm correctly informed. 
love parade in berlin is super commercial as well. it had like *500 K* 
people wallowing through the inner city streets this year, the whole shit being 
broadcasted on mtv. this one was admittedly for free (you can hardly build a 
spike wired fence around the city center), but the parties  thrown in the 
night were 25-40$ affairs. 
i don't think you can prevent raveland from being commercialized (where 
there are loads of people keen on gladly spending their money for parties with
*underground vibe* commercialization is just around the corner; and here 
in germany some of the pioneers of the scene are amongst the big winners of 
commercialization and actively working on it), but it's not always a nice 
view. commercialization in itself is not necessarily bad, only it 
strangely comes along with loss of charme and vibe.
it doesn't make sense to complain, but WON'T YOU GUYS LONG FOR THOSE 50K 
MASSIVES!!!!! 
i don't want to frighten you, but, uhem, i'm afraid those notes in the 
bay guardian are a very very bad sign...:)
u.

On Mon, 12 Aug 1996, Ulrike Laitko wrote:

> 
> sorry, i will try to make this my last one on the subject.
> (this would be much easier if you could just stop upsetting 
> me... :)

Likewise.


> it lies in the nature of technical progress that a decreasing number of 
> people is able to produce an increasing number of goods. 

See? We agree on something.
> 
> as if that lack of work wasn't a bless, your working ethics demand that 
> these obsolete people do something. so what do you want them to do?
> of course, you can have them clean doggy poop off peoples backyards 
> (excellent business idea!). if they are a bit educated, you 
> can have them program, so that every stupid text processing software 
> comes kicked out in a new release every ten minutes.
> no problem, as long as somebody wants to buy it.
> point being: i wouldn't really call this a contribution to society.
> this is mostly a contribution to *economy*. 

In case I haven't made my position clear in the last 20 or so posts on 
the subject:

1) I do not care if people work or do not work.
2) I do not want to pay for people that choose not to work.
3) I get upset when people want me to pay so they can sit on their ass.
4) I do not think that the people in 3 constitute the majority of people
   on welfare, however I do believe they account for a significant 
   percentage.

> a *good* contribution to society would be if you took care for hiv 
> positives; or if you put up a nice playground for children where they 
> could roam around and build wooden shacks and paint on walls or whatever, 
> and you would be there to watch that nobody gets hurt and give them advice; or
> if you organized some kind of neighbor-exchange-help-babysitting-stuff, god, 
> whatever,i don't know. just something nice.

And all these things sound great. Let's have people do that. Let's bring
back public works projects, and let people do community service if 
they want to continue to receive welfare. But make them do *something*
for the money that they currently get for doing *nothing.*

> *my* working ethics (yes even me has some...) demands that i do my job ok.
> it doesn't demand that i and everybody else do *some* job on every cost.
> this society is so damn rich, just milk those capitalists a bit more 
> instead of letting them enjoy all the profits and the working people pay 
> for all the expenses of the economy. 

By all means, lets destroy the concepts of initiative and drive. Lets 
take away things people have gone out and *earned* and give it to those 
that do nothing. What a brilliant idea.

That said, I do believe there is a great deal of corporate greed in the 
world. And it is getting much worse, not better. However, "let's take some 
more from them" results in taking more from *us* When you raise taxes on 
business the costs get passed onto the consumer. What's the answer to 
this? I don't know. I haven't the foggiest clue. I do know that "let's 
just take more from them" has not worked, does not work, and will not 
work. All of us end up bearing the costs, not the people you set out to 
make pay. 

                                          
                                          Black Adder

> which was what you originally stated. it is indeed paranoid logic to 
> mistake a possible reason for an intent. 

Believe it or not, U.S. military expenditures have been lessened, now 
that the "cold war" is "over." And the trend continues, which is a good 
thing. Things are being scaled back. It cannot all be done overnight, as 
some would wish. It is also important to remember that a lot of jobs are 
being lost as this occurs. It is a balancing act.

> > Time and time again, the U.S. has found reasons to get involved in 
> > conflicts that are not their own.
> 
> true enough. so why do you support that behaviour with your arguments.

There is a mailing list at nwraves@hyperreal.com, and they have a web site
as well which you can get to from the sfraves site.  Electrolush is easily
the best weekly in Seattle, and it's held at the Showbox on 1st near Pike
(across from the Pike Place Market) but I think only on friday nights.  The
Showbox is open on Saturday, but unless things have changed (which they may
have) Electrolush is only on friday.  If you're interested I could hook you
up with some friends of mine up there who frequently go to parties.  Just
let me know.  --David

Something I have to get off my chest.

At the last four events I have been to, everyone has been facing the DJ in
a concentric circle pattern.  Not only does this spook me, but it is
anti-thetical to the whole rave vibe, IMHO.  It is about you, about us,
about being free.  Not facing the *star*.  Please STOP.  Face your
neighbor.  Be your own star.

What do people think?  Am I missing something?

arkay

P.S. - and FUCK all DJs who are cultivating this star status mentality. (I
don't care if I get flamed for that).

Hey all!
>From a friend, not on sfraves, to whom I sent the original message:

> This person is right on.
 
Original message, from arkay:

> Something I have to get off my chest.
> 
> At the last four events I have been to, everyone has been facing the DJ in
> a concentric circle pattern.  Not only does this spook me, but it is
> anti-thetical to the whole rave vibe, IMHO.  It is about you, about us,
> about being free.  Not facing the *star*.  Please STOP.  Face your
> neighbor.  Be your own star.
> 
> What do people think?  Am I missing something?
> 
> arkay
> 
> P.S. - and FUCK all DJs who are cultivating this star status mentality. (I
> don't care if I get flamed for that).

I'd have to agree.  Arkay, you're definitely not missing something ;o)
I think sometimes the pattern is less conscious than
people think...sort of how like sometimes people's eyes gravitate to the
TV if it's on, etc...and usually one faces the speakers, which are
usually aligned with the DJ...what I like to do, if there is space, is
just sort of bounce around to different areas, try to dance with others
for a bit, and then move on...I also like to spin sometimes, but usually
this isn't very easily done without bumping into someone =) Generally, if
you start to tilt around to dance with the person behind/beside you, they
are pretty receptive.  Even if it's just for a while :o)
And it's a lot more fun than staring straight ahead at the person's back,
or at the floor, but I have to say at times I am guilty of floor staring
:) I think it's the long hair %^)

peas,
shamini

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Aug 12 12:04:28 1996

Date: Mon, 12 Aug 1996 12:11:18 -0700 (PDT)

X-Sender: gutman@mail.inreach.com

From: A-RON <gutman@inreach.com>
Subject: HUNNY review and deli gripes.
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


HUNNY was a nice mellow party.. good for a friday night.  Initially there
were some bad vibes present ( assholes harassing and grabbing a female
friend at least 4 times  <WTF?>)  This made her almost want to leave, and
party elsewhere... But we put on our own positive vibes, and drowned out
that negativity.  I understand the need for a safe, non-bustable space like
the deli, but THE DELI SUCKS (IMHO).  People have had cars broken into (more
than once), and there seems to be quite an asshole factor there sometimes.
There are hardcore water Nazis, and $3 for water <sigh>.   

PLEASE UNDERSTAND, I am not dissing the promoters of this event.  They did a
great job of decorating and putting a lot of energy and effort forth.  I
think that if this party had been elsewhere... (east bay perhaps?) it would
have GONE OFF!  

Dutch blew us away with some hard-driving Psycho trance... I was expecting
the funky breaks from DJ Dan, but he played some slightly experimental stuff..  

We left slightly early, and headed to the east bay to chill.  We ended up at
Lake Temescal park in Montclair.  This is a great little park to chill at
early in the morn, cause it opens at 5:00 (though the gates for parking
don't open untill 8:00), there's lots of grass, a playground, and a little
beach where you can stretch out in the sand.   I don't know if it would be
good for a party though. (cause there are lots of homes right there, and the
sound would travel well over the water)

So, Hi and Hugs to everyone I saw at HUNNY, and Have a great week everyone!

Aaron.

BTW:  Standing on your head, and doing yoga positions is great while you're
mashing out. =)

>Something I have to get off my chest.
>
>At the last four events I have been to, everyone has been facing the DJ in
>a concentric circle pattern.  Not only does this spook me, but it is
>anti-thetical to the whole rave vibe, IMHO.  It is about you, about us,
>about being free.  Not facing the *star*.  Please STOP.  Face your
>neighbor.  Be your own star.
>
>What do people think?  Am I missing something?

nope... people need to focus on SOMETHING. as soon as someone busts out a
pair of glo-sticks or starts breakdancing, people stop facing the DJ, but
until then he/she's the closest thing to a focal point. I don't think DJ
idolization is much of a problem except at big parties where people come to
see a specific dj... smaller UG's seem to have less of this.

-m.

From: aguevara@compattic.com (Adam Guevara)
Reply-To: aguevara@compattic.com
To: sddpw@sirius.com
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Facing the DJ (Was: raves or rock concerts)
Date: 12 Aug 1996 20:13:52 GMT
Message-Id: <3255103486.8207819@compattic.com>
Organization: Computer Attic
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

 This is a good one, since I talk to a lot of DJ's and on more that one
occasion has this information been relayed back to me:

DJ's generally enjoy people facing them for purposes other than fame.  I know
some DJ's that like seeing famillar faces while they spin, bringing down the
nervousness level between DJ and crowd.   Others look at the crowd in order
to see if what they're spinning is "right" or "off" (This is my MAIN reason).
  Some Dj's have said they watch the crowd as a visual monitor, watching the
crowd move helps them stay onbeat or singals if they're on the droves of a
trainwreck.  Some people watch a DJ to see if the song is really being mixed
in or if it's just a really sick record.  And then theres the "newbe" DJ's
that are watching and taking notes as how to be more adept @ thier art.
mimicing and praticing the very same mixed in the confines of thier home...



As for "Star Status" well, as I always say, "we create our own reality.." 
When I spin, I generally step from out of the crowd myself (since im dancing
like crazy) not kicking it with ,what seems like, an inner circle behind the
turntables.  While dj'ing im hardly aware of the crowd @ times, putting
myself as much into the music as possible.  Im trying to cure myself of this,
since the crowd can "feel" @ times when it's being neglected.. When I step
off the "vibe platters" I join the crowd, dancing away reality, creating my
own.
If you believe in your heart that all of this is just to pump a Dj's ego,
then it might be time to step back and look at your own...


"dance with me...."

--Adam
____________________________
Transmitted from Computer Attic
SuperCenter:  (415) 363-8100
Corporate HQ: (415) 614-7500

Dear All

The Mantra people are all deeply sorry to have to inform you that we lost our
space at Clemintina Alley this Sunday, and there's no chance of getting it
back =( 
It was all very short notice (we found out late Saturday night/early Sunday
morning) so we had no time to think of another place.
We had some heavy conflict with the management at Cat's and so they kicked us
out. I'm sure that it's all good in the end, and time for us to move on to
something with a higher vibration. To be honest, I personally didn't feel
good about this club, and thought the staff and management were a bunch of
wankers. AND someone actually stole beautiful sacred things from my altar
(talk about bad karma) I see this as a sign ofsomething being "wrong" in the
energy fields around Mantra. Time to  shift gears and move on elsewhere. I'm
glad we're out of there, but really sorry to let everyone else down.
We will be taking a short break from Mantra until after Burning Man (we may
throw a free party before then, check our info # 415 331 1500 x888)  We hope
to be back in a new location possibly on Friday nights. Look for our new
flyers.
Thankyou so much for supporting us and bringing your good vibes into our
space. We love you all (yes, even the thieves) and hope to see you soon at
our next venue.
Love and light from Mantra
***Raven***

I have mixed feelings on this issue, because I see dj'ing as an artform and
occasionally I really enjoy looking at art.  I will usually spend atleast a
few minutes up front at a party watching the dj do his/her thing....not all
night, just for a few songs.  I don't see it as worshiping, I just respect a
good dj and periodically like to see him/her make it happen.  

On the other hand, if that is all a person does is stand up front and watch,
well I'm not into that.  Maybe we could hook up some kind of video system
for these people and sit them in a room with a bunch of moitors showing
different angles of what the dj is doing.  Ya think :)  Maybe get a comentator?

Rick

I don't mind having everyone face the dj.  I don't see it as worshiping 
the dj.  I find that when most people are facing the same direction 
there is more of a sense of unity.  
When I've been to parties where everyone is facing many different 
directions the energy has felt more scattered to me.

:)
peter

set).

was too wasted to play on Sunday aswell.
So my next big question is why weren't we informed on the Nation/Spundae info
line that he was going to spin at 1015 on Saturday night???? I would much
rather have seen Sasha than driven to Santa Cruz for the goa party (much as I
love the trance scene, I would have done anything for the chance to see Sasha
play in San Francisco).
So I appreciate everyone at Nation/Spundae for trying to get this off the
ground against heavy opposition, but I am also extremely frustrated at not
seeing Sasha last night. I would never have gone to this event last night and
paid $15 if I had known that he wasn't going to spin.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Well, this weekend was interesting, to say the least...

Friday Was F-8 @ the Demension Se7en warehouse.  A really great time, despite
the near shutting down by the S.F. Popo and a few other instances...  I had
the privlige of playing ticket taker (such a glorious job =P).  But a
delightful time neverless, conversing with everybody that popped thier heads
outside for a breath of fresh air (aploigies to thoses who had a hard time
getting in and out after 3AM, cos, well, I want'ed to be dancing on the floor
too ;). 
I must say DRC left an impression on me, it was an honor to hear her spin...

Saturday: After: helping cleanup from the F-8 event, a birthyday partie in
SJ, the power outage causing 2hrs to get from SJ to SF, and Nation getting
shut down (not to mention staying up for 36+ hrs) I pretty much shut down
myself on Saturday night...  But from what I hear, nothing much was agoing on
anyhow...

Sunday, Civic Center Dancing in the shadows of city hall.  The coolest
feeling of feeling the vibe from the dragonflies contenusly buzzing around
the speakers and turntables.  The police playing babysitter, checking up on
is every 1/2 hr or so.  People smiling and having a grand ole time despite a
few other people running around w/ cameras and camecorders(ecch, defenetly
not a photogenic person). Left @ about 4ish to do some shopping to add to my
vinyal collection.  Left the City @ 6:30 and spent the evening intergrateing
the new tunes to the allready ultra cool tracks I posses...

Weekend highs: Meeting some new SFRavers (You know who you are),  having a
really deep discussion w/someone about truths and realities discovering im
not alone in my quest.

Weekend lows: Calling to find out DOWN 2 EARTH was cancelled, Having to "step
up" on a drunk guy who was forcing himself on a girl...

But weekends were made such fun...   Sorta sad to se it go...

Till next time,

"dance with me..."

-Adam

Transmitted from Computer Attic

Corporate HQ: (415) 614-7500

     I didn't know anybody in the Bay area who raved.  I just went one 
     night.  Nobody brought me.  I almost like it better alone because 
     there's no babysitting, or that clique-iness, or you and your friends 
     just talking about stuff and wrapped up in the subjective experience 
     (group viewpoint, close peer relationships,etc).  You walk in, the 
     journey begins.  This is getting tougher now as I get to know more of 
     you, but it's really beautiful.  That's how you seperate the vibey 
     ones... they come out at you.  They share and speak for the group.  If 
     you can, go alone someday.  It really helps you appreciate the 
     intangible aspects of the whole thing.
     
     Plus, now when I find those people I met when I was alone, it's really 
     beautiful.  Thanks to everybody who reached out... I'm still touched 
     and that's why I go.
     
     AndyW

From: Rick Riffle
I have mixed feelings on this issue, because I see dj'ing as an artform and
occasionally I really enjoy looking at art.  I will usually spend atleast a
few minutes up front at a party watching the dj do his/her thing....not all
night, just for a few songs.  I don't see it as worshiping, I just respect a
good dj and periodically like to see him/her make it happen.  

On the other hand, if that is all a person does is stand up front and watch,
well I'm not into that.  Maybe we could hook up some kind of video system
for these people and sit them in a room with a bunch of moitors showing
different angles of what the dj is doing.  Ya think :)  Maybe get a comentator?

Rick

Subject: raves, concerts, who cares?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hello all-

my take on this whole "should we or should we not face the dj?" is this -
YOU FACE THE DIRECTION YOU WANT TO FACE!!!  YOU LET OTHERS FACE THE
DIRECTION THEY WANT TO FACE!

i find that it changes as the course of the rave progresses.  sometimes a
crowd in general is feeling bonding centered, where people are really hipp
on meeting each other.  sometimes a crowd in general is very other centered,
where most individuals are collectively concentrating on something other,
like a dj.  and there are individuals that are in their own universe and
want to stay there.

IT'S ALL GOOD.  do what you are going to do where you are going to do it.
if you don't like the vibe of this party, either get people to turn around
(unlikely), leave and go to another party (more likely), or find your space,
create your own vibe, and the people who are on the same plain as you will
come.  guarenteed.

let each dance in his or her own way.

love to you all, regardless of the universe in which you choose to reside-

matt l


matthew d. p. k. lanier
thinker, trained belly-button lint technician
415-752-3218
mdpkl@best.com
http://harker.coolware.com/matthew/

	me, july 19, 1996

Well... usually I am too busy meeting people or dancing to be watching the
DJ much.. but I remember one instance when I did.  It was at Carlos'
birthday party at the deli (beginning of summer), and he finally came on at
like 5:30 in the morning after Dubtribe and other good DJs..   I was really
tired from dancing all night, but Carlos was throwing down the BEST music.
So I was up in the balcony right over the turntables, and could look down
right over the mixers and tables.. but I could only see Carlos' hands.  I
also could look out over the whole room, and see all the happy people
RUSHING to the music.  

So I think that watching DJs is fine, as long as you're not being annoying
to the DJs themselves or anyone else. Hehe... this reminds me of a story
about this naked girl jumping on DJ Dimitri's tables during some party. =) 

Aaron. 

At 01:24 PM 8/12/96 -0700, you wrote:
>I have mixed feelings on this issue, because I see dj'ing as an artform and
>occasionally I really enjoy looking at art.  I will usually spend atleast a
>few minutes up front at a party watching the dj do his/her thing....not all
>night, just for a few songs.  I don't see it as worshiping, I just respect a
>good dj and periodically like to see him/her make it happen.  
>

 I myself was a little miffed about the Sasha incident.  I actually left around 
3.30 AM because I had to get to work early today.  I was disappointed that 
Sasha hadn't yet played, but my body was beginning to shut down from lack of 
food, water, and sleep.
 I do have to say that I have one of Digweed's mixed CD's, and he did rock the 
place this morning.  But that's no consolation when you've paid good money to 
come and see the best DJ (imho) in the world.  
 Just thought I'd let you know how I feel.

-Todd

blkadder@value.net wrote:

> > Is Value.net really a good value?
> 

The company where I work just hired Value.net to do their ip 
routing, based on the recommendation of an employee.

nonetheless.

so value.net is a misnomer, as is best.com, IMHO.

> From: gervasio@egr.uri.edu (Jose Gervasio)
> Date: Mon, 12 Aug 1996 12:18:05 -0400 (EDT)
> Subject: Course Evaluation Humor (fwd)

> Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
> 
> > 
> > >Taken from the MIT Course Evaluation Guide, Fall, 1991
> > >
>         The Best and Worst Comments Received
>         ====================================
> 
> "This class was a religious experience for me...
>  I had to take it all on faith."
> 
> "Text makes a satisfying `thud' when dropped on the floor."
> 
> "The class is worthwhile because I need it for the degree."
> 
> "His blackboard technique puts Rembrandt to shame."
> 
> "Textbook is confusing...
>  Someone with a knowledge of English should proofread it."
> 
> "Have you ever fell asleep in class and awoke in another?
>  That's the way I felt all term."
> 
> "In class I learn I can fudge answers and get away with it."
> 
> "Keep lecturer or tenure board will be shot."
> 
> "The recitation instructor would make a good parking lot attendant.
>  Tries to tell you where to go, but you can never understand him."
> 
> "Text is useless.  I use it to kill roaches in my room."
> 
> "In class the syllabus is more important than you are."
> 
> "I am convinced that you can learn by osmosis by just sitting in his
>  class."
> 
> "Help!  I've fallen asleep and I can't wake up!"
> 
> "Problem sets are a decoy to lure you away from potential exam
>  material."
> 
> "Recitation was great.  It was so confusing that I forgot who I was,
>  where I was, and what I was doing -- it's a great stress reliever."
> 
> "He is one of the best teachers I have had... He is well-organized,
>  presents good lectures, and creates interest in the subject.  I
>  hope my comments don't hurt his chances of getting tenure."
> 
> "I would sit in class and stare out the window at the squirrels.
>  They've got a cool nest in the tree."
> 
> "He teaches like Speedy Gonzalez on a caffeine high."
> 
> "This course kept me out of trouble from 2-4:30 on Tuesdays and
>  Thursdays."
> 
> "Most of us spent the 1st 3 weeks terrified of the class.
>  Then solidarity kicked in."
> 
> "Bogus number crunching.  My HP is exhausted."
> 
> "The absolute value of the TA was less than epsilon."
> 
> "TA steadily improved throughout the course...
>  I think he started drinking and it really loosened him up."
> 
> "Information was presented like a ruptured fire hose --
>  spraying in all directions -- no way to stop it."
> 
> "I never bought the text.  My $60 was better spent on the Led
>  Zeppelin tapes that I used more while doing the problem sets
>  that I would have used the text."
> 
> "What's the quality of the text?  `Text is printed on high quality
>  paper.'"
>

On Mon, 12 Aug 1996, pauly wrote:

> My two cents:
> 
> blkadder@value.net wrote:
> > On Mon, 12 Aug 1996, Diana Greer wrote:
> > > Is Value.net really a good value?
> > 
> 
> The company where I work just hired Value.net to do their ip 
> routing, based on the recommendation of an employee.
> 
> My experience has been that their routers go down at least once 
> per day.  usually it's only for a few minutes, but it sucks 
> nonetheless.

Consider this a personal response, and in no way representitive of my 
employers viewpoint(although I hope he would agree): You are full of shit. 
Period. I am the Sys Admin of Value Net. I bust my ass to make sure the 
system stays up. Our routers and everything else do not, and never have gone 
down on a daily basis. 

1) I have network monitoring utilities that tell me when something goes 
   down. In two seperate locations for redundancy.  
2) I have hooks to paging software to page me if a piece of our equipment
   goes down. 
3) We were down on Sat. night for approximately 1/2 hour while we drove
   to get the back-up generator. This was the first unscheduled down-time
   in *MONTHS*

If your employer is having problems, *CALL US*. Suprisingly, unlike many 
other smaller ISP's, you will get a human, that will talk to you promptly. 
But please before casting aspersions on myself and the company I work for, 
get your fucking facts straight.

quick weekend report - nation obviously wasn't happening so we decided to
go to the old standby, 1015.  haven't been in a while due to imposing,
round-the-block lines but we quickly got to the front of the line around
11:30 only to be denied entrance due to my tennis shoes.  weak!
decisions decisions... sound factory or club universe?  we decided that
it was too early for universe (too meat-markety before 2am) so we dropped
down $10 for some mediocre club house being played at excruciating volume
at sound factory.  after it let out we went back to 1015 where they were
more than happy to take my cash and tennies..  the main floor was rocking,
and the music was out of sight!  was that sasha who played until 8 or so?
also, when did they rearrange the dj setup?  with the new setup the
crowd lines up facing the dj in that concentric half-circle, stare at
your neighbors back mode being talked about in the raves vs. rock concerts
thread.  anyway after dancing my proverbial ass off for four hours,
i needed to chill so we went to the other old standby, the endup for
a beautiful sunny sunday morning kicking it in the backyard with some
heinekens and a fattie.  the mighty dub katz at +8% got my attention
so it was back on the dance floor for a couple more hours before returning
home around noontime for some chili verde, a hot shower and a nice long nap..
i'm not as bummed about missing nation as i am about missing the LTJ bukem
drum&bass freebie.. damn!!!  see yall next time...

Precedence: bulk

***This is a bricklayer's accident report that was printed in the newsletter of
the English equivalent of the Workers' Compensation Board. Thanks to John
Sedgwick for this report.***

Dear Sir:
     I am writing in response to your request for additional information in
Block #3 of the accident reporting form. I put "Poor Planning" as the cause
of my accident. You asked for a fuller explanation and I trust the following
details will be sufficient.

     I am a bricklayer by trade. On the day of the accident, I was working
alone on the roof of a new six-story building. When I completed my work, I
found I had some bricks left over which when weighed later were found to
weigh 240 lbs. Rather than carry the bricks down by hand, I decided to lower
them in a barrel by using a pulley which was attached to the side of the
building at the sixth floor.

     Securing the rope at ground level, I went up to the roof, swung the
barrel out and loaded the bricks into it. Then I went down and untied the
rope, holding it tightly to insure a slow descent of the 240 lbs of bricks.
You will note on the accident reporting form that my weight is 135 lbs.
     Due to my surprise at being jerked off the ground so suddenly, I lost
my presence of mind and forgot to let go of the rope. Needless to say, I
proceeded at a rapid rate up the side of the building.

     In the vicinity of the third floor, I met the barrel which was now
proceeding downward at an equally impressive speed. This explains the
fractured skull, minor abrasions and the broken collarbone, as listed in
Section 3 of the accident reporting form.

     Slowed only slightly, I continued my rapid ascent, not stopping until
the fingers of my right hand were two knuckles deep into the pulley which I
mentioned in Paragraph 2 of this correspondence. Fortunately by this time I
had regained my presence of mind and was able to hold tightly to the rope,
in spite of the excruciating pain I was now beginning to experience.

     At approximately the same time, however, the barrel of bricks hit the
ground, and the bottom fell out of the barrel. Now devoid of the weight of
the bricks, the barrel weighed approximately 50 lbs. I refer you again to my
weight.

     As you might imagine, I began a rapid descent down the side of the
building. In the vicinity of the third floor, I met the barrel coming up.
This accounts for the two fractured ankles, broken tooth and severe
lacerations of my legs and lower body.

     Here my luck began to change slightly. The encounter with the barrel
seemed to slow me enough to lessen my injuries when I fell into the pile of
bricks and fortunately only three vertebrae were cracked.

     I am sorry to report, however, as I lay there on the pile of bricks, in
pain, unable to move and watching the empty barrel six stories above me, I
again lost my composure and presence of mind and let go of the rope . . .

--

Just my .02 worth.  People are not mindless cattle and should not act as
such.  I wholeheartedly agree with the Dj's view.  Since most ravers are
seeking the vibe, perhaps they should focus on just that.  Love.  

The invisiable energy of Love projected out of themselves like a river,
towards their brothers and sisters would perhaps make a wonderful focal
point.  Especially when shared with the DJ, lighting people and everyone
else participating, the focal point need only be Love.  The evidence of
things unseen lay in the ability to focus upon everything.  Taking in all
welcome and even unwelcomed sights, sounds, colors and experiences--and from
there projecting what is appropriately righteous for Love.

Troy J.

>
>>Subject: Mouse balls
>
>>"Memo of the Month," From The Washington Monthly, January/February
>>1991, page 24:
>>
>>"This is an actual alert to IBM Field Engineers that went out to all IBM
>>Branch Offices.  The person who wrote it was very serious.  The rest of us
>>find it rather funny.
>>
>>"Abstract:  Mouse Balls Available as FRU (Field Replacement Unit)
>>
>>"Mouse balls are now available as FRU.  Therefore, if a mouse fails to
>>operate or should it perform erratically, it may need a ball replacement.
>>Because of the delicate nature of this procedure, replacement of mouse
>>balls should only be attempted by properly trained personnel.
>>
>>"Before proceeding, determine the type of mouse balls by examining the
>>underside of the mouse.  Domestic balls will be larger and harder than
>>foreign balls.  Ball removal procedures differ depending upon manufacturer
>>of the mouse.  Foreign balls can be replaced using the pop-off method.
>>Domestic balls are replaced using the twist-off method.  Mouse balls are
>>not usually static sensitive.  However, excessive handling can result in
>>sudden discharge.  Upon completion of ball replacement, the mouse may
>>be used immediately.
>>
>>"It is recommended that each replacer have a pair of spare balls for
>>maintaining optimum customer satisfaction, and that any customer missing
>>his balls should suspect local personnel of removing these necessary items.
>>
>>"To re-order, specify one of the following:
>>
>>"P/N 33F8462 - Domestic Mouse Balls
>>"P/N 33F8461 - Foreign Mouse Balls"
>>
>

On Sat, 10 Aug 1996, Nancy Shaw wrote:

> 
> 
> "Trainspotting" was awesome.  Imagine an American film dealing honestly 
> and humorously with drug use and youth culture?  No, what we get from our 
> mainstream studios is mainstream, homogenized crap...but that is a 
> different thread.
> 
> Marginally rave-related:
> Super-cool was the inspired use of techno as a soundtrack!!  The 
> throbbing beats of the club scene (with familiar faces high on e and the 
> intoxicating music), the plaintive tones of Underworld, jarring techno at 
> the end...Here is a film that presents the emotional range of techno, 
> that actually _respects_ the music.  The ONLY time I have heard it in 
> American films, tv, etc. is as a joke, the stock portrayal of clanging 
> noise with no redemptive musical worth...
> 
> Must be because the film's European, where techno is actually mainstream and 
> popular.  But any other music for this subject would have been glaringly 
> discordant...new, exciting sounds to accompany the trip to the edge, the 
> life of young heroin addicts in Scotland.  Like the character says, 
> "everything is changing...music is changing..."
> 
> But mainstream American entertainment will not acknowledge that.  Even 
> major recording studios still think electronic music is a fad that will 
> blow over, rather than seeing it as the beginnings of future music... Our 
> big-budget studios, our mainstream culture, is decrepid, plodding along 
> mired in the past and what will safely sell to the under-stimulated 
> masses....

Dear Mr. Adder, or can I call you Black?   

you wrote with much VENOM, in response to my humble thoughts:

> > The company where I work just hired Value.net to do their ip
> > routing, based on the recommendation of an employee.
> >
> > My experience has been that their routers go down at least once
> > per day.  usually it's only for a few minutes, but it sucks
> > nonetheless.
> 
> Consider this a personal response, and in no way representitive of my
> employers viewpoint(although I hope he would agree): You are full of shit.
> Period. I am the Sys Admin of Value Net. I bust my ass to make sure the
> system stays up. Our routers and everything else do not, and never have gone
> down on a daily basis.

I reguarly have difficulties accessing the 'net.  Very often, about once
per day, normally accessible sites become completely inaccessible. 
Netscape times out -- tells me it can't find even AltaVista.  I
complained to the higher powers in our organization, in fact the one
that recommended you, and he responded to me "oh, one of their routers
probably rebooted" and shrugged.  Case closed, as far as he was
concerned.

Now if you want to tell me I'm full of shit because I said your routers
go down once per day, then you go right ahead.  Maybe they don't and
maybe I AM full of shit on that matter.

But if you're trying to tell me that I don't experience delays and
network problems regularly, then YOU, dear snake, are full of shit,
because I do.  Full stop.  End of matter, as far as I am concerned.
 
> 1) I have network monitoring utilities that tell me when something goes
>    down. In two seperate locations for redundancy.
> 2) I have hooks to paging software to page me if a piece of our equipment
>    goes down.
> 3) We were down on Sat. night for approximately 1/2 hour while we drove
>    to get the back-up generator. This was the first unscheduled down-time
>    in *MONTHS*

All that equipment and you STILL can't get it right?  ;-)  Maybe you
should get some monitering equipment for your monitering equipment!

> If your employer is having problems, *CALL US*. Suprisingly, unlike many
> other smaller ISP's, you will get a human, that will talk to you promptly.
> But please before casting aspersions on myself and the company I work for,
> get your fucking facts straight.

I'm really surprised, Black Adder.  In all the messages I've read by
you, you normally come across as being very reasonable.  You certainly
never seemed as STUPID as you do now.  I mean, come on, now!  I JUST
TOLD YOU THAT MY COMPANY IS A CLIENT OF YOURS AND YOU JUST TOLD ME I'M
FULL OF SHIT?  That's pretty stupid Black Adder, really really stupid.

I had looked forward to meeting you once.  And now I can only look
forward to some asshole sysadmin upstream from me reading all my
correspondence and trying to figure out exactly WHO I am and WHICH
machine I'm on so they can FUCK with me.

Good luck with your routers, snake,
p.

>I just curious to know what you all think of people going to raves/clubs
>alone? Is it not wise or acceptable...

I know lots of people who do. Personally, I try to go with a partner
(ideally my wife) whenever possible, to have somebody on a similar
wavelength who can bounce all the good vibes back at you. I don't think
it's dangerous, or anything like that. It's just so much more fun when you
can share the happiness with someone you care about.

Driving there and back with people *is* a good idea, if only to avoid
falling asleep on the way home.

Peace,

[Home is where the stereo is, unless my turntables get there first!]

On this thread of driving while impaired (once again, I have to say duh!
how can someone actually make an argument that driving high, drunk, spun,
exhausted, whatever, is actually ok?)....

For those who have seen the California drivers license handbook recently
... they no longer refer to "accidents" ... because they are really not
accidents, they are COLLISIONS!!  There is no accident about having a
collision with another vehicle, a tree, a pedestrian, whatever.  Even if
someone else caused it, if you're driving consciously and seeing what's up,
you can avoid it.

Someone, somewhere is responsible, either for
-driving when their reaction time was less than usual
-for being a lousy driver to begin with (ever watch how some car's wheels
are drifting in their lane on the freeway?  these are people who cannot
steer their car without over-correcting, there oughta be a school for
that!)
-for allowing themselves to be distracted (I think handheld car phones
should be outlawed for most of the population)
-for not taking care of their car (I overheard two girls at FnF talking
about leaving during the night, even though their car had no headlights --
for crying out loud!  that's so ridiculous!)

Driving is a big responsibility, and if you're not up to it, that's ok,
just don't do it.

Ranting (and not much raving lately!)

Leslie

Message-Id: <v015305041148d489f189@[206.86.235.114]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: lesliea@best.com (Leslie Ayres)
Subject: Re: raves alone
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>I just curious to know what you all think of people going to raves/clubs
>alone? Is it not wise or acceptable...

I think it's important as an human being to learn to be so comfortable with
yourself that you can do anything alone.  Movies, restaurants, traveling,
whatever.  You don't have to do it all the time, and it's fun to be with
friends, too, but if you are dependent on other people coming along to go
anywhere, you'll end up going where THEY want, and not where YOU want, a
lot of the time.

Besides, even when you go to a party with friends, half the time you're
wandering around alone anyway!  Extra advantage, you get to leave when YOU
want, no negotiating!

One of the biggest breakthroughs in my life was when I was visiting my
sister in Phila, and it was my birthday, and I wanted to go out and dance
... but had no one to go with me, so I went alone and found a club that
looked interesting, asked the door guy what kind of music they played
(house was the right answer) and went in and danced for 2 hours.  I was
probably the only person there alone, and was one of the only people
dancing solo on the dance floor, and was definitely the most tattooed and
pierced woman there (come to think of it, I was probably the only one not
wearing tight jeans and a half-shirt with poufy hair), but I had fun,
because I did what I wanted to do!  Was it a little scary?  Yep.  Was it
worth it?  Totally!

Leslie

On Mon, 12 Aug 1996, Alan Wong wrote:

> I just curious to know what you all think of people going to raves/clubs
> alone? Is it not wise or acceptable...
> 

 To tell you the truth, I kind of like going to raves by my self.  Up 
until this summer I always went with large groups of friends or with my girl 
friend and her friends.  Although they were all great people, I found 
that I didn't meet that many NEW people.  When I wanted a hug, I could 
always find the friends (that I came with) and I usually didn't wander as 
much because we had a central meeting spot.  But this summer my friends 
always found excuses not to go party and my girl friend was gone for the 
summer, so I hade no choice but to go by my self.  There was some great 
parties that I didn't want to miss because I didn't have anybody to go 
with.  And at all of those parties (BP, SFR picnic, and FnF) that I went 
to by my self I met some wonderful people. So my point is most people 
that go to raves are friendly, open, loving people that are always happy 
to meet new people and make friends.  Trying going by yourself, you might 
like it.

Love, mew, mew, purrrrr, plurrrrrrrrrrrr

Mattloaf


P.S. another plus is that you get to leave when you want to leave, no 
more complaining friends to deal with.

     This discussion reminds me of another from awile back which was 
should the DJ be on the dance floor in the first place. I feel that the 
DJ should be there right with everyone who is dancing and I agree that 
there is a sense of togetherness when everyone is facing the same way.
For me, the DJ acts as sort of a guide while I'm dancing. There is 
nothing like being right up front near the DJ and seeing him or her 
really getting into their set. It gives me an extra boost of energy
to keep right on dancing=).
                                  Reagan

> directions the energy has felt more scattered to me.

going to show and I start work at 8.00am.

I know of many ravers that do the choclate covered coffie bean thing for that
natural buzz.  
Others use more exotic natural stimulants, such as Ma Huang, Bee Pollen,
Royal Jelly or Gensieng (my favorite), all that are legal (still).  The idea
is totally not new however, just look at the ingredents of Herbal E.  
But if I were to advise anyone on the natural kick, I'd recommend to go to
GNC and pickup the ingredents seperatly.  Such combinations of varied herbs
could have less-than-appealing results (it's less expensive as well)...


"Dance with me..."


--Adam

I've never been to a bad rave, and I don't mind that much (well...no, I
really don't) when I miss some of the best times, as I have this year.  I
look ahead, and I get the feeling that every year will bring better
parties, as people learn what works best and what people like most.  My
only concern is that prices will continue to increase, till even the most
intimate, super-underground parties cost $20+, but even that won't deter me
from spending time with my wonderful, beautiful friends and family, and
from celebrating life through dance.

Party on,

- E

Subject: What's wrong with flyers?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

Hey, why is it that so many people complain about being handed flyers at
parties?  It's not like that's gonna ruin the vibe or anything.
Personally, I like coming home from a party and looking over the six or
seven flyers I collected the night before.  Heck, sometimes I even pick 'em
up off the floor!  They're worth grabbing for the artwork alone, sometimes,
and a lot of creative energy goes into some of them.  You can look through
your flyers, decide which parties you want to attend, and throw the rest
away.
I save some flyers, even of parties I don't attend but that are still cool
parties, so I can mail them to Sarah A. Fleming, who wanted to flyer up a
wall in her room (anyone remember her?  She used to be on this list) with
flyers of good parties.  I know other people who like to put 'em up on
their walls, too.
How 'bout this: if you see me, and have flyers to get rid of, lay 'em on me :)

Peace, love, etc.,

- E

Received: from [205.134.228.115] (ppp115-sf2.sirius.com [205.134.228.115]) by mail1.sirius.com (8.6.12/960710) with SMTP id MAA12246 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 13 Aug 1996 12:56:56 -0700

Mime-Version: 1.0

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: natural@sirius.com (Natural)
Subject: Re: Bay Guardian Article
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>i don't want to frighten you, but, uhem, i'm afraid those notes in the
>bay guardian are a very very bad sign...:)
>u.

> The articles are good, but I think it is kind of
>ironic that they are brining above ground the "underground."  It saddens
>me in a way.  I'm not sad that the "scene" is more popular.  I'm glad
>hat there are lots of wonderful people with whom to share it.  I'm just
>worried a bit about this "outing" of the scene.  What if some of us don't
>want it outed?

Dear All,
                I was concerned when I saw these and other comments in
response to the recent ELECTRONIC MUSIC discussion in the Bay Guardian.
        As far as I can recall (and my memory dims as old age draws near),
the ELECTRONIC MUSIC discussion was about just that, ELECTRONIC MUSIC.
Admittedly, all of the people who took part in the discussion consider
themselves part of the 'underground scene' that you hold so dear (as most
of us were exposed to the wonders of electronic music in the same way i.e.
in the middle of a crowd, under a strobe light, and out of our minds), and,
although the 'scene' WAS discussed at the table it was not mentioned in the
article, and most definitely not 'outed'. The only reference to the 'scene'
that I saw was the boxed out club listing of 'places to hear electronic
music'.
        What was printed (admittedly misquoted in places and sorely lacking
in others) were our opinions and feelings about about a form of music that
has changed and shaped our lives for the past ten years. I don't see that
as a bad sign. We were not asked to participate as 'scions of the scene',
we were included because (as pointed out in the introduction) we are
involved in producing electronic music and running labels which specialize
in electronic music. There were some glaring omissions from the list; Jeff
Taylor from UVR, Darin Marshall and Graeme, Freaky Chakra, Single Cell
Orchestra (although now in NYC), but overall I felt that the article was
positive, and IMHO exposure of this nature is a good thing.
       In short; knowledge is power, and life (and the 'scene') is what you
make it - contradict at will.

       Jon Williams

Received: from tgrigsby (tgrigsby.us.dhl.com [199.41.137.104]) by shellx.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id NAA07989 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 13 Aug 1996 13:30:20 -0700
Date: Tue, 13 Aug 1996 13:30:20 -0700
Message-Id: <199608132030.NAA07989@shellx.best.com>
X-Sender: tgrigsby@best.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: Re: Does Value.net have the same safety record as Value Jet?
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>Inability to reach certain sites can be caused by many different things 
>that have absolutely *NOTHING* to do with your provider. Perhaps some 
>disinterested third party would be kind enough to offer you some 
>education on the subject. 

May I throw some water on the fire?  BA is right, the web is just that, a 
web of connections.  Your ISP is not directly connected to everything on the 
web.  The URL will be resolved using data on one of a number of domain name 
servers on the 'net.  Then the connection will go through several nodes 
before hitting the address you're aiming for.  Any one part of this could 
have very heavy traffic, affecting the overall connection.  To blame it 
solely on the ISP's routers is naive at best.

>>  You certainly
>> never seemed as STUPID as you do now.

This and your other comments were not called for, including the suggestion 
the BA might use his position as the sysadmin unethically.  Calm down, 
folks; there's absolutely no need for this kind of thing.  

S

BTW, I just finished reading "Marabou Stork Nightmares" by the same 
Irvine Welsh.  A very brutal novel but at times funny in a sick and 
pathetic way.  It's about an abused boy who grows up to be a soccer 
hooligan.  The POV is this character in a coma as his life and various 
hallucinations go through his mind.  Near the end he becomes a raver, 
learning the positive posibilties as well as limits.  Despite this 
experience, in the end his hatred for everything is turned inward on himself.

David

I like to look at the dj sometimes because I know a lot of them and it 
makes me smile to see my friends having a good time up there and 
enjoying themselves.  

Another thing that it seems you havent been exposed to is the shamen 
idea.  that is where the dj is a "leader" in the sense that he is helping 
ebb and flow the vibe and movement of the party.  he is the shamen.  a 
very respected position in our tribe but no means for fame or recognition 
beyond respect and love.

love drenalin

Subject: Re[2]: What's wrong with flyers?  A rant...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     Drenalin (bless his groovy spinnin soul) wrote--------------------
     
     On Tue, 13 Aug 1996, Eric P. Peterson wrote:
     
     > and a lot of creative energy goes into some of them.  You can look 
     through > your flyers, decide which parties you want to attend, and 
     throw the rest
     > away.
     
     You could also recycle them!  =)  (instead of throwing them away)
     
     love drenalin
     --------------------------------------------------------------------
     
     And that's why they bug me.  Recycling that stuff requires chemicals 
     of the funkiest caliber.  I don't mind flyers, just don't push them on 
     me.  If I think it's cool, I'll take it.  If I look at it, and I don't 
     want it, take it back.  The part that sucks is too many people who 
     just don't seem to give a shit get paid for handing x-number of them 
     out, and that's why you see them in huge piles at the end of the 
     night.  The other thing that kinda bothers me is when I'm in a great 
     space dancing with friends or zoning or whatever, and some corporate 
     butt munchkin comes up thrusting a piece of hard cardboard at me.  No 
     I've never been outright papercut or wounded, but it's distracting.
     
     I do have a wall of them at home.  And that's the part that makes me 
     sick because I only take the ones I really like (either sentimental 
     value, aesthetic value, or a damn cool lineup and I plan on going).  
     This means hundreds of them are out there somewhere, and will never be 
     put to good use.  They failed.  They didn't advertise, they weren't 
     kept, and they're floating around lost in the wind somewhere hoping to 
     get stuck to a chainlink fence in a bad part of town or rained on or 
     something.  I'm getting bummed now.
     
     I guess whatever it is; dogma, flyers, drugs, etc... the choice 
     whether I take it or not should be mine and not yours.  If you pass 
     out flyers, be cool with people who don't take them, and don't dump 
     them in big piles at the end of the night.  If you do, you really 
     suck.
     
     $0.02
     AndyW
