     Basically, you're screwed fellow SanJosean...
     
     Nothing worthwhile in San Jose on Tuesday.  Only weekly worth a pigs 
     butt is Velvet Shop (IMHO) and that's on Thursdays next to Toon's 
     (just moved from Agenda).  Good progessive happenin.  Everything else 
     is deep house (which I'm not a big fan of) or club type music (mumble  
     'pump up the volume' while twirling finger in martini here).
     
     Raving out of San Jose is not the ideal arrangement.  I recommend 
     writing off the week as a wash, and living LARGE on weekends.  Give me 
     a ring if you want to rideshare up to the city some weekend, or just 
     hang out.
     
     408-435-5259 (days)
     408-378-0580 (eves)
     
     AndyW
     
     ---------------------------------------------------------------------
     
     Tuesday
     
     Breathe Deep - House w/DJs Jay-J, Ruben, Miquel, guests. 10pm-4am, 
     21+, $5. 1015 Folsom., SF. 415.998.9515 
     
     Succotash! - tasty jazz - funk - beats - space w/DJs tom thump, rasta 
     q-tip. 21+, Free. up & down club, 1151 folsom st.,
     SF. 
     
     supper - funk, acid jazz w/DJs Caspar, guests. 21+, Free. Julie's 
     Supper Club, 1123 Folsom @ 7th, SF. 415.861.0707 
     
     L-Tryptophan - ambient, techno w/DJs guest DJs weekly. 21+, Free. 1624 
     California @ Van Ness, SF. 
     
     Lost in Space - house, hip-hop w/DJs Pause, Dark Money, Winnie B, Eric 
     Lacy. 21+, Free. Cafe Mars, 798 Brannan @
     7th, SF. 
     
     Eclectic - house, jungle, drum & bass w/DJs Yamu, Siege, Franko, 
     Foster, guests. Fresh fruit & condoms to all
     9pm-2am, 21+. Paradise Bar & Grill, 5356 College Ave, Oakland. 
     
     The Deep - house, techno. 9pm-2am, . Palookaville, 1133 Pacific Ave, 
     Santa Cruz?. 408.425.3316 
     
     Speakeasy - house w/DJs Shannon, John Howard, guests. semi-weekly
     Coco Club, 139 8th St, SF. 
     
     Fly! - House, Techno, Trance with an emphasis on the Trippy Tip w/DJs 
     Dano, Keith, weekly guests. Visuals by TNT
     Blast!.9pm-3am, 21+. Minna Street Gallery, 111 Minna St, SF.

not set a ticket price yet, so call the Harmony voice mail to get more

From: jlawrenc@stratacom.com (Jeremy Lawrence)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: "Trainspotting" (Warning: spoilers) (SRR)
Reply-To: jlawrenc@cisco.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Warning: you may not want to read on if you haven't seen the
movie yet.


Gioni wrote:
> Yes, it was definately anti-drug...especially having the baby in it...I 
> didn't think it was very comedic at all.  Perhaps the narrative was 
> sarcastic but not comedic...subtle difference.

IMHO train-Spotting was non-judgemental when it came to drugs: it
portrayed them in a detached (and cynical) way. Despite showing the
sordid details of the heroin scene in Edinburgh, the film also showed
just how nasty alcohol can get. It also made the point that the heroin
users weren't stupid.

The scenes with the baby were deliberately ambiguous. We don't know
what killed that baby - the baby didn't look as though s/he had starved
to death.

What the film did do was invite the audience to make their own
judgements about what was going on. In England, it was criticised by
conservatives for being pro-drug because it doesn't explicitly condem
the drug use it portrays.

Jeremy

hey all...just back from a trip to Seattle,Victoria,VAncouver, and Banff.
Arrived to find 717 messages from SFR so I've got a a lot of reading to do..

Unlike my trip to the chicago underground a few years ago..I didn't make it
to any parties while away to report on.  I tried to see Ethan when he played
in Victoria, but the ferry wanted $80.00 to ferry the car over so I could
drive to the party...Besides Garth Brooks was in town, selling out 180,000
tickets for three nights...and it seemed that everyone in British Columbia
was trying to stay in Vancouver.   After looking for a hotel for hours, we
ended up sleeping in our car in Harrison Hot springs or the way to Banff.

However, I read in the B.C. paper about raves in Israel. Seems like
promoters are putting on "Rave" or "Moon" parties in the desert. The article
said they had brought in Domino from the UK and paid him $7,000 to spin. The
most intersting thing in the article was about the secret police, going
underground to arrest the sellers of X. They agents were bragging about
putting away sellers of X for 25 years, and possession for x and acid was
5-10years!!!!!!....FYO

                                   Good to be back...SpinSilver

I have a comment, a thought, and a suggestion regarding coffee.

comment: it sounds like a GREAT idea! :)  I am not beyond other stimulants,
but I have found that I don't like to do them at raves.  Coffee would be just
the right amount to keep awake.  It should indeed be iced, 'cause it's
usually too damn hot at raves in the first place.  That and so you don't
spill scalding coffee all over when you get bumped. 

thought:  Coffee is a diuretic (I think), and would thus promote dehydration,
especially in large amounts (and in combination with other things).

suggestion:  Where there's coffee there should be free (or _very cheap_) water
available, and the caffeine purveyor (sp?) should have a sign or something
letting people know they should drink water.  Of course free water requires
coordination with the people throwing the shindig.

Sorry if I'm wrong or worrying to much about it.

I don't go to a whole lot of raves, but I would be glad to man the
machines for an hour or so at any that I do go to.

-mike

On Tue, 13 Aug 1996, Reagan Reid wrote:

> 
>      This discussion reminds me of another from awile back which was 
> should the DJ be on the dance floor in the first place. I feel that the 
> DJ should be there right with everyone who is dancing and I agree that 
> there is a sense of togetherness when everyone is facing the same way.
> For me, the DJ acts as sort of a guide while I'm dancing. There is 
> nothing like being right up front near the DJ and seeing him or her 
> really getting into their set. It gives me an extra boost of energy
> to keep right on dancing=).
>                                   Reagan
> 
> 
> 
> On Mon, 12 Aug 1996, PETER FOGEL wrote:
> 
> > I don't mind having everyone face the dj.  I don't see it as worshiping 
> > the dj.  I find that when most people are facing the same direction 
> > there is more of a sense of unity.  
> > When I've been to parties where everyone is facing many different 
> > directions the energy has felt more scattered to me.
> > 
> > :)
> > peter
> > 
>

Steve,
	I was kinda into this a couple years ago, although I personally never
was into having a "cool sig".  Back then there were some
newsgroups (alt.ascii-art, alt.binaries.pictures.ascii) for this stuff.  
There is some pretty amazing ascii art out there.  I don't
know the newsgroups' states now, but I'm going to send out a faq from
back then, and then an example of the kind of stuff they used to post.  
So the next two msgs from me will be those.  Keep in mind the faq is from '94.
Hope you like Star Wars...  Sorry to everyone else if you don't care, I just
thought you might be interested!!

Oh, yeah, two ways they can get screwed up. 
1) Tabs - different users have different Tab values (8chars, 4chars, etc.)
   Using Tabs in ascii-art can guarantee that it might be screwed up.  Always
   use spaces.

2) The width of the art.  If your shell/viewer/whatever is 60 columns, and my
   pictures are 80, the lines are going to wrap.

3) Ah, one more.  If your viewer uses some kind of proportional font (can't
   remember what they're called, but you know, when the width of different 
   characters is different...), you will have problems.

If you like these I have more...
And I'm sure there are websites devoted to it.

-mike

           ___    _   _    ____   _      _   ______   _____     ____ 
       O ,/ _ \  | \ | |  / ___! | |    | | |  ____! |  __ \   / ___!
      /\/| !_! | |  \| | | (___  | | /\ | | | !__    | !__) | | (___
     /   |  _  | | . ` |  \___ \ \ \/  \/ / |  __!   |  _  /   \___ \ O  ,
    /\   | | | | | |\  |  ____) | \  /\  /  | !____  | | \ \   ____) ||\/
   /_/_  !_! !_! !_! \_! !_____/   \/  \/   !______! !_!  \_\ !_____/ |/\_



   1.  What is ASCII art?

   Any image that can be sent over the net, received and immediately viewed
on any standard terminal type or communications software, and can be printed
on any printer.  This requires the image be made by using only letters,
numbers, puntuation marks and symbols such as:

               / \ | - _ + = # . , : ^ ' ` " ~ % @ < > ( ) [ ] { }

   These characters are part of the ASCII (American Standard Code for
Information Interchange) set.  This part of the ASCII set, called the
'printable' set, is used for text files, which is what is sent over the net.

   ASCII art should be viewed with a non-proportional font, also called a
'mono-spaced' font.  In other words, your software should display so many
letters per inch, regardless of the actual width of the letters.

   Most ASCII pics are viewed on a monitor that displays 80 characters
across.  But some ASCII art is wider, say, 81 to 132 characters across, and is
meant to be printed.

   Some gray scale art may look like a negative image when viewed with light
colored letters on a dark background.  This is because it is meant to be
printed with dark ink on light paper.


   2.  What are the different kinds of ASCII art?

   The first four use the standard printable set.  They are:

   o  Line drawing - Such as the light bulb above.

   o  Lettering - Large and styled, like the title "ASCII ART FAQ" above.

   o  Gray scale pictures - These create the illusion of gray shades by using
      letters for their light emitting value (assuming you are viewing light
      letters on a dark background).  Here is an example of how they break
      down by light intensity:

      Darker    .'`,^:";~
        /\      -_+<>i!lI?
       /||\     /\|()1{}[]
        ||      rcvunxzjft
       \||/     LCJUYXZO0Q
        \/      oahkbdpqwm
      Lighter   *WMB8&%$#@  (light value scale from Jorn Barger)

   Here is a gray scale pic: (from The Scarecrow)

                    :<!!:
              ..:::tNi@Nin!+: :::xr
            '!)Q88i@8888NNidbo@Ni8ir
            .s:S988TR88RX*###RB8888i:x
          x+RRX88888NL#?!< :<?#RR888bX
         !MN*#M#*BRR#8iXxi@NUX!MN88888:
        <x@T!M!::(R8H@888888888xX88888#=
        x8W8Ui@!~!XMMM9M8RRRRBMMM!T588.
       .N8888M<<<~!#MXMHM8N888RMR<9R888N!.
       XQ888M!<:::sxXU!?MTT222#MM<?M8888~!
       988NMMf<!!~`"!Rk:X!"""#*N!:~!T588 !
       "R(#MF `<      "!!~     ~<9XN#88XX<:
        "%/9" x~       :L       XH?R?M888x%
         xi/ ~M:u::~  <88>x<:<uuUF<~*"<?8!~
        X38M::#M88R::d<88k9bxH888f4r o<<Ri
       '!88N!!X6?M&i8#<88Rt88NMR9%!!'8:<?8!
         #R?<:~B:M88~ 488H~"88XM8~ ~HRtxH#
      +++x8!:<'8!@8!.  ""!:.#8M8# ~<!@!M?::
      -<!#\x~:.?<M~ <<::;;>> ?%8xx!:i:`MHbLX
       :*:!!:nM.~!~`<<! <`~" d<?98NHRNi!?888eu.
       ` `xH98MN.      '~~:. ?:x888!888xd88888f
        :@8R?R?88ex  .xuux98  WM888M88(W888888f
      .oX"#MMX!!R88b ~"##**".d8f?RRX8PW8888888f
    .u8888iXMMnWU7T#@s.     @88kX888RN88888888f
   .@888888NK9*MR88N86Q:.. x8T888R#88888888888f
  x8888888888@iX#M@8888888N88888#X@88888888888f
 d88888888888kM888NN868RRRRRRR5b@8888888888888f
'8888888888888!M888888888888888888888888888888!

   o  3-D images - They can be viewable by people with similar vision in both
      eyes.  You try to focus as if you are looking at the back of the
      monitor.  The image should pop into focus and create a 3-D illusion.  
      Other 3-D images are viewed by putting your nose on the monitor glass.
      For more information, see the alt.3d group.

   There are also Picture Stories, Geometric Articles, and Picture Poems.  A
Picture Story is what it sounds like, a story told with accompaning ASCII
pictures.  A Geometric Article is where text itself is formed into shapes. A
Picture Poem is a Geometric Article that is a poem.  Examples are shown at
the end of this FAQ.

   See the long version for examples.

   The other kinds of ASCII images contain 'control codes' for animation and
color.  These pics have to be processed before they can be sent over the net.
This processing changes the control codes to regular 'printable' ASCII
characters, so the pic can be sent as a text file.  This is called
'uuencoding'.  The file is processed back again after it is received.  This
is called 'uudecoding'.

   o  ASCII animations - You see an animated image produced by a sequence of
      changing ASCII pictures.  The speed will depend on the system you are
      using.  ANSI escape sequences are in the long version of this FAQ.

   o  Color - You can view color ASCII pics, if you have a color screen and
      'ANSI' color compatible software.

   Examples are in the long version of this FAQ.


   3.  How do I save, 'uudecode' and view animations and color images?

   You need to do the following if you want to save an animation or color
image from a newsreader, uudecode and view.  Type the name of the file where
I have 'FILENAME'.  On a Unix system, the process is usually as easy as:

   o  Press the 's' key while you are looking at the post in your newsreader
      (or while the message is selected in elm if it was mailed to you).

   o  Quit your newsreader (or elm) and go to where the file was saved.

   o  Type 'uudecode FILENAME'.  This may change the file's name.

   o  You may need to decompress the file if it has a suffix such as .Z or .gz
      or .zip (among others).  For .Z, type 'uncompress FILENAME' and for
      .gz, type 'gunzip FILENAME' and for .zip, type 'unzip FILENAME'.

   o  Type 'cat FILENAME' and press the return.

   To slow down an animation while viewing on your Unix host, you need to type
'cat -u FILENAME'.

   If you have uudecoded a file and downloaded it to your PC, you have
to type 'type FILENAME' and press the return to view it.  If you have
uudecoded and downloaded it to your Amiga, open a large Cli/Shell and type
'type FILENAME' and press return to view it.


   4.  How can I learn to make ASCII art?

   Unfortunately, there aren't many text books on the subject. :-)  A good
way to learn is to study how an artist has made a picture.  What characters
are chosen.  How are the characters laid out?  How is a texture made.

   You can also modify existing art.  Take a piece of art you think could be
improved.  Make a copy.  Now work on it.  When you are good at that, try to
improve a really good pic.  Then see if you can fix a damaged file.  Now take
some small pics and put them together into a big composite image.

   See question 6 for info about the file 'asciitech.aa'.


   5.  Are there any ASCII tools?

   Not many.  The Emacs editor offers some help, if you know how to use it.
Q-Edit is an ASCII editor with block cut and paste.  And TheDraw can do some
ANSI tricks but is limited by RAM size.  There are Unix and DOS scripts for
flipping an ASCII pic (like modasc by Ric Hotchkiss).  BBSdraw is available
for the Amiga.  So is CygnusEd, which allows column editing.  And there's the
TPU editor for VAX.


   6.  Where can I find ASCII art?

   You can FTP ASCII art (single pics and archives of dozens or hundreds of
images) from many sites, including these:

      ->  Host: mordor.ind.wpi.edu
          Path: pub/ascii/art/pictures
                pub/ascii/art/movies

      ->  Host: ftp.mcs.com
          Path: mcsnet.users/jorn/ascii-art
                Jorn's FTP site

      ->  Host: ftp.ncsu.edu
          Path: pub/ncsu/chking/Archive
                Chris' FTP site

      ->  Host: ftp.cs.ttu.edu
          Path: pub/asciiart/sullivan
                Steve's FTP site

      ->  Host: ftp.cs.uoregon.edu
          Path: pub/juan/Ascii
                Juan's FTP site

   The following is a gopher server:

      ->  Host: cs4sun.cs.ttu.edu
          Path: 11/Art_and_Images/ASCII

   The long version of this FAQ contains a longer list of sites.  And it
tells you which sites have animations and lineprinter art.

   If you need more technical info about ASCII art, get Jorn's file called
'asciitech.aa' in Jorn's 'ascii-art' folder at his FTP site.  His site also
has many files of ASCII art.

   Jorn and Chris' FTP sites also have the big Scarecrow's ASCII Art Archives.
The Scarecrow's archives contain hundreds of pieces of art, special sections
on sig art, bbs art, and more.

   As well as a file called the Most Often Requested Edition.  It contains
the pics that people request the most on the group.  It has pics for wishing
friends a happy birthday, Star Trek, flowers, dragons, hearts, and so on.

   There's also the long version of this FAQ (containing complete examples of
all forms af ASCII art, plus ANSI escape cods, and examples of Figlet fonts).
You'll also find the Scarecrow's files of humor, GIFs, etc. (which are listed
in the answer to the next question).


   7.  Can I get The Scarecrow's files via email?

   Yes.  If you do NOT have FTP available, you can get filos by email.
To receive || send email to boba@gagme.wwa.com with || in the subject line.
          \||/                                     \||/
           \/                                       \/

    File Name                      Version   Size   Subject line 

 o  Short version of the FAQ           1.5 - 19 K   REQUEST SHORT FAQ
 o  Long version of the FAQ            1.5 - 61 K   REQUEST LONG FAQ
 o  Most Often Requested Edition       1.1 - 90 K   REQUEST MORE
 o  The Scarecrow's ASCII Art Archive  1.0 - 349 K  REQUEST SAAA 1.0
 o  The Scarecrow's ASCII Art Archive  2.0 - 362 K  REQUEST SAAA 2.0
 o  The Scarecrow's Funnies (humor)    2.1 - 68 K   REQUEST FUNNIES
 o  Best of Scarecrow's Sig Gallery    1.2 - 207 K  REQUEST SIGS
 o  Best of Scarecrow's BBS Gallery    1.2 - 78 K   REQUEST BBS
 o  Best of Scarecrow's GIF Gallery    1.1 - 62 K   REQUEST GIFS
 o  Best of Scarecrow's 3-D Gallery    1.0 - 30 K   REQUEST 3-D

   The long version contains descriptions of the above files.


   8.  How do I make those big letters?

   You can make lettering like the above subtitle "ANSWERS" by hand, or
use a program called Figlet.  With Figlet, the letters you type are
automatically turned into big letters.  There are over 30 fonts for use with
Figlet.  Some host systems also have a program called Banner.


   9.  Where can I get Figlet?

   You can FTP Figlet from:

      ->  Host: ftp.isu.edu
          Path: pub/figlet

          This is the official site and contains the latest fonts.


   10.  How can I make gray scale pictures?

   You can make them from scratch if you are a very good ASCII artist.  An
easier way is to use a program called 'ASCGIF'.  There is also Gifscii (with
a version for the Mac), ANSIrez and GIF2ANSI for the PC.  These programs
makes an ASCII pic from any image you can convert to a GIF.


   11.  Where can I get gray scale converters?

   You can FTP ASCGIF from:

      ->  Host: usc.edu
          Path: archive/usenet/sources/comp.sources.misc/volume30/ascgif

      ->  Host: wuarchive.wustl.edu
          Path: usenet/comp.sources.misc/volume30/ascgif

      ->  Host: ftp.uu.net
          Path: usenet/comp.sources.misc/volume30/ascgif

   You can get GIF2ANSI from:

      ->   BBS: Exec-PC (414) 789-4210
                GIF2ANSI.ZIP is in the "Mahoney MS-DOS" file collection.


   12.  What is 'anti-aliasing'?

   The short, plain english explanation is that special care was taken to use
letters for their shapes.  This makes the picture or font look smoother.


   13.  How do I have my sig automatically added to my posts?

   On most Unix systems, name the file you want to be used as ".signature"
and put it in the top level of your home folder.  Your news software should
pick it up.

   If you're using elm for your mail, and elm doesn't pick up your sig, you
need to put the following in ypur elmrc:

localsignature = ~/.signature
remotesignature = ~/.signature

   If you're using vm (in emacs) for your mail, place the following in your
.emacs file, which will add the .signature file:

(setq mail-signature t)

   If you're using pine (with pico) for your mail, place the following in
your .pinerc file:

signature-file=~/.signature


   14.  How do I use an animation in my plan?

   On most Unix systems, name the file you want to be used as ".plan" and put
it in top level of your home folder.  It does not work with all finger
commands.  Putting an animation in your plan is not universally recommended.


   15.  Where can I post ASCII Art?

   You can post any of the above types of ASCII art to alt.ascii-art or to
alt.binaries.pictures.ascii groups.  To make it easier for us readers, put
one of the following identifying words at the beginning of the subject line
of your post:

     LINE - Standard ASCII line art.  Line pictures and large lettering.
      GIF - Gray scale image.
      BIG - Wider than 80 columns and-or longer than 24 lines.
ANIMATION - Animation.  Usually uuencoded.
    COLOR - Color.  Usually uuencoded.
      3-D - 3-D art.
  REQUEST - Request for a certain picture or type of picture.
   REPOST - Repost of a previously posted pic.
     TALK - Discussion, no pics included.
   BINARY - Binaries (software like Figlet and ASCGIF).

   If someone requests a picture only days after it has been posted, and you
would like to fill that request, please email the picture to the person
requesting it.  It's better than reposting so soon.

   Try to eliminate unnecessary blank space to the left of the pic.  If
you're posting a collection of pics, try to keep each pic on its own lines
(and separated from other pics by a couple of lines).  Check for tab damage.

   Most guidelines for posting apply here too.  Try to keep quoted materials
to a minimum.  One exception to the usual rules are the use of sigs.  Because
alt.ascii-art and alt.binaries.pictures.ascii are about ASCII art, it is
within the scope of the groups to post sigs.


   16.  Who made this FAQ?

   It is made by your old friend, the Scarecrow with info gratefully
received from the following nice people:


                               JORN BARGER

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 14 Aug 1996 06:58:54 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "THX1138" <THX1138@planet-jubip.com>
Subject: WOW!!!!, What A Weekend..........
Cc: Ulrike Laitko <laitko@hpbio1.Biologie.HU-Berlin.de>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear All;

        Well after seeing some of the worlds best DJ's @ Spundaes Nation
like Mark Hunt, & Scot Marc Spairo from Orlando, Florida, DJ Taylor from LA,
and of course Sasha from England I thought it would be enough, but as we
were leaving 1015 a friend of mine asked me if I wanted to go to an after
party over a friend of his house.

        I was initially trying to avoid going to the End Up, because it's a
scary place, so I decided to go with my friend and just thought it was going
to be a bunch of people sitting around partying. AAAAA well it was, but we
ended up having people like DJ Taylor, DJ Scot, & DJ Mark, as well as some
of SFR's greatest DJ's in front of a very large box of records spinning new
Techno genre music for the rest of Monday & well into Tuesday day & night.
Rose, former owner of LA's Sketch Pad was also present, wow she's sooo nice.

        Wow, Wow, Wow, you think I like to have a good time, those guys
party their brains out putting me well under the table. Between the four or
five of us we had everything. It's Wedesday @ 6am and I just got up after
sleeping 24 hours, wow, wow, wow.

        All of these people are just sooooo nice, sooo down to earth with
the exception of our habits. I felt like I was back on top of Simon's
rooftop cafe, and it felt soo good. It's sooo wonderful how the music takes
you back to places and times along with how you felt back then. Did I
mention Simon's, Northeast Florida's greatest club and Techno venue, he
Simon was in the crowd. What a couple of nights indeed.

        I would just like to thank Taylor, Josh, Scot, Mark, & of course
Kevin for such a wonderful night and a rare opportunity to directly support
our world wide scene, I won't let you down Kevin, and I promise you that I
will continue being the person I am & respect you wishes, for I know no
other way to be.

Peace, Love & Thanks For A Bunch of Wonderful Nights
Brian

Dear All;

        Yes, 1015 Folsum has a dress code Saturday Night; which I am for. I
feel most ravers spend all their money on drugs, and not on clothes. Though
I agreed trendy clothes are over priced, please do not complain. This is a
rare happening, and I personally like getting dressed up, and often feel
over dressed at raves causing me to dress down. The scene needs a place for
people who take PRIDE in their appearance wearing something more than, yuk
dirty blue jeans, dirty tee shirts, a baseball cap; even if they are clean.
These people often wonder why people of sexual interest walk away from them.

Just Something To Think About
Brian

Brian writes:

>Yes, 1015 Folsum has a dress code Saturday Night; which I am for.

Whats up with with this shit?  This is exactly the sort of club attitude
that drove me away from clubbing 10 years ago (oops, showing my age). 

If people want to dress up, go for it. Just don't tell ME how to dress.
I just don't understand some peoples (and club owner/promoters) desire
to CONTROL others especially how one dresses.

I will never support a club/restaurant/job/etc. that has a dress code. I
would hope most people would boycott this sort of thing. Whats next... a
return  to the velvet rope and the doorman only letting in those that
look cool enough? I don't want to be a clone and I DO want to celebrate
DIVERSITY.

People who have control problems should control their OWN lives and give
everyone else a little room to be themselves...

peace,
martin

I was also thinking of something in the iced coffee/iced espresso
genre... such a thing would be refreshing as well as stimulating.
The only problem would be logistics, ie. coolers or refrigerators,
people to distribute the actual java, etc. I don't think anyone would
be up for spending the whole night passing out coffee, but 1 hour (or
whatever) shifts could certainly be doable. An "on your honor" system
might even work, as well.

$0.50 sounds like a good price, esp. compared to the usual $3
smart drink or water price. That and the smiles it would bring 
would more than cover costs :)

Thoughts, comments, suggestions?

> Yes, 1015 Folsum has a dress code Saturday Night; which I am for.

What do they require?

Most clubs are way too hot to wear lots of fancy clothing in,
at least if one intends to dance a lot.  One could have quite a dry
cleaning bill even if  one didn't keel over from the heat.

Dress shoes are really incompatable with dancing

> I feel most ravers spend all their money on drugs, and not on clothes.

I think most of us spend more of it on music than either of those, actually.

>The scene needs a place for people who take PRIDE in their appearance

That place is anywhere you want to be.
Most parties seem to have lots of beautiful and beautifully-dressed people
dancing.

Some of the rest may not yet have figured out what appearance they want
or how to get it.  It may not be available in a store.

If 1015 is legislating a particular appearance, it would be useful to know
what that is.

>wearing something more than, yuk dirty blue jeans, dirty tee shirts, a
baseball cap

So, just in case I happen to show up at 1015 on a Saturday night in clean,
tiedyed jeans and a tiedyed tshirt and Birkenstocks, would they let me in?

The Tie-Dyed Side of the Force

hello all-

allow me to vent for a moment.

this morning, i came out to my car, thoroughly enjoying my vacation
(especially yesterday, sarah!) and find that it's been broken into for the
second time.  gone was:
        1 backpack
        1 pager
        1 portable stereo
        a bunch of cd's
        1 dc - ac converter

all that stuff is replacable.  this stuff is not:
        1 chain with my sfraves laminates and ticket on it (why the hell did
they want that?)
        1 bag of tapes with mix tapes from friends, and tahoe tapes, and
some of my music

i can deal with replacing the big stuff, that's life in the city.  but why
did they have to take the stuff that has the memories?  at least i didn't
have christina (my guitar) or boris and natasha (computer and ricochet), or
i would most likely be out shooting people today.

thanks for letting me vent, and i'm off to find another consulting job to
replace this stuff.

i hope this teaches me that no object is worth getting this worked up over.
i still have each of the memories attached to each thing, and that they
cannot steal from me.

love to you all-

matt l


matthew d. p. k. lanier
thinker, trained belly-button lint technician

mdpkl@best.com

At 10:15 AM 8/14/96 -0700, you wrote:

>Most clubs are way too hot to wear lots of fancy clothing in,
>at least if one intends to dance a lot.  One could have quite a dry
>cleaning bill even if  one didn't keel over from the heat.

        I agree, so I wear cool party clothes like Pose, Lip Service(great
inexpensive vinyl clothes usually round $60 if ya shop around for a pair of
pants, I've spent much more on blue jeans & if your thin they make you feel
so hot(not temp) & sexy; vinyl clothes are just soo erotic & contrary to
popular belief are not hot), watches by Storm, Dog Pile, Hookups, Pig Pen,
everything from Verso(my fav), sunglasses by Chris Roth, Boots by Parachoe
...etc. These clothes are designed for partying/dancing.

        Not to brag, but there are nights when if you count the sunglasses,
watch and jacket, the value of these clothes can approach a $1000.

        I'm mainly talking about people who wear their tour dead shirts &
clothes from 1970. People the Dead are dead and you are sooo out of fashion,
it's not cool to not take a bath and not wash your clothes for a year. You
don't even look like a raver, you look like a clueless stoned Dead Head. I
was one and could see it if the band was still going, but it died when
Jerry(RIP) died.

>Dress shoes are really incompatable with dancing

        Get a pair of boots, or shop around and find something that looks
nice and feels comfortable. Most guys are clueless when it comes to
shopping, I personally spend the entire day walking & driving from shop to
shop to shop; from the Haight to the Castro, to downtown. Most of the time
you cannot walk into a one store and find something different or cool. There
are days when I do the above mentioned and don't buy anything.

        People have asked me if I shop in London, Paris, LA and New York and
I'm so honest I always tell them no, right here in the bay area. It feels so
good when people pay you an honest compliment.

> I feel most ravers spend all their money on drugs, and not on clothes.

        DJ's yes, but most ravers I feel no. Nice or nice expensive clothes
are of little or no value to an addicted raver. This is why I have to guard
my clothes or stick them into the check at the club or rave.

>That place is anywhere you want to be.
>Most parties seem to have lots of beautiful and beautifully-dressed people
>dancing.

        At clubs yes, at raves no.

>Some of the rest may not yet have figured out what appearance they want
>or how to get it.  It may not be available in a store.

Peace
Brian

ps People take pride in your appearance for no one else will, it's a
statement of how much you care about you, and to a lesser extent what other
people think. Once again believe in yourself, hey I'm worth clothes that
cost twice what I can afford, how bout you.

Dear Matthew;

        Sorry to hear that you stuff got stolen, but dude where do you live;
in the city. Mannnn you should know better than that guy, anytime something
like happens to me, I look at it like it's my fault. Because I know better,
why did ya leave stuff in your car, that momentary laziness will cost you
every time.

        These people who break into cars check them every night, they are
always out there. I lost a $320 pair of sunglasses and close to $400 of
other stuff, I was lazy and a fool to think that it wouldn't get stolen.
These people will trade that stuff for a $5 crack rock, even if they know
it's valuable.

        I get really annoyed at people who leave stuff in their car and it
gets stolen and they complain. You live on hostile streets, be aware and
protect yourself. Complacently will get you robbed and/or hurt/killed. Sorry
to be soo strong but hopefully you will learn a lesson from it.

        Please don't get me wrong I hate the people who do it, and the law
who does nothing about it except take a report over the phone. These people
are scum, addicted, and maybe just plain hungry, I cannot understand how
they live with themselves it is beyond me.

Peace

Precedence: bulk

I was going to stay out of this, but I find this just a tad bit too
offensive...

Brian writes:
>         I agree, so I wear cool party clothes like Pose, Lip Service(great
> inexpensive vinyl clothes usually round $60 if ya shop around for a pair of
> pants, I've spent much more on blue jeans & if your thin they make you feel
> so hot(not temp) & sexy; vinyl clothes are just soo erotic & contrary to
> popular belief are not hot), watches by Storm, Dog Pile, Hookups, Pig Pen,
> everything from Verso(my fav), sunglasses by Chris Roth, Boots by Parachoe
> ...etc. These clothes are designed for partying/dancing.
>         Not to brag, but there are nights when if you count the sunglasses,
> watch and jacket, the value of these clothes can approach a $1000.

Ooo...POSE!  How cool...I'm happy that you have so much money and time
and energy to spend (I would say WASTE) on your clothes.  I would rather
spend my time, money and energy on something else, one example being
music.  Whether it's practicing my singing, playing sitar, 
going to a show, a rave, etc...I really dig nice clothes too, but 
I usually would rather spend $35, say, on burning man, than on a 
pair of cool Pose(r) socks.  Myself, I would feel pretty stupid 
wasting 1000 dollars on clothes,even if I did have it
(I work at the VA--not likely!)
I guess it just depends on what you think is important...your inside, 
or your outside. I prefer to hang out with people who are beautiful.  
It doesn't have anything to do with what they wear.  It has to do 
with their energy (I guess you don't understand that yet).  
They could be naked, scarred, conventionally "ugly"...wear clothes 
from 1812...I really don't care. I find that people who are all 
caught up in their appearance are generally shallow, stupid, boring, 
petty, etc...of course this is all just MHO, but hell, you're 
spoutin' off yours, so I feel free to do the same...

Re: tour shirts, deadheads...
>         I'm mainly talking about people who wear their tour dead shirts &
> clothes from 1970. People the Dead are dead and you are sooo out of fashion,
> it's not cool to not take a bath and not wash your clothes for a year. You
> don't even look like a raver, you look like a clueless stoned Dead Head. I
> was one and could see it if the band was still going, but it died when
> Jerry(RIP) died.

I don't doubt that you "were" clueless and stoned.  DeadHead, I doubt. If
you knew anything about the Dead you would know that the music never
stops...it has taken new and exciting forms, but that's off topic...
I go to raves to dance to great music, meet cool people (not their cool
clothes), and generally have a good time.  I wear what I feel comfortable
in (which is actually not dirty tour shirts.  and yes, i take a bath every
day...I'm aquarius, I can't bring myself out of water!)
It's not a huge issue for me.  It wouldn't even be an issue now,
except you are trying to pass judgement on people who don't dress and
think about clothes the way you do.  Get a clue!  If dirty tour shirts 
bother you, don't talk to people who have them on.  I certainly am not
going to talk to someone who is preening about at a rave, concerned more
with what he/she is wearing than even being there, really.  Not that I
mind well-dressed individuals...but I do mind when those individuals tell
me what MY priorities should be in life.
 
>         DJ's yes, but most ravers I feel no. Nice or nice expensive clothes
> are of little or no value to an addicted raver. This is why I have to guard
> my clothes or stick them into the check at the club or rave.

That's your own issue...you're all caught up in the "look" scene, the
"material" scene, so you're going to have to deal with the "paranoia"
scene too..."they want what I have, so I'm going to have to GUARD my
STUFF!!!"  Obviously we don't live in a perfect world; unfortunately the
majority of people have to deal with stuff getting stolen because wealth
is not distributed evenly, and MONEY and THINGS have become more
important than LOVE and THE PERSON HIM/HERSELF...

<sigh>

Ok, enough venting for one post.  Flame away...

shamini

and ps...I dig bell bottoms.  I really don't care if you do or not.

scene was about freedom of expression. As far as I'm concerned, the
only way to be out of fashion is to compromise your own fashion for
someone else. Clothing should be a statement of who you are as an
individual, not of how well you fit into a "scene". Everyone's got
something different going on upstairs, so let's dress just like it and
stop the sneering.

> At 10:15 AM 8/14/96 -0700, you wrote:
> 
> >Most clubs are way too hot to wear lots of fancy clothing in,
> >at least if one intends to dance a lot.  One could have quite a dry
> >cleaning bill even if  one didn't keel over from the heat.
> 
>         I agree, so I wear cool party clothes like Pose, Lip Service(great
> inexpensive vinyl clothes usually round $60 if ya shop around for a pair of
> pants, I've spent much more on blue jeans & if your thin they make you feel
> so hot(not temp) & sexy; vinyl clothes are just soo erotic & contrary to
> popular belief are not hot), watches by Storm, Dog Pile, Hookups, Pig Pen,
> everything from Verso(my fav), sunglasses by Chris Roth, Boots by Parachoe

> watch and jacket, the value of these clothes can approach a $1000.

> it's not cool to not take a bath and not wash your clothes for a year. You

> was one and could see it if the band was still going, but it died when
> Jerry(RIP) died.
>

> 
>         Get a pair of boots, or shop around and find something that looks
> nice and feels comfortable. Most guys are clueless when it comes to
> shopping, I personally spend the entire day walking & driving from shop to
> shop to shop; from the Haight to the Castro, to downtown. Most of the time
> you cannot walk into a one store and find something different or cool. There
> are days when I do the above mentioned and don't buy anything.
> 
>         People have asked me if I shop in London, Paris, LA and New York and
> I'm so honest I always tell them no, right here in the bay area. It feels so
> good when people pay you an honest compliment.
> 
> > I feel most ravers spend all their money on drugs, and not on clothes.
> 
>         DJ's yes, but most ravers I feel no. Nice or nice expensive clothes

> 
> >That place is anywhere you want to be.

>         At clubs yes, at raves no.

Dear Brian:
Hon, I have enough money, and if I wanted more, I could easily get it.
Obviously you didn't read through my post.  Money and clothes are not
the end-all and be-all of my life.  What you don't understand is that
for many people (including people on this list who have corresponded to
me and are not taking the time to respond to your posts) is that wearing
$1000 of clothes, or worrying about what they wear, has nothing to do
with how they feel about themselves.  It has to do with what they do with
their life, not what they wear.  I appreciate that you are trying to make
people feel better about themselves, but maybe you should face the fact
that many people are not as insecure as you and don't need clothes to
make them feel cool.

obviously, you and I have differences on what we think is important to
the rave scene.  let's just leave it at that.

shamini

Brian,

FYI regardless of your intentions your post did come across as quite
infalmatory to more than just Shamini.  And its the actions/words we
must base our initial reactions on *not* what someone claims they
intended after the fact.  You make a public statement and you'll get
reactions based on it--don't expect everybody to ask you what yopu
really meant before replying publicly.

Oh, and nice/expensive/trandy/whatever clothes DON'T make someone "more
than they are".  And re-read your original post, you were judging people.

or whatever but I don't condem others for dressing any other way.

Dear Tim & All

        Yes, they do when we decide whether or not to associate with a given
individual we first see the person, unless we are blind. How they appear to
us is the first part of the equation; different people weight it very
differently. If you smell or look out of place your ability to attract/repel
another is definitely lessen/increased by the later. To say that it isn't
your just lying to yourself. 

        I feel like I'm apologizing for something I didn't do; insult
people. If you were dressed like I mentioned in the previous post, and you
walked up to me at a rave or a club and asked me my opinion; as a friend i
would tell you that I thought you either smelled if you did, and/or looked
out of place. I wouldn't lie to you and say, yeah man you look like the
shit, because that wouldn't be honest.

        I'm sorry if I offended anyone, but again it wasn't my intention,
maybe you shouldn't be so insecure. If you were offended and you say you
feel good about the way you dress, what's the difference what I say,
especially since you feel I don't have a clue; for in the end it only
matters what you think. So a so called attack from me shouldn't bother you
in the least, right.

Peace
Brian

Precedence: bulk

My oh my, what a thread (no pun intended)! Here's my $0.02, for what
it's worth:

Dress codes are very elitist, and are totally contrary to the rave
scene. As far as I'm concerned, clubs that impose standards on what
one wears are way too concerned with asthetics. I've been denied
entrance to clubs in the past for wearing jeans or sneakers. OTOH,
when I lived in New York City, I visited clubs where my date and I got
to bypass the line, and enter -- purely because of our appearance.
Whenever this happens, I choose to not go to those places again --
in both cases, the attitude of the club owners and employees just
bothered me too much.

Last year, on my birthday, my (now ex) girlfriend was denied
entrance at the Palace in Sunnyvale because she had a two-piece outfit
on. It didn't matter that she had a mere 1" of midriff showing. It
didn't matter that many other ladies entering the club were wearing
far more provocotive and revealing outfits than she. They had a hard
and fast rule, which, as the manager put it, was "to promote having a
certain clientelle at our club." And she had the audacity to turn us
away, on my birthday! Needless to say, I never have ventured near that
place again.

When I first went to raves, I dressed up for them. I also noticed that
I was paying a lot of attention to how I looked, and was concerned
over the care of my clothes (silk shirt, linen dress pants, leather
jacket), etc. All that took my attention away from the people there.
Nowadays, while I still like to look somewhat fashionable, I dress in
more comfortable and casual clothes, and focus more energy on all
those smiling faces.

PLUR,
E. Nygma	(masquarading as George -- this sendmail configuration on
		shellx.best.com really sucks!)

P.S. I love the variety of fashion in our scene. Let's keep it diverse.

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

hello all-

i'm going to speak my opinion now.  flame me privately, and keep it off the
list, as flames should be.

i've been on sfraves long enough to know that the positivity and negativity
ebb and flow dependant upon many factors that we don't understand.  but
nonetheless, there are months of nothing but positivity, followed by intense
bursts of flame war after flame war after flame war.

i need to ask if something can be done: can we take flame wars private as
soon as they neither benefit the bystandards nor relate to raving (what this
list is ostensibly about?)

i am the first to admit that about 95% of my posts are off topic.  but i am
also first to admit that i make every attempt that 95% of my posts are
positive in some way, and if they are not, they are done privately.

yes, within any family, there are good and bad times, but i am of the belief
that, for our own collective mental health, we should make every attempt to
let positivity outshine?  that does not mean smoothing over negative issues
as has been suggested; rather, it means to approach issues with... i'm
starting to preach here, and won't subject you to that.  i have made my point.

love to you all, and may you have a good day.  i will see some of you at
wish tonight.

love-

matt


matthew d. p. k. lanier
thinker, trained belly-button lint technician

     Greetings Wonderful People,
     
     I wear comfy clothes to raves because they feel good.  Some wear funky 
     clothes because they like them.  Some wear gnarly vinyl and monkey 
     boots because it feels good.  If I saw all vinyl at a rave, I would 
     puke.  If I saw all cereal box shirts I would puke.  If I saw all tye 
     dies, I would puke as well.
     
     Stop roasting each other's most beautiful attributes!!!  We're all 
     assholes in charming, unique and different ways if you dig long enough 
     to find out.  I like looking out and seeing people 16 to 60 freaking 
     out having a good time, and looking like they came from all over the 
     place to be here.
     
     I know this doesn't seem like such a big deal, but it's gotta be 
     said...
     
     Embrace diversity or we're going to end up just like everybody else.
     
     Love,
     AndyW
     
     P.S.       Sorry my gateway is rather slow, so if somebody already 
     said this I'm just agreeing...

>         Yes, they do when we decide whether or not to associate with a given
> individual we first see the person, unless we are blind. How they appear to
> us is the first part of the equation; different people weight it very
> differently. If you smell or look out of place your ability to attract/repel
> another is definitely lessen/increased by the later. To say that it isn't
> your just lying to yourself. 
> 
So the question is then, do you want to be with people who are repelled by 
sneakers?  (and since when did the idea that someone smells bad 
get associated with casual dressing?)  As I understand it, we are talking
about someone who can get into a rave and not a club by their dress...

>         I feel like I'm apologizing for something I didn't do; insult
> people. If you were dressed like I mentioned in the previous post, and you
> walked up to me at a rave or a club and asked me my opinion; as a friend i
> would tell you that I thought you either smelled if you did, and/or looked
> out of place. I wouldn't lie to you and say, yeah man you look like the
> shit, because that wouldn't be honest.

Who are you to tell people that they are out of place?  If, 'as a friend',
you feel that you have this right, then I'm sorry, but you are in fact
insulting people.  You are also judging them, something you have been
denying doing for several messages now.  
> 
>         I'm sorry if I offended anyone, but again it wasn't my intention,
> maybe you shouldn't be so insecure. If you were offended and you say you
> feel good about the way you dress, what's the difference what I say,
> especially since you feel I don't have a clue; for in the end it only
> matters what you think. So a so called attack from me shouldn't bother you
> in the least, right.
> 
This is true, but I don't think that I am responding to this issue because
of any insecurity.  I feel that you are taking on an attitude that judges
people, and your claiming that it is based on trying to help these poor
people who don't wear the right self-respecting clothing bothers me.
I thought one of the things we were achieving with the whole rave movement
is simply letting people go out and have fun in whatever form they choose,
and accepting their choice as one of the many raindrops of life.

anyway... what's a beautiful day without a bit of a storm.


-john.

Hello fellow ravers,

 Well, for the record (whose record? Nobody's ! I just like typing...) I'd
have to say I used to do the rave getup back in 92-93'.  You know, funny
hats, Bert 'n' Ernie - type shirts, anything plastikey.. But I came to
several realizations in the past years, these are:
       - The merging-into-society factor turns to nil if your trying to
escape from a busted underground.
       - The police jackability factor goes way up when your driving in the
wee hrs of the morning with such clothes on.
       - My dancing style turns my clothes into a sog stained mess,
regardless what im wearing...
       - I like dancing shirtless anyways.

But the main reason is...  

                  When I dress up nicely, I have to keep beating all the
ladies off me with a 4ft kendo bokken...


                             (ok, I lied.  But hey, we all get to dream big,
right?)

Allthough there is some validity to Brian's statement in that since my change
of clothing style 3 yrs ago, (now I wear mostly black, ang greys) I can count
the number of people actually walking up to me and socializing on one hand.
which, in a way, isn't that bad since thoses that do chat with me I tend to
keep at true and honored friends...


"Dance with me..."

Adam

Transmitted from Computer Attic
SuperCenter:  (415) 363-8100
Corporate HQ: (415) 614-7500
____________________________

At 2:03 PM -0700 8/14/96, Tony Rotundo wrote:
>Positive or negative, I really wish this list contained more rave related
>topics.  I'm really not on it to be part of a social/support group, but
>rather to (hopefully) exchange ideas and information pertaining to the Bay
>Area Rave Scene.
>
>With all due respect (for I certainly love an occassiona NRR =), even if
>100% of a person's posts are positive, if they aren't rave related to some
>degree, at some point, then they are misdirected...
>
>Teetering On the edge...
>
>Tone
>=)

I agree with Tony *completely*.

It seems that about 1 in 10 or maybe even 1 in 15 messages on this list
actually have to do with

  "Raving, the culture music and activities"

-- which would ideally include directly relavent posting related to
upcoming party info, party reviews, music and DJ info and reviews.

Rather most of the messages on this list for some time seem to have mostly
to do with

  "Raving, a 12-step support group"

I really wish there were a digested or moderated form of SFR that contained
only rave and rave culture information. I really don't care if that means
that it's dry and lacking character if that also means that the information
ratio increases. I like information. Unfortunately, it seems that the
internet is containing more and more content daily but the
content/information ratio is sinking like a dropped anchor, down, down,
down...

Until then, it's just filter SFR and all the other rave-lists that I
subscribe tointo their very own virtual dumpsters and I read them when I
have time to kill.

_____________________________________________________________________________
"The playa is closed. Please leave immediately."

>Date: Wed, 6 Dec 1995 22:20:52 -0800
>From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
>Subject: Solution to a plague that will divide us all 
>
>My brothers and sisters, 
>
>After some self-examination, and introspection, along with some of my own
brand of self-criticism, I have come to a
>conclusion;I am a hypocrite. 
>
>I have for years preached the credo, I have even lived the credo of which I
spoke, but I have come to realize, that even after
>all of this, my deep faith in my own lived convictions was but an edifice;
it must be dealt with. 
>
>Yes, I have talked, and even acted on my own behalf in this matter, but I
have NOT, I repeat, NOT taken any ACTION to
>make my deeds a reality, a tangible reality. So I confess to you, my
brothers and sisters, so that I may find some compassion
>within you, that I might find the will and strength to take that final
step. Yes, that final step from living my words, to acting on
>my words. Making my words *LIVING ACTION*. I like to call my step, LA for
short, but bear with me, please. I have
>been remiss, and I will correct my mistake with great vigor. 
>
>For years I have lived and breathed the credo, now I offer my soltution for
one and all. A solution to a plague that will,
>eventually, destroy the house we have all built. Yes, my brothers and
sisters, I am taking my credo and making it real. BBYR,
>or better said "Bathe Before You Rave", will now be a reality at every
event I attend! 
>
>For years, now I have taken showers or baths in preperation for my long
nights of crackerjacking and raving. My preperation
>has guaranteed a certain comfort level, to those around me for 8 hours
straight (or 8 hours gay as it may be) while dancing,
>and most certainly for the 4 hour brain cooldown at various dens on
iniquity (like the onld DNA). From here on in, all of you,
>especially my most odiferous, funk laden,
sosmellynotevensageorganjacansupressthaFUNK, bothers and sisters can rest
>assured, that I will act. 
>
>LABBYR - Live Action Bathe Before You Rave 
>
>I will: 
>
>-Notify my brtheren of thier funk, lest they sin against thy neighbor.
>-At holiest of holies events I will carry perfumes, soaps, and other sundry
items to releive my bretheren of thier plague, so that
>their days might be long, and odor free.
>-At holiest of holies, bring in at least 2 portable showers, and baths for
those who offend, to continue to attend. So sayeth me.
>-Provide for thy bretheren that which they may not possess; give them water
and soap.
>-Provide copius incense for those unknowing of the offense they offer their
bretheren.
>-Be kind in the notice, but quick in the delivery of the cleansing. Do unto
them, as you do unto yourself everyday.
>-Be sure to bring a high powered water hose; for some funk of thy neighbor
may require drastic measure, so sayeth me.
>-And lastly, a sprinkle a day helps keep odor away. 
>
>Oh yes my brothers and sisters, I do have a calling, and cleanliness before
raving is thy name! 
>
>Yours in the wash,
>The Reverend Chief Boot Nocka 
>
>I seal my covenant with thee, now pass the Irish Spring!

expensive brand-name clothing.  This is frontin', and I'm not saying
anything here I haven't already said to him in person in email.

it was that started this, let it work its way through.  Brian, I hope you
come on back when you've had enough riding on the high horse.

To The People Who Flamed Me(With The Exception Of Those I Successfully
Clarified My Position With):

       I offered you the opportunity to discuss your strong, insulting,
insinuating comments & feelings over the phone with me. It's been over 2.5
hours now and only one person had the guts to get back with me. If you felt
so strongly about it; why didn't you call me, what better way to resolve
this situation, huh.

        No, but you would rather cause chaos, & negativity on this list
because that's all your about and all you have to offer. I despise who and
what you are, you fake your feelings just to cause trouble and try and make
others feel bad so you can feel good, or just feel some thing. You twist
peoples words just to get a rise out of them, & I'm an easy target for that.
To say there aren't people on this list who regularly do that, is wrong
because we have a lot of them.

        If you believed in what you wrote you would call me, I feel that you
are just gut-less cowards hiding like children behind your terminals;
waiting like vultures to prey and twist anything anyone states. I honestly
hate you, and if I see you out on the scene I will be happy to just walk
away from you, this is the only time I've ever snubbed anyone or ever will.
You know nothing about peace, love, friendship, honesty and what it is to
help another.

        MEAN, HEARTLESS, JEALOUS PEOPLE LIKE YOU SUCK

        People who know me, know just what kind of person I am; a good one
who has no hate for anyone on the planet except people like you.

        I sincerely apologize to anyone who unnecessarily has to read this,
this will be my last post on this topic, and I will not offer anyone, any
suggestion on anything.

Sincerely
Brian

>> marathon dancing swirl continuously for as much as three to four DAYS.

>> to 30,000 TEENAGERS dancing around the clock, 80 percent of them under
>> the influece of drugs.
>>         Another sign of the times is the a surge in use of MDMA, a
>> laboratory-synthesized variant of a hallucinogen that naturally occurs in
>> the body.  It's the new drug of choice among those who formerly ingested
>> LSD, snd went on to pursue chemical-free spiritual awareness.  Also known
>> as Ecstasy, it's a cross between a psychadelic and an amphetamine; in the
>> majority of users creates a sense of loving presence and an improved
>> reorientation toward intimate relationships.  And it deepend meditative
>> calmness.
>>         A 1987 survey of Stanford University students showed that 39
>> percent had taken MDMA at least once.  By the end of the 1980s, an
>> estimated 10,000 doses per month were in circulation in the US; by 1993,
>> six million doses a year were being manufactured in home-based
>> laboratories..."

I didn't go to nation for some reasons, and I didn't read all my mail yet so
don't get all upset if you've heard this 10000000000 times before.
   I kept hearing rumors about how there was going to be a Ravve documentary
filmed at Nation, and also a music video, and something else. Was this true?
If so, do you guys think that it would be negative publicity? They did
documentaries on Skateboarding, BMX, and other not so known sports and that
didn't really hurt them. But of coarse, raving is something that is looked
up upon among high school kids and most other people. I'm kinda afraid that
soon if these things happen, there won't be any parties worth going to anymore.
    I think that with all these new people, will come a new scene, vibe,
aura, and atmosphere. Everything could evolve into just another preppy drug
orgy. That's what basically most people think raves are about. Everyone I
know that don't rave think it's ll just a bunch of drugged out kids. They
think that they'll see sex everywhere because of the "E" rumors.
    People just don't know very much at all. I know I'm worrying a bit too
much, but, this is a fairly big deal were involved with, big money, tons of
people. I bet WILD 107, LIVE 105, KOME, and KMEL will be having their own
raves soon. When that happens, I'll just have to have my own, you all will
be invited. Old house music, old rave music, new rave music, and fresh dj's,
but older ones too. And a list of people who aren't allowed to enter. Dream
come true eh??? It'll happen.

Keep it alive!


Aryck

I just wanted everyone to know how much I enjoyed the free Jungle party on
Sunday. The mission rock was a great place to have it, and the crowd really
blew me away. The dancefloor was PACKED and the atmosphere was really
friendly. Raymond Roker (URB) spun a pretty good set..most of his mixing
was excellent..his mellow style lost some of the crowd, though.  I like the
mellower side, but not at 11pm. Another DJ who I didn't know was on next,
but you could tell as soon as Bukem hit the decks. Having heard Jungle in
London last year, I can honestly say that the British have a special knack
for it (it's their music after all). There's some good american Jungle
DJ's, but the way Bukem dropped those bombs...it was truly a thrill.
Oh..and being a free party didn't hurt either:)
-peace-
alex

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id SAA04815; Wed, 14 Aug 1996 18:31:03 -0700 (PDT)

Received: from smtplink.acer.com ([204.160.139.137]) by acergw3.acer.com (8.7.3/8.7.3) with SMTP id SAA23316; Wed, 14 Aug 1996 18:27:49 -0700 (PDT)

Date: Wed, 14 Aug 96 18:23:26 pst
From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9607148400.AA840072927@smtplink.acer.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, "Ronald Knegtel" <knegtel@horatio.ucsf.EDU>
Subject: Re[2]: clothes make the raver
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     ==============================================
     Well, friends, that is were the concepts of sharing and unity come 
     into play. If you want to sit down, just find a volunteer to go first 
     and the rest of us can sit on his/her naked body/clothes.  ;-)
     
     The Frying Dutchman
     =============================================
     
     
     I'll bring the 'Slip and Slide' if somebody else brings the DJ's and 
     the audio gear!
     
     
     
     So I'm writing this^ and I think, wait that could be really nifty.  
     Maybe not naked, but bathing suits or something... and then I got this 
     vision that we could throw a festive at a water park like Raging 
     Waters and have it go into the evening.  And then the Bosch-like 
     nightmare started... (you should be getting that 'starting a dream 
     sequence' wavering on your monitor now)
     
     The chill wading pool
     ---------------------
     Lots of people on GHB groping one another in a state of body buzz 
     bliss.  Lifeguards working overtime to keep people from bobbing their 
     heads underwater.  One kid starts bad tripping, screaming "there's 
     water all over me".  Poor sod... another poor raver is crying because 
     their Elmo got all wet, and doesn't feel quite right anymore.
     
     The Main Pool
     -------------
     Three foot waves make consistent audio impossible (Boom Boom Gurgle 
     Gulr-oom Boom Boom).  DJ getting pissed because splashes are getting 
     the mixer and vinyl wet.  Speakers hanging from above, water is 
     killing the bass.  Raging, but the water is making everybody tired.  
     Bike lights are shorting out everywhere, but glowsticks are going 
     strong.  Everybody on E is getting stomach cramps from drinking the 
     pool water.  Ravers wearing vinyl don't notice the difference between 
     this and a "normal" rave, <bless their waterproof souls!>   ;)   
     
     Hardcore Trance
     ---------------
     Hundreds of people running into each other as they get disoriented 
     after the combination of splashing water and strobe lights.  Nobody on 
     any drug whatsoever can tolerate it, but in the melee to get out, more 
     splashing occurs.  The scene only gets worse from there.  Eventually 
     in the interest of public safety, the promoters make this chill pool 
     number two.
     
     Drum and Bass/Dub Room
     ----------------------
     Occasional splashes of water killing spliffs left and right.  
     Outbursts of Jungle causing severe problems as water keeps splashing 
     out of pool onto the mellow Dubbers trying to get their hookah started 
     up.
     
     Other Areas
     -----------
     A small group keep alternatingly jumping into the jacuzzi and coldest 
     pool around while giggling like crazy.  Others wading around picking 
     wet flyers out of the various pool and building a large 'flyer mache' 
     artform shaped like the mound from 'Close Encounters' near one of the 
     DJs.
     
     Cops come and Threaten to Shut Off Water... and Power.
     
     As the gents walking back to their cars, some realize what an awesome 
     synergic effect cold, water AND *X* have on their manly dimensions.
     
     Everybody goes to 1015 folsum and gets pissed because bathing suits, 
     beach towels and flojos don't qualify for the dress code.
     
     And then I wake up.
     
     Hope I'll see some of you this weekend... if I can get out of this 
     cooking hell hole!!!!
     "San Jose, it's hotter than you think"
     
     Loving You!
     AndyW

After these messages, we'll be right back! Actually what you wrote below
is not a dream. We used to have "indoor-tropical-swim-paradise" parties
in Holland (the climate does not often allow outdoor events) where people
were indeed partying in their bading suits, swimming etc. You just put
everything you don't want to get wet in a locker and off you go. Sadly,
these events lost their appeal (although I never went there myself, often
too commercial for my taste) after a girl was raped at one of them...
Now back to our feature persentation:

On Wed, 14 Aug 1996, THX1138 wrote:

> 
>         I feel like I'm apologizing for something I didn't do; insult
> people. If you were dressed like I mentioned in the previous post, and you
> walked up to me at a rave or a club and asked me my opinion; as a friend i

I guess I have to jump on the bandwagon here.  What do you mean "look out 
of place?"  Are you implying that there is only one way to look i.e. "in 
place", and that's the way to go.  I don't buy that.  Why don't we work 
on our perceptions of others and not judge by appearances, instead of 
deciding that someone is "in place" or "out of place."   For crying out 
loud, it sounds like the hallway of highschool.

Subject: Re: Re[2]: 1015 on a saturday night
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 1996 03:16:00 GMT
Message-Id: <321292c2.1782849@mail.crl.com>
References: <9607148400.AA840045766@smtplink.acer.com> <9608141801.ZM3124@tempest.organic.com>
In-Reply-To: <9608141801.ZM3124@tempest.organic.com>
X-Mailer: Forte Agent .99e/32.227
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I believe you're close.  Just as people on this list sometimes
complain about a "gangsta factor" judging by the age and dress of
partygoers, so nightclub promoters wish to limit the "street" look of
their patrons with a dress code.  It's more for appearance, of course
real gangsters aren't going to be kept out.  I remember being told to
take off my baseball cap while in the Sound Factory, but I just stuck
it in my pocket until security passed.

There is always a comfort level when it comes to dress.  Just as
someone wearing a suit would feel self-conscious at a rave, I would
feel strange if overdressed (too clubby) or underdressed (grubby
sweats) at a party.  It is good that there are places to go where
people can wear Armani suits or vinyl pants and feel special but not
like a total weirdo.  Although it is fun to wear attention-getting
clothes, there are few places (Burning Man) where one is encouraged to
be strange/jarring/out-of-place looking.  But we were talking about
shoes.  As far as the no tennies policy, that would be conducive to
reducing the street factor; however, dress shoes are just way to
uncomfortable for dancing.  I haven't found any kind of non-gym shoes
that are conducive to dancing.  And Brian, remember one thing:  some
gym shoes are very stylish, beautiful, and colorful, if not dressy.
So those wearing the fabulous platform vinyl Adidas would be left
outside the club.  

*hugz* to all
David

Date: 15 Aug 1996 08:59:17 -0700
From: "Jason Green*" <Jason_Green*@quickmail.apple.com>
Subject: REALLY LAME POSTS!!!
To: "sfraves" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
X-Mailer: Mail*Link SMTP-QM 4.0.0 FC1
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Okay.

This has been said many times before, but I will say it again. 
 
WHY ARE 90% OF ALL THE POSTS ON THIS LIST MEANINGLESS BULLSHIT?

Please let me define "MEANINGLESS BULLSHIT:"
Clothes, blah, blah, movies, blah, blah, I flame you, you flame me, blah, blah, "Hey everybody!  Just wanted to say that I'm studying right now!"

WHY WASTE BANDWIDTH WITH THIS????  Ever heard of PRIVATE e-mail???

I don't think it would upset me as much as it does if people would do two things:

#1. THINK BEFORE YOU POST.
Ask yourself "Do the other 1000+ recipients REALLY need to know what I am about to shoot off into e-mail land?  It is pertinent -SFRAVES- information that people will find at least SOMEWHAT beneficial, informative, or entertaining?  Or is it just plain BLAH that people REALLY don't need to know about?"  This is where NRR comes into play - even though we really shouldn't HAVE to have this classification, because this is a RAVE RELATED e-mail list, but apparently people just can't seem to grasp that, so we have a tag for this sort of thing: NRR.  EVERYBODY KNOWS THIS TOO.

(and if you absolutely MUST post your non-rave post...)

#2. PUT A TOPIC IN YOUR HEADER.
Here are a few (among SO many) examples of posts that DO NOT CUT IT in this aspect: "Check this out!"  "Hi!"  "Wow"  "Cool!"  "Read this..."  ETC.  I'm sure you get the picture.  How is anybody supposed to tell what is inside a post such as the above described?  The only way is of course to open it up and read it.  Now, A LOT of e-mail comes in through SFRAVES, EVERYBODY in this list knows that.  So, for people like myself (and many, MANY others) it gets VERY TEDIOUS to weed through all of the untitled posts throughout the day just to try to find something of content.  It is really very simple, and I fail to see what is so hard about doing this.  This has been said, asked, requested and BEGGED before, but PEOPLE STILL DO IT.  I find it VERY inconsiderate and rude.  Especially for people that work jobs where REAL, WORK-RELATED e-mail comes in on the same program,  and you have to swim through bullshit to get to it.

PLEASE, PEOPLE!!

One last thing.  Doesn't anybody have anything BETTER to with their time besides talk back and forth about such topics?  I mean COME ON!  I know some people are at work, and have to entertain themselves somehow, but USE A LITTLE IMAGINATION HERE.  I am not in any way trying to insult anyone, but I just think that we are all very intelligent people, and we can do more with our minds besides GAB.  The rave scene/movement is a very advanced, creative, technological, spiritual thing.  SFRAVES - *RAVES*, right?  But most of the time when I am reading the posts on here, I feel like I'm stuck in a really bad episode of SAVED BY THE BELL or something.  

Disclaimer:  I am completely aware that with this post I have probably started FLAME FEST 96, but I really don't care.  The only reason I just don't unsubscribe is simply this:

THERE IS ACTUAL **RAVE-RELATED INFORMATION** ON THIS LIST - THAT IS WHY IT WAS STARTED.  I FIND THIS INFORMATION BENEFICIAL, AS DO OTHERS.  PLAIN AND SIMPLE.

Sorry for rubbing anybody the wrong way, and please everyone, be CONSIDERATE of the other 1000+ recipients on this list - YOU ARE NOT THE ONLY ONE.  YOU AND 10 FRIENDS ARE NOT THE ONLY ONES.  There are A LOT of people one here.  Respect everyone, please.

_jason_

my quota by a couple of megs...)

one last time (Tuesday night) before I leave...

Here's what Jason Green might call a really lame post, but I wanted to
express it anyway.  I found this on the Web, and wanted to send it from my
heart to yours.  Hope you enjoy:

We Have Always Known

Our souls entwined, eternally
Journeying onward, reaching for forever
Searching for what we have always known

Crawling blindly, we stumble into one another
Feeling, talking, discovering
Learning what we have always known

Lights appear to guide us
Our paths exposed - our travels explained
Paths converging, entwined forever
Showing us what we have always known

Physically apart, filled with sorrow
Fires build - warming, shrinking the distance
Reminding us we were always together
Showing us the paths we can take
Discovering what we have always known

Choices arise, worries cloud our minds
The lights dimmed, the fires cooled
The eternally entwined stretch and pull
Parting - a gap, more than physical distance between us
Ignoring what we have always known

Straying from our path, pulling apart
Crawling blindly again
The lights too dim - the fires too cool
Losing our way in the travels of our lives
Forgetting what we have always known

Our love pulls on us, rejoining the paths
Drawing us together
The lights brighten
The fires gain heat - all greater than before
Repeating what we have always known

The future calls, the distance ignored
Walking upright, our paths bathed with light
Our hearts filled with fire
Our love shining, pushing us forward
Yearning to be joined again
Reaching to hold what we have always known

One day, our paths combine
Our souls mated together
Our lights illuminating each other
Our fires warming us - the ONE
Becoming what we have always known

Our love explodes, bathing us in our beauty
A glow surrounds us - lighting our heart
lifting our soul, guiding our life
Being the ONE - living the path
Finally knowing what we have always known

Looking back -
Always knowing each other
Understanding our paths were always one
Learning the lessons we needed
Discovering our truth
Taking the journey of what we have always known

Living forward -
Never straying, never apart
Bathed in the beauty
Enhanced by the connection
ONE
Living what we have always known

- Jon L. Grimes

i think, brian didn't have in mind to deny that true beauty comes from 
the inside and what more of that kind of pc truths might be essential for 
you. yes it's true. true beauty comes from the inside.
i know him, and he would definitely be the last one to treat somebody in 
normal casual or even stinky old clothes with less friendliness than anybody 
else. (sounds hard to believe after he went off here so pissy several 
times, but its true nevertheless)
i believe he just wanted to point out, and this is my opinion too, that he 
thinks you somewhat owe it yourself and your friends to look nice at a 
party, to make that event even more special for everybody. maybe sf as the 
old hippy pit it is is not the best place to make such a remark. 
i guess the way he chose to do so was kinda strange, telling everybody 
how much time he spends to shop for clothes (man some people *work*) and 
how fucking valuable his outfit is; but hey, he was on top of the world and 
the air is kinda thinnish there.

as for me, i totally love seeing these cute kids with their baggy pants 
or little silver dresses and piercings and reflecing orange dyed hair when 
i'm out at a party and i always appreciate it if i notice somebody has made an 
attempt to look special (and i try to provide that myself), be it in a 
fashionable or individual way, successful or not. 
i like seeing hats and boas and everything, i wish we would have more of 
that stuff in berlin, where the scene is kinda more *cool* you know.
i especially like it when guys dress up a bit beyoind (sp?) the usual jeans 
t-shirt doc martens thing, in some kind of britpop kinda way, or, 
i *love* seeing guys in gaultier-like kinda gay clothing, i like seeing 
those skirts and little half-seethrough poloshirts with knitted collars and 
whatnot, and i absolutely like seeing if they do funky stuff with their 
hair, like fixing it in cute little horns or something like that.
you know this is just a little eye-thing, nothing really important, but i 
like it. i don't give a lot on brand names btw, they get worn out so 
quickly if everybody has them, so something funky from a thrift store or 
selfmade may be much nicer and more successful in many cases.
i'm really sorry brian is so pissed, i guess it's not really anybodies 
fault, i already noticed that he has his little ways when it comes to 
email correspondence, always taking things too personally.
in the end, i think, both sides opinions are not that far apart 
in that thread (compared to that socialism thing at least), so if this one 
could fall peacefully asleep, why shouldn't everybody be able to leave as 
friends now.

c'mon brian! :) smile :)

whoa can anybody tell me why my emails always grow that long?
thanks for the response on my vegas post, but actually i'm still pretty 
clueless about whats going on in vegas itself apart from the fact that it 
apparently is not much. anybody???
ulrike

hey jason (and others who don't like nrr posts)-

as offender #1 of your distaste for nrr posts, i shall disagree with you now.

for me, rave related means related to the people who rave.  if raving were
just going out to dance and listen to good music, i would agree totally with
you.  for me, it is much more than that, though.  i have observed that
raving is a lifestyle that tends to extend beyond the bounds of parties,
into your social interaction, many people's job interactions, even affecting
such personal things as their very view of the world.  raving is not the
same for everybody nor should it be, but many people have had the experience
of feeling their life change at a rave.

thus, i tend to believe in an all inclusive definition of raving which is
more of a lifestyle than a party, and many i have talked to agree with that.
you may disagree and that's fine, but it remains that people will post what
they believe to be rr material: for you, it may be party reviews; for me, it
may be the social network that has been built around the raving lifestyle.
both are good and correct, and our only disagreement comes in determining
what's rr and what's nrr.

i post alot of stuff that is rr for me, because it relates to my friends who
are ravers, or the changes in my life that came from raving, etc.  our
definitions are not the same, and we'll have to compromise on that.

thus, disagreeing with the content of many posts is fine, deleting many
posts is fine, but holding others to your standards is a losing battle.  

i hope this has come across the correct way, for i mean no offense to anyone.

love to you all, and may your day me as rr or nrr as you wish-


matt l


matthew d. p. k. lanier
thinker, trained belly-button lint technician, world record length .sig!

http://harker.coolware.com/matthew/

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Aug 15 09:59:32 1996
