From: Troy Sheets <tsheets@xanadu.cyborganic.net>
Message-Id: <199608151659.JAA18893@xanadu.cyborganic.net>
Subject: More e-mail etiquette
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 1996 09:59:24 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


This is the official Sun Microsystems policy on email, and I think
it has a lot of relevence to sfraves.  Enjoy:

---------------------------

Everyone knows that Sun lives by e-mail.  Well over a million e-mail
messages travel between Sun's domains (Corp, Eng, UK, etc.) each day.
The average message is 16,000 bytes long, so the total traffic exceeds
16 gigabytes every day.  And that doesn't include the e-mail traffic
between users in the same domain.

With numbers this large it is easy to see that Sun not only lives by
e-mail, we could die by it as well.  It is necessary, therefore, to
occasionally remind everyone about proper e-mail usage.  This is that
reminder.

Please keep these things in mind as you use e-mail for your work and
pleasure:

1. MESSAGE SIZE
We often think of e-mail as virtually instantaneous.  How many times do
we send documents to people while talking to them on the phone and
expect them to receive it within a few seconds?  It is easy to forget
that there are limits to what our e-mail system can do.  It does take
longer to send large messages.  For example, a 10MB (~10 million bytes)
report attached to an e-mail message will take at least 24 minutes to
go over a 56Kb link to a small office.  All traffic over that link will
be affected and will increase the time required to deliver the
message.  We have seen people attempting to send up to 40MB attachments
in e-mail, and we are starting to impose 5MB limits on the systems that
handle inter-domain e-mail.  If you have a message larger than 5MB you
need to find a different way, such as ftp or a web page, to share that
information.

2. INFORMATION FORMAT
Information format is often related to message size.  Graphics, word
processor documents, and audio files can be very large.  Are they worth
it?  If you are sending a 500,000 byte postscript file of three slides,
each of which has five lines of 20 characters each, the answer is
probably no unless the recipient needs to print them out on
transparencies to use for a presentation.  Non-ASCII formats also
require special software to process them.  If your recipient doesn't
have the right software then they cannot use the information.  Keep in
mind that more and more employees are working on laptops or remotely
connected in ways that don't allow them to run many of the applications
that we take for granted.  If special formatting is required or adds
something important, then use it.  But if you can get your message
across in plain text in the body of the message it will get there
faster and be more easily used by everyone.


3. MULTIPLIERS
If you send an e-mail attachment that is 1MB in size to 100 users it
will consume 100MB of disk space around the company.  If all of those
users share a single mailbox server, which is very common in the field,
then you could quickly consume 100MB of disk space on a single
machine.

When a mailbox server runs out of disk space it often starts bouncing
e-mail until the problem is fixed.  Additionally, the users cannot fix
the problem themselves because they cannot even delete messages!  So it
is very important that you consider the multiplier effect when you send
out large messages.


4. KNOW YOUR AUDIENCE:
Much of the e-mail we send goes to mailing lists (also called aliases)
containing many users.  In addition to the multiplier effect you should
keep in mind the purpose of each mailing list and choose the correct
list for your message.  For example, if you want to sell your car (and
live in the Bay Area) you should send your e-mail to "forsale@sun.com"
and *not* to "allhome@sun.com".


5. DO NOT REPLY TO ALL
There are two major options when you reply to a message: your reply can
go to the sender only, or to everyone that received the original
message.  Your mail program uses one option or the other as the default
(you can change the default or explicitly choose which kind of reply to
use for each message).  When you are typing your reply you can look at
the top and see who the reply is going to.  Do not reply to everyone
unless everyone needs to see the reply.  In general, not everyone needs
to see your congratulatory reply about the new VP's promotion.


6. CONTEXT--BUT NOT TOO MUCH
We all get lots of e-mail.  If I get a reply that says "I agree" but
nothing else, I will have no clue as to what you are agreeing with
because I presented 3 different choices in my original message.
Conversely, if your reply says "I prefer option 2" and then you include
my entire 1000 line message and 4 attachments I'll be a bit miffed
about the waste of disk space and network bandwidth.


7. CHAIN LETTERS, CRAIG SHERGOLD, VIRUS ALERTS, ETC.
The forwarding of chain letters is against company policy.  They are a
complete and total waste of Sun's computer and network resources (isn't
that redundant?).  I've also called several 1-900 numbers and the
psychics all agree that the risk associated with not forwarding chain
letters is so small that you cannot assume that your broken leg is in
any way related.

Virtually all of the Good Samaritan pleas (send a postcard or hat or
letter or whatever to some poor waif in a hospital in some foreign
country or Texas so they can get into the "Guinness Book of World
Records" for collecting the most postcards, hats, or letters) are
hoaxes.  If you can't verify the truth of the request for yourself by
calling the recipient then it is a hoax.  And did you ever notice that
the person who forwards the request never claims to have verified it
for themselves?  It is always a "friend" who has verified it.

Finally, if there is a real virus threat you will be notified of it by
our own Network Security Group.  If you think that you are the first to
hear about some threat, don't send it to everyone in your office, send
it to "nsg@Sun.COM".  They will investigate it and make any needed
announcement.


8. NOBLE CAUSES AND JOYOUS OR UNFORTUNATE EVENTS
There are many noble causes that deserve support, and Sun employees are
known for their caring and generosity.  Similarly, from time to time
our co-workers experience things that are wonderful (birth of a baby,
promotion, anniversary, winning the lottery, etc.) or tragic (death of
family member, death of self, serious illness, etc.).  If e-mail
arrived via a large mailing list for each one of these causes and
events we would all be quickly overwhelmed, so please avoid the use of
building or area aliases to announce these things.

If the cause you wish to support is large enough in scope you should
ask Corporate Affairs to sponsor and announce it.  If it is not that
large, use fliers, special interest aliases, or special-interest
newsgroups to publicize it.  For personal events, send e-mail to the
person's immediate co-workers and friends only.



SUMMARY
E-mail is an important tool for running our business.  But like any
tool is can be misused, overused, and abused.  The above guidelines are
intended to help you avoid being labeled as an abuser of e-mail.  If
everyone follows these guidelines maybe we'll hear fewer people
complaining in the hallway about how much useless e-mail they have to
go through each day.

tsheets@schwa.eng.sun.com                  <- Official Use Only
http://www.cyborganic.com/People/tsheets   <- Instant Content
troys-list@schwa.eng.sun.com               <- Inquire Within

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" Beats and
       atmospherics w/DJ Seth. KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Randy Cone said:

> Grow up.

No, Jason does have a good point, even if not phrased in the
most diplomatic of terms.

As a user of Hyperreal as a development tool, I'd like to request
that people read over the following guidelines, which apply to
*all* email lists:

	- is your post relevant to the purpose of the list?
	- have you made more than two posts to the list today?
	- is your message better suited for private email?

Those questions, I believe, are fair and reasonable.  The net, like
anything else, is a finite resource :)

Thanks,

	Sami

I have tried to send this a few times but I have not seen it come back so
here you go...


I suggest reading the initial Welcome to SFRaves message you get when you
subscribe to the list. I recently had to resub to the list and I actually
read the Welcome message, I havn't seen it in a long time. To my surprise
90%-95% of the post on here are all off subject. The welcome message explain
what is rave related or not. Most all of the people on here, including
myself love to hear about other things that happen to us that are not rave
related. But for those that don't want to hear it or see the flames all over
the place, they have to live with it if they want to stay subbed on this
list. I know there is the delete key, but the should have to be deleting
10-20 post that envolve 2 or 3 people flaming each other publicly. So let
have some respect for everyone and take it off the list and make it private.
If someone want to read the flames then they should ask to be included in
there flame war. The CC: is good at times, but lets not over use it. We
don't need to include sfraves in every single post. I kinda like the flames
myself, it gives me a better and true understanding about what kind of
people are on the list and how they truly are as a person.

Anyway that's my 2 bits on this matter...


Tim (knucklehead)

they do provide any additional info.

>5. DO NOT REPLY TO ALL
please please please do not reply to all (esp. when i am one of the cc:'s)
nothing is more irritating that getting your name in the cc: list at the
start of a flame war and getting multiple copies of everything. :(

>6. CONTEXT--BUT NOT TOO MUCH
this has to be my biggest complaint. if you are responding to specific parts
of a message, then cut out the irrelevant stuff. if not, at least chop off
the other person's 20-line ascii signature file.
we owe it to organic.com to not suck up too much of their bandwidth, as they
are providing it to us for free use.

>Okay.
>
>This has been said many times before, but I will say it again. 
> 
>WHY ARE 90% OF ALL THE POSTS ON THIS LIST MEANINGLESS BULLSHIT?
>
>Please let me define "MEANINGLESS BULLSHIT:"
>Clothes, blah, blah, movies, blah, blah, I flame you, you flame me, blah,
blah, "Hey everybody!  Just wanted to say that I'm studying right now!"
>
>WHY WASTE BANDWIDTH WITH THIS????  Ever heard of PRIVATE e-mail???
>
>I don't think it would upset me as much as it does if people would do two
things:
>
>#1. THINK BEFORE YOU POST.
>Ask yourself "Do the other 1000+ recipients REALLY need to know what I am
about to shoot off into e-mail land?  It is pertinent -SFRAVES- information
that people will find at least SOMEWHAT beneficial, informative, or
entertaining?  Or is it just plain BLAH that people REALLY don't need to
know about?"  This is where NRR comes into play - even though we really
shouldn't HAVE to have this classification, because this is a RAVE RELATED
e-mail list, but apparently people just can't seem to grasp that, so we have
a tag for this sort of thing: NRR.  EVERYBODY KNOWS THIS TOO.
>
>(and if you absolutely MUST post your non-rave post...)
>
>#2. PUT A TOPIC IN YOUR HEADER.
>Here are a few (among SO many) examples of posts that DO NOT CUT IT in this
aspect: "Check this out!"  "Hi!"  "Wow"  "Cool!"  "Read this..."  ETC.  I'm
sure you get the picture.  How is anybody supposed to tell what is inside a
post such as the above described?  The only way is of course to open it up
and read it.  Now, A LOT of e-mail comes in through SFRAVES, EVERYBODY in
this list knows that.  So, for people like myself (and many, MANY others) it
gets VERY TEDIOUS to weed through all of the untitled posts throughout the
day just to try to find something of content.  It is really very simple, and
I fail to see what is so hard about doing this.  This has been said, asked,
requested and BEGGED before, but PEOPLE STILL DO IT.  I find it VERY
inconsiderate and rude.  Especially for people that work jobs where REAL,
WORK-RELATED e-mail comes in on the same program,  and you have to swim
through bullshit to get to it.
>
>PLEASE, PEOPLE!!
>
>One last thing.  Doesn't anybody have anything BETTER to with their time
besides talk back and forth about such topics?  I mean COME ON!  I know some
people are at work, and have to entertain themselves somehow, but USE A
LITTLE IMAGINATION HERE.  I am not in any way trying to insult anyone, but I
just think that we are all very intelligent people, and we can do more with
our minds besides GAB.  The rave scene/movement is a very advanced,
creative, technological, spiritual thing.  SFRAVES - *RAVES*, right?  But
most of the time when I am reading the posts on here, I feel like I'm stuck
in a really bad episode of SAVED BY THE BELL or something.  
>
>Disclaimer:  I am completely aware that with this post I have probably
started FLAME FEST 96, but I really don't care.  The only reason I just
don't unsubscribe is simply this:
>
>THERE IS ACTUAL **RAVE-RELATED INFORMATION** ON THIS LIST - THAT IS WHY IT
WAS STARTED.  I FIND THIS INFORMATION BENEFICIAL, AS DO OTHERS.  PLAIN AND
SIMPLE.
>
>Sorry for rubbing anybody the wrong way, and please everyone, be
CONSIDERATE of the other 1000+ recipients on this list - YOU ARE NOT THE
ONLY ONE.  YOU AND 10 FRIENDS ARE NOT THE ONLY ONES.  There are A LOT of
people one here.  Respect everyone, please.
>
>_jason_
>
>
>

Received: from [206.86.235.114] (lesliea.vip.best.com [206.86.235.114]) by shellx.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id MAA07694 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 15 Aug 1996 12:35:51 -0700
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 1996 12:35:51 -0700
Message-Id: <v01530503ac7ef8c07f81@[206.86.235.114]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: lesliea@best.com (Leslie Ayres)
Subject: More on REALLY LAME POSTS!!!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Jason is right on.

I, who have felt that being a part of SFRaves has changed my life in a very
positive way, have been contemplating leaving this list because of the
volume of crap that has been rampant lately.

Jason is right.  We have to think before we post, and self-edit the content
for general interest.  If you have a need to say "it's a beautiful day and
I love you all" create a personal sublist of people who actually know you,
and will be happy to hear from you.  It's a lovely thought, but if 500
people each spend 15 seconds to read that message, that's over two hours of
other people's time taken on ... sorry ... non-productive fluff.

I also concur that flame wars are private and should remain that way ...
Many of these discussions shouldn't happen in the first place, but copying
them to the entire list is ridiculous ... and it's NO accident ... when I
see flaming messages sent by one individual to another, with a cc to
SFRaves, I have to wonder what twisted psyche is at work.  Hey, you want to
fight and be nasty?  Don't copy me on it, I don't want to watch, and
frankly it just makes those involved look foolish, mean-spirited, and
ignorant.

Yes, we are like a community, and yes, there are subjects that may not be
directly rave-related that are of interest to a majority of people in our
group. Jokes and stuff can really be fun.  But use your head, and be clear
in your message heading what's in there.

Half the messages I write, I delete before sending because I ask myself
"does this message really add anything new to this discussion" and "is it
worth the time to ask people to read it?"  .... and the answer is NO half
the time.... maybe if we all judged our offerings a little more
objectively, the volume of crap would die down....

Hope to see things improving soon... or   : (

Leslie

>
>This has been said many times before, but I will say it again.
>
>WHY ARE 90% OF ALL THE POSTS ON THIS LIST MEANINGLESS BULLSHIT?

>blah, "Hey everybody!  Just wanted to say that I'm studying right now!"

>WHY WASTE BANDWIDTH WITH THIS????  Ever heard of PRIVATE e-mail???

>I don't think it would upset me as much as it does if people would do two
>things:
>
>#1. THINK BEFORE YOU POST.
>Ask yourself "Do the other 1000+ recipients REALLY need to know what I am
>about to shoot off into e-mail land?  It is pertinent -SFRAVES-
>information that people will find at least SOMEWHAT beneficial,
>informative, or entertaining?  Or is it just plain BLAH that people REALLY
>don't need to know about?"  This is where NRR comes into play - even
>though we really shouldn't HAVE to have this classification, because this
>is a RAVE RELATED e-mail list, but apparently people just can't seem to
>grasp that, so we have a tag for this sort of thing: NRR.  EVERYBODY KNOWS
>THIS TOO.
>
>(and if you absolutely MUST post your non-rave post...)
>
>#2. PUT A TOPIC IN YOUR HEADER.
>Here are a few (among SO many) examples of posts that DO NOT CUT IT in
>this aspect: "Check this out!"  "Hi!"  "Wow"  "Cool!"  "Read this..."
>ETC.  I'm sure you get the picture.  How is anybody supposed to tell what
>is inside a post such as the above described?  The only way is of course
>to open it up and read it.  Now, A LOT of e-mail comes in through SFRAVES,
>EVERYBODY in this list knows that.  So, for people like myself (and many,
>MANY others) it gets VERY TEDIOUS to weed through all of the untitled
>posts throughout the day just to try to find something of content.  It is
>really very simple, and I fail to see what is so hard about doing this.
>This has been said, asked, requested and BEGGED before, but PEOPLE STILL
>DO IT.  I find it VERY inconsiderate and rude.  Especially for people that
>work jobs where REAL, WORK-RELATED e-mail comes in on the same program,
>and you have to swim through bullshit to get to it.
>
>PLEASE, PEOPLE!!
>
>One last thing.  Doesn't anybody have anything BETTER to with their time
>besides talk back and forth about such topics?  I mean COME ON!  I know
>some people are at work, and have to entertain themselves somehow, but USE
>A LITTLE IMAGINATION HERE.  I am not in any way trying to insult anyone,
>but I just think that we are all very intelligent people, and we can do
>more with our minds besides GAB.  The rave scene/movement is a very
>advanced, creative, technological, spiritual thing.  SFRAVES - *RAVES*,
>right?  But most of the time when I am reading the posts on here, I feel
>like I'm stuck in a really bad episode of SAVED BY THE BELL or something.
>
>
>Disclaimer:  I am completely aware that with this post I have probably
>started FLAME FEST 96, but I really don't care.  The only reason I just
>don't unsubscribe is simply this:
>
>THERE IS ACTUAL **RAVE-RELATED INFORMATION** ON THIS LIST - THAT IS WHY IT
>WAS STARTED.  I FIND THIS INFORMATION BENEFICIAL, AS DO OTHERS.  PLAIN AND
>SIMPLE.
>
>Sorry for rubbing anybody the wrong way, and please everyone, be
>CONSIDERATE of the other 1000+ recipients on this list - YOU ARE NOT THE
>ONLY ONE.  YOU AND 10 FRIENDS ARE NOT THE ONLY ONES.  There are A LOT of
>people one here.  Respect everyone, please.
>
>_jason_

On Wed, 14 Aug 1996, THX1138 wrote:

> ps People take pride in your appearance for no one else will, it's a
> statement of how much you care about you, and to a lesser extent what other
> people think. Once again believe in yourself, hey I'm worth clothes that
> cost twice what I can afford, how bout you.

	A statement about how much I care about me or a statement about
how much I want other people to think that I care about myself? Do I care
about myself? There are others to do this than to "dress to impress". To
each their own. Should I pull my dreads out because I do not care about my
hair being styled? I happen to like my comfy black jeans that have been
with me through the posh hotels and Scottish glens alike. Traveling with
club clothes is impractical for me and it eats up money that I could spend
on records, plane tickets, or gas for the generator. I would think expense
impressive clothes might make me feel good if I was looking for external
validation of my own worth, especially in things like watches. Why should 
I participate in a game I dropped out of a long time ago? And what right 
does anyone have to demand that I play it? I will probably think some 
clothes are cool like the reflective jacket Brian has (unless you are 
going to something that one has to be stealthy at because a glowing 
silver jacket would only be stealthy against an aluminium building) but 
they are not something I will wear so why buy one? 

dave

(.......... thinking......)

Ok, now I got it.  

The diversity of this list is truly amazing.  After reading the Horiscope
posts (which, BTW, was TOTALLY NRR) one can tend to realize that about 90% of
the mail generated is by >10% of those subscribed...  Why?  Well, I'll tell
you... 
Because most of thoses subscribed are hesitant to post, mainly cos of
retailation posts like yours, Mr. Green.  

I was unawares of the Limit of 2 posts-per-day as listed by the Hyperreal
staff...  And as for Rave related, well are we all not ravers? Dosen't that
thread keep us alive.  Through NNR posts this week alone I:  -Found other
ravers in my city
    -Introduced, and welcomed new ravers to the list
    -Found out about two underground venues this weekend

So I ask the "silent majority"  yea, you that guy or gal who sits behind that
terminal to voice up...  I do the same thing to... Read a post and, want to
answer and then say, "Nah, it dosen't matter anyways".

Well it dose.  really.  

And if you "the silent ones " out there choose not to respond, well, I guess
im wrong and will gracefully slip back into hibernation. Till the list
becomes more liberal (which will happen someday)...

Note: this isnt a post for you: Tim (knucklehead), Amy, Kaysee, BA, Geoff
white, Matt K, Brian D. nor the other "Regulars"  You have broken through the
shyness level.  But the ones that less frequently post, or not at all.  waht
do you think of all of this?  is it cool?  a waste of time? Please voice your
opinions...

Aside from dancing, this is really my only other mode of expression, since
I'm not too sociable to ones I don't really know...

***Standing in the shadows***

On Thu, 15 Aug 1996, Leslie Ayres wrote:

> I also concur that flame wars are private and should remain that way ...
> Many of these discussions shouldn't happen in the first place, but copying
> them to the entire list is ridiculous ... and it's NO accident ... when I
> see flaming messages sent by one individual to another, with a cc to
> SFRaves, I have to wonder what twisted psyche is at work.  Hey, you want to
> fight and be nasty?  Don't copy me on it, I don't want to watch, and
> frankly it just makes those involved look foolish, mean-spirited, and
> ignorant.

Don't say something in public that you do not wish public response on. 

If you are going to make controversial, assinine, or just plain mean 
statements to the entire list, expect for them to be dealt with in a 
public fashion.

Nobody bitches when people post flowery, unsubstantial, and wholly 
"inappropriate(per the charter of the list)" messages. These also go to 
the same number of people as the flames do.   

I like the flowery, "inappropriate" messages once in a while. I like the 
flames once in a while also. When I find either in amount greater than my 
liking, I hit the D key. 

This issue has been brought up again and again. The charter of this list 
would seem to be outdated, and in need of revision, to reflect the more 
"communal" nature of this list which encompasses a lot more now than it 
did at its inception. 

                                        Black Adder

Just checked out Burning Man's home page.  One of the attractions is 
entitled "RAVE!"  Here will be the six soundsystems (almost all from the 
Bay Area!) positioned in a _quarter-mile_ radius.  Does this alarm anyone 
else?  (Much bleeding noise as pounding techno will carry VERY well over 
the stillness of the open desert).  Basically, six competing sound 
systems grouped together in a small space.  

Also, they have named this area the "Techno Ghetto" and write that here, 
in an "overpopulated underfunded area", "loitering youths will form rival 
gangs."  Although I know this is in keeping with this year's theme of 
"Hell," I find the allusion of a rave camp to rival gangs inappropriate 
at best, and antithetical to the message of the rave movement.

I don't want to nitpick, but I get the feeling that the "RAVE!" area 
(including choice of its name, "RAVE!" sounds a tad cheesy-commercialized) 
was designed by someone who is not too familiar with our subculture.

Still going,
N

On Thu, 15 Aug 1996, Nancy Shaw wrote:

> And how come no-one ever does this in the East Bay?  Say, Berkeley 
> Marina?  ;>

	There is a little story about this that I have not heard the full 
version of. A little while back, there was a daytime party in the Marina. 
Cops came round to check it out and caught some people underage drinking. 
That lost the Marina for any use with amplified sound. The aquatic park 
is off limits as well without permits (so there is a fee and its is 
restricted to certain hours, and if you apply for a permit, I think you 
will need to get around the precidence of underage drinking now). East 
bay locations are difficult because there are residental areas everywhere 
and you will generate noise complaints if you are not on EBMUD land. 
EBMUD land though is patrolled and few people are willing to take the 
chance or manage a shuttle into the party.... Shuttles have been run 
before, but they are difficult to manage especially in the morning when 
300+ people all want to leave on the NEXT shuttle...

dave

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Aug 15 13:53:28 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id NAA13647; Thu, 15 Aug 1996 13:53:28 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from netcom22.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id NAA13640; Thu, 15 Aug 1996 13:53:25 -0700 (PDT)
Received: (from larryc@localhost) by netcom22.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id NAA10245; Thu, 15 Aug 1996 13:53:14 -0700
From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)
Message-Id: <199608152053.NAA10245@netcom22.netcom.com>
Subject: The (semi) lurker option
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 1996 13:53:14 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

[ to SFRaves list ]

 Hi, this is the "departed" Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com. Given the
recent posts about the ever-green topics of appropriate posts, ratio
of posters to the total number of SFRaves subscribers, and flames, I
thought I'd share some of my recent SFRaves experience .

 Some of you folks might remember that I had announced that I was going to 
unsubscribe from SFRaves. I didn't go into all the reasons, but here
are the main ones:

1. Need more time to concentrate on self-improvement and other "chores".  2. Reading about upcoming parties too tempting - I go to rave, makes for less time to devote to 1. 
3. Reading posts involving opinions, politics, philosophy, good/bad
   clothing, "who's a gangsta?", etc. too time consuming - also 
   tempting - if I get involved in the discussion, even in a passive
   read-only way, takes up too much time and mental energy that could
   be put to better use.
4. Too many people posting ( Hey, what's  Larry mean by that? ). It
   just gets too confusing to me to keep all of youse guys and gals 
   identified and individualized in my poor head! I'm sure if I had a 
   more extrovert personality , I could remember distincly everyone's 
   name/birthday/favorite shoes/favorite intoxicant/favorite diety/etc., 
   but the sheer number of folks gets me dizzzzyyy !...!...! 

But, having been away for a few weeks, I found: 

A. I miss reading the "nice" and "positive" posts . It was like having 
   gotten used to the voices of friends and neighbors in the ambient 
   soundtrack of my life, and to then have those voices go silent.  
B. I was still interested in reading people's reactions to the weekend's 
   raves, especially for "hard" information ( "Promoter X really screwed 
   up","the location was really beautiful","too crowded", etc ) and folks 
   feelings .  

So, how am I handling being subscribed to SFRAves again? 

DELETE/DELETE/DELETE - Thank god for the "Subject:" line - once I see 
  what conversational path a subject is going, I can get pretty ruthless
  with the DELETE on any future posts along that same line. Since I do
  archiving of my own email, it trims my mail storage requirements 
  quite well.  Also helps to keep me out of the flame wars. 

SFRAVES DOESN'T "NEED" MY OPINION - There are more than enough folks on 
  SFRaves to comment on any given topic, my input is not all that unique 
  or irreplacable. With this attitude, I have successfully restrained myself
  from making at least 8 posts which would have been variations on "me too!",
  "try this brand of ***", "that's YOUR opinion, here's the FACTS", or
  "you're an ignoramus with a poor grasp of truth, society, spirituality, 
  and/or physics" within the last two weeks. ( this post being a major lapse! ).


 ... that's my opinion ...

 Larry the Lurker/larryc@netcom.com

	id NAA20068; Thu, 15 Aug 1996 13:39:09 -0700

From: simitzis@netcom.com (Steve Simitzis)
Message-Id: <199608152039.NAA20068@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-reply-to: <1194643421.23870670@compattic.com> (aguevara@compattic.com)

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> From: aguevara@compattic.com (Adam Guevara)
> Reply-To: aguevara@compattic.com
> Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
> Date: 15 Aug 1996 20:37:52 GMT
> Organization: Computer Attic
> Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
> Precedence: bulk
> 
> 
[snip]
>
> I was unawares of the Limit of 2 posts-per-day as listed by the Hyperreal
> staff...  And as for Rave related, well are we all not ravers? Dosen't that
> thread keep us alive.  Through NNR posts this week alone I:  -Found other
> ravers in my city
>     -Introduced, and welcomed new ravers to the list
>     -Found out about two underground venues this weekend

Well, not to throw the ol' "me too!!!", but I'm going to have to
second that. Probably what makes this list esp. appealing is the fact
that we all, for the most part, live in the Bay Area. Unlike other
mailing lists, where one person may be from Nebraska and another from
Italy, we all actually have a chance to *meet* each other in various
social settings and possibly form future friendships...

Agreed, I have also met people through this list that I would not
ordinarily have said "hi" to at a party, and this is due to the fact
that I liked something that person had to say, and wanted to get
to know him/her better.

Before this list, I was a reader of alt.rave - Take a minute and
point your newsreaders to this unfortunate newsfroup. After
reading a zillion posts about "was jesus gay???" or "MAKE MONEY
FAST!!!!", you'll return to SFRaves appreciating all of "crap"
on the list.

No matter how loosely, it's all RR, because it's about us and
our lifestyles as ravers.

New-ish to the Bay Area, and new-ish to the list,

Steve

Date: 8/15/96 9:17 AM
To: Jason Green*
From: Eric P. Peterson
Here's what Jason Green might call a really lame post, but I wanted to
express it anyway.  I found this on the Web, and wanted to send it from my
heart to yours.  Hope you enjoy:

We Have Always Known

Our souls entwined, eternally
Journeying onward, reaching for forever
Searching for what we have always known

Crawling blindly, we stumble into one another
Feeling, talking, discovering
Learning what we have always known

Lights appear to guide us
Our paths exposed - our travels explained
Paths converging, entwined forever
Showing us what we have always known

Physically apart, filled with sorrow
Fires build - warming, shrinking the distance
Reminding us we were always together
Showing us the paths we can take
Discovering what we have always known

Choices arise, worries cloud our minds
The lights dimmed, the fires cooled
The eternally entwined stretch and pull
Parting - a gap, more than physical distance between us
Ignoring what we have always known

Straying from our path, pulling apart
Crawling blindly again
The lights too dim - the fires too cool
Losing our way in the travels of our lives
Forgetting what we have always known

Our love pulls on us, rejoining the paths
Drawing us together
The lights brighten
The fires gain heat - all greater than before
Repeating what we have always known

The future calls, the distance ignored
Walking upright, our paths bathed with light
Our hearts filled with fire
Our love shining, pushing us forward
Yearning to be joined again
Reaching to hold what we have always known

One day, our paths combine
Our souls mated together
Our lights illuminating each other
Our fires warming us - the ONE
Becoming what we have always known

Our love explodes, bathing us in our beauty
A glow surrounds us - lighting our heart
lifting our soul, guiding our life
Being the ONE - living the path
Finally knowing what we have always known

Looking back -
Always knowing each other
Understanding our paths were always one
Learning the lessons we needed
Discovering our truth
Taking the journey of what we have always known

Living forward -
Never straying, never apart
Bathed in the beauty
Enhanced by the connection
ONE
Living what we have always known

- Jon L. Grimes



------------------ RFC822 Header Follows ------------------

--------------------------------------
Date: 8/15/96 10:40 AM
To: Jason Green*
From: Sami Khoury
Randy Cone said:

> Grow up.

No, Jason does have a good point, even if not phrased in the
most diplomatic of terms.

As a user of Hyperreal as a development tool, I'd like to request
that people read over the following guidelines, which apply to
*all* email lists:

	- is your post relevant to the purpose of the list?
	- have you made more than two posts to the list today?
	- is your message better suited for private email?

Those questions, I believe, are fair and reasonable.  The net, like
anything else, is a finite resource :)

Thanks,

	Sami

> This issue has been brought up again and again. The charter of this list 
> would seem to be outdated, and in need of revision, to reflect the more 
> "communal" nature of this list which encompasses a lot more now than it 
> did at its inception. 

Just because a few people have decided to willfully, or out of
ignorance, ignore the established purpose of this list, doesn't
make that purpose outdated.  Seeing  a lot of garbage by
the "No Littering" sign doesn't invalidate that sign's intention.
I would *guess* that if asked, most of the few hundred lurkers here
would prefer posters to at least try to stay true to the original 
charter. 

Because SFRaves doesn't have much of a police force, it's citizens
are free to abuse this resource and commit heinous crimes of
expression against each other and the community.  Perhaps, like a
good rave or succesful TAZ, we can self-regulate and generate some
kind of harmonious vibe.  If not, we can try to make it happen in 
other places, or wait for circumstances that would make our
involvement more worthwhile.

Lee

>>>Stay away from beans and cabbage!
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>Subject: Darwin Awards
>>>>
>>>>These are nearly always granted posthumously. This citation is bestowed upon
>>>>(the remains of) that individual, who through single-minded self-sacrifice,
>>>>has done the most to remove undesirable elements from the human gene pool.
>>>>
>>>> ----------------------------------------------------------------
>>>>[San Jose Mercury News]
>>>>An unidentified man, using a shotgun like a club to break a former
>>>>girlfriend's windshield, accidentally shot himself to death when the gun
>>>>discharged, blowing a hole in his gut.
>>>>
>>>> ----------------------------------------------------------------
>>>>[Hickory Daily Record, 12-21-92] Ken Charles Barger, 47, accidentally shot
>>>>himself to death in December in Newton, N. C., when, awakening to the sound
>>>>of a ringing telephone beside his bed, he reached for the phone but grabbed
>>>>instead a Smith & Wesson .38 Special, which discharged when he drew it to
>>>>his ear.
>>>>
>>>> ----------------------------------------------------------------
>>>>[News of the Weird, 18 May 93, San Jose Mercury News] A 24-year-old salesman
>>>>from Hialeah, Fla., was killed near Lantana, Fla., in March when his car
>>>>smashed into a pole in the median strip of Interstate 95 in the middle of
>>>>the afternoon. Police said that the man was traveling at 80 MPH and, judging
>>>>by the sales manual that was found open and clutched to his chest, had been
>>>>busy reading.
>>>>
>>>> ----------------------------------------------------------------
>>>>[Unknown, 25 March 1993] A Vapid Death
>>>>
>>>>A terrible diet and room with no ventilation are being blamed for the death
>>>>of a man who was killed by his own gas. There was no mark on his body but
>>>>autopsy showed large amounts of methane gas in his system. His diet had
>>>>consisted primarily of beans and cabbage (and a couple other things). It was
>>>>just the right combination of foods.
>>>>
>>>>It appears that the man died in his sleep from breathing from the poisonous
>>>>cloud that was hanging over his bed. Had he been outside or had his windows
>>>>opened it wouldn't have been fatal but the man was shut up in his near
>>>>airtight bedroom. He was ``...a big man with a huge capacity for creating
>>>>[this deadly gas].'' Three of the rescue workers got sick and one was
>>>>hospitalized.
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> ----------------------------------------------------------------
>>>>[Reuters, Mississauga, Ontario] Man slips, falls 23 stories to his death.
>>>>
>>>>A man cleaning a bird feeder on his balcony of his condominium apartment in
>>>>this Toronto suburb slipped and fell 23 stories to his death, police said
>>>>Monday.
>>>>
>>>>Stefan Macko, 55, was standing on a wheeled chair Sunday when the accident
>>>>occurred, said Inspector D'Arcy Honer of the Peel regional    police.
>>>>
>>>>"It appears the chair moved and he went over the balcony," Honer said.
>>>>"It's one of those freak accidents. No foul play is suspected."
>>>>
>>>> ----------------------------------------------------------------
>>>>[UPI, Toronto] Police said a lawyer demonstrating the safety of windows in a
>>>>downtown Toronto skyscraper crashed through a pane with his shoulder and
>>>>plunged 24 floors to his death.
>>>>
>>>>A police spokesman said Garry Hoy, 39, fell into the courtyard of the
>>>>Toronto Dominion Bank Tower early Friday evening as he was explaining the
>>>>strength of the building's windows to visiting law    students.
>>>>
>>>>Hoy previously had conducted demonstrations of window strength according to
>>>>police reports. Peter Lauwers, managing partner of the firm Holden Day
>>>>Wilson, told the Toronto Sun newspaper that Hoy was ``one of the best and
>>>>brightest'' members of the 200-man association.
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> ----------------------------------------------------------------
>>>>
>>>>[Times of London] A thief who sneaked into a hospital was scarred for life
>>>>when he tried to get a suntan.
>>>>
>>>>After evading security staff at Odstock Hospital in Salisbury, Wiltshire,
>>>>and helping himself to doctors' paging devices, the thief spotted a vertical
>>>>sunbed. He walked into the unit and removed his clothes for a 45-minute tan.
>>>>
>>>>However, the high-voltage UV machine at the hospital, which is renowned for
>>>>its treatment of burns victims, has a maximum dosage of ten seconds.  After
>>>>lying on the bed for almost 300 times the recommended maximum time the man
>>>>was covered in blisters.
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>Hours later, when the pain of the burns became unbearable, he went to
>>>>Southampton General Hospital, 20 miles away,in Hampshire. Staff became
>>>>suspicious because he was wearing a doctor's coat. After tending his wounds
>>>>they called the police.
>>>>
>>>>Southampton police said: "This man broke into Odstock and decided he fancied
>>>>a quick suntan. Doctors say he is going to be scarred for life."
>>>>

On Thu, 15 Aug 1996, Sami Khoury wrote:

> 	- have you made more than two posts to the list today?

Ok, I'm not going to tread over ground that has already been covered.
I just wanted to weigh in on excessive posters.  Ok, ok, excessive is all
relative, but I really don't think any individual should be averaging more
than a couple posts a day.  People should remeber to exercise
responsibility when practicing their freedom to post.  If you haven't
figured it out yet, some of us are MORE FREE THAN OTHERS.  Some of you
have SFRaves on ALL DAY, while at work or wherever.  Because of your
unusual time-space relationship to the list, you end up feeling the need
to post or respond to messages more frequently and more quickly than those
who might check their SFRaves mail "only" once or twice a day, and not for
hours at a time.  When you respond to a post, realize that you are
potentially silencing another opinion that may be rendered
frustratingly redundant by your zipitty-quick response (actually,
tedius redundancy seems to be a virtue on the list these days).  Also, 
you are at an unfair advantage when entering a debate -- not only do
you have more airtime, a lot of times your challenger might not even be on
the floor to answer your charges.  Think of everyone on the list as
delegates to the SFRaves convention.  Don't hog the podium.  Don't abuse
your freedom.  Don't loiter around the convention center.  Go outside...
or back to work, as it may be.  

I understand that there is more to excessive posting than boredom.  I'm
sure that lonliness and/or a sense of dislocation (age/space/etc) also
play a part.  Just understand there are limits to this medium.
Respect the freedom we have by respecting the responsibilty we share.  

Rok.  

ps.  Some of us are no longer here because they lack the privalege of
     large quotas on their accounts.  That's sad.

On Thu, 15 Aug 1996, Lee Fogel wrote:

> > This issue has been brought up again and again. The charter of this list 
> > would seem to be outdated, and in need of revision, to reflect the more 
> > "communal" nature of this list which encompasses a lot more now than it 
> > did at its inception. 
> 
> Just because a few people have decided to willfully, or out of
> ignorance, ignore the established purpose of this list, doesn't
> make that purpose outdated.  Seeing  a lot of garbage by
> the "No Littering" sign doesn't invalidate that sign's intention.
> I would *guess* that if asked, most of the few hundred lurkers here
> would prefer posters to at least try to stay true to the original 
> charter. 

Well on this I can speak from personal experience. Many moons ago, as 
some others now are, I was perturbed by the large number of "off-topic" 
posts. So, I emailed the List God, and said "List God, would you consider 
creating other mailing lists, for those that wish to discuss all the subjects 
not directly related to raving, as people are wont to do? They are ignoring 
the commandments you have given us." And the List God, in his greatness said 
"No." Several moons after this, after a continually increasing number 
of off topic posts, I again posed the question to the List God. And again the 
List God, in his greatness, said unto me "Nay, it shall not be so. For 
SFRaves is a community, and as a community, is about much more than raving." So 
realizing the futility of my meager efforts, and my unworthiness to 
trouble the list God, I too joined the unwashed masses and experienced the 
guilty pleasure of posting what once were "off-topic" messages. 



                                        Black Adder 


P.S. The commandmants really need to be changed to reflect this....

On Thu, 15 Aug 1996, Nancy Shaw wrote:

> Just checked out Burning Man's home page.  One of the attractions is 
> entitled "RAVE!"  Here will be the six soundsystems (almost all from the 
> Bay Area!) positioned in a _quarter-mile_ radius.  Does this alarm anyone 
> else?  (Much bleeding noise as pounding techno will carry VERY well over 
> the stillness of the open desert).  Basically, six competing sound 
> systems grouped together in a small space.  

	First off, a quarter mile is not a small space when the systems 
are pointing on an outward vector so sound mixing should not be a problem 
(except maybe for an ambient system). And why does this idea of competing 
sound systems come into play. Six systems is not a huge festival, and 
only we in the Bay Area consider more than one system to be competing. 
We have Gateway (trancy and some techno), CCC (psydelic trance), 
Spaz/etheon (live acid, more acid, and gabber), Wicked (straight out 
house), and the happening which is Thomas Trouble's thing and I am not 
sure what they are doing... Burning Man Ravecamp(tm) will have something for 
everyone, and be a place to hear sounds you haven't heard before... Get 
over this thing of competing, no one seems to think an ambient room 
"competes" with the main floor, why should it be a problem with different 
types of music...

> I don't want to nitpick, but I get the feeling that the "RAVE!" area 
> (including choice of its name, "RAVE!" sounds a tad cheesy-commercialized) 
> was designed by someone who is not too familiar with our subculture.

	Nope, it was thought up by some people from some of the sound 
systems going up. Talk to the people who thought it up. Or better yet, 
before talking about everything being commericalized, look into what you 
are talking about. How many times are people going to object to the same 
thing before they go and TALK to the people involved before they say this 
and this don't add up. In some cases I thik that is warranted as when one 
attempts to communicate with someone (like a promoter) but never gets a 
response, but no one has asked the BurningMan project where the money 
goes or who thought up a name or where the festival first came from... 
Instead, we the group of "PLUR"y people who are removed from the common 
indecenties of the normal people out there go around assuming, now how is 
that different from anyone else?!

dave

On Thu, 15 Aug 1996, Dave Bayer wrote:

> 
> 
> On Thu, 15 Aug 1996, Nancy Shaw wrote:
> 
> > Just checked out Burning Man's home page.  One of the attractions is 
> > entitled "RAVE!"  Here will be the six soundsystems (almost all from the 
> > Bay Area!) positioned in a _quarter-mile_ radius.  Does this alarm anyone 
> > else?  (Much bleeding noise as pounding techno will carry VERY well over 
> > the stillness of the open desert).  Basically, six competing sound 
> > systems grouped together in a small space.  
>

> everyone, and be a place to hear sounds you haven't heard before... Get 
> over this thing of competing, no one seems to think an ambient room 
> "competes" with the main floor, why should it be a problem with different 
> types of music...


Dave, I meant "competing" in the sense of having to share a space where 
the sounds may collide.  I didn't know they would point _outward_.  That 
makes a big difference!


> 
> > I don't want to nitpick, but I get the feeling that the "RAVE!" area 
> > (including choice of its name, "RAVE!" sounds a tad cheesy-commercialized) 
> > was designed by someone who is not too familiar with our subculture.
> 
> 	Nope, it was thought up by some people from some of the sound 
> systems going up. Talk to the people who thought it up. Or better yet, 
> before talking about everything being commericalized, look into what you 
> are talking about. 

Sorry if I was unclear.  I meant the term "rave" itself, its connotations to 
the mainstream (something I was just _about_ to write a separate post 
about, but didn't get a chance to).  I did not mean at all that the systems involved _or_ BM is commercialized.


How many times are people going to object to the same 
> thing before they go and TALK to the people involved before they say this 
> and this don't add up. In some cases I thik that is warranted as when one 
> attempts to communicate with someone (like a promoter) but never gets a

> that different from anyone else?!

first to admit if I took a humorous thing too seriously.  Yes, I wrote 
down my impressions from reading BM's descriptions without researching 
everything first.  Maybe clarification (like stating, "I may be totally 
wrong on this" or whatever) was in order.  I didn't mean to 
inadvertently insult anyone involved with BM or "RAVE!"   All props to them for 
creating something like this for everyone!

From: mikes@nit.AirTouch.COM (Mike Schneir)
Message-Id: <9608152359.AA17059@nit.AirTouch.COM>
Subject: Re: REALLY LAME POSTS
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 1996 16:59:16 -0700 (PDT)

Precedence: bulk

Ok, I'll Bite.

Personally, I sometimes enjoy the somewhat/non -rave related posts more than
reading 8000 long posts reviewing the weekend's raves (not that I don't like
those, too!)  I feel a lot closer to the people on this list (whom I haven't
even met) from the NRR posts than from the RR.  And I do feel this list is
(or has become) about the "ravers" as much as the raves.  And I like the "have agood day I love you" type posts.  It's posts like those that make me feel
there's enough love here to forgive me when I post something stupid (is that a
disclaimer?? :)  
 
I do agree that there's a problem.  Some solutions are (and most ofthese have
already been suggested.  I'm encapsulating)
 
1) Put NRR in the subject (been said many many times).  But put it at the
BEGINNING of the subject line.  My mail list shows only 30some-odd characters
of the subject line, so take a long subject, throw in a 'Re:' or two,
and I don't see the NRR at the end of the line until I read the mail.  There
should probably be more descriptors in use, like SRR (Somewhat), RAOL (Random   Act of Love), and FLAME ;)  How about something to distinguish Up and Coming
Raves, Rave Reviews, Humor, Music, General, Movies, Eating Habits,... On  
second thought, that's too structured.  F**k it, but if people could at least
be descriptive in their subject headings...
 
2) Update subject lines.  When the thread changes direction, change the subject line. 
 
3) When including other people's text, only copy what's neccessary!!!  If it's
neccessary to copy 180 lines, so be it, but if not, don't.  And don't copy  
the sig if it's in extra 50! 

4) Try to be concise.  This one is the most difficult, and I know I find myself
hard put to write short posts at 80 columns.  Long posts are great - when
they're filled with good info.
 
5)Find and use the delete key.
 
6) Flames probably should go private sooner, though I hate to say this, because
I sometimes really enjoy reading them.

Too bad we don't have a sister list for the non-rave stuff, but I guess that's
not to be.
 
I don't love you all, but I like most of you ;^)
-mike

The RAVE! area is actually called the Techno Ghetto.  There's a mayor -
Turbo Ted.  They have put a lot of thought into what should and shouldn't
be involved to suit the unique needs of ravers.  Here's a URL of the map
that shows how everything will be set-up:
http://www.sirius.com/~shag/burn/  The theme camps sound fun...

Nancy, I can understand your point, if the sound systems were facing one
another there would be a huge problem, though it might be fun for a moment
to stand in the exact center and implode.  No, the systems will be facing
out and larger systems will be even further than the 1/4 mile.

For it's size and increasing popularity Burning Man is doing all they can
to keep it from becoming commercialized.  The fact that MTV is making the
conscious decision NOT to attend counts for something, at least.

Tony

[snip]
> 
> Too bad we don't have a sister list for the non-rave stuff, but I guess that's
> not to be.

My experience with this has been bad. I was once on another mailing list
that was once split up into "on-topic", "off-topic", and "purely
informational" (the domain name policy lists at the InterNIC)

What happened? Well, some people who subscribed to only one list
missed a lot of great stuff, many people CC'ed msgs to all three
to ensure that they reached everyone, most people complained about
posts that were misdirected, etc. So, in an effort to reduce traffic
on one list, the traffic increased to nearly ten-fold for those who
were subscribed to all three. I was getting nearly 500 msgs a day
before I couldn't take it anymore.

Just my 5 drachmas...

Steve

ps. Today's cool Solaris message:
NOTICE: /: optimization changed from SPACE to TIME

Well I can't decide- I'm hedged on the issue. I believe we have a community
which should be able to come to some sort of compromise. There isn't just
ONE way this list should work, and it angers me to see people on either
extreme being so stubborn. Noone is better than anyone else on this list
and we shouldn't be so quick to criticize without at least trying to
understand another point of view. How does this sound:

Don't be shy about posting something that you really want to
share...something that you would want to tell your friends at a rave or
wherever...But think before you post. If it's really NRR, (the poltical
discussion we had last week which was interesting but totally irrelevent to
the list IMO) temper yourself.

We should be able to come to some sort of consensus on this, folks.

-peace-
alex

I wanted to rehash my post because it did seem to be totally against NRR 
messages.  

I do like and appreciate most of the NRR messages however as of late 
there seems to be a lot of negativity not just in the NRR posts but the 
RR as well. 

People jumping down each others backs etc...many posting to the whole 
list as opposed to a personal PRIVATE reply.  Further we must all 
remember that messages can be easily misread or miswritten.  We should 
remember to add a :) if something is in jest.  Also people should reread 
a message before posting it.  Does it say exactly what you wanted it to 
say...could it be misunderstood in any way, how can I shorten it or 
change it to truly represent what I want to say.

I am as guily of this as any other, however I do not post very often at 
all...

I am sure Brian meant no harm with his "clothing" post but it came across 
as being very offensive.  And I remember another post of his that did the 
same thing.  I don't won't to single him out though because everyone is 
guilty of it in some fashion or another.

And when you reply to someone's post go through the same process.  Did 
they really mean that...could I take that in some other fashion, can I 
look at this in some other light?

And remember this list is large so try to keep it private if no one else 
really needs to read it.

And no flames!  Please support all argumentative posts with some solid 
reasons.  We can argue positively and come to a good compromise or 
solution.  Flaming gets no where.  A good debate is always helpful, like 
the meateaters vs. non-meateaters thread.  No one was waging a personal 
battle against another...everyone was just expressing their opinion and 
trying to back it up with solid reasons...though the thread did linger on 
a bit too much and I did start hitting "d" quite a lot towards the end.  :)

Thanks,
G

From: Karen Hardie <pounce@vcn.bc.ca>
Subject: a posting hint (NRR at ALL!)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9608151851.A24510-0100000@opus.vcn.bc.ca>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I can't count the number of times i've seen someone get flamed and then 
come back with a hurt message saying "come on, i was kidding, you all know 
me better than that."  Well, we DON'T know you obviously or you wouldn't 
have gotten misunderstood.  Email is a wonderful thing, but it's not the 
telephone or video - we can't read each others' deeper shades of emotion 
and wit with only text.

Don't be afraid to post, but don't get all defensive and angry if someone 
misreads it and flames you.  The best response, I think, is to not 
respond to senseless flames that are obviously just attacking you without 
any sort of clearly defined reasoning.  And don't take flames from ppl 
who've never met you so PERSONALLY!  :)  if someone feels like venting a 
little steam on me through email, who cares?  it's not hurting me any.

my $0.02
pounce
-----------------------------------------------
...  -listen: there's a hell
of a good universe next door; let's go

		- e.e. cummings

At 2:03 PM -0700 8/14/96, Tony Rotundo wrote:
>Positive or negative, I really wish this list contained more rave related
>topics.  I'm really not on it to be part of a social/support group, but
>rather to (hopefully) exchange ideas and information pertaining to the Bay
>Area Rave Scene.
>
>With all due respect (for I certainly love an occassiona NRR =), even if
>100% of a person's posts are positive, if they aren't rave related to some
>degree, at some point, then they are misdirected...
>
>Teetering On the edge...
>
>Tone
>=)

I agree with Tony (and now Leslie) *completely*.

It seems that about 1 in 10 or maybe even 1 in 15 messages on this list
actually have to do with

  "Raving, the culture, music and activities"

-- which would ideally include directly relavent posting related to
upcoming party info, party reviews, music and DJ info and reviews, and such.

Rather most of the messages on this list for some time seem to have mostly
to do with

  "Raving, the 12-step support group"

or better said: "SF Raves, the 12-step support group"

I don't rave because I want or need a 12 step support group. Raving's not a
12 step support group. But based on a lot of the postings to SF Raves, it
seems pretty clear that some of you are intent on *making* it a 12-step
support surrogate.

Well, last time I checked, I didn't see anything in the charter for the
list about that.

I wasn't directed to begin my postings to the list with anything resembling
"My name is Wayne, and I am a Raver. I am not ashamed."

If those of you that wish to spam the list with your off-topic dribblings
continue to do so, I would at least hope for a digested or moderated form
of SFR that contained only rave and rave culture information. I really
don't care if that means that the moderated digest would be dry (i.e.
lacking all the *useless* dribble) and lacking character if that also means
that the information ratio increases to something worth subscribing to.

I like information. Unfortunately, it seems that this list specifically and
the internet as a whole is containing more and more 'content' daily but the
content/information ratio is sinking like a dropped anchor, down, down,
down...

Until then, all I can do as a defensive measure is filter SFR and all the
other rave-lists that I subscribe to into their very own virtual dumpsters
and I read them when I have time to waste.

_____________________________________________________________________________
 I am sickened by your weakness.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Aug 15 20:47:47 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id UAA25436; Thu, 15 Aug 1996 20:47:47 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from emout19.mail.aol.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id UAA25430; Thu, 15 Aug 1996 20:47:44 -0700 (PDT)
From: SteveOSac@aol.com
Received: by emout19.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id XAA16858; Thu, 15 Aug 1996 23:47:08 -0400
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 1996 23:47:08 -0400
Message-ID: <960815234704_386340659@emout19.mail.aol.com>
To: larryc@netcom.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: : ( List Solutions : ) God(s,ess) Bless SFR!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I too, as I'm sure many others, share the same frustration with loving the
list sooo much, but always fighting to keep up, and still having enough time
to do all the things that make life great.  Even with the semi-lurk opt, I
still spend well over an hour a day sorting, deleting flaming, etc. The idea
has been proposed before to have seperate lists for music, partys, politics,
etc, it was shot down like a fat duck. ...I understand why, that negates the
common ground we share.  But let's not completely ignore possible situations
to the shared frustration that in the last month has made myself, and 3 other
people I know and love leave the list.  It may not appropriate to call some
official meeting or something, especially since most of us don't have much to
do with the actual operation of this blessid list we are all so grateful for,
but let's think about it and talk it over, especially when we see each other
in the field, or on the dancefloor as the case may be.
I think the key will be a solution that uses the same principals that have
made the list work as well as it has thus far, minimal governing rules,
common sense, and having faith in PLUR. (pleease don't flame me on this)  And
for those who feel that hasn't worked so far, I invite you to check out an
AOL chat room or some other open forum of more than 20 or so average
citizens.  I love this list and everyone on it.  And damnit I want to be able
to stay here, especially when school starts.  So please, if you agree with
some of the pro-reducto opinions speak up (as self defeating as that seems),
and whether you do or not, please at least consider some of the guidelines or
possible solutions that have been proposed.
I'm still grinding it over in my head, but the solution I've been thinking of
targets the flames and flamers, maybe somehow a sublist for any conflict
beyond two volleys. If you've got no interest in conflict, simply don't
subscribe to that list. Yes, as an sfr'er once put "Without friction the jade
is not polished",  ...but with this much the jade is worn thin.
BTW, I know I've often been the first one to violate the two posts a day
guideline (not a rule or limit), but I just recently really starting thinking
about solutions, so forgive my hippo, Crissy.
Thanks for listening,
StEvEoberk,
(the raver formerly known as steveosac)
BTW #2 I think the "using the subject heading" is THE most important of the
guidelines (guidelines, not rules).

I'm not so concerned about Jason's viewpoint. I think most all views are 
important and deserved to be heard and talked about at some time 
(although perhaps only with oneself or a close friend). Hence my intial 
displeasure with someone trying to tell 900 plus people what to do in a 
public forum.

 My biggest motivation for posting was the hypocritical nature of his 
post. His post was not rave related at all. He was mearly voicing his 
(and some others) opinion on email ethics and more importantly on what 
was bothering him. He also requested that folks take certain postings to 
the private sector. Not a bad suggestion; why doesn't he heed his own 
advice? If he had taken a concise, respectful approach to a complex and 
delicate issue (communication among humans) I would have been happy to 
show the same respect.





> As a user of Hyperreal as a development tool, I'd like to request

> *all* email lists:
>

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id VAA27748; Thu, 15 Aug 1996 21:20:52 -0700 (PDT)
From: Sami Khoury <khoury@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <199608160420.VAA27748@taz.hyperreal.com>
Subject: posts and stuff
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 1996 21:20:52 -0700 (PDT)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9608152039.A20724-0100000@ese.UCSC.EDU> from "Randy C Cone" at Aug 15, 96 08:50:59 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Randy said:

> I think most all views are important and deserved to be heard and
> talked about at some time

Of course.  The complaint that many on the list are voicing now is
that people are showing very little discretion about the forum in
which they express their views.  No one is questioning anyone's right
to voice their opinion -- only where they do it.

>  My biggest motivation for posting was the hypocritical nature of his 
> post. His post was not rave related at all. He was mearly voicing his 
> (and some others) opinion on email ethics and more importantly on what 
> was bothering him. He also requested that folks take certain postings to 
> the private sector. Not a bad suggestion; why doesn't he heed his own 
> advice?

Ah.  So you're saying that, while there are off-topic posts, no one
should complain about them lest they themselves make an off-topic
post?  Right :)  This is the classic self-referential argument.  Jason
probably realized that his post was 'hypocritical' in that it was not
rave related but expected people not to do the obvious "look who's
talking" thing and understand his point.

> > 	- is your post relevant to the purpose of the list?
> > 	- have you made more than two posts to the list today?
> > 	- is your message better suited for private email?
> 
> Sami, I really appreciate your posting of these guidlines. I have
> questions tho; who developed these guidlines?

What difference does that make?

These are things I've picked up after having been on the net for a
number of years.

> Is there any real justification for them (other than common courtesy)

Common courtesy.  Bandwidth.  System load.  Netiquette.  Hyperreal is
a machine that provides a number of email lists, web pages, and tons
and tons of information on topics that would not be allowed elsewhere
in a non-autonomous environment.  The load on this machine is immense --
at peak, it uses a full T1 all to itself.

This really is a resource.  We really are part of a community.  The
messages we send to each other impact others around the world both
in their content and the very act of propogating them to all the
members of the list.

> and are there perhaps times when guidelines need to be ignored.

Sure.  Like when someone sees things getting out of hand and decides
to make an issue out of it (as Jason did).  Most of the off-topic
stuff that does fly through here hardly constitutes "a time when
guidlines need to be ignored".

	Sami

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 1996 19:27:30 -0700

I got that one sunshine. Here's one back.
--------------------------------

 From the Wall St Journal (exact date unknowm, roughly summer of 1991)
"...Medieval War Machine Impresses The English but Scares the Sheep..."

..Nor is the piano the strangest thing to startle the sheep. A few min-
utes later, a car soars by - a 1975 blue two-door Hillman, following the
same flight path and meeting the same loud fate. Pigs fly here, too. In
recent months, many dead 500-pound sows (two of them wearing parachutes)
have passed overhead, as has the occasional dead horse.

 It's the work of Hew Kennedy's medieval siege engine, a four-story tall
30-ton behemoth that's the talk of bucolic Shropshire, 140 miles North-
West of London. In ancient times, such war machines were dreaded imple-
ments of destruction, flinging huge missles, including plague-ridden
horses, over the walls of besieged castles. Only one full-sized one
exists today, designed and built by Mr. Kennedy.

  Mr. Kennedy and his partner have spent about $17,000 (U.S.) assmebling
the Trebuchet (pronounced tray-boo-shay) from ancient texts, some in
Latin, and crude wood-block engravings of siege weaponry. The big
question is why. Mr Kennedy looks puzzled, as if the thought hadn't oc-
cured to him before. "Well, why not? It's bloody good fun!" he finally
exclaims. For several hundred years military technicians have been trying
fruitlessly to reconstruct a working trebuchet.

  How it works seems simple enough. The heart of the siege machine is a
three-ton, 60 foot tapered beam made from laminated wood. It is pivoted
near the heavy end, to which is attached a weight box filled with 5 and
a half tons of steel bar. Two huge A-frames made from lashed together
tree trunks support a steel axle, around which the beam pivots. When the
machine is at rest, the beam is vertical, slender at the top and weight
box just clearing the ground.

  When launch time comes, a farm tractor cocks the trebuchet, slowly
hauling the slender end of the beam down and the weighted end up. Several
dozen nervous sheep, hearing the tractor and knowing what comes next,
make a break for the far side of the pasture. A crowd of 60 friends and
neighbors buzzes with anticipation as a 30 foot, steel cable sling is
attached- one end to the slender end of the beam and the other to the
projectile, in this case a grand piano (purchased by the truckload from
a junk dealer).

"If you see the missle coming toward you, simply step aside," Mr. Kennedy
shouts to the onloookers.

Then, with a great groaning, the beam is let go. As the counter weight
plummets, the piano in its sling whips through an enormous arc, up and
over the top of the trebuchet and down the pasture, a flight of 125 yds.
The record for pianos is 151 yards (an upright model with less wind re-
sistance). A 112-pound weight made it 235 yards. Dead hogs go for about
175 yards,and horses 100 yards; the field is cratered with the graves of
the beasts, buried by a backhoe where they landed.

Mr. Kennedy believes that dead horses are they key to his success in re-
constructing his trebuchet. That's because engravings usually depict the
trebuchets hurling boulders and there is no way to determine what the
rocks weigh, or the counterweight necessary to fling them. But a few
drawings show dead horses being loaded onto trebuchets, putrid animals
being an early form of biological warfare. Since horses weigh now what
they did in the 1300s, the engineering calculations followed easily.

Finally, there's the prospect of flinging a man into space - a living
man, that is. This isn't a new idea, Mr. Kennedy points out. Trebuchets
were often used to fling ambassadors and prisoners of war back over
castle walls, a sure way to demoralize the opposition.

Some English sports parachutists think they can throw a man in the air
and bring him down alive. In a series of experiments, they've thrown
several man-sized logs and two quarter-ton dead pigs into the air; one
of the pigs parachuted gently back to earth, the other landed rather
more forcefully.

Trouble is, an accelerometer carried inside the logs recorded a centrif-
ugal force during the launch of as much as 20 Gs (the actual acceleration
was 0 to 90 miles per hour in 1.5 seconds). Scientists are divided over
whether a man can stand that many Gs for more than a second or two before
his blood vessels burst. "It would be splendid to throw a bloke, really
splendid," he says wistfully, "He'd float down fine. But he'd float
down dead."

--

Received: from [206.86.235.114] (lesliea.vip.best.com [206.86.235.114]) by shellx.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id XAA23517 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 15 Aug 1996 23:10:46 -0700
Date: Thu, 15 Aug 1996 23:10:46 -0700
Message-Id: <v01530500ac7f2b215562@[206.86.235.114]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: lesliea@best.com (Leslie Ayres)
Subject: Re: final thoughts REALLY LAME POSTS!!!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Black Adder said in response to my post...

>Don't say something in public that you do not wish public response on.
>
>If you are going to make controversial, assinine, or just plain mean
>statements to the entire list, expect for them to be dealt with in a
>public fashion.


On the whole, I agree, if you make statements to the list, sometimes the
reply should be to the list also.  (Although several of you know that I
have made private responses expressing my opinion on what I felt were
questionable posts... private, so as not to fan the flames nor publicly
embarrass someone.)

What I'm referring to, however are the times that:

1.  The original response or flame or whatever was NOT to the whole list.
I often see messages quoted in responses that never came over to the whole
list... where it was a private discussion, but the responder now wants to
take it public by cc-ing SFRaves.

Perhaps people might take the time to write TWO messages --- one
appropriate to the list with information or general opionion (i.e. "1015
Folsom's dress code is....) , and then one to the person you have an
personal issue with (fill in your own blank here, please.) ; )

2.  The manner of communication is obnoxious and uncivilized.  Name-calling
and personally attacking another person is NEVER appropriate. Period.
(Clue: are there words like "stupid" or "idiot" or "clueless" directed at a
specific person?  Not to mention the expletives I've seen addressed at
individuals on here.)   What's the point?  It makes them feel terrible,
makes you appear like the stupid idiot, not them, and other than some
vicarious sense of entertainment for some, does nothing positive for the
group.  It's the end of real communication when you do that, but if you
feel you must, please keep it private.

I patiently delete intelligent articulate debates that I have little
interest in (like vegetarianism vs carnivores, socialism debates, etc.)
even though they are really NRR.  But they are at least civilized and are
clearly of interest to others in the group.

Over and out (on this topic at least!)
Leslie
