On Thu, 15 Aug 1996, Sami Khoury wrote:

[snip]

> >  My biggest motivation for posting was the hypocritical nature of his 
> > post. His post was not rave related at all. He was mearly voicing his 
> > (and some others) opinion on email ethics and more importantly on what 
> > was bothering him. He also requested that folks take certain postings to 
> > the private sector. Not a bad suggestion; why doesn't he heed his own 
> > advice?
> 
> Ah.  So you're saying that, while there are off-topic posts, no one
> should complain about them lest they themselves make an off-topic
> post?  Right :) 

Wrong! I'm saying (listen carefully) that if you want off topic posts 
private you should make your own off topic posts private.

> This is the classic self-referential argument.  Jason
> probably realized that his post was 'hypocritical' in that it was not
> rave related but expected people not to do the obvious "look who's
> talking" thing and understand his point.

I just like to see people walk their talk and not expect others to do 
their bidding while not subjecting themselves to the same discipline.
Teaching by example OR calm, resoned discourse is often more efficient at 
getting desired results. 

> 
> > > 	- is your post relevant to the purpose of the list?
> > > 	- have you made more than two posts to the list today?
> > > 	- is your message better suited for private email?
> > 
> > Sami, I really appreciate your posting of these guidlines. I have
> > questions tho; who developed these guidlines?
> 
> What difference does that make?

A lot really. At least to me. It means more coming from a sysop or like 
individual rather than from some yahoo who is disgruntled 'cause their 
delete finger is sore.


> 
> These are things I've picked up after having been on the net for a
> number of years.
> 
> > Is there any real justification for them (other than common courtesy)
> 
> Common courtesy.  Bandwidth.  System load.  Netiquette.  Hyperreal is
> a machine that provides a number of email lists, web pages, and tons
> and tons of information on topics that would not be allowed elsewhere
> in a non-autonomous environment.  The load on this machine is immense --
> at peak, it uses a full T1 all to itself.

Ah... now we start to see some real reasons for intelligant use of email 
and related technology. How much simplier if someone had stated this as a 
reason for responsible posting instead of spewing emotionally laden 
debris sure to agitate and upset people. 





> This really is a resource.  We really are part of a community.  The
> messages we send to each other impact others around the world both
> in their content and the very act of propogating them to all the
> members of the list.


Well stated and appreciated!!




> > and are there perhaps times when guidelines need to be ignored.
> 
> Sure.  Like when someone sees things getting out of hand and decides
> to make an issue out of it (as Jason did).  Most of the off-topic
> stuff that does fly through here hardly constitutes "a time when
> guidlines need to be ignored".


Says who? hmmm Or perhaps you like when just anyone of unknown 
qualifications tells large groups of people how to behave.

Jason, I truely mean you no ill will and I am sorry if my rash statement 
hurt you in any way. I prefer to let people communicate and work things 
out for themselves rather than censor them. If you really are dedicated 
to keeping this list rave related, I would appreciate you deal with folks 
on an individual basis. However I certainly will not chide you for 
requesting this publicly in the future.


Peace all,


Ran

                              -=*=-
                                ~

Steve

:  (ninjkool@xs4all.nl) writes:
: > 2) A more individual future. I always wonder for myself, how long am I
: > supposed to go on raving anyway? I'm 25 now, that's seems to be okay? 30?
: > 40? I'm not sure especially since raving can be such a physical thing to
: > do. Is this a generation heading for massive burn-out at 30, after which
: > we can sit down and talk about the good old days while enjoying K-Tels
: > "Collected Rave anthems" ("yeah man "Energy Flash" that was the shit, they
: > don't make music like that anymore").
: > I'm extremly curious about expectations about these subjects, friends I
: > ask about this are always very evasive: maybe that says it all.

: 	I've been doing this "rave" thing for three years now, and as I'm
: heading off to my first year of university I have to say that I've shared
: your feelings that maybe age is a factor. When I look at all the
: inexperienced youths fucking themselves up at parties I sometimes question
: whether I'm too mature and responsible to associate with these people --
: then I put on my Grover shirt and start to kick it. You're only as old as
: you feel, admit to, whatever and you should never let a number (that's all
: age is) get you down.

: 	You've got to grab you inner-child by the hand and take him out to
: a party with you, it's only when you lose your ability to see the beauty
: in everyday life that you "grow up". Maturity and responsibility does not
: have to equal unhappiness, despite whatever the baby boomer generation may
: have taught us. We live, we love, we rave.

: 	Last weekend I found a blue balloon on the way home from a rave. A
: BLOO BALLOON! Not only that, it's was partly filled with helium so it
: would just hover in the air.. I was estatic the entire way home, playing
: with it and letting it lead me there.. that's what life is all about,
: finding a balloon and loving it.

: --
:                             http://sunphlour.comnet.ca
:                    rave safety + ottawa underground information

friends,

i subscribed to sfraves as a complete newbie, had never been to a rave.
this was about three weeks ago. i wanted to go to a rave, and hoped through
the list to find a good event and hopefully some nice people to make this
new experience a little smoother.
        i ended up going to Chrysalis with matt lanier and shawna, and i
had the time of my life... how did i end up meeting them?
        by replying to a friendly, inviting post by matt regarding who was
going to chrysalis.

and what, you might ask, made me think that matt would be receptive to my
newbie interest? none other than his "totally NRR" posts encouraging
everyone to have a wonderful day, etc. i felt a positive vibe coming from
matt, i acted on it, and i am incredibly glad i did.

now i see flame wars about this, i see matt and others thinking of leaving
this list, and i am deeply saddened.

i would not have had such a wonderful introduction to raving had it not
been for the screwball off-subject inbox-cluttering posts of one really
nice guy.
        if that isn't rave-related, i don't know what is.

please, please, pretty please, with a glow-stik on top,

_peace_
_love_
_unity_
_respect_

brian

my friend jeff asked me to post this-

                     READ IT !!! IT'S A MUST !!!
     i checked this party out last night at the cats alley. jungle in the
back room and chicago house in the main room. i was inspired by my friend
india, who's totally into jungle music. i met her childhood friend jessy
and the rest of the girls. they showed me how to appreciate the art of
symmetry through dancing. the rest of the kids on the main floor displayed
a tremendous amount of discipline and creativity in their dancing. they
also portrayed their unique personalities through their clothing.  i was
reminded of the parties i used to attend in new york. this summer, ive
been going to parties here in sf at least twice a week. i extremely
suggests to those of you that i've met in the past to strive for
perfection. by this i mean, we should bring out the professional dancer in
all of us. that's what these parties are all about, not only dancing  but
presenting ourselves as if we are performing to each other. respecting
ourselves, others, the dj and the MUSIC at the same time will give us 
great time and good luck.
      REMINDERS:                                                        
it's about more than just fun! when we are at the parties we should
not forget to think about our career my young brothers and sisters. how
are we going to support ourselves without using other people? having a job 
leads you to become independent and responsible living creatures.we
could still go to parties, right guys!! it does makes a big difference.
since 1991, i've been going to parties. based on my opinion and past 
experiences we should always think what are the goods things we can get 
out of those parties and learn from the negative ones.i totally awakened
myself to what im going to do in the future. through those parties, i
discovered the purpose of my existence:        

.                i remember myself as a person                          
                 who likes to make or invent things                    
                 that i could offer to anyone i care
                 about,                                                 
                 who loves to buy clothes appropriate                    
                 to my body and taste, and                              
                 who dance to familiarized myself to                    
                 the wonders of kinetics                                
                 but i was disorganized and not disciplined. 
                 i found out that i could do more and                    
                 through further exploration,                          
                 i'll achieve my
                 long waited perfect self.                                   
                 the message that i would like to share 
                 is
                 know thyself and the life you chose                   
                 will be easier and enjoyable.
     
       i recommend to all the bytes to participate to this upcoming party
     
                         THE BURNING MAN !!!!!!!!!!!!

hi all,

it's the last week of school..and i'm finishing the final project..it's a
game where you go to a rave and try to hook up with your friend who's
brought you back some sticky bud from the land of happy mj.

this rave is my total fantasy party..eight rooms with trip-hop, junglistic
ambient, chicago house (thanks sarah aberant for your rad post), space
music, techno, etc...and of course, a juice bar complete with spirulina
smoothies.

hazards include undercover agents, tweakers (sorry if you're a tweaker),
germ-coated water bottles, and noise complaints.

this is so much fun..writing code seems to me a lot like writing
prose..only the computer reads it and tells you right off whether it sucks
or flies.

neophyte computer nerd,

ann

Hi everyone.  I've been lurking in your lights for some time now.  For
the most part, it has been enlightening, beautiful, and fun.  I want
extend a sincere hug to everyone of you.  I love the vibe that used to
permeate through this list, Starchild's spiritual insights into the
community, warm and fuzzies being spread around in the form of hugs,
kisses, and poetry, new toys people plan on sharing at the next party.
With all the :( :( on the list right now, I'd like to recommend that
everyone put a lollipop in their mouths, and think about the silent E (for
empathy) after PLUR. 
A bit about myself:)
Staight from the doc's office-
I'm 20 years old, 6'1", 165 lbs, short black hair, and completelyacko.
Why I'm here-
Why not?
The trip began with Cool World part II :p in Oaktown.  I was so
overwhlemed by the scene that I danced all night in front of the speakers.
Since then i've progressed to wallflower status.  But still too shy to
mingle.  I love the music and the beautiful people, and hope to feel at
home one day.
What I do- I'm currently in the middle of a seven month hiatus from UC
Berkeley.  One of those I want to see the world again for the first time
thing.  I work as a personal care attendant, and am currently hunting for
a day job.  
What's fun-
guitar, swimming, basketball, dancing, computer, reading, and munching on
candy.
What's not-
Zoning out, depression, apathy, thinking about all of the above.


That's me in a nutshell.  Love ya all. 

Sen Chang

-I think I can I think I can I think I can

Subject: nrr - has the dust cleared yet?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hello all -

when i went to bed last night after unsubbing, i got to thinking:

1) have i responded maturely to this recent conflict over nrr posts?

2) is leaving the list the correct way to respond to disagreement?

3) is there a better way to handle my disagreement?

and i realized, NO, NO, and YES.

i took many of yesterday's posts quite personally, and because of that, i
tried to take it out on ya'll.  sorry.

i realized that leaving a community is not the proper way to deal with a
disagreement, and i almost walked out of a community that i feel very
strongly about.  that would be silly and irresponsible of me.

so, please accept my public apology for the following things:
        1)nrr posts: i'm a prime offender of totally nrr posts.  i shall not
discontinue posting, but i shall let the positive energy in others shine
through while i exercize more discression to those who don't
appreciate/don't have the time to wade through my posts of mindless, totally
heart related blathering.

        2)guilt trip:  i tried to pull a guilt trip on the list, and felt
like shit for it.

        3)taking ya'll too personally.

so, i love ya'll, and hope to see you soon!

love-

matt l


matthew d. p. k. lanier

On Thu, 15 Aug 1996, Leslie Ayres wrote:

> Black Adder said in response to my post...
> 
> >Don't say something in public that you do not wish public response on.
> >
> >If you are going to make controversial, assinine, or just plain mean
> >statements to the entire list, expect for them to be dealt with in a
> >public fashion.
> 
> 
> On the whole, I agree, if you make statements to the list, sometimes the
> reply should be to the list also.  (Although several of you know that I
> have made private responses expressing my opinion on what I felt were
> questionable posts... private, so as not to fan the flames nor publicly
> embarrass someone.)
> 
> What I'm referring to, however are the times that:
> 
> 1.  The original response or flame or whatever was NOT to the whole list.
> I often see messages quoted in responses that never came over to the whole
> list... where it was a private discussion, but the responder now wants to
> take it public by cc-ing SFRaves.

I ABSOLUTELY agree with this. Posting someones private correspondence to 
you publicly is one of the rudest things that someone can do on the 
Internet. 

> 2.  The manner of communication is obnoxious and uncivilized.  Name-calling
> and personally attacking another person is NEVER appropriate. Period.
> (Clue: are there words like "stupid" or "idiot" or "clueless" directed at a
> specific person?  Not to mention the expletives I've seen addressed at
> individuals on here.)   What's the point?  It makes them feel terrible,
> makes you appear like the stupid idiot, not them, and other than some
> vicarious sense of entertainment for some, does nothing positive for the
> group.  It's the end of real communication when you do that, but if you
> feel you must, please keep it private.

I am glad you have made the determination of what activities and modes of 
discourse and interaction are appropriate for all of us. I think you are 
about the fifth or six person to do so. Which one of you is "right?" What is 
appropriate or non-appropriate anymore? Why should any of us be subjected to 
enforced positivity, hiding our real feelings as to not upset anyones' 
delicate sensibilities? 

Those questions nonwithstanding, I agree generally with what you are 
getting at. What I object to is everyone dicatating to everyone else what 
is appropriate. There is only one person that I know of(apologies if 
there are more that I am not aware of) that is qualified to make that 
determination, and we have yet to hear anything from him on the subject, 
probably because he is too busy with "real" business, as opposed to the 
soap opera that is SFRaves. 

                                   Black Adder, 
                                   (who really needs a cool soap opera
                                    name like Lance, or Murdoc, ya know
                                    something masculine....)

Hey y'all.  
I hope I'm not out of line sending this to the list; I thought it was
important enough to send here.  I think there will be enough people on
here who will care about this issue, though in a great sense it is NRR (I
could make justifications for why it IS RRR :oD But I won't)
Ok, enough blabbering.  Here it is.  My apologies in advance for those who
may take offense!
love,
shamini


     
Save Bert and Ernie!!!!
 ----------
     
Subject:        Petition to Save Sesame Street
     
This is a petition to save Sesame Street.
     
All you do is add your name on the list and then forward it to 
everyone you
know. The only time you send it to the included address is if you are 
the
50th, 100th, etc. Send it on to everyone you know.
     
PBS, NPR (National Public Radio), and the arts are facing major 
cutbacks in
funding. In spite of the efforts of each station to reduce spending 
costs and
streamline their services, the government officials believe that the 
funding
currently going to these programs is too large a portion of funding 
for
something which is seen as "unworthwhile."
     
Currently, taxes from the general public for PBS equal $1.12 per 
person per
year, and the National Endowment for the Arts equals $.64 a year in 
total.
     
A January 1995 CNN/USA Today/Gallup poll indicated that 76% of 
Americans wish
to keep funding for PBS, third only to national defense and law 
enforcement
as the most valuable programs for federal funding.
     
Each year, the Senate and House Appropriations commitees each have 13
     
subcommitees with jurisdiction over many programs and agencies. Each 
subcommitee passes its own appropriation bill. The goal each year is 
to have
each bill signed by the beginning of the fiscal year, which is 
October 1. In
the instance of the Corporation of Public Broadcasting, the bill 
determines
the funding for the next three years. When this issue comes up in 
1996, the
funding will be determined for fiscal years 1996-1998. The only way 
that our
representatives can be aware of the base of support or PBS and 
funding for
these types of programs is by making our voices heard. Please add 
your name
to this list if you believe in what we stand for.
     
This list will be forwarded to the President of the United States, 
the Vice
President of the United States, and Representative Newt Gingrich, who 
is the
instigator of the action to cut funding to these worthwhile programs.
     
If you happen to be the 50th, 100th, 150th, etc. signer of this 
petition,
please forward to: kubi7975@blue.univnorthco.edu. This way we can 
keep track
of the lists and organize them. Forward this to everyone you know, 
and help
us to keep these programs alive.
     
Thank you.

X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>

It's getting closer.  The ripples travelling back growing like the 
anticipation of a great change, like ghosts of dancers, like premonitions of 
adrenalin...  Can you feel it?  The children whisper, just beyond the range 
of hearing, murmur and giggle to themselves, peeking out to see if it's here 
yet, hiding but waiting...

...for the sun to set on a hot dry Friday...

...for night to fall...

...for the world to grow quiet and drowsy...

...for the cool night breeze to stir...

...for the people to come together...

...for the music to scale upward....

...for the bass to pound...

...for the lights to sear...

...for the dance to begin...

...thesmilethehugthesweatthestomptheshakethescreamtheboomboomboomboomboom....

Can you feel it?

From: "hey, where am I?" <shawna-@ix.netcom.com>
Subject: Re: final thoughts REALLY LAME POSTS!!!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>I am glad you have made the determination of what activities and modes of 
>discourse and interaction are appropriate for all of us. I think you are 
>about the fifth or six person to do so. Which one of you is "right?" What is 
>appropriate or non-appropriate anymore? Why should any of us be subjected to 
>enforced positivity, hiding our real feelings as to not upset anyones' 
>delicate sensibilities? 



I would be inclined to agree with Leslie on this one, but not because I
think it is "wrong" for people to be flaming other people on the list the
way they have been.  It *is* my personal opinion that people should not be
treating other people they way some people have been on the list, but
contrary to popular belief that opinion is not involved in my agreement.  
Seems to me that most of the flames that have been getting sent out, while
flaming away, are also trying to make valid points along with these flames.
Yeah, a few of these flames simply say "you're stupid, you suck".  But most
of them say "you're stupid, you suck *because*..."  Point being, in addition
to the flames, people are also attempting to convey their own opinions &
thoughts on a given subject. I would also assume that because people are
attempting to make these points, they would like it if the other people
reading the posts would get these points.  However, most people, especially
the ones that the posts are aimed at, completely fail to see the actual
point because all they see are the flame sitting on top of it.  This is
human nature.  People don't usually realize that when making a statement,
it's a two part equation:  the point being made + the presentation of the
point, how it's perceived by others.  Basically, I think you're shooting
yourself in the foot by sending out your thoughts/opinions in the form of an
enormous flame unless you don't give a shit about whether or not the other
person understands your point, which you obviously do or you wouldn't have
bothered to include your opinion/thoughts.  A true debate happens with two
parties successfully share their opinions/thoughts about given subjects and
make the other understand where they're coming from, even tho it may not
change their respective opinions.  The recent veggie/meat discussion is a
very good example of that.  Lots of people expressed their differing
opinions, and I'm sure (myself included) that many people came away with new
information & thoughts on the subject, without necessarily changing their
own opinions on it.  I'm sure that would have happened *way* less had
everybody's posts been "you suck you fucking vegetarian/meat-eater" rather
than of the sort we saw.  Point is, I'm sure everybody here would like to
have their opinions/ideas/thoughts heard and understood by everybody else,
even if it doesn't change everybody else's opinions.  The only way to
successfully do that is to remove the flame factor (imo), with the exception
being if your only point is in itself to send the flame.  So if you're
interested in getting your point across, in addition to your flame, think
about what you're saying and how you say it, I think that will insure an
actual exchange of ideas & information rather than just telling people they
suck.  Much more practical, don't you think?

Love,
Shawna

p.s.  You all suck!  ;)

            
          Do not go gently into that good night!
         Rave! Rave into the dawning of the light!

practical stuff, and just 'stuff'-- prices: bring small bills and lots of 
change..NOTE, I've never had to throw anything away and it's time to 
lighten my load. (me rent mongo house with tons of space for 12 years!)

Bay, take Richmond Bridge to 101 north, exit Central San Rafael...get 
into left lane.  Make a left onto 3rd.  One way heading west.  Remain in 
left lane.  Make a left onto 'D' street.  Get into right Lane.  Cross 
2nd street (past Frenchies Hitching post and Arco gas station) proceed 
4-5 blocks, mail box on left, make a left onto San Rafael Avenue. short 
block.  Make a right at stop sign onto 'C'.  Third house from corner and 
you'll hear the music.

Maureen & Phoenix

>
>my friend jeff asked me to post this-
>
>                     READ IT !!! IT'S A MUST !!!
>     i checked this party out last night at the cats alley. jungle in the
>back room and chicago house in the main room. i was inspired by my friend
>india, who's totally into jungle music. i met her childhood friend jessy
>and the rest of the girls. they showed me how to appreciate the art of
>symmetry through dancing. the rest of the kids on the main floor displayed
>a tremendous amount of discipline and creativity in their dancing. they
>also portrayed their unique personalities through their clothing.  i was
>reminded of the parties i used to attend in new york. this summer, ive
>been going to parties here in sf at least twice a week. i extremely
>suggests to those of you that i've met in the past to strive for
>perfection. by this i mean, we should bring out the professional dancer in
>all of us. that's what these parties are all about, not only dancing  but
>presenting ourselves as if we are performing to each other. respecting
>ourselves, others, the dj and the MUSIC at the same time will give us 
>great time and good luck.
>      REMINDERS:                                                        
>it's about more than just fun! when we are at the parties we should

Hello,

On Sat, 17 Aug 1996 10:15:37 +0000, "E. Nygma" <enigma@best.com>
wrote:
>One of the principles of raves that I was taught is that it is up to
>each and every individual to provide the vibe for a party.
>Circumstances will be circumstances (particularly the physical
>ones), but the vibe is the product of the expression and attitude
>each of us brings to the event.
>
>Let us all do our share to bring a positive vibe to this list 
>(including myself)!

This post brings up one of the major problems with human society.

First off, I should say that the following may be obvious to some (and
so excuse me), but perhaps it is not to others.

Second, I should say that I agree entirely with the above post.  

>From my experience, vibe consists of two things:

1) Being positive.
2) Accepting everyone as if they were a close friend.

Usually, the second part is done by limiting to a relatively small
group.   In the case of a rave, you define things such that "anyone
who is attending this rave must be cool".

It's sort of a circular argument, but oddly enough it works.

Until it stops working.  :-)

IE if everyone is positive, and accepts everyone else, then that is
generally self-supporting.

HOWEVER, if the event is attended by a significant number of people
who are not interested in doing this, then that can bring down
everyone else - because then the event starts looking like anywhere
else in the world.

It is easy to be positive and respect everyone, when almost everyone
else is doing so.   However, when a significant number of people are
acting negatively, it becomes much harder, simply because both
positivity and negativity are "catching", ie are transmitted from
person to person, sometimes without their consciously knowing it.

Thus, the trick is to be positive and accepting even in the face of
negativity (this is what is usually termed "spirituality" or
"saintliness").

So, once one knows the value of the "vibe", one must be continually
vigilant, ie one must be constantly remembering to avoid being
negative and to instead be positive and accepting.


Cheers,

Ken                         <*>
kstuart@mail.telis.org

" Turn the earth to sand and still commit no crime
  How one thought will live provide the others die
  For I have riches more than these " - John Lodge

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Aug 17 14:53:48 1996

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: lesliea@best.com (Leslie Ayres)
Subject: Re: (Somewhat RR) aging and raving
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The biggest problem with raving in general, I think, is burning yourself
out ... whether its on substances, or by letting other parts of your life
get ignored because partying takes up so much time, or whatever.

I hope to be raving for many more years (it's been 3 years now, and I'm
42), but definitely I have to stay aware of how much it's taking out of me,
vs. how much it's giving back....  Sometimes I have to step back, take a
break, remember all the other parts of who I am.

I have several friends, though, who are 25-ish, have been partying for
several years, and who are uncomfortable at parties with lots of really
young kids who are taking too many drugs, and sort of spinning off into
nowhere ....  they say it reminds them of their own less-mature years --
been there, done that.

Maybe the kind of parties you're attracted to, and the kinds of people who
are there, change as you mature and spend more time in the scene.  But
raving is a little like religion for me, and I hope to have it all my life!
Raving makes you young and keeps you young if you do it right!

As Shawna likes to quote .... Do not go gentle into that good night!!!

Leslie

------- Forwarded Message
[forwards deleted to protect the conspiracy]

A friend sends me this, and swears it arrives from authoritative source. 
Scary.

>From the "sometimes things are better left unreported" file

The following verbatim account of a segment of a Bob Dole appearance a
week or so ago at a cotton cooperative in Bakersfield which is sure to
make you think either

(a) he's completely unhinged, and therefore should never be president; or 
(b) he's completely unhinged, and therefore should absolutely be
president. You decide.

"My wife was here six days last week, and she'll be back next week, and
she does an outstanding job. And when I'm elected, she will not be in
charge of health care. Don't worry about it. Or in charge of anything
else. (Muffled crowd gasp.) I didn't say that. It did sort of go
through my mind. But she may have a little blood bank in the White
House. But that's all right. We need it. It doesn't cost you anything. 
These days, it's not all you give at the White House - your blood. You
have to give your file. I keep wondering if mine's down there. Or my
dog. I got a dog named Leader. I'm not certain they've got a file on 
Leader. He's a schnauzer. I think he's been cleaned. We've had him
checked by the vet but not by the FBI or the White House. He may be
suspect, but in any event, we'll get into that later. Animal rights or
something of that kind. But this is a very serious election."

------- End of Forwarded Message

Leslie Ayres wrote:
> 
> The biggest problem with raving in general, I think, is burning yourself
> out ... whether its on substances, or by letting other parts of your life
> get ignored because partying takes up so much time, or whatever.
> I think it is important to try and have raving be related to all aspects of one's life 
rather than be a way to escape from aspects of one's life. 
For me, (mainly the dancing aspect) raving  helps me connect more to myself.
Dancing helps me open up to my feelings and experience the flow of life.
If I start to feel burnt out on raving, I take time to evaluate why I'm raving and what 
raving is to me.

:)
peter

Subject: Viberation!! review
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 18 Aug 1996 14:06:44 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Wow, I guess one of the benefits of being at work on
Sunday is that I get to be the first one to write a
review of Viberation!  

When I first got out there around noon, it was kind of
overcast and windy, and we had to set up in a different
part of the beach than previous parties at Bonny Doon
since there were people already sitting at that spot. 
(grr!)

But everything got set up okay, and soon the party was
up and running!  It was almost like it was two parties,
at first it was overcast and the voicemail had just gone
up, and it was happy people smiling and chillin'.  Then,
BOOM!  It's sunny, people start coming down the hills,
everybody running and dancing!  I don't know if it is
because of the close proximity (in time) to Beautiful
People or if everyone is just resting up for Burning Man,
but this was the most substance free party I've ever been
to, and it didn't seem to affect the vibe one bit!  I
brought my friend from New York, and he was amazed at the
positivity and energy that seemed to be emanating from
everywhere!! 

Thanks to everyone who made this party go off!  Adam, Michal,
Knucklehead, Ran, Branka, I'm sure I'm forgetting tons of
people, (there were more SFRavers than you could shake a
stick at!).  And thanks to Terry, we're gonna miss you
big guy! 

Smiles,
     Chin

Some one just told me that you can get a ferry to Angel Island that leaves
on Friday And picks you back up on Sunday night.  Angel Island is really
beautiful and it occurred to me that this would be an amazing location for
a party, like an all weekennd thing.  Presumably getting a permit for it
can be no more difficult then getting the permit for burning man.  We
would need to recruit a few people that have boats.  Although I have a
sneaky suspision that I am not the first person to come up with this idea
and that there must be a good reason why no-one has done this already.
But if not why not that's what I say.
Tristan.

From: kstuart@mail.telis.org (Ken Stuart)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: What to do if you are not getting any posts from sfraves
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 1996 03:18:25 GMT
Reply-To: kstuart@mail.telis.org
Message-ID: <321adad5.9510795@mail.campus.mci.net>
References: <960818170914_459446847@emout13.mail.aol.com>
In-Reply-To: <960818170914_459446847@emout13.mail.aol.com>
X-Mailer: Forte Agent .99f/32.275
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello,

If you are not getting any posts from sfraves, do the following:

Send a message to    majordomo@hyperreal.com

that has a message body consisting ONLY of the word "which", ie:

which

(the subject line doesn't matter - make one that let's you know what
it is about, such as "sfraves test")

IF hyperreal is working, you will get a response like this:
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

>>>> which
The string 'kstuart@mail.telis.org' appears in the following
entries in lists served by majordomo@hyperreal.com:

List                    Address
====                    =======
sfraves                 kstuart@mail.telis.org

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This response shows you are still subscribed to sfraves and that
everything is working - this will mean that everyone is too busy
dancing to send messages.  :-)

If you don't get any response at all, it means hyperreal is not
working (which seems to have been the case this time).

If for some reason you were unsubscribed from sfraves (normally this
would be due to your ISP having severe problems and sending lots of
bounces and error messages back to sfraves), then the "which" command
would produce results that would NOT include "sfraves", and you would
know to re-subscribe (assuming that your ISP's problems were fixed).

This same method works for ANY mailing list which is serviced by
"majordomo" software.


Cheers,

Ken                         <*>
kstuart@mail.telis.org

My favorite CD for 1996 so far = Orbital - "In Sides"

Leslie Ayres wrote:
> 
> The biggest problem with raving in general, I think, is burning yourself
> out ... whether its on substances, or by letting other parts of your life
> get ignored because partying takes up so much time, or whatever.
> I think it is important to try and have raving be related to all aspects of
one's life 
rather than be a way to escape from aspects of one's life. 

Yes, yes, those familiar circumstances.  Last summer was definitely the
burn-out stage for us.  I mean party after party after party, etc.... And
getting higher, and higher, and higher.  Oh, when I look back at pictures and
hear stories, and just plain out stepping out of my shoes to what I was like,
I can only say that it's good to be alive!!!!!
Sometimes you just don't realize how deep you get into this scene (although
it's hard not to when you absolutely love the music, people, vibes, energy,
etc.).  For me, it just became the time back in January to leave SF to go to
school, and now that I'm back for the summer, I appreciate everything a lot
more, and I'm enjoying every party I go to........without the drugs.  I have
just learned how to spread my time out more so that raving is still a big
part of my life, but not my whole life.  School comes first for me now.

> For me, (mainly the dancing aspect) raving  helps me connect more to
myself.
> Dancing helps me open up to my feelings and experience the flow of life.
> If I start to feel burnt out on raving, I take time to evaluate why I'm
raving and what 
> raving is to me.

Agree 100%!!  I can't even begin to describe it.  A lot of my friends who are
settled down and don't really go to parties anymore wonder what it is that
still drives me to go out.  They tell me that this scene's getting old.  Now
who's going to tell me I'm too old to dance?  I'm only 22!!!!   It doesn't
matter if you're 60, you're NEVER too old to dance!  For me, dancing is a
release, it makes me feel good!!  It's like a soulful journey.  House music
does it for me.  When I go out dancing I like to let myself go with the
music.  Yeah, I tend to go to many parties, but I give myself a few days to
rest and then I go back.  It's like an addiction, but a positive one with
absolutely no comedowns.  

:-)  Karen

Good day,

>it was the finest party i have been to in my life.  i just wish the bp people could have been there 
>to enjoy it, also, for i missed a few of the people who went to bp instead.

I'm glad you had a good evening to counter that nasty little break in incident.  Getting rippred off 
always leaves me with this empty feeling.  Going to a really good party, and being with
friends has got to be one of the best ways to fill it up :)  I know what you mean about otherwise
material objects having strong emotional attachments or memories associated with them.
I had some speakers stolen from my van a few years back, and it wasn't the bigger new ones
that I mourned, but these old 6x9's, in Jason built custom boxes, that had been with me on 
innumerable road trips and outings to beaches and parks.  I used throw them up on the roof, 
where you could hear them a few hundred yards away, until the vibrations would knock them
to the ground, only to be picked up for another go at it :) 

Amy mentioned a party that was supposed to be happening in a church on friday night.  Was
this the same party? (St. John's Divine Rhythm Society)

I drove out on Saturday to check out Viberation on the beach.  It was a little cool for this Sacto. valley 
veteran (100+ for the last 2 weeks), but the music and the sound were superb.  It was the second 
time hearing Tom and Le Le, a coupla ripper sets.  Jonathon's set sounded good, but I only 
caught the last few minutes and was still settling in.  I had hoped to hear Tim spin, but got delayed
leaving town and missed him.  Sorry man :(  You have to be really dedicated to drag a sound 
system back up that hill.  (Thanks to everyone involved!) 

Take care,
                    Jason

P.S. The coffee idea is a great one; iced coffee could even be brewed ahead of time and put
         into coolers (even less work at the party).  Let me know if I can help out with this.

if memory serves, there are six campgrounds on angel island. if you
don't have reservations for one then you are kicked of the island
at sunset. angel island is a state park and wildlife reserve. not
a chance you'd ever get a permit. and nowhere to run if you get
busted...

how's about cronkite beach in marin? that's where i went to
spot the comet some months back. The full moon backlighting on
the waves and lagoon was amazing. the hills around seemed pretty
much deserted to me.

-pauld

tranquilizer.  Usually knocks you out in 5-10 minutes. A friend of
mine has an out-of-US prescription.  I don't know if it messes with the
adrenal glands, but I've never seen her get excited about anything.

Hello,

What he said makes perfect sense if you know two things:

1) His wife is the head of the Red Cross, which does more good for
people in one day, than the entire government has done in the last 30
years.

2) The Clinton administration illegally obtained over a thousand FBI
files on all their political opponents.  In the days of Nixon, a
staffer was sentenced to years of prison for looking at ONE file of a
political opponent.

PS   If you think there are a lot of messages in sfraves right now,
try starting a Clinton-Dole debate !   I propose that now that equal
time has occurred, this thread should stop right now.   Read
alt.politics.* and leave it off of sfraves.

PPS  A large portion of the following are jokes (Dole has a reputation
for cracking more jokes than virtually anyone).   Oftentimes, jokes
need tone of voice and body language...

>charge of health care. Don't worry about it. Or in charge of anything

>through my mind. But she may have a little blood bank in the White
>House. But that's all right. We need it. It doesn't cost you anything. 
>These days, it's not all you give at the White House - your blood. You
>have to give your file. I keep wondering if mine's down there. Or my
>dog. I got a dog named Leader. I'm not certain they've got a file on 
>Leader. He's a schnauzer. I think he's been cleaned. We've had him
>checked by the vet but not by the FBI or the White House. He may be
>suspect, but in any event, we'll get into that later. Animal rights or
>something of that kind. But this is a very serious election."

for the good of the people ends up seizing control of the people for the good of the economy. " - Bob Dole

What he said makes perfect sense if you know two things:

1) His wife is the head of the Red Cross, which does more good for
people in one day, than the entire government has done in the last 30
years.

files on all their political opponents.  In the days of Nixon, a
staffer was sentenced to years of prison for looking at ONE file of a
political opponent.

From: Troy Sheets <tsheets@xanadu.cyborganic.net>
Message-Id: <199608191548.IAA23818@xanadu.cyborganic.net>
Subject: Ninja Tunes.
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 1996 08:48:22 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Saterday night at Mission Rock with Ninja Tunes was great.  We arrived
pretty early, around 8:30 to enjoy the last of the daylight on the water.
Mission Rock can really be a cool venue.  The Ninja Tunes tour had their
own laser which they projected on a huge cargo ship across the water.  
NT also had a ton of live video mixing equipment, and a bank of Macs with
Internet connections.

The music was great.  I think that was NT's own sound system, and it 
roared.  Mission Rock is also probably one of the most acoustically
perfect venue too.  With no walls for the the sound to echo off of,
the beats were especially clear.  And speaking of beats, they were phaaaat.
The best music I heard was from around 9pm-11pm.  The music had lots of
tempo changes, going from funky breaks, to jungle, to hip hop, to electronic
wierdness, to just plain wierdness, and back again.  It takes a bit of
time to get used to the tempo changes, but once you are into the groove the
changes make the music especially interesting.  This fresh music was
a welcome changes for a SF music scene that I personally feel is getting
stale.  We bought a Ninja Tunes CD at Soundworks on Sunday and have enjoyed
it quite a bit.

Unfortuanataly, Mission rock was +21.  I really don't have a problem with
people drinking.  But the fact is that young people simply have the energy
you need to have a dance party really go off.  I am sure some of the jungle
sets would have been better if there was more 17-20 year olds banging their
bodies to it.  Oh well, there were plenty of people getting into it,
and I don't think there is anything wrong with the people standing around
the DJ trying to see what they were spinning.  There were several tunes
that I, personally, would have really like to know what they were.

I hope we continue to see this sort of new, innovative music in SF. 

-troy

In-Reply-To: <321754FD.1323@pacbell.net>

On Sun, 18 Aug 1996, PETER FOGEL wrote:

> Leslie Ayres wrote:
> > 
> > The biggest problem with raving in general, I think, is burning yourself
> > out ... whether its on substances, or by letting other parts of your life
> > get ignored because partying takes up so much time, or whatever.
> > I think it is important to try and have raving be related to all aspects of one's life 
> rather than be a way to escape from aspects of one's life. 
> For me, (mainly the dancing aspect) raving  helps me connect more to myself.
> Dancing helps me open up to my feelings and experience the flow of life.
> If I start to feel burnt out on raving, I take time to evaluate why I'm raving and what 
> raving is to me.

When I first started raving the experience was so new  and exciting.  In the 
recent past I've found that the newness and excitement has died down for 
me a little bit.  I found myself thinking I *had* to go to a party rather 
then I *want* to go.  When this happened I decided it was time to take a 
break to preserve the excitement and wonder.  

I've also found my personal evolution in raving interesting.  I've 
learned about the music and have become somewhat picky about what I 
listen to.  I don't have such a distaste at suffering the ignominious 
club crowd in order to hear some first-rate music anymore.

I can also see other people's evolution on this list--from when some 
first start out to when some have been in it for years and years and years!!

But, I agree, I think sometimes you have to take a step back and 
acknowledge what you are getting out of raving, what you are putting back 
in, and most importantly how you are enjoying yourself!

-KC


              ****Shit, goddamn, get off your ass and jam****

Ken,
Thanks for your reply. Your remarks were quite observant!

>From my experience, vibe consists of two things:
> 
> 1) Being positive.
> 2) Accepting everyone as if they were a close friend.
>
> Usually, the second part is done by limiting to a relatively small
> group.   In the case of a rave, you define things such that "anyone
> who is attending this rave must be cool".

I've noticed how my attitude about attending a rave varies with the
size of it. I go to massives with the sense of adventure, seeking
out to find what the world has to offer.  I also prepare to encounter
people and cultural elements that repulse or scare me, in the quest
to find new people, friends, and cultural elements that excite me. 

OTOH, at smaller venues, I expect to be more intimate with the folks
there -- not that this actually happens, though. I also tend to feel
safer in such a place.

> HOWEVER, if the event is attended by a significant number of people
> who are not interested in doing this, then that can bring down
> everyone else - because then the event starts looking like anywhere
> else in the world.

I think this is much more likely to occur, at least in portions, at a 
commercial massive with lots of advertising. The target audience is 
much bigger than the more traditional "rave" audience, and includes 
uninitiated teenagers, gangs, woman-chasing ginos, etc.

> It is easy to be positive and respect everyone, when almost everyone
> else is doing so.   However, when a significant number of people are
> acting negatively, it becomes much harder, simply because both
> positivity and negativity are "catching", ie are transmitted from
> person to person, sometimes without their consciously knowing it.

It's amazing how the vibe of the promoters, the venue owners, or the 
folks working the door will affect a rave. Many reviews I've read 
here often refer to the nature of the door people -- did they smile, 
how thoroughly did they search, what they rejected, etc.

> Thus, the trick is to be positive and accepting even in the face of
> negativity (this is what is usually termed "spirituality" or
> "saintliness").
> 
> So, once one knows the value of the "vibe", one must be continually
> vigilant, ie one must be constantly remembering to avoid being
> negative and to instead be positive and accepting.

This is a key to living a great life. How powerful and fulfilling a
life one leads is largely a function on how one chooses to be,
circumstances be damned. Do you decide how your life is going, or do
others decide for you?

>A friend of mine asked me a question about a presciption drug called
>"Rohypnol" found only in Europe,  but can be found underground here in the
>US, and I was wondering if anyone out there might know anything about it?  I
>think it goes by the street name of "Rophie"?

Hey Antone,

Rohypnol is a legal prescription drug (and apparantly easy to come by for
smuggling purposes) in Mexico.  A couple of years ago it started gaining
notoriety in Florida and some of the deep-south states, when, as you
reminded us, women reported being dosed and then raped.  The effects, I've
heard, are sorta like drinking a 12 pack of beer, and I imagine, the
potency is magnified if mixed with drinking.   They were dubbed "roofies"
because  the idiots who were using it, I guess, don't know how to spell,
and were reading "rohypnol" as "rophynol".    Anyway if you're looking to
get drunk, why not just down a 12 pack?  I guess the answers to that are
obvious:  tastes great, less filling... don't need to pee, no puking, and
hey, it's a great way for losers to get laid.

Peas to the underground,

b))merang fidget

Here's a guess at what happened to you.  I went to the Ninja Tunes party 
on Saturday that was at the Mission Rock Resort.  Tix were available at 
Bulletproof in advance.  We got to Mission Rock at midnight and there was 
a huge crowd to get in the door.  We got in relatively easily because we 
had tickets, but I'm not sure about everyone else.  When I was in line, a 
woman told me there was another party just down the road on China Basin 
but she couldn't afford to go and the map point was on Minna Street.  Is 
it possible that you bought a ticket for one party and then went to the 
wrong one?

-KC

Here are my five ways you know it's a going to be/has been a great party.  
Every one of these 
things was inspired by the last three Harmony parties I've been to!!  
Those parties were magical and magic things happened throughout those 
weekends!!


5. Good karma that day- (e.g. I came *very* close to losing my wallet and 
money before a party, but *someome* was looking out for me, and made me 
open the car door and look on the ground and therefore saved me from 
losing credit cards, dinero, etc.)

4. You flip on the radio to a random college station en route to a party 
and to your surprise they are playing *good* electronic music (not KMEL's 
cheese house-mind you!!)

3. You hair and make-up and outfit that you so carefully put together is 
a complete disaster by the next morning!

2.  You make it home *after* the newspaper!!

1. You spend your week recovering from your weekend!

:)-K

              ****Shit, goddamn, get off your ass and jam****

going down at Jelly's on China Basin. A single map point (973 Minna)

tix for Out-A-Sight were $12 each. Point towards
http://www.outasight.com, and you can contact the promoters there.

groove that had everyone jumping!

Subject: nrr - i'm back, and life is good!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

hello all-

i'm back from my vacation, i actually went a full day without touching my
computer!  (that was wierd).

i've been thinking about the collective freek-out that happened on sfraves
this week (you know, people yelling about nrr posts, too much volume, etc),
and i must say one thing:

I'M GLAD THAT WE'RE A FAMILY.  FAMILIES FLAME EACH OTHER, GET MAD, YELL, AND
EVENTUALLY WORK IT OUT.  I WOULDN'T HAVE IT ANY OTHER WAY.

so, to everyone, whether you're a lucker or you name is eric p [=)], thanks
for being part of this grand experiment called the electronic community.
we're on the forefront of a type of communication and lifestyle that may be
a large part of the future.  we're the pioneers (and many thanks to the
earlier unix guru's that made it possible) of the internet culture.

so everyone, sfraves has had growing pains over the past 4 months with the
religion debate, the veggie-meat, socialism, clothes, and nrr stuff.  but
these growing pains (and the fact that we seem to work through each of them)
signifies, at least to me, that something good is happening.

so, i dedicate all my energy of this exact moment to you all [stop and feel
it for a moment.  stop.  stop.  stop.  wait just a second more], and i hope
you like it.

i love you all, and flame me privately if you don't like it-

matt l

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Aug 19 10:38:19 1996

From: swoosh@ucscb.UCSC.EDU (John Elias Darrow)
Message-Id: <9608191737.AA06316@ucscb.UCSC.EDU>
Subject: Re: Funky and Tribal Funk
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 1996 10:37:00 -0700 (MDT)
In-Reply-To: <199608190747.AAA24780@mail-gw.fsr.net> from "Wowser" at Aug 19, 96 00:47:20 am
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Saturday was the strange day for me.  I got up and my neighbor was
cleaning his driveway.  and then another family a few houses down was 
cleaning their yard, and as I proceeded downtown I counted 12 separate
people in a three block stretch cleaning the sidewalk and yards.  and I
asked if there was some neighborhood cleanup thing I missed and was told,
no... it just seems a good morning to clean up.  and that was just the 
beginning of a very strange day... so that night I went to Tribal Funk.
It was only three blocks from my house and it was...
very clean.  All that cleaning must have cleared the air making the party
just shimmer in lack of dirt.  But I think a little dirt is important...
I found the party didn't capture my interest for too long...
Everybody was very friendly, the music was very strong and the lighting
was great... but I think a certain amount of dirt is necessary to inspire
you to let go and strive for that clean feeling.  That process of filtering
away the crap and rejoining that crystal clarity is what feels so good,
and if everything is already perfect, there's not so far to go, and not
so much to feel.  Although it was a lot of fun listening to the music pound
through that big space.  

I guess that means I need to start looking at things a different way,
let go of my current perspective and start exploring others,
to create more dirt.  maybe that's part of the reason I'm moving away 
from Santa Cruz next month... I've finished my cleaning here,
and the winds seem to be blowing.

Life is pretty interesting.

-john.
http://www.he.net/~swoosh/
> 
> Sunday night was kinda funky...almost like there was something in the air.
> Something hot.  Sticky.  That ol' swirling confusion again.  YUK.  It was a
> strange night for dreams.  A strange night for reality.
>

  for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 19 Aug 1996 11:32:01 -0700
X-Sender: epaul@macpo-1
Message-Id: <v02130502ae3e61376102@[146.225.54.58]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 1996 11:32:55 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: epaul@Synopsys.COM (Eric P. Peterson)
Subject: Beautiful People review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The location was the same as for Bass Instinct, but inside it was a whole
nuther world!  The Harmony crew decorated the space beautifully, as usual.
The lights and visuals were the best I've seen at a Harmony event in a
while (thanks, Ran!).  The familiar tapestries were there (Harmony, We are
the Flowers of Life, I am the sun - you are the moon - together we are
radiant, and a very nice mushroom tapestry I've never seen before).  Happy,
friendly faces filled the place, and the music was outstanding the whole
night through!  The music was so good that my upper body kept groovin'
during the times when my legs couldn't take any more :)
It was never too dark to see who was who.  There were wooden platforms on
either end of the space, with people dancing or chilling as time went on.
If there was a single negative vibe in the whole house, I sure didn't
detect it.  As always, the vibe was one of happy love and community,
everyone having a great time, and everyone eager to share their joy.  I
knew at least half the people there, and made some new friends, both from
the list and from beyond (so to speak: I don't think I met any aliens
there, but ya never know ;)).
I'd be willing to bet that, if you went to the space right now, you'd still
feel some of the vibes left over, mixed with those from the Gateway party.
I'm halfway tempted to drive up there, just to see.

Thanks to Harmony, and to all who attended, for a truly enchanted
evening/morning!

Love,
Eric

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Aug 19 11:46:03 1996

Received: (from gonzo@localhost) by solaria27.Stanford.EDU (8.7.5/8.7.3) id LAA02932; Mon, 19 Aug 1996 11:45:53 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 1996 11:45:53 -0700 (PDT)
From: Jonathan Mark Logan <gonzo@leland.Stanford.EDU>
To: friends&family <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: ninja tune
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.960819113309.2775B-100000@solaria27.Stanford.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

		
this show was phhhbbbaat!  I was sad to miss Hug o' War, but seeing as DJ
Food and Coldcut are my fave triphop artists, I couldn't pass it up.  
I particularly liked the first couple hours of the Ninja Tune repertoire,
when they were playing more downtempo, experimental freak-out triphop, and
less people were on the dancefloor.  As far as I understand, the setup
consisted of 4 turntables, with all of the Ninjas (I think 4
people) swapping on and off the tables and tag-teaming all night (which
amounted to about 8 hours... wow!).  

I think the bulletproof folk got a little liberal with the ticket sales,
because Mission Rock started to get really crowded after midnight, so much
so that I started getting really claustrophobic and left around 1am.  But
it's all good, cuz I was tired as hell anyway.  I had heard enough Ninja
to reinforce my love for that wacky label.  

I hope other folk had a good
time at Chrysalis!


	seeyuz on the playa,

			jon


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Aug 19 11:57:45 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id LAA15226; Mon, 19 Aug 1996 11:57:45 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from dns2.noc.best.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id LAA15213; Mon, 19 Aug 1996 11:57:40 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from shellx.best.com (shellx.best.com [206.86.0.11]) by dns2.noc.best.net (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id LAA15432 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 19 Aug 1996 11:57:38 -0700
Received: from tgrigsby (tgrigsby.us.dhl.com [199.41.137.104]) by shellx.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id LAA25235 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 19 Aug 1996 11:49:03 -0700
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 1996 11:49:03 -0700
Message-Id: <199608191849.LAA25235@shellx.best.com>
X-Sender: tgrigsby@best.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: Beautiful People
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Did you feel it?

I stepped up to the gate at F-8 at 8:30 and bought the first two tix to 
Beautiful People.  Feeling pretty proud about this, I grabbed a phone and 
left a message for the ever wonderful Leslie Ayres to tell her where the 
party would be.  Then it was off into the night.  Why wait?  I headed 
straight for the location and stepped in.  Things were just getting 
stabilized.  Adam (RLunatic) was helping get the final touches on the 
decorations.  This man, as usual, was showing us all how to cut loose.  The 
glo-stick flashin', Dr. Seuss hat wearing, glow-in-the-dark paint streaking, 
PHREAK!  LOVE THIS GUY!

I'm getting smarter about dressing for dancing.  Tank top, baseball cap to 
keep my hair out of my face, belt to keep my britches up.  It was a small 
vibey party so I could bring a back pack without fear of it being stolen -- 
a nice feeling.

After taking a quick look around I was not very confident about the size of 
the space.  I really didn't think it would hold 250 dancing ravers.  Maybe 
150, but 200?  I still don't think there was ever that many at one time, but 
it was never overcrowded.

The music was fantastic!  The set that stood out: Minor Minor.  The vibe was 
perfect.  The visuals were cool.  The sound was POUNDING.  I danced my poor 
ole body into oblivion.

And Brendan (Runway_Model 99) was Mr. GQ for the night.  This man shows up 
in a dress shirt and tie!  WOW!  I bow to his sleek motif.  An hour later I 
saw him dressed to dance, t-shirt on and glo paint in his hair.  The man was 
partyin'!

Leslie showed up around 1:30 (yes!).  I love talking to Leslie -- she's such 
a sweetie, but she never pulls a punch.  We watched a couple getting 
*seriously* nasty in the chill space.  Voyeur that I am, I got quite a kick 
out of it ;)

There was a lurker there, Amy Pedersen.  She attends San Lius Obispo, and if 
you've never met her, she *really* shakes it.

Kirsten was there, and we shared deep, dark secrets (ooooooo!)  She is so 
cute and so much fun to hang with.  And we danced.  And danced...

This party was what I needed.  BIG TIME.  No bad moments.  All night long, 
no bad moments.  It went off perfectly.  I guess the most frightening part 
of the whole evening was when I saw a hamsta scurrying across the floor.  
Seems they stowed away in my back pack.  I guess *everyone* wants to go to 
BP!  I followed him to see where he was going.  He zipped back behind the 
curtain against the back wall.  I peeked back there to find about 100 
hamstas bopping among the stuff piled behind the curtain.  The lights 
filtered throught the curtain, and they were jamming hard core to the sets 
being laid down.  Oh, and there were squirrels too, dressed in their gangsta 
wear, chilling and frontin' and making time with some of the girl squirrels, 
who of course were wearing their tightest bootie britches, with little holes 
cut out for their tails.  Some of the hamstas had a dance circle going.  I 
saw this one little guy shaking it, then flipping on his back and wiggling 
his feet in the air.  These guys really know how to move...

I danced until I was too pooped to pop.  I packed up and headed out around 
5am, bid everyone good night and stepped into the cold, sleepy hamstas 
waving from my backpack, to head home...

...thesmilethehugthesweatthestomptheshakethescreamtheboomboomboomboomboom....

...the music soaring, pounding, slipping, slowing...

...the black of night fading to pastels...

...the tired little children, smiling, rubbing their eyes...

...a squeak of tennis shoes sneaking away...

...the last ripples flowing outward, dissipating...

...a shift in reality...

...the world begins to awaken, and stir...

Did you feel it?

S

Subject: Thank you beautiful people!!!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Wow!,

    What a weekend! We want to thank everyone who came out to BP and 
once again combined their energies to create a very funfilled positive 
night!! We could not do this without you!!! What you all create 
(positivity, love, peace and happiness) is the driving force behind us. 
It gives us great pleasure to be able to contribute whatever we can, to 
help make your night as positive as possible. It is really a beautiful 
feeling, for all of us!!

    So thank you, thank you, thank you!!!

    For those of you who asked, BP was $15 because we were tring to 
raise money for two different purposes. One was the Gateway Burning Man 
trip, and the other was the Harmony 3 year Anniversary. We were able to 
raise a little money for both of these ventures, and thank everyone for 
help us achieve this. We are really interested in getting our parties 
down to $10 again. And hopefully someday (in the near future) will!! 
(Not at the 3 year though... :(   )

    Speaking of which... Tickets for the 3 year anniversary are almost 
ready!! We have already sold some, but we are only selling 1000, so get 
ready to hit the stores. They will hopefully be availible in stores by 
September 1st, or sooner! (Housewares on Haight in SF., and Solid 
Grooves on So. Bascom Ave in SJ.) If you wish to pre-purchase your 
ticket(s), you can! Just call the Voice Mails #'s to find out how! 

    This party is going to be totally worth everysingle penny! 
(Actually, more!!!) We are going completely crazy with our budget. 
Which means more good things for you!!! You'll see!!!

Peace and positivity,

Harmony :)

Also, there is some talk about us putting together Beautiful People pre 
party for the 3 anniversary party. If this actually does take place, it 
will happen on the weekend of the 6-7th of September, which is the week 
before the anniversary party (September 14th). So keep your ears open 
for this one!   Nanu! Nanu!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Aug 19 13:30:57 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id NAA24935; Mon, 19 Aug 1996 13:30:57 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from netcom.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id NAA24928; Mon, 19 Aug 1996 13:30:54 -0700 (PDT)
Received: (from simitzis@localhost) by netcom.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id NAA09286; Mon, 19 Aug 1996 13:06:05 -0700
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 1996 13:06:05 -0700
From: simitzis@netcom.com (Steve Simitzis)
Message-Id: <199608192006.NAA09286@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: what a weekend!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


:)

Well, all my weekends have been great since moving here, but maybe I'm
just picking the most wonderful places to go... After such a fantastic
weekend, I almost feel relieved to be back in my messy cubicle; if I
had any more fun, the very notion would have lost its meaning.

Beautiful people was. That's all I have to say about the event :) So
many of you were there! Thanks for the smiles, the hugs, and the good
conversation :) [you know who you are :)] I danced my *ass* off...

Saturday afternoon was spent sleeping at home, and then sleeping on the
beach in Santa Cruz listening to some groovy tunes; showed up late
to Viberation, but it was a good excuse to make the trek down. 

It was about 9pm, and by this time, I had spent the entire day limping
around... seems I killed my legs and ankles @ BP... Briefly, the
thought of skipping Hug o' War to rest passed through my head; my
body, even at 21, just can't handle the torture I used to endure.
I should probably take it easy so I don't get worn out, I thought.

wait a sec... That sounds like my mother talking! So I packed my
Slinky(tm) and cruised up to Hug o' War. This was an event not to
miss; there was some serious turntable wizardry going on here (who was
that before Joe Rice again?). The "Happy Happy Joy Joy" song put me in
just the right frame of mind for the nite [No, not a cheesy techno
remix; the actual song :)].

Thanks, Gateway and Harmony for two truly special parties!!!! Even
though they shared the same space, I never had the feeling that I
was at the same place two nites in a row. Actually, I never had the
feeling that I was any place in particular... 

To the friends that I missed, I hope your weekend was just as wonderful!

Steve

--

     Saturday, August 24
     
     Abduction (Groom Lake, Nevada) - by ZzyZx Productions, 8-Up 
     Productions, and G.C.D. 
     
     Stage #1...sighting at 6pm (Trance & Techno): Steve Wilder
     (London), Mr. Groove (Las Vegas, Desert Underground Network), D.N.A. 
     (New York, Caffeine Records), Huggie (Los Angeles, Global Energy 
     Music, Caffeine Records), Twist Top (Washington DC, Deepdish Records), 
     Gavin Hardkiss (San Francisco, Hardkiss Records), Sotero (San Diego), 
     Grover (Las Vegas, Global Energy Music), Brian (Los Angeles, 
     Moontribe). 
     
     Stage #2...identified at 9pm (Trip Hop & Cosmic House): HighTech
     Hippie (From Venus To Mars), Jerry Jam (New York, Las Vegas, Desert 
     Underground Network), Nobby Bollox (London, S.A.D. Records), debut of 
     Couch Nation (Global Underworld Artist featuring: Jeff Scott, Nicholas 
     & Ben Luckenbill, Joe Viena, and Joaquin Coodor), Omar Santana (New 
     York, Tricked-Out, H2Oh), DJ Duane (New York, Las Vegas, Fastasyland 
     Productions), Phunk (Chicago, Las Vegas, G.C.D.), William Paul 
     (Jacksonville, Florida, Las Vegas), 
     
     Stage #3...top secret (Space Funk): Elof (Las Vegas, Da Joynt),
     Ces-One (Las Vegas).
     Drum Circle: Rich-E (Las Vegas)
     
     "The government has been withholding information pertaining to
     the secret base located at Area 51 on Groom Lake (it's a dry lake bed) 
     from the people of the world.  We want to know what is really going on 
     there, and this is your chance to help find out...while busting some 
     phat trancey grooves on top of the speaker stacks.  Abduction will 
     have petitions ready for you to sign indicating that you want the 
     government to tell us what is really going on.  In essence, this is a 
     political rally...and an alien invocation at the same time.  There 
     will be multiple stages of sound totalling 150,000 watts pumping out 
     the booming bass, plus concessions, lasers, and a medical tent."
     
     Sound By: SHREDDER. All land has been leveled & cleared.  No
     hills or sand.  Just baked desert. dance dirt!!!
     6pm. $25. all ages. Tix at Ticketmaster. at Groom Lake in Rachel, 
     Nevada (aprox 20 miles from Area 51).

     http://www.unlv.edu/~bright/LVraves

> Hey Antone,
> 
> Rohypnol is a legal prescription drug (and apparantly easy to come by for
> smuggling purposes) in Mexico.  A couple of years ago it started gaining
> notoriety in Florida and some of the deep-south states, when, as you
> reminded us, women reported being dosed and then raped.  The effects, I've
> heard, are sorta like drinking a 12 pack of beer, and I imagine, the
> potency is magnified if mixed with drinking.   They were dubbed "roofies"
> because  the idiots who were using it, I guess, don't know how to spell,
> and were reading "rohypnol" as "rophynol".    Anyway if you're looking to
> get drunk, why not just down a 12 pack?  I guess the answers to that are
> obvious:  tastes great, less filling... don't need to pee, no puking, and
> hey, it's a great way for losers to get laid.
> 
> Peas to the underground,
> 
> b))merang fidget
> 
> 
> 
> Peter Sandifer
> Customer Service

In addition (and more ominous), Rohypnol leaves the user with little or no 
memory of events which transpired while under the drug.  Also, traces of the
drug leave the system within a few days.  Prosecuting the fuckers who rape
women with the drug's aid is difficult because the victims are unsure of what
happened, and if they aren't tested very quickly, the drug is gone from their
system, which makes prosecuting much more dificult.  And there are probably
numerous cases where the person is so unsure they don't bother saying anything.
There have been a few reports of Rohypnol abuse in the Bay Area.  Not a great
way to get laid, but a great way to rape someone.

I think Rohypnol is a colorless, relatively tasteless liquid, but I'm not sure.

-mike

PS: why does Florida seem like the obvious place to find such a thing?

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Aug 19 15:09:02 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id PAA06864; Mon, 19 Aug 1996 15:09:02 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from netcom.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id PAA06851; Mon, 19 Aug 1996 15:08:59 -0700 (PDT)
Received: (from simitzis@localhost) by netcom.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id PAA07664; Mon, 19 Aug 1996 15:08:49 -0700
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 1996 15:08:49 -0700
From: simitzis@netcom.com (Steve Simitzis)
Message-Id: <199608192208.PAA07664@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: party review: Oracle BBQ (bordering on NRR)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Well, did anyone go to the Oracle BBQ on Friday? Hmm... Maybe it was just
too underground :) In any case, anxious for the weekend, the BBQ sounded
very appealing; a chance to lounge in the sun (and get paid for it), and
hopefully find some salad to munch on.

So as I walked to the field, I heard the muffled *boomboomboomboom* that
sounded oh so familiar to me... I paused with a moment of gestalt, and an
excited anticipation for what was to be this past weekend. 

As I drew closer to the field, of course I was tricked; the familiar
beat was soon layered with the cheesy bubble gum house that could only
reek of bad wedding DJ... but nonetheless I was thrilled to be away
from the evil Sparc 20.

Then I discovered the whole reason I was there: Mr Wedding DJ decided
to throw down some line dancing song (similar to the Electric Slide or
the Hustle); I'd never heard it before, but apparently everyone else
had... What was once a quiet gathering of developers and corporate
types blossomed as crowds of happy Oracle employees shared the
lawn with the DJ. Everyone was dancing, and smiling. A feeling of
childishness youth happiness freedom shined from the faces of my 
co-workers;

Once the song ended, a few people decided to stay and continue dancing
"freestyle". But after a few minutes, the party died down, and people
returned to their shells... perhaps they wished to keep at it, but
maybe they were too shy... maybe they thought they didn't know how to
dance... noone wants to be singled out... as quickly as the happiness
came, the inhibitions soon followed. oh well; I had my last handful of
fruit and walked back.

just some thoughts from my cubicle -

Steve
