From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Aug 19 17:15:05 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id RAA23061; Mon, 19 Aug 1996 17:15:05 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from value.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id RAA23049; Mon, 19 Aug 1996 17:15:00 -0700 (PDT)
Received: (from scarab@localhost) by value.net (8.6.12/8.6.9) id RAA16046; Mon, 19 Aug 1996 17:14:58 -0700
Date: Mon, 19 Aug 1996 17:14:57 -0700 (PDT)
From: KaySEE <scarab@value.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
cc: Kristi Holland <kristih@sfsu.edu>
Subject: BP/Ninja Review
Message-ID: <Pine.BSD/.3.91.960819162636.3194B-100000@value.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, seeing as it's a slow monday on sfraves and that there isn't 
already a barrage of reviews, I thought I'd put in my laudatory comments 
about BP and the Ninja Tunes Tour.

Friday/BP

It was a beautiful small space fully decorated to the hilt like every 
Beautiful People that I've gone to.  This one held special meaning because my 
best friend and I went together to BP in May.  It was only our second rave 
together and our first *amazing* one.  That was a most memorable night 
that we both cherish.  She is now leaving me for Europe (can you believe 
that? :P ) so this was our last weekend partying together.  And this 
third BP turned out to be as special as the first and the second.

This was the smallest party I've ever been to and also the smallest space 
I've ever been in.  But it really worked well, especially with creating a 
community vibe.  It was easy to find your friends and safe to leave your 
stuff lying around.  There was a really long bathroom line because there 
was only one toilet, but it was cool because the line meshed with the 
dance floor.  So you could boogie while waiting for the bathroom, 
if you were able to uncross your legs, that is! :)

Someone had brought flourescent paint that adorned many ravers.  And 
Brendan brought his day-glo "disco" stickers, the ones you see in Mexican 
music stores.  Turntables in spanish would be tocadiscos, eh? :)  These 
stickers were everywhere!

The dj that really stood out was Minor Minor.  He played from 12:00-2:30, 
and it was a great set.  I was amazed at the versatility of his sound.  
He played mostly trance (at least from my limited knowledge), but stuff that 
varied from the more housey trance to low-key hardchore.  I was amazed at 
how well he mixed these different sounds up and made them flow so smoothly.  
I remember checking a couple of times to see if the dj had changed because it
sounded different, but, NO, it would still be Minor Minor!

Gregg came after Minor Minor, and he did a great job.  I heard more than 
one person say, "Wow, he's rippin' it up!"  Gregg provided my friend and 
I with the sweetest part of the evening.  He stuck in Born Slippy by 
Underworld, and we got all sappy and glowy reminiscing about the 
Orbital/Underworld show that we had such a great time at!

I had some really nice chats with people and had a lot more people than 
usual talk to me out of the blue.  I can't figure out if that was the 
party, the size of the party, some freak of nature, or my new perfume I 
was wearing!!! :P 

We left around 4:30-5 because we had big days ahead of us.  I still got 
hardly any sleep, and felt like I was in a hallucinatory haze.  Sleep 
deprivation, can you get addicted to THAT?! :)  But, the masochist in me 
decided my body hadn't had enough punishment yet, and we ventured out to 
the Ninja Tunes Tour at Mission Rock.

Saturday/Ninja Tunes

I'm really glad I went to the Ninja gig because I got to hear a lot of 
music I never hear in SF.  We got there around 1 a.m. and danced to some 
really funky, groovy Trip Hop and Jungle.  The jungle was really good, 
more funky than what I've heard (which is admittedly very little), and 
much less spastic.  Somehow the music worked miracles on my decrepid body 
and got me shakin' it for a little bit.  However, after about an hour, my 
back and knees decided pavement just wasn't made for dancing.  

Mission Rock Resort is really interesting.  It is two floors, with inside 
bars and outside decks.  It looked a bit dilapidated, and I pondered the 
thought of a 7.1 at that moment, then I quickly *didn't* think about that!.  
The music was upstairs and downstairs 
outside.  It was a bit cold which turned into a blessing in disguise when 
you really worked up a sweat.  It felt really heavenly to not overheat.  

At around 2:30 a.m. Jonah Sharpe came on.  I hadn't heard him before, and 
I have to say he played the *exact* bassy, techno-ish, trance  (maybe 
psuedo Trip Hop kind of like the Chemical Brothers but not quite) that I 
love.  Some was akin to what I've heard Ethan play, 
and some was a bit more on the techno side with a lack of organic sounds.  
If anyone could describe (one word or less--just kidding!!) what exactly he 
was playing, I'd love to know.  I don't want to pigeonhole the music, but 
I would like to be able to look around for more of it.

I have to stick in a couple words about the crowd (bizarre).  It was this 
strange mixture of ravers, clubbers, regulars (it's a bar) who probably 
got trapped there, and this SF hipster element looking for the next big 
thing! (no offense to anyone, I absolutely hate labels, but need a few 
for descriptive purposes:) I found the crowd enormously entertaining, 
fun-loving, and 
interesting.  It was less friendly than some of the raves I've been to, 
but much more friendly than some of the clubs.  Anyway, it was fun being 
around a very large diverse crowd.  

It ended at 4 a.m. and my very tired body is still in recovery :-/

-KaySEE

(who is now sig-less because the sig (bad words and all) ended up on letters 
meant for future graduate advisors--very embarrassing!  I accidentally 
sent it to my dad once.  That was not good.  
I'm an adult, but there are always things you just don't want to explain 
to your parents!  Especially narrow-minded, preachy parents! Arg!!!  Time 
to get a separate email account!!)

	rohypnol is the so-called "date-rape drug" which is getting a
	little hype these days.  seems evil people sneak it into a
	victim's drink and rape them.  why is this easy?

	apparently rohypnol renders a person under its influence rather
	delirious or passed out, and basically they don't remember a
	thing from the experience.  rape victims usually only know they
	have been sexual because there is evidence of the activity, there
	are no memories.

	kind of sick.  and considering the effects, it doesn't even sound
	very interesting to take recreationally.

ORC:  The CCC party at the Sandbox was pretty cool.  I walked right in as everyone
was sitting on the floor, getting ready to do meditation.  I felt a little
awkward walking in as everyone was seated, looking straight at us, but it was 
really cool, everyone trying to gel together like that...the end of the 
meditation was like, whoo!  Talk about opening your eye...though some people found
the loud vibrations and lights to be uh...too much...

I had a really good time.  You?

While out and about this weekend at a second-rate party called "Top 
Secret," I picked up a flyer for "Open." I was reading through and 
noticed how much more interesting than the usual Chicago tripe it seemed 
when I realized that the listed phone numbers were for SF and it said  it 
was "brought to you by same people as 2nd Chakra."

There I am trying to figure out why some SF flyers would be at this 
Chicago rave when I was introduced to the two girls who has brought them. 
Seems that anybody with a wad of flyers gets into raves around here for 
free, so they brought what they had handy.

I can't wait to hear how this country-wide promotion affects the turn out.

I was gonna say the same thing, but then I thought "Yeah, but those things are
fun (for a number of people anyway), and some of them are very addictive, 
both of which create a demand."  But like you said, rohypnol doesn't sound
like the kind of drug that would be sought after for recreational use, and
I would guess that only a very small segment of the population would sink
so low as to use it for raping someone (The stories I've heard happened with
college and *shudder* high school students).  So why would it be widely
distributed (although I'm not sure it is)??  But maybe someone gets a kick
out of passing out and not remembering, or maybe if you take it in small
amounts you just get really high, or maybe the ease with which you can
"get some" and not get caught, or ...  The scary part is that a lot of people
don't consider "date rape" to be nearly as bad as "rape".  How many people
have you known that try to get someone drunk...?  Hmm.  On second thought, I
guess there's a LARGE segment of the population that would be interested in
rohypnol.  F**k.

Angry again,
-mike

some equipment and his support of our efforts.  :)

[ to sfraves list ]

 According to an article in today's ( Tues, Aug 20 ) Chronicle, the 
Park Bowl at 1855 Haight St. is going to close, to be replaced with
a big Amoeba CD & vinyl store. Sheesh - "newbies" to the local scene 
used to confuse the Ameba store with the Amoeba store across the bay -
now, people will really be confused! They'll just be two blocks away 
from each other.

 The last night for the Park Bowl's "Rock & Bowl" will be this 
Saturday. Any news about whether there will be a last "Pack n' Bowl"
this Thursday? The article was all about "Rock & Bowl" , not one
mention of "Pack n' Bowl".

     I know that SoCal raves have the graphics for their laminates 
     available on the Hyperreal site, as well as instructions for how to 
     print them.  We might consider that... You can also make your own 
     design.  If you have access to a computer (in this forum this IS a 
     rhetorical question), you can spark up paintbrush or macpaint or corel 
     or whatever it is you use.  Make a groovin design (we KNOW YOU CAN!!!) 
     Go to a kinko's or something if you want to print it out really nice.  
     Have it laminated.  Buy some really nice string.  Couple bucks tops.  
     Embrace your individuality while proclaiming your community.

Hey kids,

If you haven't yet had the chance to listen to SF's microbroadcast radio
station,  Radio Libre (103.3) tune in now.

If you want to catch my show, I'm on tonight from 9:00-10:30.  (I'm on once
a month), combining music an an odd array of twisted parables,
action-packed vignettes and potty-mouth humor.  The stories I tell on-air
are often borderline crude, but with always slightly sauteed in a sauce of
satirical social conscience.

Tonight's Line-up (Tuesday August 20)

Music: Ambient
Some of the Stories I will tell:
        Grandpa Fidget and the Poison Plot
        Looking to Score (featuring the Telegraph Ave. hippies)
        Fodd Not Bombs vs. the Nazi Cops
        The Hunting Trip
        Dumped at the Drive-In

        ...and many more!
        Please tune in tonight.

In 2 weeks (September 3rd) Max Love and King Me are on the air at the same
time, 9-10:30.  Their show is looser than mine, more spontaneous and
bizarre, (in the tradition of Negativland) and certainly worth listening
to.

In any case, Radio Libre is all about freedom of the airwaves.  The FCC
looms over them, and threatens to make their lives miserable. If you
believe the airwaves should be returned to "the people", start your support
by simply tuning in to see what's going on.  Many of the programs feature
music you will *never* hear on any other station, and all DJ's work for
free.

Any questions about Radio Libre, contact me privately, I'm fixing to
unsubscribe from sfraves for the day

Peas to the underground,

-boomerang fidget


Peter Sandifer

First of all, I'd like to give a huge mental hug to everyone who
helped out and attended Viberation. It was everyone's contributions 
that made the party turn out as well as it did. I hope everyone had a 
great time and was able to make a few more friends.

   Special thanks to: The Viberation Crew for your enthusiasm with 
this project, The DJ's (Tom, Tim, and Le Le) for spinning x-tra phat 
sets, Epicenter for providing the kick-ass system, Randy for hooking 
it all up, Mike Migurski for designing the flyers, Chin for the giant 
Snoopy, Loren for being the designated free fruit distributor, Adam 
for just about *everything*, and last but definitely not least, the 
Harmony crew for your incredible selfless efforts with this party.

   N-E-wayz, As I leave I'd just like to say that you all are the 
greatest bunch of people I've ever met. Collectively, you've really 
redefined what "raving" means to me. The energy is so great on this 
list, together you can accomplish anything. I wish all of you good 
luck in your future endeavors, and I hope to see some of you again 
soon. But don't worry, sfraves is only an email away and my computer 
is coming with me. I intend to be lurking in your hearts forever.

Love alwayz,

CT

Terry Estioko
6304 Rancho Mission Road #305
San Diego, CA 92108

across the border into the US in order to fund the Contras in South America.

documented and referenced in a major newspaper.  It ran starting Sunday 
and ended today.  If anyones interested its on their webpage at 
http://www.sjmercury.com/drugs

Subject: Field of Dreams - some more info

I really don't want to post this yet but before rumours get completely
out of hand, I have some more info to add to the Field of Dreams story.
Before I get into it though, I'd like to make it clear that I'm speaking
for myself as an individual and not on behalf of Ottawa promoters or
ravers.  I also have no connection with Orion productions however, I saw
a lot of what went on behind the scenes to salvage things.  I'm working
with a number of people here in Ottawa to piece together what happened
this weekend at Field of Dreams because a lot of people deserve to be
acknowledged for everything they did to turn a disaster into one of the
most beautiful experiences I've ever witnessed.  When we have a clearer
picture of what happened, we'll write up a statement giving out thanks
and respect to all those who deserve (and there's a *lot* of them) but
we want to take our time with it to make certain no one gets missed.
Please do not take anything I say here as fact, I'm only trying to
explain what I saw happen - I really wanted to hold off writing this
until I could confirm more of it.

Basically, it's known that FoD was a massive undertaking with a lot of
talent that, had it run smoothly, would have been an incredible party.
For whatever reason (and I won't speculate as to why, I honestly don't
know), people didn't show.  Also, the party was really disorganized
right from Friday.  Anyhow around 1 or 2am Saturday, some of us heard
the promoters were panicking and getting ready to run (I don't know for
certain if this is the reason they were leaving but they were definitely
leaving).  An Ottawa promoter, without warning and who had nothing to do
with the party, was told he was to take control of the party.  He
grabbed two others of us and told us what was going down.  Our first
reaction was to try and find some of the DJs who hadn't been paid and
were quite likely stranded to try and get them taken care of before the
promoters left.  We weren't able to get them quickly enough though.
That's the bad shit, what comes next is so incredibly positive that I
don't think anyone should dwell on what went wrong or who's to blame,
etc.

After this point, it was pretty hectic for the next couple of hours.  I
don't know exactly who did what but we managed to get the main stage
turned on and organized some of the DJs to finish playing the party.
The sound company running the main stage would not turn it on until
they'd been paid up front even though it was set up and ready to go.
The promoters had been taking everything they got from the door sales
(which wasn't much) and trying to pay for the system all weekend.  Why
they let us use the system at all I'm not sure because they were still
owed $2500 (CDN) but nonetheless, they let us move the party there,
knowing full well they weren't going to be paid, which was pretty damn
cool of them.

Next, Lenny Dee, Carl Cox, and Electric Indigo agreed to play even
though they hadn't been paid in full or in some cases, at all.  Carl
Cox, as I understand it, had received some of his payment but was still
owed a lot.  Although these three played until the end of the party,
there were a lot of other DJs there and I don't doubt that a number of
them offered to play without getting payed as well.  In order to try to
keep the party going, we had to get some money to the sound company and
we also needed money to keep the shuttles running.  There was absolutely
no money to pay off people and none of us could cover it.  A silent
investor in FoD who was not himself a promoter but stepped in to salvage
things, went on the mic to explain that we needed money to keep things
going and keep the shuttles going.  We passed a collection box around
and people literally threw in all the money they had on them!  From a
crowd of maybe 800-900, we raised close to $1200 in a few minutes (don't
take the numbers as fact, I'll need to double check them).  As far as I
know, about $1000 of that went to the sound company with the
understanding that we could use it until noon.

Until 7am, the DJs spun absolutely incredible sets.  The vibe was like
nothing I've ever seen before.  It was so powerful it just overwhelmed
you.  A lot of us truly experienced what the rave is all about in those
few hours.  We all knew we were experiencing something unique and none
of us held back.  I have honestly never seen people dance with such
complete abandon and joy.

In the meantime, we spent most of the morning scrambling around trying
to explain to people that they weren't getting paid and trying to ensure
all the DJs and ravers weren't going to be stranded.  Security did stick
around and agreed to keep watch on the sound systems even though at that
point, I'm sure they realized they weren't getting paid either.  At
around 6:30am, 21 police cruisers surrounded the site and we thought we
were being shut down (this sound system was incredibly loud and we
weren't more than a couple hundred yards from residential).  I'm not
exactly sure who it was that called them however, when I spoke to some
of them they said they hadn't come to shut down the party but they were
expecting a riot when the sound system was shut down at 7am.  I'm not
sure who decided to do this but I assume it was the sound company - as I
said though, I don't know why they let us use at all so it was cool that
they let us go until 7am.  We explained to the police that the last
thing anyone was going to do was riot and they were really cool about
the whole thing.  They didn't try and move into the party or even stop
anyone who tried to leave.  They stuck around to make sure things went
smoothly as the party shut down but most of them left when they saw we
were all leaving peacefully.  

At 7, we went on the mic to shut the party down.  The crowd was totally
cool with it and no one gave us a hard time.  We tried to give respects
out on the mic but things were still in total confusion and there was no
way we could thank all the people who deserved it.

We spent the next couple of hours trying to get shuttles back to Ottawa
and Montreal since the other bus company had to be sent away since none
of us could come up with the money to pay them.  The police helped us
find shuttles and the fair ground owners paid for three of them.  We
used the remainder of the money collected to pay for a fourth shuttle.
We had hoped to hold onto some of it to help pay to get some of the DJs
home but at that point, the priority was to make sure no one got
stranded at the site.  There were still a number of people who didn't
make the shuttles but we managed to find rides back for every one of
them so no one was stranded.  Everyone's car was packed but people still
agreed to take back stranded ravers.

We sent someone back to Ottawa to take care of the DJs and see if an
afterparty could be organized since we had some legendary talent sitting
around in Ottawa and a lot of them didn't get to play during the
weekend.  Sunday night, a more or less unannounced afterparty ran in a
small Ottawa club with Motomasa, Smoove Dee, Christian Vogel, Roy Davis
Jr., Dietrich, and Prototype all playing for free.  Neil Landstrumm was
also there to play but we couldn't get equipment for him to do live
P.A..  Carl Cox had planned to come down but declined later because I
think he needed the rest.  Needless to say, it was an awesome party.

There's a list of respects and thanks that's unbelievably long after
this weekend.  I don't want to list them off now because I don't want
anyone to feel slighted if I miss them.  All of the DJs were wonderful
even though most didn't get paid and some even lost money since they had
paid for their own transportation.  Everyone we had to deal with who was
owed money didn't give us a hard time - they understood what had
happened and a lot of them went out of their way to help out.  A number
of the Ottawa promoters helped out to make sure the DJs were taken care
of.  I can't say what happened in Montreal but I believe some DJs may
have ended up there and I hope they were taken care of as well.  There
were a couple of individuals who really deserve to be recognised but
we'll get to that later.  Most important though, the ravers from
Montreal, Toronto, New York state, Ottawa, and I'm sure other areas,
were incredible.  The solidarity I witnessed this weekend as they pulled
together to save the party was like nothing I've ever seen.  Speaking to
a lot of them afterward, they were all so cool and understanding about
the whole thing that I've got the utmost respect for them.

While the Ottawa scene can't fully repay all those who deserve it, we're
doing what we can to make what amends we can.  We will get out a
statement giving out proper acknowledgement to everyone but we want to
do it properly so please be patient.  We lost track of a number of
people in the confusion and we still haven't heard the whole story yet
so it's going to take some time.

All I can say though is it was an incredible experience.
Understandably, a lot of people are upset and we all sympathize with
them, but I hope that we can focus on the positive things that happened
this weekend and build on them.  It would be a shame to waste this
opportunity.  To the inevitable mud slingers - trying to fix blame isn't
going to help anything, what happened happened, let it rest.

peace and respect to all,

Sean

p.s. If anyone can bounce this off to relevant mailing lists and
newsgroups I missed, it'd be much appreciated.  Although the event was
local to the Ottawa/Montreal area, a number of international DJs should
be recognized for what they did.
-- 
Sean Hennigar                    email: hennigar@on.bell.ca
------------------------------------------------------------

Cybertribe,
 
Well, I'm finally back on the East Coast and back at work after spending
ten days out in San Francisco.  I flew out on Friday, August 9th, and flew
home on Sunday, August 18th.  I stayed the whole time with friends in
South San Francisco and San Jose, but had rented a car to be able to get
around on my own.
 
This was the fourth time I was out there in the last four months.  What
can I say?  I had such a great time every other time I visited for a
weekend, that I keep going back.  I had met a girl in particular who I
thought was completely amazing, and that got me thinking a lot about
moving out there permanently.  So, I decided that I should go out there
for at least a week and see if SF was really for me.
 
The first time I ever went to San Fran was four years ago the week of my
21st birthday.  I stayed with a friend from college and my best friend
from Minnesota had joined me there.  This last trip was *exactly* four
years later, and brought back tons of memories of that time.
 
Sunday, August 11th was my 25th birthday, but this definitely was not the
best birthday of my life.  I did get to spend some of it with my friend
Sandra from Princeton, NJ who is living in San Jose (and who is the
nicest, most caring, most understanding person I have ever met).
 
I don't know if this time I could actually say I had the time of my life 
this past week and a half because I had a lot on my mind and on my heart.
But nevertheless, it was very interesting and I learned a lot.  I
also got to do a lot of soul searching.  I filled up the weekdays by
interviewing for jobs (which ended up being very gruelling), and the
nights by going out to parties.
 
I'm going to send a follow up message to list the parties and raves I went
to and DJed.  Peace to all the SF ravers that I got to meet and hang out
with.
 
One love.
 
-MARSHAL VILLAROSA
-NEW JERSEY UNDERGROUND
http://www.hyperreal.com/~mars


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Aug 20 16:54:50 1996

Date: Tue, 20 Aug 1996 16:54:42 -0700 (PDT)
From: DJ MARS <mars@hyperreal.com>

cc: ne-raves@world.std.com
Subject: Part II: Back EAST from the WEST SIDE...

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Precedence: bulk

Cybertribe,

Here's a list of the events/parties I checked out in San Fran this past
week:

8/9/96
------
Friday night, I went to a few parties: FedEx, Hunny(?) at the Deli, and
then to Nikita at 1015 Folsom St. to see Carl Cox blow the spot up.
 
 
8/10/96
-------
Saturday afternoon, this guy Mosha threw a party out in Richmond on the
Bay (at the Sunset spot) which I was going to spin at, but it got broken
up by the cops before we got there.
 
Saturday night was supposed to be this big party called "Nation" with
Sasha and John Digweed, but the cops didn't even let the party start.  So,
Jimmy Tennant from the Bagok Tribe threw a party at his place in South San
Fran and I DJed there for hours.
 
 
8/11/96
-------
Sunday morning, went out for a birthday breakfast (yummy =] ).
 
Sunday evening, hit the "Sunset" party at Richmond.  Fukin' phat.  Saw a
few SF ravers there and NYC raver Mike Gee.  I was introduced to this girl
Toni from Rhode Island by Raf and Jan, and we bought tickets for Nation
off them which was moved to that 1015 club.  People cheered as the sun
went down.  Hella nice. ;)
 
Sunday night, went to the "Nation" make-up party and ran into DB from NYC!
Soooo funny to see him out there.  He invited me out to robot wars this
past weekend, but I never made it over there.  [DB if you read this,
sorry.  By the way, I still have your baseball cap from Structure last
year--I'll bring it up to Temple or something.]  I also finally talked to
Sandra Collins after meeting her exactly four years ago.  That is so crazy
that it's been that long.
 
 
8/12/96
-------
Monday night, went on rides at the Santa Cruz boardwalk. =]
 
 
8/14/96
-------
Wednesday night, DJed at "Groove" at the Deli. Carlos and Dreamer went off
as well. It was definitely slamming.
 
 
8/15/96
-------
Thursday night, checked out Funktion at the Maritime Hall and ran into
Kevin Gimball from Special K prods. in Philly and O'keef who spun there.
>From there we went to Natural at Mission Rock, and to ThurZdaze at the
Deli.
 
 
8/16/96
-------
Friday night was a crazy fukked up night.  After an interview at Organic
Online, I went down to Haight St. to eat and go to a couple shops and ran
into this girl from Seattle who was down in SF interviewing, too.  She
was buying tickets at that Frequency 8 record shop for the Harmony party
that night called "Beautiful People."  I had never heard of any of the
DJs, but kept it in mind for somewhere to go that night.
 
After going back and picking up the guys, we headed out to the Good Family
party, but it was pretty slow.  We didn't stay around long enough to find
out if King Britt ever made it out there.  Next, we stopped by Stompy but
Derrick Carter never showed (Mark Farina and Preston played).  After that,
it was off to the Deli where "Five" was going on.  It was overpacked with
waaaay to many heads in there.
 
My friends wanted to go over to some girls' house over in the East Bay,
so we ended up splitting up.  I wanted to check out this Irian Jaya party,
but had left the flyer at home with the info number on it.  How did that
go off???  I ended up driving back over to F8 alone to see if they were
still selling tickets for B.P.  They were closed, but a note on the door
said, "The party's at 150 Folsom St.  There still may be tickets
available.  Please come join us!"  I was like, "Right on!" (heh) and headed
over there.
 
This party was the *BOMB*.  I walked into this place and was just like,
"Now this is a party!"  The music was mostly trance, and I had no idea who
any of the DJs were.  All I know is that i danced a lot and I met "hella
people" there.  If you were there, please e-mail me...
 
 
8/17/96
-------
So, on Saturday, after going to bed around 3 in the afternoon, I got woken
up and dragged out to Antioch where this dude Sausee was having a house
party.  I spun there for a while, then we headed over to Jellys to see
Doc Martin spin a three hour set.  That guy is *AMAZING*.  The crowd was
so into it.  The place closed at 5am, and everyone was chanting for
"...ONE MORE SONG!!!"  Incredible.
 
 
8/18/96
-------
Visited a friend in San Jose, flew out of SF at 10pm, arrived in
Newark, NJ at 6am.  "Boy are my arms tired..."
 
 
SF has an amazing rave scene and it's much different from the New York
City scene in so many ways, that I don't even know where to begin.  I
just know that I love it, though.  There have been so many times in the
past year and a half where I've totally wanted to never go to another
party again and quit DJing because of how shitty the parties and the
people were here on the East Coast, but SF reminds you why you got into
it in the first place.
 
My SF trip was definitely an interesting experience despite it turning out
completely different than I had ever planned...
 
Peace,
MARSHAL VILLAROSA
NEW JERSEY UNDERGROUND

Keep your smile smilin'!!! =]
http://www.hyperreal.com/~mars

>Same old rules: no eyes, no groin.
>
>A normal person wouldn't steal pituitaries.
>
>Damn, I'll burn you into a BBQ chicken!
>
>Take my advice, or I'll spank you without pants.
>
>Who gave you the nerve to get killed here?
>
>Quiet or I'll blow your throat up.
>
>You always use violence. I should've ordered glutinous rice chicken.
>
>I'll fire aimlessly if you don't come out!
>
>You daring lousy guy.
>
>Beat him out of recognizable shape!
>
>I have been scared shitless too much lately.
>
>I got knife scars more than the number of your leg's hair!
>
>Beware! Your bones are going to be disconnected.
>
>How can you use my intestines as a gift?
>
>The bullets inside are very hot. Why do I feel so cold?

Forwarded message:
From:	awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com (Andy Wyszkowski)

     I know that SoCal raves have the graphics for their laminates 
     available on the Hyperreal site, as well as instructions for how to 
     print them.  We might consider that... You can also make your own 
     design.  If you have access to a computer (in this forum this IS a 
     rhetorical question), you can spark up paintbrush or macpaint or corel 
     or whatever it is you use.  Make a groovin design (we KNOW YOU CAN!!!) 
     Go to a kinko's or something if you want to print it out really nice.  
     Have it laminated.  Buy some really nice string.  Couple bucks tops.  
     Embrace your individuality while proclaiming your community.
     
     Peace,
     AndyW

     remember his name!!!) on the Punk movement from some PBS special>>>

Subject: Harmony tickets & how to get them...
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello everyone,

    I have now gotten finger pains from writing each of you personally, 
so I'll do it all at once!... :)

    Harmony tickets are now availible, however they are not yet 
availibe in the stores. They are availible via MAIL ORDER only (right 
now). This was specifically geared for our mailing list, but hey you 
guys can jump on this too!!! 

    We are selling the tickets at stores starting September 1st. In the 
mean time you can purchase them from your own couch, in the comfort of 
your own home!!! 

    All you need to do is send the following:

1) Your complete name, or at least one that you will recognize in your 
mailbox.

2) Your complete address, including ZIP CODE!!!

3) A money order for the amount of $20, for each ticket you request.    
        For example, 1 ticket=$20 , 2 tickets=$40, etc.

    Please only send money orders, NO CASH, NO PERSONAL CHECKS, NO 
PAYCHECKS, AND NO MONOPOLY MONEY!!!! (and this includes Camel Cash)

4) Also, on a peice of paper tell us wether or not you would like to be 
on the Harmony/ Beautiful People mailing list. If you are already on 
it, then please do not sign up again. But if you are not on it, you 
should be! It's cool!!!


Now all you have to do is send these things to the following address:

HARMONY
Po Box 111084
Campbell Ca. 95011-1084

You might want to consider doing this quickly, cause they go on sale 
elsewhere during the BM festival, and we might sell out. We are not 
responsible for any lost or stolen tickets, and each ticket is 
irreplacable. (So please hold onto them!!!!)

Any other info will be given on our Voice Mails #'s 

(408) 486-9591  &  (408)450-3044

Hope to see you there!!!!!!!!

Peace and positivity,

Greg :)

Don't use aol if you have a choice. But if you don't have a www browser then
you'll have to go to the www through aol (I'm sure they have a space for
that). After that, find

clicking on items related to what you want such as sfraves.

Lack of knowledge isn't stupid, not using the knowledge you have IS.

Go to Elevate next weekend! You can find info on the SoCal Raves section of
Hyperreal. It'll be in the Angeles Crest National Forest, and it'll be
guaranteed extra-PLURy. Actually, LA has a thriving techno scene. Just
don't look for clubs, because there aren't any worth speaking of. Louis XIV
host soccasional clubs, and there are a few others (Karma on Friday nights,
for example,) but avoid Magic Wednesdays at all costs!

Just check out the SoCal Raves Calendar. It's all there...

Have fun. I'll be at Elevate m'self!

Subject: Divine Rhythm Society-Kudos!

Halleighluia!! (help me out w/the sp. on this Matt).  Excellent party.  I was
just a bit leary 
about going to a rave in a christian church, but was overwhelmed at the
amount of mutual respect and acceptance.  No false fronts, no "hey dudes, we
can relate to your people" type shit.  Honest to goodness good vibes
throughout.  Didn't know of the D.J.'s but they all played well.  The
organist's set at 6am was definitely the bomb.  Drummin on my new Djembe (:
was therapeutic indeed! Got to see some old friends and made some new, hi
Jonathan, Rachel, Lisa, Paul, Burger King! Big thanks to St. Johns!
Good to see progress towards scrubbin them age old stains off the walls of
Christianity.
-StEvEo

Hey, I was just surfing the web and came across THE DJ. it a 24hr online
radio station on the web. It had techno, trance, hip-hop, and alot more
other stations. It's pretty cool, right now I'm listening to REZ off of
Logic Trance 2 on TheBeat channel and just listened to"Eternal Spirit" off
of Logic Trance 2. which was on the Trance station. On MegaBPMs channel
"WEB" by DR. Galactik on Circumference 01 is playing. Those are the ones I
have been listening to. They don't mix, just one after the other like
playing CD's I think it's just like the DMX channel that the cable company
has. This is cool.

Just goto (www.thedj.com) you might  need to get real audio first for your
mac or pc so goto www.realaudio.com for that.

The trance channel plays just that and MegaBPMs play techno. They must have
about 40 types of music channels.

Subject: RR: Save Bert&Ernie!!! (Help us)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

Hello People!!!!

    I am sorry if some people on this list get offended that this is 
not rave related, but for me it is!!!! My early rave days were filled 
with the whole sesame street crew. Parading around parties, decked out 
in my favorite SS clothes, hugging my favorite SS charactors, and 
spending way too much money to do it was a part of my raving career! 
Take a look at the theme for the Beautiful People parties!! (Sesame 
Street has always and will always mean something for the Harmony crew)

    SS was, and is still a big part of some of our lives. What about 
our future generation(s)? What kind of programming will our kids get? 
World Wrestling Federation, shoot'em up cartoons, and sitcoms!! 
Mindless, thoughtless, and sometimes filled with violence!! Now tell 
me, when was the last time you saw Ernie throw Elmo out of a wrestling 
ring. SS shows kids how to be friendly and share with eachother. As 
well as teaching them how to read, write, and tie their shoes! I feel 
SS is extremely important, especially in today's society. So please, if 
you feel the same, put your name on this list, and send it out to 
everyone you know!!! 

Thank you,

Greg :)

Hey y'all.  
I hope I'm not out of line sending this to the list; I thought it was
important enough to send here.  I think there will be enough people on
here who will care about this issue, though in a great sense it is NRR 
(I
could make justifications for why it IS RRR :oD But I won't)
Ok, enough blabbering.  Here it is.  My apologies in advance for those 
who
may take offense!
love,
shamini


     
Save Bert and Ernie!!!!
 ----------
     
Subject:        Petition to Save Sesame Street
     
This is a petition to save Sesame Street.
     
All you do is add your name on the list and then forward it to 
everyone you
know. The only time you send it to the included address is if you are 
the
50th, 100th, etc. Send it on to everyone you know.
     
PBS, NPR (National Public Radio), and the arts are facing major 
cutbacks in
funding. In spite of the efforts of each station to reduce spending 
costs and
streamline their services, the government officials believe that the 
funding
currently going to these programs is too large a portion of funding 
for
something which is seen as "unworthwhile."
     
Currently, taxes from the general public for PBS equal $1.12 per 
person per
year, and the National Endowment for the Arts equals $.64 a year in 
total.
     
A January 1995 CNN/USA Today/Gallup poll indicated that 76% of 
Americans wish
to keep funding for PBS, third only to national defense and law 
enforcement
as the most valuable programs for federal funding.
     
Each year, the Senate and House Appropriations commitees each have 13
     
subcommitees with jurisdiction over many programs and agencies. Each 
subcommitee passes its own appropriation bill. The goal each year is 
to have
each bill signed by the beginning of the fiscal year, which is 
October 1. In
the instance of the Corporation of Public Broadcasting, the bill 
determines
the funding for the next three years. When this issue comes up in 
1996, the
funding will be determined for fiscal years 1996-1998. The only way 
that our
representatives can be aware of the base of support or PBS and 
funding for
these types of programs is by making our voices heard. Please add 
your name
to this list if you believe in what we stand for.
     
This list will be forwarded to the President of the United States, 
the Vice
President of the United States, and Representative Newt Gingrich, who 
is the
instigator of the action to cut funding to these worthwhile programs.
     
If you happen to be the 50th, 100th, 150th, etc. signer of this 
petition,
please forward to: kubi7975@blue.univnorthco.edu. This way we can 
keep track
of the lists and organize them. Forward this to everyone you know, 
and help
us to keep these programs alive.
     
Thank you.

Hey, I was just surfing the web and came across THE DJ. it a 24hr online
radio station on the web. It had techno, trance, hip-hop, and alot more
other stations. It's pretty cool, right now I'm listening to REZ off of
Logic Trance 2 on TheBeat channel and just listened to"Eternal Spirit" off
of Logic Trance 2. which was on the Trance station. On MegaBPMs channel
"WEB" by DR. Galactik on Circumference 01 is playing. Those are the ones I
have been listening to. They don't mix, just one after the other like
playing CD's I think it's just like the DMX channel that the cable company
has. This is cool.

Just goto (www.thedj.com) you might  need to get real audio first for your
mac or pc so goto www.realaudio.com for that.

The trance channel plays just that and MegaBPMs play techno. They must have
about 40 types of music channels.


Tim (knucklehead)

Received: from niles.com (niles.com [157.22.229.1]) by zocalo.net (8.7.5/8.7.3) with ESMTP id NAA05174 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 21 Aug 1996 13:47:41 -0700 (PDT)

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 21 Aug 1996 13:53:32 -0800
To: kcroy@best.com (kcroy)
From: peter@niles.com (Customer Service)
Subject: Re: CIA and drugs
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>nother interesting book from the drug ere, was a book titled
>Hows the Narcs Created Crack
>documenting the creation of crack cocaine as a direct result of the war on
>drugs, also deals with issues such as the unconstitutional use of the
>military to enforce domestic policy.



I only caught the tail end of this cia thing, so I apologize if I'm
repeating things already discussed...I've heard similar reports about crack
and its true importers, and I find it fascinating (and extremely
frightening).  Part of me wants to dimiss it as conspiracy paranoia, but
when you consider what's going on socially with crack, it seems
all-too-perfect.  ( I use the word "perfect" loosely).  You introduce crack
into an social class that is "undesirable" (and therefore a potential
powderkeg), and some interesting things start to happen:
1. When you smoke crack, you think about only one thing: smoking more
crack.  Therefore, your mind
    is not focused on your horrible living conditions, or on *doing*
anything about your living                  conditions.  All you need is
another rock and you'll be set.  And another, and another...

2.  Find a crowd of peoples who have been oppressed and in poverty for 400
years and offer them a way to get rich quick, (ie by selling something that
is illegal and very much in demand), and what happens?  Violence.  The
crowd  destroys itself from the inside out.

The thought genocide taking place in such a subtle and unprovable way is, I
think, scarier than anything the Snazi's ever did.  If any of this has been
planned,  it's an extremely diabolical plot and I'm not to sure how
comfortable I feel with this government hanging over my head.

If anyone else has any ideas, or have read anything about this, please
share it!  None of us is free unless we're all free!

peas,

b))merang

 please use:  rapier@trex.org

It would appear to very real considering that the Mercury has recently 
declassified docs to show some very good links.  And I do believe it is 
very true.

I'll give the CIA the benefit of the doubt though and not say that they 
were targeting blacks...they just wanted to make some money so they 
hooked a supplier who had connections to Nicaragua and the Contras there 
with a potential dealer in Rick "Freeway" Ross who happened to be from 
South Central who had lots of gang connections.

It was the bumbling bureaucrats who indirectly targeted blacks by 
creating minimum sentencing laws and such.  Since a professor stated that 
crack is about 50 times (he was forced to put a number on it) more addictive
or powerful as powder cocaine and given the get tough on crime stance 
that number became 100 times more addictive the lawmakers decided to make 
the minimum sentence for crack offenses 100 times more restrictive that 
powder offenses.  So one ounce of crack gets you the same jail time as 6 
pounds of powder.  This is where blacks get singled out.  A majority 
of crack arrests involve blacks whereas powder offenses usually involve 
whites.  This is due to the relatively cheap prices of crack versus powder.

I must say I can't believe our gov't has done this when everyone gets so 
peaved about drug use...The recent figures came out saying that ~10% of 
kids aged 12-17 have tried illicit drugs.  Maybe this is because of all 
the misinformation and lack of education that the goverment gives us...

Later,
G

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Aug 22 09:53:15 1996

From: Begroovy@aol.com
Received: by emout17.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id MAA04040 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Thu, 22 Aug 1996 12:52:40 -0400
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 1996 12:52:40 -0400
Message-ID: <960822125240_507526809@emout17.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Ameba/Amoeba -> cd purchasing situation? 
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I don't see this as much infringement. Amoeba on Telegraph has never been
interested in the whole House music genre. I used to be a really dedicated
customer of this establishment. Until I started buying mainly House types o'
music. I actually haven't been there in a year or so because they had the
same house music cd's a year ago that they had 3 years ago. If this situation
has changed please correct me. Amoeba on Telegraph is still in my opinion the
best place to buy used rock-n-roll cd's. This is there specialty. I actually
wish they would change there possition and sell more house music. This would
drop the prices on house music at Rasputins which seem high. Rasputins also
burns through house music buyers. So there selection of new house music
varies with the buyer. There are periods when they buy alot o' house and
periods when they buy lots o' trance and periods when they buy lots o'
ambient. Rasputins has by far the best house music selection and price on
"cd" of any stores I've been to in the Bay Area. If others disagree I would
greatly like to open a forum on this subject. Another good option is
electronic ordering o' cd's. I found a url http:\www.gemm.com which has a
large search engine for searching music with options to buy from different
venders throughout the country. I haven't purchased anything here yet but the
prices seem resonable. They sell vinyl this way also. If its in print they
have it. If its not they may still have it. Have a great day, PEACE! Cid

On Thu, 22 Aug 1996 Begroovy@aol.com wrote:

> I don't see this as much infringement. Amoeba on Telegraph has never been
> interested in the whole House music genre. I used to be a really dedicated
> customer of this establishment. Until I started buying mainly House types o'
> music. I actually haven't been there in a year or so because they had the
> same house music cd's a year ago that they had 3 years ago. If this situation
> has changed please correct me. Amoeba on Telegraph is still in my opinion the
> best place to buy used rock-n-roll cd's. This is there specialty. I actually
> wish they would change there possition and sell more house music. 

amoeba's electronic selection has greatly improved, a good place for used
stuff... 

> This would
> drop the prices on house music at Rasputins which seem high. Rasputins also
> burns through house music buyers. So there selection of new house music
> varies with the buyer. There are periods when they buy alot o' house and
> periods when they buy lots o' trance and periods when they buy lots o'
> ambient. Rasputins has by far the best house music selection and price on
> "cd" of any stores I've been to in the Bay Area. If others disagree I would
> greatly like to open a forum on this subject. 

rasputins used to be one of my favorites but their selection has gotten
really bad and except for used stuff I rarely buy anything there now, but
I hear they recently got a new buyer so things might improve. 

mod lang (on university) isn't the best place for house music, but in
general I think they have a better selection of "electronic" musics than
amoeba or rasputins... 

selection-wise I think soundworks (valencia/clinton park) is one of the
better places for cd's (and vinyl) in the bay area, and they let you
listen before you buy (unlike the east bay shops).  the prices are good
too.  and lots of house... 

openmind (divasadero/oak) doesn't have the largest selection, but some
real gems have been known to pop up in the used section from time to time,
and the buyer (tomas) knows his shit. definitely worth checking out...

I recently picked up a flyer for a new place opening up at the end of the
month in oakland called dropbeat, supposedly they will do mailorder and
will have a web interface...

probably the best www mailorder place I've found is modernmusic
(www.modernmusic.com), out of baltimore.  they can get most anything,
their prices are good, and the service is excellent (my last order was put
in on a friday afternoon and arrived monday).

andy

Greetings SFRavers from Sunny San Diego,

  Well,  I'm finally settled into the Loft,  A really hip community of
ravers,  graphic artists, DJ's and Video producers here in DownTown
San Diego.   We got a T1 link to the net,  and I have my own 7200 Power
PC with 128 Megs and stock full of the latest and greatest Java,  C++
tools and tons of graphics programs.

  I'm their Web master and System Admin,  which is really needed around here,
as not that many people are computer savvy.

  Anyway,  I'm doing my first gig as a DJ at Orgasm this friday,  and doing
video at Blitscrieg in LA on Saturay for my first Hardcore rave.

  Anyway,  I'm trying to get Justin's Email address,  the guy where I
stored some of my stuff,  so if he's still on the list,   please Email
me,  because after Burning Man,   I'm going to have to get this stuff..

  Anyway,  we're working to establish a strong rave scene down here in
San Diego dispite the fact that it's so oppressed and such a strong
police resistance to raving down here.   Nore than 90% of attempted parties
get busted,  and it's almost impossible to get permits to do anything.

  Anyway,  just checking in to let you folks know whats going on....

One more thing...  I still haven't cleaned up the mess made by the
Uni_mail bomber,  but since ho also bombed the whitehouse.gov site,
the secret service is stirred up like a nest of angry hornets...  and
soon I think he'll be busted...  In the meatime,  I'm using crunch@vcomm.net
as my main address.

  Radion says hi...

Crunchman

hi Troy,
Maybe you could post to some of your lists about the part time position
here at graphic imagery....

The candidtate must be a high school graduate, attending school for or have
an interest in graphic design and printing. We do not actually have presses
on site, we do all the pre-press organization and production.
Mac skills are a plus. We would like someone to make back-ups and archives
of our computer files, output information sheets, make copies, etc. Ability
to do so and familiarity with macs will be necessary.
The position pays $8.00/hour. There will be miscellaneous duties such as
packaging or handling shipments, filing paper samples, updating list of
works in progress, archiving and backing up mac files. Duties may vary from
day to day and so do the hours. It would be ideal to have someone on
Fridays but the exact hours and days are flexible. We need someone for 3-4
days a week for about 20 hours total/week.  We are a green company with
many great learning opportunities for the right individual.

Fax/send your resume to:
Graphic Imagery
1550 Bryant #925
SF CA 94103

Yup, Yup!  Last year was the crazyiest year for me.  Party Friday,
Saturday, sunday morning afterparty and sunset...every weekend.  Even week
days.  This year I've been more selective and appriciate every experience.
Next month I move away to school (San Luis Obisbo) and I will finally get a
chance to work on someing for my self.  My school/career/life.  Raving will
always be with me.  But it's just my time to take a break.  One good thing
- i'm very central to both socal and norcal scenes so if i get the chance
I'll be back here and down in LA to chech out a new scene (for me).

Yes!

I finally got mail.  I guess I should have unsubed, cuz I had over 1000
emails to skim/delete.  Went to 5 on friday around 2 am (I worked my last
day and my boss made me stay at work till 1 am.  can u say Dikhead)  By
this time most of my friend were already in the city so i went by myself.

5 was at THE deli.  I heard no sound walking up to the door (probably
muffeled by all the people) and security said they weren't letting anyone
else in.  ??   I guess they were closing at 3 am. and were charging 10
dollars for an advertized "give back 2 da scene" 5 dollar party.  What the
fuk?  I got to peek in and the place was so packed you couldn't move 5
feet.  Well, this wasn't gonna ruin my evening soooo....

 i met this guy josh passing out flyers for Good Family by 3 high guys.
Don't these guys help with ThurZdays?  Well a new promoter a new party.  So
I went.  Ten bucks.  ( the flyer say 13.oo presale?)  Young crowd but
Astryl Matrix was on.  Yeah he was!  Danced for awile.  Talked to a few
friends I knew but I was in more of a dancing mood so I didn't met too may
people.  Watched a little Star Wars.  Got my pipe'o'green took/toked and
returned.  And left around 4.30 cuz It's been a hard week at my new job.
I'm a delevery man, driving a 5 ton truck all accross the bay area.  What
fun it is to drive people crazy with a huge truck.  Dumb ass drivers.

N E WayZ

Probable bring a flower to OPEN and check it out.

Austin

X-Mailer: ScoMail 3.0.Bd

> > The thought genocide taking place in such a subtle and unprovable way is, I
> > think, scarier than anything the Snazi's ever did.  If any of this has been
> > planned,  it's an extremely diabolical plot and I'm not to sure how
> > comfortable I feel with this government hanging over my head.
> 
> I doubt though if such a thing could be though up by the CIA, it would
> require intelligence. For now they would be mostly interested in selling
> drugs to invest the profits in secret military/political scams outside
> the US, I guess.

	Don't be too sure.  The CIA may be stupid (or there may be a plot to 
make us think they're stupid, propogated by James Bond movies), but they've been 
at this game for awhile.  Here is a quote from an interesting article I found on 
the net (http://home.dti.net/lawserv/leary.html):

                 Copyright 1994 Osprey Productions/Grand Royal

   Was Timothy Leary a CIA Agent? Was JFK the "Manchurian Candidate"? Was the
                  Sixties Revolution Really a Government Plot?

                          Tinker, Tailor, Stoner, Spy

                                by Mark Riebling

[...]

1969: Leary critics will eventually point with suspicion to his close
connections during this time to an international LSD-smuggling cartel,
the Brotherhood of Eternal Love, which is rumored to be a CIA front.  The
Brotherhood is controlled by Ronald Stark, whom an Italian High Court
will later conclude has been a CIA agent since 1960, and the
Brotherhood's funds are channeled through Castle Bank in the Bahamas, a
known CIA "proprietary." For two years Leary lives at Brotherhood
headquarters, located on a ranch in Laguna Beach.  During this period,
the Brotherhood corners the U.S.  market on LSD and begins distributing
only one variety of the drug, "Orange Sunshine." Stark says he plans to
distribute the product to CIA-backed guerillas fighting Chinese
occupation; he reportedly knows a high-placed Tibetan close to the Dalai
Lama, and wants to provide enough LSD to dose all Chinese troops in
Tibet.  In the U.S., meanwhile, Stark provides enough Orange Sunshine to
dose the hippie culture and radical left many times over.  This is the
"bad acid" on which Charles Manson's followers murder Sharon Tate, and
on which Hell's Angels stab to death a black man during a concert by the
Rolling Stones.  The Summer of Love has been supplanted by a Season of
Hate.  Because of this, many countercultural insiders -- including
William S.  Burroughs, White Panther leader John Sinclair, and Merry
Prankster Ken Kesey -- will eventually entertain the theory that Stark,
Leary, and Orange Sunshine are all part of CIA plot to discredit and
neutralize the radical left.  According to former radicals Martin Lee
and Bruce Shalin, widespread use of Orange Sunshine "contributed
significantly to the demise of the New Left, for it heightened the
metabolism of the body politic and accelerated all the changes going
on...  In its hyped-up condition, the New Left burned itself out."

-----------------------------------------
Andrew Knutsen            andrewk@sco.com
Santa Cruz Operation      (408) 427-7538

95 users: Save to disk and then goto start, settings, control panel, mouse,

attachment...

have to much funk for e-mail to handle...)




*** Put your head back, reach up as FAR as you can, and smile as BIG as you
can. ***
***	 Now do you see?! The Perma-Grin will be with you...always. ;)   	 ***

I haven't picked up flyers for while, so I only have a few listings for
this weekend.  Maybe everyone should save up their energy for Burning Man...

Also, if you read this message tonight, Alex Paterson is supposed to spin at
Funktion...


                                THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi
    
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Friday, August 23rd - Nexus presents _Open_
   Hipp-E, Eric Davenport, Trance, Terence Toy, Tony, Jeno, Moshe, Shome,
   Boomerang, Fidget.
   Nexus Holistic Sanctuary, Live Butterfly Palace
   Free acupuncture, aroma therapy, herbal clinics, massage, water,
   fruit.
   $10 before 11pm if you bring a flower
   dress like an angel or fairy and receive 2$ off
   9pm-7am, . 415.273.5350 510.473.4767
   
   Friday, August 23rd - Underground Sound-tech presents _House the Phunk!_
   Anand, Scot, Lalo, Karizma, DLX, Matthew, Josh.
   will be monthly
   10pm-6am, . Sacramento. 916.815.8560
   
   Wednesday, August 28th - Burning Man 1996
   includes Wicked, Dimension Se7en, Gateway Systems, CCC, Drop Bass
   Network, SPAZ and Generation of Noise Sound Systems.
   runs entire weekend, through September 2nd.
   All ages, $35. Black Rock Desert, Nevada. 415.985.7471
   
   Saturday, August 31st - Feel Good Entertainment presents _Mega-Buzz
   One_
   Sean Murray, Galen, Solar, John Howard, John Mac, Laron, NYC Sense,
   Harry Who?, Mattski, Erik Spire, Liquid, Mei-Lwun, Jay Hartley, Chris,
   Carlos, Ghost, Frank Nitty, Essence, Henrik, Simon, Tony, Ernie
   Munson.
   6 arenas in 100,000 sq ft indoor/outdoor location
   415.569.6226 408.535.0402 510.433.9434 916.491.5950 209.569.7973
   707.523.9369
   
   Saturday, August 31st - Iner Sircle presents _Pump_
   Liquid, John Howard, Harry Who?, Rick Preston, Gouracandra, Jack
   Tripper, more.
   free water, juice and soda
   SF. 415.646.0518 408.997.6063
   
   Saturday, September 7th - Nomad Interactive presents _Origin_
   Ani (Deee-Lite NYC), Bone (Sphere Records), Jeno, Garth, Markie, Tony,
   Simon, Solar.
   415.675.5605 408.236.3398 916.484.4213
   
   Saturday, September 14th - _Harmony_
   Three Year Anniversary
   the final Harmony - presale tix only!
   408.486.9591 408.450.3044
   
   Saturday, September 21st - Out-A-Sight
   Evil Eddie Richards, Dave Hollands (NY), Steve Loria (LA), Narayan
   (Philly), Spun.
   Visuals by Donovan, Hyperdelic, Reed.
   415.437.4462
   
   Saturday, September 28th - _SuperSensonic_
   Dan Curtin (Cleveland), Ono Sendai Sound Technician (The Delta
   Quadrant), Zerox (Swell Records), Jon Santos (Mad SF), Bradley (yo
   mama).
   415.303.2312
   
   Friday, October 5th - Cloud Factory presents _Planetarium_
   DJs, food, frolinking, camping and such in Mendocino County
   drenalin, tim mcknew, deaks, cloud, brian flipp, mc^2, maya, k-go
   (st.louis), guests.
   exact data TBA
   mendocino.
   
   Saturday, October 5th - SpaceMinD Productions! presents _Free Life_
   Henry, Casper, A.R.L., Spech, Miss Piggy, Fro (?), guests.
   Visuals by SpaceBoy, Tri-Lasers.
   an AIDS Benefit for Ellipse and their youth group
   $10 w/flyer
   9pm-8am, $15. 415.286.3495
   
   , October 26th - _Spirit_

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" Beats and
       atmospherics w/DJ Seth. KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

[ to sfraves list ]
Recently, brendan asked -
> 
> i just got this ancient turntable/amp unit for free, but the stylus is too
> damn fat to play any of my records! :(

 errr - what's the symptom that reveals this needle's "fat" condition? 
Skipping tracks? Lousy high end? Faint sound? Tonearm wanders about
like a drunk moth circling a flame?

 OR - does the speed control have "78" as one of the speed options?
Is "78" the ONLY speed option?!!?
> 
> is it possible to replace the cartridge with a new one/different make? or
> are things not as simple as that?

 Depends - what make is it now? What make is the turntable? Can you see
four little wires coming out the end of the cartridge, or is the end of
the cartridge round and attached to the tone arm such that you can't see
the wires that carry the signals from the cartridge ? Or ....?

 awaiting more data -

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Aug 22 23:49:49 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id XAA16836; Thu, 22 Aug 1996 23:49:49 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from mail-gw.fsr.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with ESMTP id XAA16828; Thu, 22 Aug 1996 23:49:44 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from Maxine.lewiston.com (ppp132.lewiston.com [204.227.174.132]) by mail-gw.fsr.net (8.7.5/8.6.9) with SMTP id XAA06259 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 22 Aug 1996 23:50:10 -0700
Date: Thu, 22 Aug 1996 23:50:10 -0700
Message-Id: <199608230650.XAA06259@mail-gw.fsr.net>
X-Sender: tuskluv@mail.lewiston.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Light Version 1.5.2
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Wowser <tuskluv@lewiston.com>
Subject: NRR...just a story I heard once (somewhat long)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I was in a very trying period in my life a fews years ago...struggling to
make sense of this senseless world, struggling to see through the layers of
muck and grim, and struggling to discover answers to some very profound
questions.  I found more traps than anything else in the maze, but I did
meet up with some very interesting people at that time.  A man who claimed
he was the 'most powerful being I would ever meet' told me a story.  

Of course he was a liar about his "power", but he did stir something within
my mind.  With tears in his eyes, he was not only engulfed in the story, but
acted as though he actually remembered what he spoke of...

"Once upon a time, beyond what many know and find courage to remember, a
very large group of children lived in a special place created by a being who
was wholly gentle and loving, but all powerful.  The being was called God. 
Since the children were created in His image, they were quite 'powerful' by
today's standards.  The children grew quickly as did their abilities to
create.  They created music, art and other forms of expression all without
the assistance of instruments or paint or paper.  But their jealousy of each
other grew, and they began to create other things as well.  Ugly things.   

The children began to squabble and bicker.  They gathered only to fight.
Over Time they became prideful of their "power" and grew to disregard their
Father, God, because they felt He was too powerful. They slowly grew to
resent God, for He could do anything.  But He just gave them love, and this
was all He desired in return.  For to God, these were His children.  As Time
passed, the children fought more and more with each other and ignored God
completely.  They elected a "power" whore to be their leader. They wanted to
be Gods, not children.  All of them, that is, except for a young boy.  

There was a boy was a bit different.  He liked being a child to God because
he loved God.  He was in awe by God and sat and watched him every day.  This
boy appreciated his own talents but did not consider them as "power", as the
others did.  So while the others sought to learn more "powers", this boy
simply sat by God's side whenever he could and listened and watched.  This
was where this boy was most happy.  To this boy, Love was the "gift".

But strife broke out in the special place and the children began to fight.
They began to make war against their brothers and sister.  Sinister, secret
wars full of manipulation and greed.  When these wars of illusions began,
the young boy would call out to the other children...in a very special way.
He would beg them not to fight with his heart and his soul.  They could hear
his words but his lips did not move.  He would remind them of the beauty of
their great Father.  But they would not listen.  They rebelled against him.
They played tricks on him.  They often tried to hurt him.  Still yet, he
sought only to remind them of Love.  Of all they had.  The children despised
him for speaking truthfully.  They secretly hated him because of his love.
The children began to hate him and vowed to teach him a lesson.  Who was
this boy...speaking to them all the time about Love?  After all, they were
Gods!  How dare he speak to them about such things?!?  He was just a boy!  

One day, when the boy was speaking to the other children, they gathered
together in a place where he could not feel them.  They stood before him,
but he could not feel what they thought.  What they felt.  They had hidden
themselves in anger and secret hatred.  Suddenly, the other children focused
all their "power" and energy together and directed it at the sky.  A large
fire-ball appeared.  It swirled and shimmered with unspeakable heat.  It was
filled with their anger.  Their pride.  Their greed.  Their lust.  Their
hate.  It was huge.  It was horrible.  Instantly, the children directed the
fire-ball towards the young boy.  It moved with lightning speed and struck
the young boy before he knew what hit him.  He feel to his knees in pain.
It seared his flesh.  It ripped open his young heart.  It scortched his mind
and burned the young boy completely.  It destroyed the boy.  His screams had
been horrific.  His pain unimaginable.  And within a mere matter of moments,
the young boy existed no more.  Only ashes.  Not even his memories remained. 

The children stood before a pile of ashes, and for the first time, they knew
regret.  They had destroyed something beautiful.  They had destroyed it for
nothing.  And that is what remained.  Nothing.  Fo God appeared instantly.
He was horror stricken by the ashes he saw before him.  It was a loss which
could never be replaced.  In fear, the children tried to destroy God with
another fire-ball, as they had killed their brother.  They focused all of
their powers against God, but they failed.  For God's power was absolute.  

God's tears filled the skies. WHY?!?  Why have you destroyed someone I loved
so dearly?  There was not an answer. In His anger, he condemend the wicked
children to feel Life no longer, and he tore what remained of His love away
from them.  He scattered the children to the four winds and the earth
swallowed them up. Only after learning the value of what they had destroyed
could they ever come together again.  Only after finding what remained no
more, could they be made whole.  Sadly, the lesson remains unlearned..."

Hey, has anyone heard anything about the movie Synthetic
Pleasures?  Seems like the music will be ambient/techno,
here's a synopsis from the web site (www.syntheticpleasures.com) 

"Is reality obsolete? From low-tech function like body piercing
and artificially-stocked fishing pools, to the latest in bionics and
VR gaming, Iara Lee's cyber-age intellectual survey - call it a
*.DOCumentary - downloads a Future Shockful of data and
defines the parameters of advanced technologies that delete nature
and reprogram mankind. Cryonics defy death; the Internet exists
outside time and space; smart drugs and surgery upgrade the
mind and body. But are we headed toward human optimization,
or system crash? Timothy Leary, RU Sirius, Lisa Palac, John
Barlow and others offer sound bytes against a mesmerizing
screen display of cutting edge computer-graphics and archival
clips. Exhilarating and disturbing, Synthetic Pleasures raises
issues nobody today can afford to abort / retry / ignore."

Sounds like it could be good, could be bogus, but probably worth
a look!  It'll be showing in SF, Berkeley, San Jose, and Palo Alto
so maybe we could get one or more groups together.  

One more thing, the web site has, of all things, a Glossary.
Here's their entry for "Rave:"


       rave: usually refers to a party, usually all night long, where loud
       "techno" music is mostly played and many people partake in a
       number of different chemicals, though the latter is far from
       necessary. At a rave, the DJ is a shaman, a priest, a channeller of
       energy - they control the psychic voyages of the dancers through
       his choice in hard-to-find music and their skill in manipulating
       that music, sometimes working with just a set of beats and
       samples, into a tapestry of mindbending music. A large part of
       the concept of raves is built upon sensory overload - a barrage of
       audio and very often visual stimuli are brought together to elevate
       people into an altered state of physical or psychological
       existence. 


Smiles,
     Chin

P.S. No, I'm not affiliated with them in any way, there's just flyers
for the movie everywhere where I work.

Hey, we've all got to lighten up about death every once in a while...:


1994's MOST BIZARRE SUICIDE

       At the 1994 annual awards dinner given by the American
       Association for Forensic Science, AAFS President Don
       Harper Mills astounded his audience in San Diego with the
       legal complications of a bizarre death.  Here is the story.

       "On 23 March 1994, the medical examiner viewed the body
       of Ronald Opus and concluded that he died from a shotgun
       wound of the head.  The decedent had jumped from the top
       of a ten-story building intending to commit suicide (he
       left a note indicating his despondency).As he fell past
       the ninth floor, his life was interrupted by a shotgun
       blast through a window, which killed him instantly.
       Neither the shooter nor the decedent was aware that a
       safety net had been erected at the eighth floor level to
       protect some window washers and that Opus would not have
       been able to complete his suicide anyway because of this.

       "Ordinarily," Dr.  Mills continued, "a person who sets
       out to commit suicide ultimately succeeds, even though the
       mechanism might not be what he intended.  That Opus was
       shot on the way to certain death nine stories below
       probably would not have changed his mode of death from
       suicide to homicide."

       But the fact that his suicidal intent would not have
       been successful caused the medical examiner to feel that
       he had homicide on his hands. "The room on the ninth floor
       whence the shotgun blast emanated was occupied by an
       elderly man and his wife.  They were arguing and he was
       threatening her with the shotgun.  He was so upset that,
       when he pulled the trigger, he completely missed his wife
       and the pellets went through the window striking Opus.

       "When one intends to kill subject A but kills subject B
       in the attempt, one is guilty of the murder of subject B.
       When confronted with this charge, the old man and his wife
       were both adamant that neither knew that the shotgun was
       loaded.  The old man said it was his long-standing habit
       to threaten his wife with the unloaded shotgun.  He had no
       intention to murder her - therefore, the killing of Opus
       appeared to be an accident.  That is, the gun had been
       accidentally loaded.

       "The continuing investigation turned up a witness who
       saw the old couple's son loading the shotgun approximately
       six weeks prior to the fatal incident.  It transpired that
       the old lady had cut off her son's financial support and
       the son, knowing the propensity of his father to use
       the shotgun threateningly, loaded the gun with the
       expectation that his father would shoot his mother.  The
       case now becomes one of murder on the part of the son for
       the death of Ronald Opus.

       There was an exquisite twist.  "Further investigation
       revealed that the son had become increasingly despondent
       over the failure of his attempt to engineer his mother's
       murder.  This led him, Ronald Opus, to jump off the
       ten-story building on March 23, only to be killed by a
       shotgun blast through a ninth story window.

       "The medical examiner closed the case as a suicide."

TA-DA!!!- Alex

I don't know what you look for in a party, but I think this will be the one
to go to tonight.
Also, though I can't testify personally, I have heard "rave" reviews about
Davenport & Trance.

 Based on my experiences with Jeff Dullum, who is one of Nexus' key
coordinators, they are very much committed to our collective purpose in
this ravedance we do.  The most unique element of their parties, I think,
are the chill rooms, which tonight, as with 2nd Chakra, will feature free
massages from massage therapists, *live* butterflies flapping around
(can't quite figure that one out yet),  acupuncture, and aromatherapy
(Huh?).  Nexus is also interesting in that they work with local artists,
displaying sculptures and paintings at their venues, and performance art
(e.g. the lady dancing with a chandelier on her head at 2nd Chakra)  Also,
there will be many, many many pillows to swallow you.

If you have any toys that talk, make sounds, etc (preferably of an
"ambient" nature), please bring them to the chillroom and talk to one of
the geeks behind the turntables...there will be an interactive ambient band
playing...we want to sample your toys and/or your beautiful voices.

The party definitely is in the East Bay tonight.  Directions will be posted
at 5pm.  Call the # on the calendar.

"Serving more than 100,000 users worldwide."

WARNING!!! NON-RAVE RELATED MATERIAL!  IF YOU ONLY WANT TO SEE RAVE RELATED 
MATERIAL, COVER YOUR EYES AND HIT THE DELETE KEY IMMEDIATELY!!!

Ok, so anyway...

This man joins a monastery and takes a vow of silence.  In taking his vow 
though, he is allowed to say two words every five years.  After having been 
in the monastery for five years, the monk approaches the abbott and says, 
"Bed.  Lumpy."  These being his two words, he is silent for another five 
years.  After that time he meets with the abbott again.  He says, "Food.  
Terrible."  And again he is silent for five more years.  Then he comes to 
abbott one last time and, after five years of silence announces, "I'm.  
Leaving."  The abbott stands up and says, "Fine!  Leave!  All you've done 
since you got here is complain!"

The ameba/amoeba thing is exciting to me. Obviously I have little 
respect for intellectual property rights so it would be hypocritical for 
me to complain about a phonetic duplicity on Haight Street.No one from 
the Amoeba has said anything to us which I find rude. When people call 
us about Primus cds I just say we don't have any.I wish more young wierd 
people would open businesses on Haight. F8 has been a great addition.

Regarding the current 13 month calendar movement: I am entirely 
dissatisfied with the direction the Northern California representatives 
of this movement have been taking. I have formally announced the 
formation of the Thirteenth Collumn splinter group. Propaganda will be 
available soon.

Lately I have been contemplating the cautions of Eastern mystics in 
regards to Psychedelics. They say they cause holes in a persons aura. I 
had discounted this for a long time but I think as is the case for most 
mystic truths, often metaphors are needed to explain complicated things 
in a simple way.

PS: any HTML geeks know about the leftmargin or topmargin commands?
