On Fri, 23 Aug 1996, Chinley L. Chang wrote:

> Hey, has anyone heard anything about the movie Synthetic
> Pleasures?  Seems like the music will be ambient/techno,
> here's a synopsis from the web site (www.syntheticpleasures.com) 
> 
> "Is reality obsolete? From low-tech function like body piercing
> and artificially-stocked fishing pools, to the latest in bionics and
> VR gaming, Iara Lee's cyber-age intellectual survey - call it a
> *.DOCumentary - downloads a Future Shockful of data and
> defines the parameters of advanced technologies that delete nature
> and reprogram mankind. Cryonics defy death; the Internet exists
> outside time and space; smart drugs and surgery upgrade the
> mind and body. But are we headed toward human optimization,
> or system crash? Timothy Leary, RU Sirius, Lisa Palac, John
> Barlow and others offer sound bytes against a mesmerizing
> screen display of cutting edge computer-graphics and archival
> clips. Exhilarating and disturbing, Synthetic Pleasures raises
> issues nobody today can afford to abort / retry / ignore."
> 
> Sounds like it could be good, could be bogus, but probably worth
> a look!  It'll be showing in SF, Berkeley, San Jose, and Palo Alto
> so maybe we could get one or more groups together.  
> 
> One more thing, the web site has, of all things, a Glossary.
> Here's their entry for "Rave:"
> 
> 
>        rave: usually refers to a party, usually all night long, where loud
>        "techno" music is mostly played and many people partake in a
>        number of different chemicals, though the latter is far from
>        necessary. At a rave, the DJ is a shaman, a priest, a channeller of
>        energy - they control the psychic voyages of the dancers through
>        his choice in hard-to-find music and their skill in manipulating
>        that music, sometimes working with just a set of beats and
>        samples, into a tapestry of mindbending music. A large part of
>        the concept of raves is built upon sensory overload - a barrage of
>        audio and very often visual stimuli are brought together to elevate
>        people into an altered state of physical or psychological
>        existence. 
> 
> 
> Smiles,
>      Chin
> 
> P.S. No, I'm not affiliated with them in any way, there's just flyers
> for the movie everywhere where I work.
> 


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Aug 23 13:08:02 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id NAA29030; Fri, 23 Aug 1996 13:08:02 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from libra.sfsu.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with ESMTP id NAA28990; Fri, 23 Aug 1996 13:07:58 -0700 (PDT)
Received: (from glow@localhost) by libra.sfsu.edu (8.7.1/8.7.1) id NAA11279 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Fri, 23 Aug 1996 13:07:55 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 1996 13:07:55 -0700 (PDT)
From: BRUCE ALVIN MCDONOUGH <glow@sfsu.edu>

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: intro
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Greetings :
Since I just joined this list, I guess I should introduce myself.
My name is Bruce McDonough.  I'm a student at SFSU studying computer
science, and hope to graduate with a BS in May.  I've been in San
Francisco for almost three years, and have been to lots of parties.

My first one was a Full Moon Rave at Bonnie Doon Beach in September
(or October) 1993.  That event changed my life.  I'd never experienced
such a kind vibe before, and so many beautiful people.  And the music :)...
Since then I've been to Wicked (6 or 7 times), F&F (4 or 5), C-U (5 or 6),
Harmony, many many weeklies and other assorted parties.  Oh, yeah, about
4 BulletProof Boat Parties too.  I grew up in Escondido, Calif., about 30
miles North of San Diego since age 7, before that I lived in Connecticut.

I'm 28 now and look forward to graduating from school and (finally) maybe
making a decent living.  I've definitely had my share of diversions in
life.  I love rockclimbing, hiking, reading, writing, taking trips ;),
and DANCING.

I believe that the global house movement definitely is making the world
a better place, I just hope the kids don't lose it all to drug abuse.  Anyone
choosing to use any mind altering substance should definitely do the
reading and research required to make wise informed decisions.  Love is 
probably the only free high.

peace,
          Bruce McDonough
          glow@sfsu.edu

	id AA840832675; Fri, 23 Aug 96 13:22:05 pst
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 96 13:22:05 pst
From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9607238408.AA840832675@smtplink.acer.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Synthetic Pleasures
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     "Is Reality Obsolete"
     
     I don't mean this as a personal blast, but I'm getting kinda weary of 
     being reminded how awesome all this technology is.  Most of us are 
     actually sitting at computers (I do know people that print al of their 
     e-mail out before they read it, not too green if you ask me)... most 
     of us actually go to amazing parties, most of us dance and some even 
     make futuristic beautiful / scary / grooovin music.  I hate being 
     patted on the back when we're not even close!!!!
     
     The trailer looked stupid.  Too CYBER-Cool.  I'd rather just drop some 
     whatever (or not) and curl up with some friends I love and watch 
     Powaqquatsi (or the one before which I haven't the vaguest notion how 
     to spell) or something that's actually art rather than hyped up 
     techno-snivel.
     
     I would pay to see those gnarly FSOL images come to life (i.e. 
     Lifeforms domestic album cover or inner sleeve of domestic ISDN) ... I 
     just don't want some new thing with Leary going blah blah blah with 
     'shocking' new realizations while quoting Neuromancer and showing me 
     fractals.  It makes it look like we're dying (same place we were in 
     '89).  We have to evolve.  Does anybody feel we have to get past 
     "Strange Days" to pull this off?
     
     I think it's about being 'this way' for life, about having ideals we 
     can live with and doing it better than those before us, regardless of 
     the barriers or boundries every is so used to (age, color, blah, 
     blah).  Big deal, we have the tools (computers, communications, 
     connections).  Even Bill Gates has gotten over it and is now asking 
     "Where do you want to go today?".
     
     Pull for progress... remember the sense of possibilities you had after 
     the first rave that went off for you.  The togetherness, the 
     community, the not caring about the stupid stuff and being scared by 
     how much you cared about ideas and people and beauty and life and 
     breathing and touching and sharing.  The themes we all revel in remind 
     us of childhood, because that's the last time we felt it before it got 
     scared out of us.  Go back.  Find it.  And walk back into your life 
     with the gift of being reborn and honest for the first time.  I don't 
     expect anything from any of you, but you all amaze me with your 
     generosity and openeness.
     
     Love,
     AndyW

Subject: Wish me luck.

     Just wanted to ask for a bit of help for this weekend. I won't be
dancing for a bit cuz I have an MX series to contend. I'll be racing this
weekend (sunday) for the first time since. . . the second time I tore
ligaments in my knee, which was about. . . two years ago??? Damn, has it
been that long?? See, I'm usually doing pretty well, but the past couple
years have just sucked. . . When I was 16, I was riding down by the bay near
my house with my friend and I landed wrong off a jump costing me an Anterior
Cruciate ligament, A medial collateral ligament, both my miniscus, and about
8 months. After the eight months was over, I was better then ever, I got
super-serious with my health and was pushing myself harder than ever to
improve. About six months later, I was practicing down at Little Oakie in
Madera when some dork's bike ghost rid in front of me causing me to his it
at about 45-55mph. I all remember was hearing the impact of the bikes and
then laying there with my bike (and a couple others) laying on top of me. My
knee again, hurt like hell, and I knew that I re-tore another ligament. I
did! That was  about another 5 months off my bike and then the second ride
back, I permanently broke my right foot. I broke my navicular in my foot, in
half, shattering one side into ???? pieces, and the other side was just
slightly crushed. The doctors recommended surgery but thaty would have just
made me worse off (they wanted to fuse my bone, limiting my movement in my
foot to barely anything). 
        Now it's about 10 months later and I'm ready to race again. I dance,
go to the gym, try to run, and ride. My foot kinda works, and it's better
than the doctors could ever make it. Just watch me dance and you'll see. But
watch me walk and you'll see how it effects me.
        So anyway, there's a brief history on me. I'm racing this weekend.
I'm gonna do my best. And I'm going to at least get top ten. Damn, I should
be intermediate by now, but I'm still just a lowely novice, one class away
from the bottom.

       So wish me luck!

Have fun boogying down all.

LUVYALL

Aryck

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Aug 23 18:33:25 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id SAA28839; Fri, 23 Aug 1996 18:33:25 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from dfw-ix7.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id SAA28831; Fri, 23 Aug 1996 18:33:21 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from wck-ca4-09.ix.netcom.com (shawna-@wck-ca4-09.ix.netcom.com [199.35.213.137]) by dfw-ix7.ix.netcom.com (8.6.13/8.6.12) with SMTP id SAA22533; Fri, 23 Aug 1996 18:32:41 -0700
Date: Fri, 23 Aug 1996 18:32:41 -0700
Message-Id: <1.5.4.16.19960822183315.41072ad8@popd.ix.netcom.com>
X-Sender: shawna-@popd.ix.netcom.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Light Version 1.5.4 (16)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: frisco freaks <sfraves@hyperreal.com>, knowoneness-l@teleport.com
From: "hey, where am I?" <shawna-@ix.netcom.com>
Subject: a cool story (RR)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey all! 

Such cool things have been happening, what a great week this has been!
Ecto's coming to the Bay Area in time for my birthday (yippee!), I'm gonna
go up to visit Brenda & the Ahau Collective, BM's just around the corner, I
suddenly have two weeks of vacation, and the coolest thing happened to me
last night:  

For Burning Man, my co-worker Laurie was going to lend me some of her
camping things, like a tent, solar showers, etc.  Very nice of her!  Anyway,
after work yesterday I was supposed to go over to her house and pick these
things up.  So I head over there to do this, and she shows me all the stuff,
and we have a beer, and the evening progresses like you'd expect a normal
evening too progress. 

In the past Laurie has told me at various times about her family life & how
she relates to her husband and 15-year old daughter.  They're your typical
dysfunctional family, both she and a co-worker of ours (also a friend of
Laurie's) have told me stories of Laurie's daughter, and how she's gone
completely off the deep end, even to the point of having beaten up her
mother on a couple occasions.  Things have really gotten bad, and there is
almost no relationship between mother and daughter, it seems they pretty
much don't do anything but fight.  

So I come over, do the tent thing, do the beer thing, do the hang-out thing.
Laurie's daughter (Jennifer) eventually comes out, out of curiosity I would
assume, and talks to us some too.  Eventually, she finds out from Laurie
that I am a raver, and does eventually join in the conversation, talking to
me about how she wants to go to raves when she starts driving, and much to
my amusement produces that in/famous flyer we all remember from Lucky Charms
back in March!  I laugh & tell her what a joke that party was, and the
conversation has become pretty light hearted & amusing.  Eventually,
Jennifer pulls out her cd's and starts blasting them on the living room
stereo, mostly clubby stuff you'd hear on KMEL & whatnot.  It's funny to me,
because upon learning I was a raver, Jennifer really came out of her
sullen-teen shell and participated in the conversation, and became quite
lively, which was really nice.  She was still somewhat rude to her mother,
but it was an improvement.  So we're sitting there in the living room
listening to this music & talking about the rave scene & rave music, and I
think "hey, maybe I should play some of my mixtapes for her, maybe she'd
like them!"  So I hop up and run out to my car & grab my plastic produce bag
fulla mixtapes & such & bring 'em back in.  I pop one (a housier one,
perhaps an easier transition from clubby music than it would be to, say,
goa) in and start playing it.  So now we've got the stereo blasting with the
knob at 11, and Jennifer's up & boogying all over the living room floor,
havin a good ol' time, she really seems to like the music.  She says "jeez,
I could just dance for hours!" and keeps on going.  Then I hear Laurie,
who's sitting on the couch watching, say "hey!  I can dance for hours too ya
know!"  And before I know it, she's up and boogying too, and the two of them
are dancing their asses off in the middle of the living room with this
mixtape blasting at full volume!  So of course I hafta hop up and join them
so that all three of us are going, and it's then that I realize that two
previously entirely disparate people, an unhappy mother & daughter, with
nothing in common & no enjoyment of each other, have suddenly been unified
in the love of music and dance together, each with big smiles on their
faces, perhaps the only happy activity they've engaged in together in quite
a while.  This blew me away!  I mean, isn't this what a large part of raving
is about?  Again & again I am amazed by the unity I see in a large group of
people at a rave, even when people are off doing their own things.  I never
see anything like that anywhere else, and of course, with the same music
thumping at high volumes, I saw the same damn thing happen right in that
living room with just the three of us.  Folks, I think I just witnessed the
world's smallest rave! :)  And it may have only been temporary, I'm sure
things reverted back to normal after I took the tape out and left, but it
does give me hope for them (and others) that if even for a little while they
were able to put aside their problems & hurts, and just dance together.  Heehee!

And to you know-1'ers, you all be pleased to know that it just happened to
be Kenji's mixtape that did it! :)  Thank you Kenji!


Love,
Shawna

            
          Do not go gentle into that good night!
         Rave! Rave into the dawning of the light!

On Fri, 23 Aug 1996, hey, where am I? wrote:

> _SUBJECTS_
>
> Hey all!
>
> Such cool things have been happening, what a great week this has been!
> Ecto's coming to the Bay Area in time for my birthday (yippee!), I'm gonna
> go up to visit Brenda & the Ahau Collective, BM's just around the corner, I
> suddenly have two weeks of vacation, and the coolest thing happened to me
> last night:
>
> For Burning Man, my co-worker Laurie was going to lend me some of her
> camping things, like a tent, solar showers, etc.  Very nice of her!  Anyway,
> after work yesterday I was supposed to go over to her house and pick these
> things up.  So I head over there to do this, and she shows me all the stuff,
> and we have a beer, and the evening progresses like you'd expect a normal
> evening too progress.
>
> In the past Laurie has told me at various times about her family life & how
> she relates to her husband and 15-year old daughter.  They're your typical
> dysfunctional family, both she and a co-worker of ours (also a friend of
> Laurie's) have told me stories of Laurie's daughter, and how she's gone
> completely off the deep end, even to the point of having beaten up her
> mother on a couple occasions.  Things have really gotten bad, and there is
> almost no relationship between mother and daughter, it seems they pretty
> much don't do anything but fight.
>
> So I come over, do the tent thing, do the beer thing, do the hang-out thing.
> Laurie's daughter (Jennifer) eventually comes out, out of curiosity I would
> assume, and talks to us some too.  Eventually, she finds out from Laurie
> that I am a raver, and does eventually join in the conversation, talking to
> me about how she wants to go to raves when she starts driving, and much to
> my amusement produces that in/famous flyer we all remember from Lucky Charms
> back in March!  I laugh & tell her what a joke that party was, and the
> conversation has become pretty light hearted & amusing.  Eventually,
> Jennifer pulls out her cd's and starts blasting them on the living room
> stereo, mostly clubby stuff you'd hear on KMEL & whatnot.  It's funny to me,
> because upon learning I was a raver, Jennifer really came out of her
> sullen-teen shell and participated in the conversation, and became quite
> lively, which was really nice.  She was still somewhat rude to her mother,
> but it was an improvement.  So we're sitting there in the living room
> listening to this music & talking about the rave scene & rave music, and I
> think "hey, maybe I should play some of my mixtapes for her, maybe she'd
> like them!"  So I hop up and run out to my car & grab my plastic produce bag
> fulla mixtapes & such & bring 'em back in.  I pop one (a housier one,
> perhaps an easier transition from clubby music than it would be to, say,
> goa) in and start playing it.  So now we've got the stereo blasting with the
> knob at 11, and Jennifer's up & boogying all over the living room floor,
> havin a good ol' time, she really seems to like the music.  She says "jeez,
> I could just dance for hours!" and keeps on going.  Then I hear Laurie,
> who's sitting on the couch watching, say "hey!  I can dance for hours too ya
> know!"  And before I know it, she's up and boogying too, and the two of them
> are dancing their asses off in the middle of the living room with this
> mixtape blasting at full volume!  So of course I hafta hop up and join them
> so that all three of us are going, and it's then that I realize that two
> previously entirely disparate people, an unhappy mother & daughter, with
> nothing in common & no enjoyment of each other, have suddenly been unified
> in the love of music and dance together, each with big smiles on their
> faces, perhaps the only happy activity they've engaged in together in quite
> a while.  This blew me away!  I mean, isn't this what a large part of raving
> is about?  Again & again I am amazed by the unity I see in a large group of
> people at a rave, even when people are off doing their own things.  I never
> see anything like that anywhere else, and of course, with the same music
> thumping at high volumes, I saw the same damn thing happen right in that
> living room with just the three of us.  Folks, I think I just witnessed the
> world's smallest rave! :)  And it may have only been temporary, I'm sure
> things reverted back to normal after I took the tape out and left, but it

> were able to put aside their problems & hurts, and just dance together.  Heehee!

Subject: Dance with Your Parents!

Shawna told such a great story about a mother and daughter and music and
dancing...

"Folks, I think I just witnessed the world's smallest rave! :)"


RIGHT ON SHAWNA!  I loved your story,it shows how music and dancing really
connect us all!

As I read it, it triggered a memory of a wonderful New Years Eve at home
with my mom (who was visiting from the east coast), my husband and my
daughter who was then around 11 years old.

We were just lounging around with a fire in the fireplace, listing to great
old jazz on the radio, and suddenly a cool song came on and we all got up
and danced, laughing and feeling silly at first ... and for the rest of the
evening, at any given point, at least 2 of us were dancing. Between breaks
for champagne and caviar (it was New Years after all!) I danced with my
mom, she danced with my daughter, my daughter and husband danced together.
My mom died four years ago, but I'll never forget that night, and I know
she loved it as much as I did.

Moral of these stories?  Dance with your moms and your dads, folks! Dancing
and music bring people together, and we don't need raves to do that!  It
may start off awkwardly, and you have to know when it's the right time and
choose music they'll find appealing, but share that wonderful part of your
life with them, too.

Love, Leslie

On Fri, 23 Aug 1996, Leslie Ayres wrote:

> Shawna told such a great story about a mother and daughter and music and
> dancing...
> 
> "Folks, I think I just witnessed the world's smallest rave! :)"
[ ... middle stuff erased ... ]
> Moral of these stories?  Dance with your moms and your dads, folks! Dancing
> and music bring people together, and we don't need raves to do that!  It
> may start off awkwardly, and you have to know when it's the right time and
> choose music they'll find appealing, but share that wonderful part of your
> life with them, too.

  My parents both decided to drop in on the rave that my brother and I
organized, back in Ottawa.  While my dad stayed only for a few minutes,
more a show of moral support than anything, my mom got drawn into the
music (DJ Sunshine, from seattle - who could blame her?) and danced with
us for an hour or so.  It was great!  I was glad that both she and my dad
got the chance to see me, my brother, and my older sister dancing, and
happy, and join us.  I think it helped them to understand us better.  That
was a great night!
  My mom even scared off some of the younger & more trendy ravers!  Go
mom!  & you should have seen the grin on her face.  She even danced (for a
few minutes) to some really hard jungle!
  Anyway, all this to say - I agree.  If dancing is an important part of
your life, share it with those you love!

> 
> Lately I have been contemplating the cautions of Eastern mystics in 
> regards to Psychedelics. They say they cause holes in a persons aura. I 
> had discounted this for a long time but I think as is the case for most 
> mystic truths, often metaphors are needed to explain complicated things 
> in a simple way.
> 
The thing I always get to with this, is that at the end the question
is always one of freedom, and I think the holes then just become more
fuel for the fire... which then begs the question, just what sort
of blaze are you looking for.

Holding your balance is tricky though... burn too strong and it gets away
from you, gaping holes through the fabric of what we think we are,
leaving weak spots that catch us off guard and throw us for a loop,
but burn too weak and you get bored.

It's all good though, and you just gotta remember that the person
behind the mask is always you. 
the only one who will ever judge you is you.
and the only one that can set yourself free is you.


have a good weekend all, till BM...

-john.
http://he.net/~swoosh/

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Aug 24 04:31:58 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id EAA12537; Sat, 24 Aug 1996 04:31:58 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from fellini.syr.vcomm.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id EAA12532; Sat, 24 Aug 1996 04:31:53 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from [199.106.62.240] (mac950.zone.org [199.106.62.240]) by fellini.syr.vcomm.net (8.6.9/8.6.9) with SMTP id HAA11145 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sat, 24 Aug 1996 07:30:07 -0400
Message-Id: <199608241130.HAA11145@fellini.syr.vcomm.net>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 1996 04:41:45 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: crunch@vcomm.net (John Draper)
Subject: Orgasm review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Greetings,

Here's the latest reports from the Southland....  Ocean temp = 72 degress...
beaches at Coronado are amazing...

This evening,  went to Orgasm,  which a number of the DJ's from the loft
here were going to spin.    The 2nd room got canceled,   but the main room
hosted hardCore and Gabber pushing up to 240 BPM's and gangstas slam dancin
people into the speaker systems....   Massive amount of madness next to each
speaker bank....   I've never quite seen the like of this since I left
Australia.

The vibe was really strange.....  Most were latono,   and eyed me with
suspician as I walked around checking everythng out.   Good hard Techno was
playing,  pushing up to about 150 BPM's and that was in my comfort range so
I wasted no time in getting on the dancefloor.    Huge crowds gathered in
one of the largest "rap circles" i've seen since 16th and Harrison (remember
the Hayes theator).... Yukkk!!   Who wants to!

In the meantime,  I picked the least crowded speaker and got into my
usual trancy spaced out blissful dance patterns with a big phat smile on
my face,  ignoring all the insanity around me.

I was wearing my loose mushroom shirt I got at Ameba,  and as I looked around,
everyone was smiling and groovin to some insanely hard techno....

Soon,  that gave away to some gnarly hardcore as the BPM's started to climb
through 160,  pushing up towards 180....  In about an hour,  things reached
240 BPM's....  Nobody was dancing except a few of these dudes in the
rap circle dancing so fast it seemed like a blurr... Everyone else was huddled
next to the air conditioner vent as the temperature pushed towards 120 degrees
inside.

Later on,  just as I thought this insanity would never stop,   the turntable
wound down to silance....  Soon afterwards....I heard the usual "nursery
rhime" La ti da...  Duf Duf Duf .... Omigawd....  Happy Hardcore....  Almost
the same songs I heard in Australia... brought back memories as I was blissfully
bouncing off the walls...

About 2 am came around and our own Steve Pagen got behind the tables and
started playing the sickest funkiest shit I've heard since I left San
Francisco....

I immediately continued my bouncing off the walls,  while the younger crowds
dwindled down as the "Kiddie Kore" Clan went home to their Mama's and
girlfriends,  and us "Old Skoolers" started groovin to the sick stuff from
Pagen's turntables.   the vibe started to change into a much better one....

During one of my chill sessions as I was standing by the door,   I heard
"Pow Pow Pow Pow!" in rapid sucession....  The security at the door
said "Get inside!" and pure panic broie out as everyone bolted across the
dancefloor towards to back of the dance area.    Steve had already pulled
the plug on the music and was calmly putting the vinyl in the jackets and
getting ready to leave.    Jason,  (the other DJ from the Loft) said
"Lets book" so we bolted out the back door and headed into the alley
way with the rest of the crowd.  By that time,  the place was swarming
with cops....

We met at my car and waited to see what happened next as I dashed inside
to claim my stuff.... Cops were chasing everyone out of the venue...

So we hastily left the scene....

Hmmmm!!   The San Diego scene down here needs some lessons from the San
Francisco vibe.... I can assure you....  I got my work cut out for me...

Tommorrow night....  "BlitzKrieg", yet another LA Massive HardCore
rave.... (My favorite.... :-)  I'll be doing the Video (and getting payed)
using the "Bit Bopper" as we make our video "gobo's" dance to the toons..

Report from LA coming up....

The Crunchman from the Southlands...
  (sort of has a nice ring to it   :-)

>>Tommorrow night....  "BlitzKrieg", yet another LA Massive HardCore
>>rave.... (My favorite.... :-)  I'll be doing the Video (and getting payed)
>
> THE RAMONES!!!! Blitzkreig Bop. A,O. . Lets go, A, O. . Lets go. . 

No, not the Ramones. The Nazis. As in their method of waging war. It
means "lightning war". It is how they captured nearly all of europe in
the late 30's on their way to mass genocide and World War II. I guess
ravers will seek "unity" at any cost, even if it recalls the spectre of
fascism. Take a look at the movies of Nazi spectacles of dance and
music in Berlin and you might think it's like a rave, recalling hidden,
mysterious, primitive rituals. I've always thought "rave" had the power
to manipulate in this direction if put in the hands of manipulative,
power hungry people, combined with sheep-like, ignorant, drug-addled
followers.

IMHO, BlitzKreig is a highly stupid and questionable name for a rave.
There really is no excuse for ignorance, no matter how much "they" try
to make you think knowledge isn't hip or cool. Ravers think they've
reinvented what it means to be human, that every lesson of the past is
folly, that they're striking out for new, uncharted territories. Y'all
should get that fucking pacifier out of your mouths and suck on the
firehose of knowledge. Childlike innocence is no excuse. Those who
don't know their history are condemned to repeat it... 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

here's an article i got out of the paper a few days after the becoming- 
legendary Summer Love gathering here in BC ....

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 1996 11:16:53 -0700 (PDT)
From: Karen Hardie <pounce@vcn.bc.ca>
To: nw-raves@hyperreal.com
Subject: (long) Here's the Tyler interview!

from THE VANCOUVER PROVINCE, Thursday, August 22:

NEIGHBOURS NOT AMUSED
---------------------
The local rave scene is raging, syas Tyler Stadius.

The 29-year old DJ was one of several platter spinners working last 
weekend's 22-hour dancefest on the Tsawwassen Indian Reserve.

The neighbours in South Delta were not amused.

"It was all highly exaggerated by the newspapers," says Stadius.  
"Completely."

"It was loud, of course, but put it this way ... from the road, where you 
entered, you could barly hear the music."

Despite the hassles - noise complaints and police shutdowns - Stadius 
says raves are more popular than ever.

"It doesn't make an impact," insists the co-owner of Bassix, a Vancouver 
music shop that caters to the music and fashion whims of the all-night 
dance set.  "They'll always continue.  We'll just find a way of working 
within the restrictions."

There's a rave of sorts somewhere every weekend somewhere in the Lower 
Mainland.  Tipped off by flyers and phone messages, ravers find their way 
to warehouses or fields wheere they groove to the newest beats.

The size may vary, the venue may change, the musical style fluctuate, but 
the vibe transcends.

"A lot of the raves try to cater to more than just one style now by 
having more than one stage," says Stadius.

The biggest problem facing local rave organizers is finding a location 
and getting the permits.

"You'll get everything you need and when it comes to the night of the 
show the police will find somthing else to shut you down," says Stadius.

but love is the sky and i am for you
just so long and long enough
              - e.e. cummings

Subject: Re: Dance with Your Parents!
Author:  David Lowe <dlowe@best.com> at atlas
Date:    8/23/96 11:48 PM


On Fri, 23 Aug 1996, Leslie Ayres wrote:
     
> Shawna told such a great story about a mother and daughter and music and 
> dancing...
> 
> "Folks, I think I just witnessed the world's smallest rave! :)" 
[ ... middle stuff erased ... ]
> Moral of these stories?  Dance with your moms and your dads, folks! Dancing 
> and music bring people together, and we don't need raves to do that!  It
> may start off awkwardly, and you have to know when it's the right time and 
> choose music they'll find appealing, but share that wonderful part of your 
> life with them, too.
     
  My parents both decided to drop in on the rave that my brother and I
organized, back in Ottawa.  While my dad stayed only for a few minutes, 
more a show of moral support than anything, my mom got drawn into the 
music (DJ Sunshine, from seattle - who could blame her?) and danced with 
us for an hour or so.  It was great!  I was glad that both she and my dad 
got the chance to see me, my brother, and my older sister dancing, and 
happy, and join us.  I think it helped them to understand us better.  That 
was a great night!
  My mom even scared off some of the younger & more trendy ravers!  Go
mom!  & you should have seen the grin on her face.  She even danced (for a 
few minutes) to some really hard jungle!
  Anyway, all this to say - I agree.  If dancing is an important part of
your life, share it with those you love!
     
: : J. David Lowe :: dlowe@best.com :: http://www.best.com/~dlowe/ : :

:                                - Calvin, /Calvin and Hobbes/       :

Subject: re-greetings and re-intro!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        Hello beautiful SFpeople!

        I used to be on this list a way long time ago but certain life
changes (or calamities) have forced me to pare down my time spent on
mailing lists, and to be honest i was going nuts because i wasn't near SF
and i wanted to be (naturally!) :)
        I'm now well on my way to moving though, and will be coming in in
September, hopefully for good.

        Geez, i guess i'd better give you an intro here..
        Ok, my name's Brad, i do multimedia stuff, i'm living near Toronto
at present but i will be making the aforementioned move within a month
(yay!).
        Musically i'm into a lot of different things: Goa Trance is high on
the list, ambient stuff a la Pete Namlook/SpacetimeContinuum/Irresitible
Force but i'm also a sucker for Detroit/Chicago style techno, the harder
the better.

        One of the good things about being where i am right now has been
that i've been able to catch a lot of amazing djs. Three weekends ago i
went to an outdoor party nearby put on by Plus8 records with Richie Hawtin
and Jeff Mills spinning 4 hour sets.  My brain was permanently altered.

        Last week i went in to Toronto to see Cajmere (head of
Cajual/Relief records from Chicago) spin along with Dubtribe.  Brief
review: Cajmere is sexy as hell and played everything from traxxy vocal
house to his harder Green Velvet stuff. Dubtribe are, well, Dubtribe. :) I
had two people come up to me within a minute of each other to say "OH MY
GOD!! I've got chills running up my spine from them" while they were
playing. One of those awesome synchronicity/feeling the vibe things (it's
way more than just a metaphor!).

        Sun rays and smiles,
                        brad

hmm.. and another one.

i was at the last FnF party, and they were playing some slow stuff that was
putting me to sleep. so i went out to my car and put on some gabber.. leslie
(my rave-mom - and house nut) walks over and sticks her head in the window
Mom: Jeezus! what is that stuff?
Me: Gabber. Fun, isn't it?
Mom: It's crazy!
Me: You betcha.
Mom: I can't take it anymore. It's going to give me a bad trip.

>>     I remember my mom asking me one time she came home :  "where's that cd
>>     you play with the electronic music that comes in and out in waves ?"
>>     Me : "Oh, that's this one here, mom "Dragonfly records presents a
>>     journey into trance mixed by Paul Oakenfold" "
>>     Mom : "Oh, I love that one, put in on."
>>     Recent phone conversation "We all miss you here, and the music you
>>     used to play in the kitcen"
>        Dad: Brad! What the hell is that racket? It sounds like a pile driver!
>        Brad: Oh dad, that's a classic! X-Track by Circuit Breaker! It's
>like 9 minutes of a single drum machine run through a couple distortion
>pedals :)  Richie Hawtin did it, he's Canadian you know! (Trys to appeal to
>my dad's sense of national pride ;).
>        Dad: Well, that's just noise.
>        Brad: Yup, that's why i love it! :)
-brendan-


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Aug 24 17:44:18 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id RAA29209; Sat, 24 Aug 1996 17:44:18 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from Zool.AirTouch.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id RAA29201; Sat, 24 Aug 1996 17:44:13 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from CCMAIL.AIRTOUCH.COM by Zool.AirTouch.COM (SMI-8.6/SMI-SVR4)
	id RAA02790; Sat, 24 Aug 1996 17:44:06 -0700
Received: from ccMail by CCMAIL.AIRTOUCH.COM (SMTPLINK V2.11 PreRelease 4)
	id AA840933823; Sat, 24 Aug 96 17:33:11 PST
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 96 17:33:11 PST
From: "Ciaran O'Hara" <Ciaran.O'Hara@CCMAIL.AirTouch.COM>
Message-Id: <9607248409.AA840933823@CCMAIL.AIRTOUCH.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Introduction
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     
     Hello all:
     
     
     I've been on & off Sfraves for the past few months and feel it's time 
     to introduce myself :
     
     
     Mt name's Ciaran (pronounced Kier-on) O'Hara and I hail from the 
     Republic of Ireland. I came to San Francisco for the first time in 
     1994 for 5 months while I was still attending college back "home", 
     although if home is where you feel comfortable then San Francisco is 
     my new one/second one.
     
     I came back here in October 1995 and have been settling in here since.
     I was going to raves and clubs in Ireland for a while before coming 
     out here. I first danced to the music about 91-92 when we had a rave 
     in college. It was under the influence of a rather common 3 letter 
     acronym that I enjoyed myself. 
     
     That was still a kind of  one off incident, and I think the real 
     conversion for me was seeing the Orb play in Dublin about three years 
     ago. I went to the show with a group of friends from my hometown and 
     at the venue we all made base on a few benches. In all there was a 
     group of about 20 of us : all merry pranksters taking the electric 
     kool-aid acid test. What a night that was. No looking back since. 
     
     Spent the summer of 95 in Ireland and that was the time that I really 
     started to go off. The weather was amazing and every weekend was a 
     different party somewhere : East coast (Dublin), west coast(Galway), 
     South (Cork), North (Derry). Also got to Edinburgh and went to a club 
     there called pure, Jeff Mills played that night.
     
     Some acts I saw that summer : Orbital (I had a true spiritual 
     experience seeing them play open air to about 30,000 people), Carl cox 
     (twice), Laurent Garnier (amazing), Chemical brothers (blew me away).
     Dance, particulary techno & trance became the soundtrack for my life : 
     driving my car, going clubbing, etc.,
     
     I was a bit apprehensive coming back to San Francisco because i 
     worried that there would be no dance scene here. How wrong I was !
      In the past few months I've seen almost everyone I could want to see 
     perform :
     
     Tall Paul Newman (were any of you at the Submerge party in March ?), 
     Goldie; Underworld & Orbital @ the Fillmore; Chemical Brothers(again), 
     Carl Cox(again) and most recently John Digweed & Sasha at the 
     compromised Nation.
     
     Tend to look for smaller, more spiritual type parties these days but 
     will go to one of the clubs if there's a DJ I really want to hear  I 
     also want to get into organising my own parties as I feel I have a lot 
     of ideas and energy to give.If anyone wants to collaborate, e-mail me.
     I've also been doing what I'm thinking of callig rave poetry,but more 
     of that some other time.
     
     I've met some  special & wonderful people on the dance scene here & 
     Look forward to meeting some more of you out on the dancefloor!
     
     
     Peace,
     
     
     Ciaran

	Hi! I've been reading the posts here on SFRaves for about a week
and decided to finally introduce myself to all the wonderful people I've
been evesdropping on.
	My name is Stan and I'm a 3rd year Berkeley student. Born in Kiev,
Ukraine. Live in Texas for a part of my life I can't quite recall, and
spent some time in L.A. before moving up to Berkeley (and one step closer
to nirvana). :)
	My first rave was Chrysalis several weeks ago and it was an
amazing experience. I had just started listening to ambient music and
mentioned to my friend Brian Denny (high Brian ;> ) that we should go to a
rave sometime soon. Well, a week later he calls me and tells me that he
joined a list called SFRaves with really wonderful and loving people and
was so amazed by the friendliness of the people that he contacted one of
them (hey Matt L. !!!!) about meeting before the party. Well, Brian and I
met up with Matt and Shawna (yay!!). What can I say? I was amazed by the
openness and intensity of the party. I had a great time. The experience is
still difficult for me to put down into words; it was a truly spiritual
experience. Since then I've met a lot of great people at parties and hope
to continue the friendships I've started and to start many new ones.


Love and hand-lotion,
Stan

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Aug 24 22:10:02 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id WAA15094; Sat, 24 Aug 1996 22:10:02 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from melvax.sonoma.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with ESMTP id WAA15051; Sat, 24 Aug 1996 22:09:56 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from SONOMA.EDU by SONOMA.EDU (PMDF V5.0-5 #8366)
 id <01I8O4CPA0C095NPFG@SONOMA.EDU> for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Sat,
 24 Aug 1996 22:09:49 -0800 (PST)
Date: Sat, 24 Aug 1996 22:09:49 -0800 (PST)
From: Benjamin Edwards <edwardsb@SONOMA.EDU>
Subject: * PLEASE SERIOUSLY CONSIDER *
To: SF Raves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-id: <Pine.PMDF.3.91.960824212144.553699708B-100000@SONOMA.EDU>
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

A warm, affectionate hug to all ravers,

The SF rave scene is growing into a beautiful, loving, exciting 
environment.  Unfortunately, there are those who wish to interfere with 
and destroy our harmless fun- namely those wearing badges who drive black 
and white cars.  It seems that lately, the more underground raves, namely 
those held outdoors (usu. on public land) which do not happen weekly 
(like the ones in discos), are getting busted fairly regularly.  This 
would imply that the cops must have some inside sources of info, and 
unfortunately, the most likely source is the SFRaves Calendar.

I am NOT saying that the SF Raves calendar should be discontinued!  In 
fact, it's the best thing that's happened to the rave scene (besides the 
invention of E).  What I am saying is that the location of raves should 
not be made easy for the cops to find.  All it takes is one cop with one 
subscription to SF Raves, and after a few phone calls, he can bust a good 
majority of them.

Solution: NEVER give out the location of any underground rave over 
VoiceMail or other publically accessible medium.  ALWAYS use map points.  
I know, map points can be a HUGE hassle, but the only way a cop can track 
down a rave from a map point is to follow the cars to it.  And if you're 
leaving a map point and you see a black and white behind you, pull over 
at Taco Bell, take a leak, then proceed to the rave.  They'd have to use 
undercover cars and people to bust us after that, and I think that'd be 
too much of a hassle for them.

Another thing that tends to give away the location of a rave is the 
abundant number of cars in obscure locations.  This problem can be 
reduced if we all carpooled.  Not only would we be making the likelihood 
of bustation less, we'd also be helping the environment.  Perhaps people 
can leave their cars at some map points (like if they're in the parking 
lot of some 24 hour establishment like Safeway or Food 4 Less.

I'm sure there are a bunch of other ways to make raves less bustable, and 
all these ideas, like mine, will make raves more of a hassle to get to, 
but if it assures that we can all party until the sun rises, then isn't 
it worth it?

On another note: The E that is being dealt in the Bay Area is 
deteriorating in quality.  In other words, some people who are selling it 
are cutting it way too thin so they can make a bigger profit.  There's 
nothing wrong with making a profit, but making a profit at the expense of 
another person's trust in you is selfish and does not belong in our 
family atmosphere.

If your E doesn't hit you within 1/2 an hour, IT IS BUNK.  Even if you 
think you feel it a little, it is bunk.  You should KNOW, without a 
doubt, that you are e-ing.  So if you get dealt bunk E, do yourself and 
everyone else around you a favor; go up to the chump who tried to rip you 
off and tell him or her that he is dealing bunk shit.  Make it obvious, 
so that nobody else who sees what's going on will buy shit from him or 
her.  If a group of you bought the shit, go back as a group and let the 
dealer know that you do not enjoy being ripped off.

I'm not suggesting physical violence (which never solves anything), I'm 
saying that it would probably only take one or two confrontations like 
that to embarass the dealers of bunk E out of pulling that stunt again.  
I've confronted an E dealer who was selling bunk shit, and not only did 
he give me my $ back, but he got the hell out of there because other 
people who were sold bunk shit saw that and came back for their cash and 
to give him a piece of their minds.  THIS WORKS.  No threats necessary.  
Also, ask around about who the person is dealing it, and tell people not 
to buy from him or her.  It doesn't take long for word to get around and 
a bunk E dealer to be shut down.  If you're afraid to insist on getting 
what you paid for, then you're getting what you deserve.

Why am I so ticked about this (who wouldn't be)?  I was in Holland a 
while back and I got to try the PURE 150 mg dose, and let me tell you, 
that Xperience will make you a believer.  Besides, it goes for only about 
the equivalent of $3.60 over there.  Do a little research on the net and 
learn about E (and how friggin harmless it is).  1/2 an hour is all it 
should take before you're flyin' (unless you ate a big steak and potato 
dinner beforehand, since eating before Eing is a no-no).  Don't accept 
anything less than the best- let's keep the raves a pure Xperience.

Hi!,
I'd like to introduce myself, my name is Gavin Cook. I'm a ravin' 
citizen from Denver, CO. I'm moving to San Francisco at the end of 
September, either the 23rd or the 30th. I've been dancing into the wee 
hours since the summer of 92, though not continously:). I was one of the 
original beggars/promoters/founders of MtnRaves. I can't wait to get 
into the scene out there. I'm working on finding a place to live and a 
intresting job, If any one has any suggestions...

I'm a Macintosh geek/guru, 6'6", Love acid & hardcore tracks (any thing 
with a heartbeat above 140. <grin>) Um.. I want to be an industrial 
designer, but I haven't found the right school. <BeginGeekTalk> I'm into 
making my own tracks; I've got a SH-101, Alesis DM-5 & MMT-8, & a 
Digitech StudioQuad. Oh, & my head phones regularly save my life! I'm 
just starting out (have been for about 2.5 years)> I'm addicted to my 
Sony Playstation, & I just read that Metrowerks is releasing a PSX 
compiler for the Mac next month!<Rayman sez..."Yea"> & I won't keep you 
hanging, It's coming to Windows in a few months too.</BeginGeekTalk>

Well, I just wanted to say Hi & see if I can meet a few ppl. I'm a 
little nervous, I'm 21 & I've been living with my mom since I finished 
High School. She is partially disabled (chronic pain), & needs my 
physical & mental support sometimes. I feel bad leaving my sister (16) 
to have to help out mum on her own, But I've got to get on with my life. 
This is hard to say to strangers, but I know the feeling of community 
that there is in MtnRaves, & I hope that I can become a part of SFRaves 
too.
PLUR,  gav

I`ve been on the list for some weeks now, and I`ve discovered that all the
new people introduce themselves..
I haven`t done this yet, so I figured it was about time..

My name is Sune Alexandersen, and I live in Asker, a suburb to Oslo, the
capitol of Noway.... I hope to one day be an actor, allthough I haven`t done
much on stage yet... Some homemade stuff, and a tour with my old school....

If any of you don`t know where Norway is, I can tell you that it is in the
north of Europe...(Scandinavia..) This should be an excuse for some of my
bad spelling....

I`ve been into techno for about 2-3 years or so, and especially jungle....

The friendlyness on the 313 and the SFraves lists has surprised me over and
over....
I`d really like to go to America once in my life and join a party....

There are many (?) parties up here in the north, but the scene is kinda
destroying itself `cause of all the drugs...
Don`t get me wrong, I`m allso just out for having fun, It`s just that the
norwegian scene has become so dark and depressing `cause of all the drugs...
I`d like to quote a subscriber to the SFraves list, Bruce Alvin McDonugh:
quote "I just hope the kids don`t lose it all to drug abuse. Anyone choosing
to use any mind altering substance should definetely do the reading and
research required to make wise informed decisions. Love is probably the only
free high." end quote..
(hope you don`t mind me quoting you, Bruce.....)

E, speed and acid are particularly hot in Norway....

If you got any questions about the norwegian techno-scene, you can e-mail me..
Or if you simply just want a dancing e-mail-penpal from Norway!!!


Well, take care everybody!!!
may the vibe & the force be with you!!

               peacelovehappinessandunderstanding...
                                a warm bearhug to all from Sune!!!

        Hi all :)

        One other thing is that one's expectation of events-to-occur based
on past experiences and an over-analysis of things as they're happening
really inhibits uhhh certain experiences.  I think that the more you think
"is this it?" "oh wait! is *that* it?" "is this as good as _____ time i did
it?" the more you'll inhibit the experience, perhaps to the point where it
won't happen at all.
        I always just go out, dance, turn off my mind, put away all my
conceptual boxes and get ready to resonate and rock with what happens :)
        BTW, this post in no way condones the use of illicit
substances...but if you wanna do them i've found (from a friend of a friend
;) hee hee) that experience is a two way street: it's not only something
that happens to you, you happen to it as well. :)

        Peace in, peace out,
                        brad

        Wow, geez. Talk about culture convergence. I would have written
this exact stuff about any party on the east coast of North America, (and
specifically Montreal where i used to live). I feel for ya, i've been
there.
        But when you see everyone trying so hard to be something that
they're not, it gives you a lot of room to be who you really are (if that
makes any sense!)  You're realizations give you an edge that other's may
not have, and so they're doomed to be insecure, "tryhards" until they can
"get it" about what raves can REALLY be about.

out of Brooklyn, so i guess it'd be an import for you, but well worth it.
No cheesy stuff! :)
        Good luck & peace,
                        brad

> realize that yes, any intoxicant taken into the body is toxic.  (See the

> other drugs, like alcohol, marijuana, tobacco, etc.  E is not addictive.

> Newsweek, but the actual case studies done by reputable institutions-

> get someone to translate those for you).

> week) IS HARMLESS.  I've never gotten "the cold from hell" because I KNOW 
> HOW TO HANDLE MY INTOXICANTS NEILS!  Take vitamin C (lots), eat bananas

Date: Sun, 25 Aug 1996 15:32:54 +0200
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: exodus@earthlink.net (Austin Woffington)
Subject: OPEN review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey peeps,

Well I went to OPEN on friday and because the promoters feared losing their
space in the city (or did they lose it for sure?) the held the party at the
Pittsburg roller rink.  Haven't beeen there is a while.  The dj was set up
infront of a black tarp across the rink on the left and the chill room was
behind it.  A lot of sound bleed in the chill area but plenty of mattresses
and pillows to stay comffy.  The MUSIC for this party was INCREADABLE!!!
Yeah I love every minute of it.  I got there around 11.30-12 and Tony was
up spin the shit and got me warmed up for Eric Davenport.  mmmmMMMM yeah I
really started to move to the house and trancy rhythms.  Then Hipp-e went
next and you could tell there was a dj change when the bpm bounced up and
the energy just in the music got faster.  Damn, I couldn't stop moving but
I had to or I would collapse from no energy and the heat.  Hipp-e's a cool
guy and invited me and my friend Ann (mostly invited her but..) to an after
party but we never made it.
The music slowed to a stop and BOOM Trance started up a great set, mixing a
little of everything (trance->jungle->funky->hardcore->etc.) I can't wait
to hear more of him and the LA style when I move.
   The people were very friendly, and young.  The crowd was small though.
There was no concentration of energy because everyone was so spread out.
This party could have devinatlly rocked if it had a sufficent number of
people to contribute.  I miss out on the masses of people jumping, whaling,
yelling and screaming when a great build comes and conects with the crowd
and the crowd goes off.  The music was there but the crowd wasn't.

        After Trance came Terrence Toy and he layed down some funky beats.  =
Ahh.
Around 6 they turned on the lights but kept the party going till 6.30- 7.
When the end was near all the people that helped with the party got all the
hardcore ravers together in a circle infront of the dj booth and we all
danced together for about 10 minutes to the last songs.  Great party.  I
had a lot of fun.  Nexus does a great job and I hope more people come out
for their next gathering.

In the corse of the night I got a massage that just blew me away. Saw and
danced with Adam L and James(?).  What up bro? Got several hugs and candy
from strangers and danced so hard I was unable to go out to Hallucination
Saturday.

Maybe I'll see ya at sunset around 8.

Paz

Austin

people who would know something about the people involved.

expressed a month ago, belongs on a list centered 500 miles North of where
the people concerned are based. SoCal has come to a concensus about Dr.
Freecloud's and Blitzkrieg (they support the organizing group, they agree
to disagree on the name,) so back off...

Besides, who died and made you moral arbiter of an entire generation?

those words rung out to ravers waiting at the big heart back up location, 
after the cops shut down the original one, and we moved to the third 
spot, the ever wonderful ACME, home of so many past experiences - where i 
thought shurely i'd never return. but hey, this isnt a complaint about 
$2o, this is a story about persceverence and dedication. in my heart and 
mind, i feel everyone had done their best, and in the face of adversity 
our family came together under the pounding rhythm for yet another nite. 
yeah, i was expecting a fat set up, fat lazers, fat sound, fat 
decorations, delicious trance, and everything else for my $2o, but 
instead witnessed something different... something unique, and props to 
those who put it together, this is one raver who appreciated it all :)

			*ahau*
				love,
				tom

From: Randy C Cone <randream@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: Hallucination review.
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9608252012.A12646-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>

Hi all!

 Well, I'm still pretty beat ;) from the weekend. It really hurt to have 
our original site shut down by the cops. The party site was probably the 
nicest outdoor scene I've ever experienced (8 GoldScans hung from a 
crane!!), and I had set up a nice little ambient space with help from the 
Gateway crew.

 Tearing everything down after a full set up (I was SO ready to go off!) 
was very frustrating and disheartning. With a lot of help it went quickly.
We proceded to Big Heart for a long wait and finally the word came to go 
to Acme. I was intrigued to go as I've never been to this most infamous 
of spots. The Gateway crew, again, kicked really hard under less than 
ideal conditions (you all should try to set up heavy, delicate equipment 
in a packed room sometime) to quickly create a space that was very nice. 
The two lasers certainly helped!!

 The music was, of course, perfect all night long. Minor Minor started 
off and really kicked the party into a spacey high gear from the start. 
At the end we got to hear Very fresh tracks from KoxBox that were being 
mixed on Dat.

 The crowd was so friendly and kind! I really enjoyed the chance to just 
socialise and dance.

 I must say that Dutch was very inspiring all night long. He never gave 
up and tried his best to take care of all of us. I know it broke his 
heart to have our original site busted.

 I also want to thank my crew!!!! Martin and Steve for transport and 
setup. Martin again for teardown. And of course our firestarter Brendon 
(Anarch) for set up and helping to make the original ambient site 
hospitable. 

 To all the folks I hugged both newly met and otherwise; THANK YOU! You 
really helped to make me glow with pleasure!!!!  =)


Love to all of you,


Ran


                             -=*=-
                               ~

Dear Persons;

        The expert speaks = >, hmmmm you obviously haven't done real E or
some of it's cousin's. The amount of time it takes can depend on a lot of
variables like was it a pill, or is it powder, like you said how much it's
cut, what's the condition of your stomach, you metabolic rate/body ..etc,
and/or is it a relative of E like MDA, MDOH, MDE, or 2CB ...etc.

        Don't buy powder it you don't want cut in it, you can't screw with a
pill, and that's the bottom line. The powder in the bay area is sooooo weak,
gets you off for at most 4 hours and limits you to maybe 4 - 5 successive
doses before you are doing very expensive speed.

        Some of the cousins of MDMA like the one mentioned above don't have
these problems and the high is soooo close to MDMA the most people can't
tell the difference, plus you get visual stuff with the cousins.

Peace
Brian

At 10:09 PM 8/24/96 -0800, you wrote:

>On another note: The E that is being dealt in the Bay Area is 
>deteriorating in quality.  In other words, some people who are selling it 
>are cutting it way too thin so they can make a bigger profit.  There's 
>nothing wrong with making a profit, but making a profit at the expense of 
>another person's trust in you is selfish and does not belong in our 
>family atmosphere.
>
>If your E doesn't hit you within 1/2 an hour, IT IS BUNK.  Even if you 
>think you feel it a little, it is bunk.  You should KNOW, without a 
>doubt, that you are e-ing.  So if you get dealt bunk E, do yourself and 
>everyone else around you a favor; go up to the chump who tried to rip you 
>off and tell him or her that he is dealing bunk shit.  Make it obvious, 
>so that nobody else who sees what's going on will buy shit from him or 
>her.  If a group of you bought the shit, go back as a group and let the 
>dealer know that you do not enjoy being ripped off.
>
>I'm not suggesting physical violence (which never solves anything), I'm 
>saying that it would probably only take one or two confrontations like 
>that to embarass the dealers of bunk E out of pulling that stunt again.  
>I've confronted an E dealer who was selling bunk shit, and not only did 
>he give me my $ back, but he got the hell out of there because other 
>people who were sold bunk shit saw that and came back for their cash and 
>to give him a piece of their minds.  THIS WORKS.  No threats necessary.  
>Also, ask around about who the person is dealing it, and tell people not 
>to buy from him or her.  It doesn't take long for word to get around and 
>a bunk E dealer to be shut down.  If you're afraid to insist on getting 
>what you paid for, then you're getting what you deserve.
>
>Why am I so ticked about this (who wouldn't be)?  I was in Holland a 
>while back and I got to try the PURE 150 mg dose, and let me tell you, 
>that Xperience will make you a believer.  Besides, it goes for only about 
>the equivalent of $3.60 over there.  Do a little research on the net and 
>learn about E (and how friggin harmless it is).  1/2 an hour is all it 
>should take before you're flyin' (unless you ate a big steak and potato 
>dinner beforehand, since eating before Eing is a no-no).  Don't accept 
>anything less than the best- let's keep the raves a pure Xperience.

regarding e and the amphetamine question. Ina galaxy far far a way (say
'89, when there was adam and eve and other nifty analogs floating around) i
did a bit of research to find out what form of chemicals some friends of
mine were imbibing with great regularity. anyway, despite the word
amphetamine existing in MDMA, i came out with the impression that it was
not considered an amphetamine. I am not sure if this was a classification
of external effect (ie it acts an empathogen) or b/c its chemical effects
were different (it doesnt
_act_ on the the body like a methamphetamine) just curious, anyone with
some chem/pharm knowledge care to help out?

hmm.. my thought on map points. It seems to me that any rave can be busted,
its just a question of whether or not its worth busting. if its easy to
find out about (posted, address on VM) its really easy to bust. if you have
to send someone to actually go to some map point, maybe it just becomes a
pain in the ass. i dunno. maybe it even cost more for the poilice to send
someone undercover to go to the rave. this is kinda interesting to me:
anywya know any of the cost-benefit- shit the pol goes through when dealing
with this kind of hting?

kcroy

Greetings and happy Monday =P...


Well this weekend was full of suprises, suspense, anticipation and
,ultimatley, a really good party...

Friday: after woork a few of my co-workers and myself made it down the the
local pub where we all were exchanging stories of our past.  Funny, how they
speak of thier "wyld days" of the past (ie. years ago) while I was talking
about last weekend...  I need to find a workplace w/a younger crowd (well,
i'll settle for at least a younger @ heart crowd).  Alas, such socalizing
(coupled w/a horrible cough I had since Monday)kept me from any raving for
that night...

	id NAA12401; Mon, 26 Aug 1996 13:04:48 -0700
Message-ID: <3222035E.3F12@pacbell.net>
Date: Mon, 26 Aug 1996 13:04:46 -0700
From: PETER FOGEL <peterbf@pacbell.net>
X-Mailer: Mozilla 2.01E-PBWE  (Win95; I)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: omniscience review
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Angela and I got there about 12:30.  As we walked into the homebase warehouse 
we first passed through the ambient space.  After quickly moving thru that we
 got to the first room where garth was tearing it up in the wicked room.  
There as a giant budda set up behind the dj and some nice video projections as well
 as some flashing lights which were sometimes blinding but also had a hypnotic
effect.  Of course the wicked sound system sounded great.

Being that we just got there we proceeded to the big room to see how that was
set up.  Of all the parties I been to at this location, this party had the best 
visual set-up imo.  Lazers, video projections, giant budda behind the dj in
this room as well, and great lighting effects. The sound system in this room
was amazing.

Also in this room tracy was having an incredible set.  WOW! tracy in one room and 
garth in the other, both having great sets :).  And we just got there :)

After dealing with the confusion of which room to enjoy as we bounced back and 
forth a few times between the two rooms we settled in for awhile in the wicked 
room when markie came on.  Markie played a great set showing alot of variety
in the music he played as he did a great job mixing the many unique sounds.

Got to see some of dubtribes set.  I enjoyed the messages he was gettting 
out though I didn't relate to the amount of anger I felt in some the songs
and didn't get all that into the lyrics of asking "god to have mercy on my soul."
Musically I thought dubtribe was great and really enjoyed his third world singing
lyrics.

Enjoyed some of jeno's set, but also used some of this time to rest.  Carlos had a
good set, but the crowd was getting small and low on energy by then.  After a short 
rest I was able to dance hard once last time as I got inspired by angela who 
continued to dance hard inspite of the mostly low energy of the now dispersing
crowd.

We left probably just a little before it ended about 6:45.  This party was a bit 
less crowded than other parties I've been to there which I think made the vibe 
a little less chaotic with less traffic everywhere.  Overall i think the vibe had 
a nice happy one, which I think would have been difficult for there to be any other
kind with so much happy house music.

:)
peter
between

completely by socal-ravers, with the complete blessing of the forest
rangers.  The music was not hardcore, the people were great, and the
vibe was off the scale.  Oh, did I mention it was donation-only?

Subject: Re: HELP! BM location info needed
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>From SF take I80 to Reno, NV.

>From Reno, take I80 North approximately 30 miles to the Wadsworth/Pyramid
Lake exit (exit #43).  

>From exit #43, go North on Hiway 447 for 1 mile to Wadsworth.  In Wadsworth,
turn left to Highway 447, and go North approximately 75 miles to Gerlach.

>From Gerlach go Northwest on Highway 447 approximately 1 mile to the fork.
Take the right-hand fork, which is Highway 34.  Go North on Highway 34 for
approximately 12 miles.  Blackrock desert will be on your right.

Near the 12 mile mark you should see a 24" white dot on the asphalt to your
right and a vehicle parked several hards off the road.  The vechicle will be
marked with the BM symbol.  Leave the asphalt of Highway 34 here.  Follow
this dirt road til you arrive at Black Rock Station.  They will direct you
from there.

See ya.

Rick

From: rayvonie@ix.netcom.com (Ray Vonie)
Subject: Megga-BUZZ OnE - this saturday
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

To all SF-Ravers.

This Saturday will be an unforgetable night.  

We have worked so hard to make this a very special event.  It is our 
way of bringing in new people and new faces into the raving comunity.  
We expect a lot of new and first time ravers at this event, and we need 
the support of the old school ravers to guide the new ravers in the 
right direction.  It is alway the responsability of the older 
generation to pass thier knowledge to the younger generation so that 
traditions will continue.  We hope that all of you who consider 
yourselves the "safekeepers of the oldschool vibe" will come out and 
show everyone how it is done in the San Francisco Rave Sceene.  

This party is all about the Bay Area underground.  We are exclusively 
showcasing all the bay area dj's - only.  We have 3 massive rooms for 
the three sound systems representing the sound of the bay area.  Sound 
systems form the North Bay, South Bay, and Major Bay areas with all 
their own dj's. (for complete linup call 415-569-6226)  

Our vision is to throw a large party, but maintain the small party 
feel.  For this reason we made it a local showcase.  We feel that the 
musical consistancy and harmonius vibe will come through the dj's 
knowledge of each others styles.  This is why the vibe at a small party 
is so good, because the dj's are all friends, and know eack other.  We 
hope to showcase this vibe at our event to all the first time ravers so 
that they will fall in love with the sceene as we all did.  This is 
very important, especialy now, that we bring in a lot of new blood into 
our community, and except it with open arms.   Our rave sceene has a 
very high turnover rate.  It is hard to maintain a consistant folowing 
of support.  The 3/4 of the sceene seems to be turning over every year. 
 this is twice as fast as it was 2 years ago.  At this alarming rate, 
our sceene might disipate unless something is done.  We hope that this 
party not only brings in new people that will rejuvinate the 
underground folowing, but it redefines peoples perspectives on what a 
lage party can be like.  

The ideas of raving never used to be so philisophical.  they were 
practiced a lot more than they were talked about.  Lets sweep the dust 
of the old hats, and whistles and pull out the bell botoms, candy and 
platforms and lets do it like it used to be done, so that everyone, new 
and old, will be proud to call themselves ravers.  

Our reasons for doing this party are very simple - we want everyone to 
come together under the unifieing sounds of house music and to feel the 
positive vibe of everybodies energies all flowing with the music.  We 
want to bring in new people, and we want to respark the fire in the old 
ones.  

We have done everything we could on our end.  We have a secured - Fully 
Permited location to go all night long, and we have packed it with an 
incredible production, and we have goten out the word.  Now all that is 
left is for people to suport the party, and at the same time, support 
their underground community, and help out their rave sceene. 

Tickets are only $18 in advance.  We did everything humanly possible to 
make them this inexpensive.  This is something we are trying to do to 
show people that large parties do not have to cost a fortune.  This is 
a realy good price, because you are getting more than 3 large parties 
for the price of less than one.   We are also donating a portion of our 
procedes to the Bay Area Homless Alience.  Just think- your partying 
will help the less fortunate this winter.   We encourage everybody to 
buy tickets and please arive early to help set the tone and the mood 
for the evening.  

We will be filming this party so that we can someday cronicle the rave 
sceene, and we hope to see you in the vidio.  Wear your best outfits to 
help set the mood.  Your positive vibe will atract others and it will 
spead across the party like a wave of energy.  

For all information on the party please call our info #.
415-569-6226.  

advance tix are available in 8 locations and are on the back of our 
flyer.   for any questions ofr comments please e-mail or leave voice 
message.   

Thank you once again for all your support. And wee look forward to 
seing everyone at the party this saturday night.

Subject: Re: e/phetamine, E, PIHKAL...
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

> regarding e and the amphetamine question. Ina galaxy far far a way (say
> '89, when there was adam and eve and other nifty analogs floating around) i
> did a bit of research to find out what form of chemicals some friends of
> mine were imbibing with great regularity. anyway, despite the word
> amphetamine existing in MDMA, i came out with the impression that it was
> not considered an amphetamine. I am not sure if this was a classification
> of external effect (ie it acts an empathogen) or b/c its chemical effects
> were different (it doesnt
> _act_ on the the body like a methamphetamine) just curious, anyone with
> some chem/pharm knowledge care to help out?

 Hey!  
 With these questions lately about E, etc...I was just thinking,
 a great book that you might want to check out is
 PIHKAL (Phenethylamines I Have Known and Loved) by Alexander and Ann
 Shulgin.  Shulgin was often deemed the father of MDMA, though he didn't
 really invent it.  He did invent an incredible number of other
 psychoactive compounds.  This book, PIHKAL, is killer.  I would highly
 recommend it to anyone interested in drugs for research of any sort. 
 He goes into the chemical structure, the making of, the metabolism by 
 the body, and for us not-so-huge-chemistry buffs, a brief explanation 
 of the drug's effects, as per about 8 different people, and the different
 effects at different dosages.  Plus there is a nice little "fictional"
 story in there...and a great spot on personal freedom... 
 There are about 250+ drugs in there that are discussed, including MDMA,
 MDOH, MDA, etc...which are all phenethylamines.
 I know you can get the book at Great Expectations on the Haight.  I'm
 sure other places will have it too.
 Sorry if this has been discussed b4.
 Happy reading!
 shamini

Subject: Re: E
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk

>I've read in several different sources, net and book, that E is (or can be?)
>neurotoxic, that it burns out the serotonin receptors in the brain.  Anyone
>else care to comment on this.  I'm sure others must have read this.  I wonder
>if there's been any new data on this.  I did research a couple years ago.
>
>Bruce


Bruce,
John's Hopkins University in Baltimore, renowned as one of the top notch
med. universities, released a report last fall that E does just what you
suggested...in monkeys. Reported "brain damage" (their wording) included
terminal depression! Question is, how much does it take?  Unfortunately, I
never read the actual medical journal  ( I just saw a snippet in the
Chron.)  I mean, did these docs dose our little ape friends out of their
minds every day for  4 weeks?  Or did they send them out to one or two
kickin parties a month for a couple of years?
It's hard to say unless you read the article...but I encourage anyone with
enough time (or internet
access) to do a search.  I actually spent two days in the Cal Library
trying to find the article, but couldn't.

Bottom line...while E is a beautiful thing and has potential to change the
way we keep in touch with our emotions and with our fellow humans, I think
that there is a certain danger in doing it even once a week.  My personal
theory is that our serotonin levels, which I believe can replenish
themselves if given the chance, can actually dry up at the source (thus the
"brain damage") if partying is done in excess.  My advise is, that until we
know more about the JHU study and what it really means, we ought to ALL
consider what sort of permanant damage we might be doing to ourselves.  The
trick, I feel, is to take what we have learned through E and practice a
opening up "cleaner" doorways to our super-consciousness.  We've all been
there, and so we know that it exists.   Can we get there on our own?
Better cautious now than terminally damaged ten years down the road.

Anyone with more hard fact on this, please submit them.

Evolve.

b))merang
