At 10:09 PM 8/24/96 -0800, you wrote:
>A warm, affectionate hug to all ravers,
>
>The SF rave scene is growing into a beautiful, loving, exciting 
>environment.  Unfortunately, there are those who wish to interfere with 
>and destroy our harmless fun- namely those wearing badges who drive black 
>and white cars.  It seems that lately, the more underground raves, namely 
>those held outdoors (usu. on public land) which do not happen weekly 
>(like the ones in discos), are getting busted fairly regularly.  This 
>would imply that the cops must have some inside sources of info, and 
>unfortunately, the most likely source is the SFRaves Calendar.
>
>I am NOT saying that the SF Raves calendar should be discontinued!  In 
>fact, it's the best thing that's happened to the rave scene (besides the 
>invention of E).  What I am saying is that the location of raves should 
>not be made easy for the cops to find.  All it takes is one cop with one 
>subscription to SF Raves, and after a few phone calls, he can bust a good 
>majority of them.
>
>Solution: NEVER give out the location of any underground rave over 
>VoiceMail or other publically accessible medium.  ALWAYS use map points.  
>I know, map points can be a HUGE hassle, but the only way a cop can track 
>down a rave from a map point is to follow the cars to it.  And if you're 
>leaving a map point and you see a black and white behind you, pull over 
>at Taco Bell, take a leak, then proceed to the rave.  They'd have to use 
>undercover cars and people to bust us after that, and I think that'd be 
>too much of a hassle for them.
>
>Another thing that tends to give away the location of a rave is the 
>abundant number of cars in obscure locations.  This problem can be 
>reduced if we all carpooled.  Not only would we be making the likelihood 
>of bustation less, we'd also be helping the environment.  Perhaps people 
>can leave their cars at some map points (like if they're in the parking 
>lot of some 24 hour establishment like Safeway or Food 4 Less.
>
>I'm sure there are a bunch of other ways to make raves less bustable, and 
>all these ideas, like mine, will make raves more of a hassle to get to, 
>but if it assures that we can all party until the sun rises, then isn't 
>it worth it?
>
>On another note: The E that is being dealt in the Bay Area is 
>deteriorating in quality.  In other words, some people who are selling it 
>are cutting it way too thin so they can make a bigger profit.  There's 
>nothing wrong with making a profit, but making a profit at the expense of 
>another person's trust in you is selfish and does not belong in our 
>family atmosphere.
>
>If your E doesn't hit you within 1/2 an hour, IT IS BUNK.  Even if you 
>think you feel it a little, it is bunk.  You should KNOW, without a 
>doubt, that you are e-ing.  So if you get dealt bunk E, do yourself and 
>everyone else around you a favor; go up to the chump who tried to rip you 
>off and tell him or her that he is dealing bunk shit.  Make it obvious, 
>so that nobody else who sees what's going on will buy shit from him or 
>her.  If a group of you bought the shit, go back as a group and let the 
>dealer know that you do not enjoy being ripped off.
>
>I'm not suggesting physical violence (which never solves anything), I'm 
>saying that it would probably only take one or two confrontations like 
>that to embarass the dealers of bunk E out of pulling that stunt again.  
>I've confronted an E dealer who was selling bunk shit, and not only did 
>he give me my $ back, but he got the hell out of there because other 
>people who were sold bunk shit saw that and came back for their cash and 
>to give him a piece of their minds.  THIS WORKS.  No threats necessary.  
>Also, ask around about who the person is dealing it, and tell people not 
>to buy from him or her.  It doesn't take long for word to get around and 
>a bunk E dealer to be shut down.  If you're afraid to insist on getting 
>what you paid for, then you're getting what you deserve.
>
>Why am I so ticked about this (who wouldn't be)?  I was in Holland a 
>while back and I got to try the PURE 150 mg dose, and let me tell you, 
>that Xperience will make you a believer.  Besides, it goes for only about 
>the equivalent of $3.60 over there.  Do a little research on the net and 
>learn about E (and how friggin harmless it is).  1/2 an hour is all it 
>should take before you're flyin' (unless you ate a big steak and potato 
>dinner beforehand, since eating before Eing is a no-no).  Don't accept 
>anything less than the best- let's keep the raves a pure Xperience.
>
>
>

     That's not entirely true. You can have perfectly clean
methylenedioxymethamphetamine and you could have screwed it yourself by say,
eating a meal a couple hours before, or even a sandwich just a little while
before. In my experiences, food in your stomach makes a huge diffirence
between a good trip and none at all. Me and my girl dropped it and I was
having a good time while she (80lbs lighter and a chicken sandwich in her
stomach) didn't feel much at all.
        Another time, I gave her a hit and it didn't do anything to her
really, for about 2-3 hrs, then it hit waaaay hard. 

        Don't eat for 6 hours before, save your food till you feel it (best
food you'd ever have).

"Painlessly" for the Germans ;)  The Blitzkrieg was meant to conquer quickly
before adequate defenses/reinforcements could be mounted, and especially to
strike terror into those under assault.  It actually did sort of work (witness
the early stages of the war), but Hitler and the Germans' egos were bigger
than their brains.  They abandoned the air-raids of England just prior to an
invasion (which if successful would have prevented the US from establishing
air bases there...), and they got bogged in a multi-front war.  They probably
would have ended up being defeated anyway, though.


As far as the rave, though I think it's a lame name (AK-47's on the poster?),
let them use it.  It's their right.  People don't have to go (although they
will...)


-mike

>> mine were imbibing with great regularity. anyway, despite the word

>> not considered an amphetamine. I am not sure if this was a classification
>> of external effect (ie it acts an empathogen) or b/c its chemical effects
>> were different (it doesnt
>> _act_ on the the body like a methamphetamine) just curious, anyone with
>> some chem/pharm knowledge care to help out?
>
> Hey!  
> With these questions lately about E, etc...I was just thinking,
> a great book that you might want to check out is
> PIHKAL (Phenethylamines I Have Known and Loved) by Alexander and Ann
> Shulgin.  Shulgin was often deemed the father of MDMA, though he didn't
> really invent it.  He did invent an incredible number of other
> psychoactive compounds.  This book, PIHKAL, is killer.  I would highly
> recommend it to anyone interested in drugs for research of any sort. 
> He goes into the chemical structure, the making of, the metabolism by 
> the body, and for us not-so-huge-chemistry buffs, a brief explanation 
> of the drug's effects, as per about 8 different people, and the different
> effects at different dosages.  Plus there is a nice little "fictional"
> story in there...and a great spot on personal freedom... 
> There are about 250+ drugs in there that are discussed, including MDMA,
> MDOH, MDA, etc...which are all phenethylamines.
> I know you can get the book at Great Expectations on the Haight.  I'm
> sure other places will have it too.
> Sorry if this has been discussed b4.
> Happy reading!
> shamini 
> 
> 
>
>
In fact, you can basically find that whole book at one site on the net. I
forgot what it was but use your browser for PIHKAL and it'ss lead you right.

Aryck

>>http://www.cityscape.co.uk/users/bt22/legal.html
>><BASE HREF=3D"http://www.cityscape.co.uk/users/bt22/legal.html">
>>
>><TITLE>Legal Highs</TITLE>
>>
>><H1>Legal alternatives to Ecstasy</H1>
>>Herbal Ecstasy and other legal highs<p>
>>Many people are worried about taking Ecstasy and are turning to safe,=
 legal
>alternatives. Or are they? Here is a run down on what is available.<p>
>>We bought as many "herbal Ecstasy" products as we could find and made a
>list of all the ingredients. These included: Tibetan Ma Huang, Wild
>Brazilian Guarana, Chinese Black Ginseng, Wild Ginko, Biloba, African raw
>cola nut, Gotu-Kola, Fo-Ti-Tieng, Green tea extract, Rou Gui (rare form of
>Chinese nutmeg), yohimbara (relative of yohimbe), Calamus, Kava kava
>tincture, raw ephedra, tincture of ephedra, broom and lettuce opium=
 (Lactuca
>virosa), also in resin form for smoking. Then we sent the list to a German
>expert on psychotropic plants. <p>
>>Her verdict was that most of these ingredients have a speedy effect, but
>not basically different to drinking coffee or Red Bull. Only one ingredient
>had extra effects, the herb called Ma Huang in Chinese and Ephedra in
>English, whose extract is the drug ephedrine. This has a stimulating
>"shivering skin and muscle effect" which some people associate with=
 Ecstasy.
>"You feel shivers up and down your spine, especially in the roots of your
>hair. It makes you sweat and you feel your muscles and skin more intensely.
>It can act as an aphrodisiac, especially for women. A major difference from
>Ecstasy is that this herb helps you to concentrate your mind on a task, so
>that some people find it a good drug to use for mental work." <p>
>>Ephedra or ephedrine makes your heart beat faster and makes you breathe
>more deeply. This can feel exhilarating, but an overdose can be very
>unpleasant and may cause muscle spasms and even a heart attack. The safe
>dose varies according to the individual so that its easy to overdose unless
>you are used to it, so try a small amount first. According to British
>National Formulary, ephedrine is "not recommended and should be avoided
>whenever possible" and must not be used by people with heart disease,
>diabetes, hypertension or kidney disease. Side effects include racing=
 heart,
>dry throat, anxiety, tremor and cold extremities. The maximum dose is 600=
 mg.=20
>>Herbal Ecstasy pills are sold at about =A310, not much less than an E. A
>friend took some and liked it, but a man with her took the same amount and
>had a panic attack; he was taken to hospital and was told he could have
>choked to death. Much cheaper is ephedra herb. Make a tea by brewing the
>dried herb in a cup of water for at least 3 minutes; then strain and drink.
>Start with one teaspoon per person and try more if it is not strong enough.
>It is astringent and bitter, but is more palatable with a little milk.<p>
>>Other herbal highs include Khat or qat, a herb that is chewed in the=
 Yemen;
>tastes foul but gives you a buzz since it contains drugs similar to
>amphetamine and ephedrine. Khat is increasingly sold in clubs but should be
>fresh to have the full effect. Long term use has been linked to cancer of
>the tongue.<p>
>>Poppers (Isobutyl nitrate)<p>
>>Legal in Britain, sold in sex shops and some clubs in small bottles. When
>sniffed or breathed in an open mouth "poppers" give strong rushes of energy
>for a minute or less, especially while on E. However, they can cause black
>out, headache, nausea and have caused death by heart attack.
>>DXM (Dextromethorphan Hydrobromide)<p>
>>This is the active ingredient in some cough mixtures and capsules which=
 can
>be bought over the counter, which some people use as a substitute for
>Ecstasy.<p>
>>Low dose is similar to alcohol producing carefree clumsiness plus a touch
>of psychedelic and speedy effect. Intense and rhythmic music can induce a
>state of euphoria and dancing becomes fun. Overdoses can be unpleasant;
>imagination may become vividly experienced and on higher doses you may feel
>dissociation from your body. Dose is about 100-200 mg, but depends very=
 much
>on the individual. Beware of cough medicines containing other active
>ingredients as they may have other effects, and avoid if you are taking an
>antidepressant of the MAOI type. Other types of antidepressants such as
>Prozac may increase the effect.<p>
>>Mushrooms<p>
>>Dried mushrooms are classed as an illegal drug, but if you wait till
>autumn, pick psilocybin mushrooms and put them straight into your mouth you
>can get a legal high similar to acid, and preferred by many people because
>they are natural. But being natural does not remove the dangers of LSD:
>mushies can also make you paranoid in the wrong situation and may trigger
>psychosis.<p>
>>Herbal Ecstasy compared to placebo<p>
>>You may have heard people swear that herbal Ecstasy is better than MDMA.
>Last summer I gave out 100 samples of 'herbal Ecstasy' and asked people for
>responses, but half were given vitamin pills instead. Several people
>reported they had had their best E experience ever; but about half of those
>had taken the vitamin tablets! I reported this in Eternity magazine and the
>American suppliers added a sticker on packs sold in the US saying "Tested=
 by
>Nicholas Saunders in Britain; "'The best Ecstasy I had ever had'".<p>
>>This is known as the placebo effect: people feel what they expect, because
>expectation can actually have the same effect as a drug by releasing
>neurotransmitters into the brain. This is a true natural high, and some
>people can get there without any drugs by 'contact high', or even just by
>getting themselves into the mood.<p>
>>My conclusion is this. Most herbal products are no better than speed=
 unless
>they contain ephedra which is probably just as dangerous as MDMA. Legal
>drugs are not safer than illegal ones, nor are all herbs. Remember that
>poisoned arrows are tipped with a natural herbal product!<p><p>
>>Nicholas Saunders<p>
>>Published in Eternity Magazine, edited from a more detailed section in the
>book Ecstasy and the Dance Culture.

On Mon, 26 Aug 1996,:

> >Another time, I gave her a hit and it didn't do anything to her really, >for about 2-3 hrs, then it hit waaaay hard. 
> 
> Thats what happened to me this last weekend. I bought my E from this
> girl, and after it didn't kick in for 3 hours, I was totally ticked off!
> I grabbed my friend, we went back to my car, and just as I was about to
> put the key in to leave- BAM!! It hit! I just turned to my friend and
> said: "Dude, we have to get back in there RIGHT NOW!" :-) And then
> everything was cool.


Note:  I am NOT flaming in any way, shape, or form.

It just saddens me to see that to some people the party is a measure of 
how good the drugs are or if they are on drugs at all.  That is an 
attitude I'd worry about.  I guess to each his own.  I am the first to 
admit to the relationship between raves and drugs and don't frown upon 
it.  It is just something I feel that one needs to evaluate.  Why do you 
go?  What do you want to get out of it?  I know the drug aspect is low on 
my hierarchy of reasons why I rave.   I personally don't need substances to 
dictate whether I have a good time or not nor whether I decide to stay or not.
The people and the music do that for me.  I've heard the comment that 
"this party isn't that great, but maybe if I do E it will make it better."
That just isn't what I think about raving, but that's just me....
Hmmm... maybe I'm being "holier-than-thou".  I dunno. :\


-KaySEE

>I've read in several different sources, net and book, that E is (or can be?)
>neurotoxic, that it burns out the serotonin receptors in the brain.  Anyone
>else care to comment on this.  I'm sure others must have read this.  I wonder
>if there's been any new data on this.  I did research a couple years ago.

check out "e is for ecstasy" in the hyperreal drug section... very useful,
pretty long and totally nonpartisan (warn't written by a raver OR a fed!
=).

I think the author's conclusion was that seratonin levels in the brain does
seem to be lower among e-using rats but: the doses they gave to rats were
something like the equivalent of a person taking 20 hits, twice a day,
every day (!!!) and that lower seratonin levels don't necessarilty mean
something's wrong or that e's causing it because people just don't know
that much about neurochemistry anyway.

-m.

On Aug 26,  5:39pm, Troy Sheets wrote:
> Subject: Re: Drugs are bad!!!
> >
> >         Here's an idea by me: See everyone. . .drugs are drugs. No matter
> > how good it feels, anything that alters your normal state of mind is
> > harmful. Basically everything kills brain cells, shit, aging kills brain
>
> So maybe drugs do harm you physically a bit.  But that is a risk that
> I think the world can take, espically if certian chemical compounds are
> the key in awaking a society that is quickly slipping into complete, and
> total global insanity.
>
> I will choose a tiny bit of physical toxicity if it will snap myself
> and the world out of a 2000 year old bad trip...
>
> -troy
>
> ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
> tsheets@cyborganic.net                     <- You have found me
> tsheets@schwa.eng.sun.com                  <- Official Use Only
> http://www.cyborganic.com/People/tsheets   <- Instant Content
> troys-list@schwa.eng.sun.com               <- Inquire Within
>-- End of excerpt from Troy Sheets

My $0.02, it's very likely that many synthetic drugs are bad for you in the
long run (depending on how enthusiastic one administers them...). However,
many people are into mountain climbing, car racing, hanggliding etc. Lots
of people are killed while taking part in such activities too. The bottom
line for me is that my body is mine, and mine alone. We have a limited
number of years on this planet and we can use our body (and mind/soul)
in whatever way we feel gets us the most out of those years. One can
live a quite and peaceful life, but to experience things that add intensity
and meaning to it all, one has to take risks every now and then. Every
time you get into your car you take the risk of ending up as a statistic.
Even if many of us may end up in the funny farm 30 years from now, at
least we (hopefully) lived our lives to the fullest. Moderation and
diversity in how we get our kicks is probably the best way to go.
And the body can take a lot of damage without showing any effects, especially
the brain which is capable of letting other parts take over functions
which are lost by accidents etc. Alcohol kills brain cells and you don't
make any new ones and still you can be social drinker and not become
senile early in life. Another interesting find from all the E research
(found somewhere among the hyperreal stuff) is that people expected regular
E-users to become more aggressive due to serotonine depletion, while in
fact the opposite turned out to be the case. Short term memory appears
indeed to be affected, which is also a side effect of legal drugs like
prozac (even though that drug influences serotonine levels in a different
way). In any case, we will be in good company in the psychiatric wards...

The Frying Dutchman


--

        You don't smoke do you??? I can't tell you how many times I've heard
someone say that. I'm one of those people that do all that crazy stuff like
flying through the air and landing on soon to be broken body parts.
        But drugs are a diffirent story, you do have a limited time on this
earth but, would you really want to spend 1/3 of it on drugs, 1/5
recuperating from the drugs, and the rest living with the aftermath of the
drug use??? I just try to persuade people from doing them because eventually
you'll have to live your real life, and if you spenmd all your time in a
made up world, you can't give your full attention to making your REAL world
the best it can be for you and whatever offspring you may have. 
        It's cool sometimes, but realize that you can't always live like that.
I don't mean to start an argument, I'm just venting my thoughts.
Nothing wrong with voicing yer opinion.

Aryck

Hello again!

    Well this is a little short noticed, but here we go!!

    The Harmony Anniverary party is costing a bundle. In fact, even if 
we sell all the tickets @ $20 we might not break even. (This means we 
are probably spending a little too much money!) But we have always put 
%100 of all revenues straight back into our parties. We don't take 
paychecks or anything! ;) This makes the party more enjoyable for all 
of you!!!
    
    But anyways, the 3 year party's budget has gotten completely out of 
control! We do not want to make any budget cuts, cause that would just 
take away from the party. We want to spend as much as we can to make it 
as intense as possible!!! Because of this, we are planning a smaller, 
more intimate family party/ fund-raiser for the week before. 

    It's going to be a "Beautiful People" party. It will be in San 
Francisco, on Friday September 6th. (The purpose of this party is to 
raise money for the three year party) The admission cost will be $15 :( 
Now we know that some of you just went and purchased your anniversary 
tickets. We also know that $20, even for this party is kinda harsh on 
the pocket. So, if you come to Beautiful People, with your actual 
Harmony 3 year ticket in your hand, we will let you in for $10 (or 
maybe less... hopefully less, but we'll see...) 

    There will be a lot more information about this Beautiful People 
party coming up. So keep your eyes and ears open!!! Call the infomation 
line for more info... (408)486-9591   (408)450-3044

Peace, love and harmony,

Greg :)

Ray Vonie wrote on 8/26/96:
>To all SF-Ravers.

This party is all about the Bay Area underground.  We are exclusively
>showcasing all the bay area dj's - only.  We have 3 massive rooms for
>the three sound systems representing the sound of the bay area.  Sound
>systems form the North Bay, South Bay, and Major Bay areas with all
>their own dj's. (for complete linup call 415-569-6226)

Although I don't like MASSIVES persay, this is wholy a good idea and would
be one reason I would go to this party.  I'm leaving for the weekend to
secure a job in San Luis Obisbo so I'll be missing out on BM (and this
party).  Just a few comments (OPINIONS) on what Ray wrote.
>
>Our vision is to throw a large party, but maintain the small party
>feel.  For this reason we made it a local showcase.  We feel that the
>musical consistancy and harmonius vibe will come through the dj's
>knowledge of each others styles.  This is why the vibe at a small party
>is so good, because the dj's are all friends, and know eack other.  We
>hope to showcase this vibe at our event to all the first time ravers so
>that they will fall in love with the sceene as we all did.

Vibe doesn't come from the dj's directly, but rather indirectly through the
feelings and conections the crowd makes with the music the dj is spinning,
the people around them and through connecting with ones self.  I have never
felt this "small party" vibe at a large gathering with the exception of a
few of the Gatherings parties, and a few parties way back when (I don't
even recall the names but I do recall my experiences).  IMHO to create this
"small party" vibe in a large party, you must have an experience crowd and
a crowd willing to give more to the party than they are taking.  If
=46eelgood Ent. pulls it of I will be most impressed.

 This is
>very important, especialy now, that we bring in a lot of new blood into
>our community, and except it with open arms.   Our rave sceene has a
>very high turnover rate.  It is hard to maintain a consistant folowing
>of support.  The 3/4 of the sceene seems to be turning over every year.
> this is twice as fast as it was 2 years ago.  At this alarming rate,
>our sceene might disipate unless something is done.  We hope that this
>party not only brings in new people that will rejuvinate the
>underground folowing, but it redefines peoples perspectives on what a
>lage party can be like.

I'm not sure I understand what your trying to say here.  Almost sounds like
the scene needs this party to go off to continue its existance.  Hmmm.  It
seems that in the past year or so Promoters have come and gone, or just
changes names.  The scene isn't dieing its just changing.  I see this next
year will be a great year for parties since most of the new promoters will
be around of at least a year and better parties come with more experience
(ie Nomad, bagok, utra 5, GK).  Those promoters who have been around for a
while I hope will continue to stay around and produce quality parties
(Gathering, Wicked, F&F, space children and others).  The influx of new
"blood" into the scene does produce a demand but this is not a necessity to
solve these "problems" we share with our scene.
PLUR is what we need more of and spreading more positive energy to our
scene will do more good than adding more newbies to the scene.
>
>The ideas of raving never used to be so philisophical.  they were
>practiced a lot more than they were talked about.  Lets sweep the dust
>of the old hats, and whistles and pull out the bell botoms, candy and
>platforms and lets do it like it used to be done, so that everyone, new
>and old, will be proud to call themselves ravers.
>

I dislike catagoizing people.  But a raver doesn't have to have all those
physical items to promote positive energy.  Though I've been known to carry
a whistle or two, some stickers, candy and the occational vicks bottle, but
I don't have to show my suport for a party.  <there's those ear muffs>


>Our reasons for doing this party are very simple - we want everyone to

>positive vibe of everybodies energies all flowing with the music.  We
>want to bring in new people, and we want to respark the fire in the old
>ones.

>We have done everything we could on our end.

>Permited location to go all night long, and we have packed it with an

>their underground community, and help out their rave sceene.

>Tickets are only $18 in advance.  We did everything humanly possible to

>a realy good price, because you are getting more than 3 large parties
>for the price of less than one.   We are also donating a portion of our

> >>Mushrooms<p>
> >>Dried mushrooms are classed as an illegal drug, but if you wait till
> >autumn, pick psilocybin mushrooms and put them straight into your mouth you
> >can get a legal high similar to acid, and preferred by many people because

 Just wanted to mention here that this article isn't clear on the fact  
that some wild mushrooms can be fatal if ingested. Most wild mushroom 
toxins have no known antidote and if you have ingested toxic mushrooms 
then all the doctor can do is pump your stomach (useless if you wait 
until you feel really ill).

Well fam', just got back in from the Seattle trip.  All is well.  I think
they are facing a lot and most seem to be dealing with it quite well.  There
is really not a "scene" there...like what we know and love in The City.  But
such is the diversity of this planet.  I think we should be thankfull for
what we have in SF as far as dancing and music goes.  Truly, it is one of
the best places in the world!!!!!!!  Seattle was great, however, it was most
difficult to find any rave scene whatsoever.  There was a lot of that rap,
hip-hop stuff they call "rave" music, but to me its not even close to what
the SF DJ artists can produce at a happening and viby event.  One supposed
rave party sported a "break dancing" contest...which is far from the rave
scene I know and love in SF.  The outdoors, hiking, shopping and ambiance of
Seattle are hard to beat though.  It's a fantastic place to be.  But as they
say, "I left my heart in San Francisco".  I did not make it to Electrolush,
but have heard good things about it.  I thought there would be other
gatherings to be found, but either I missed out or there were none.

Love,

Troy J.
(Wowser)

PS.  Does anyone know about the scene in Vancouver, BC?  By what I saw in
Seattle, BC seems THE place to be in the Pacific NorthWest.  Any comments?

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Monday August 26 11:42 PM EDT

Dole Ad Says Drugs the New 'Nuclear' Threat

SANTA BARBARA, Ca (Reuter) - Republican presidential candidate Bob Dole
picked one of the most chilling images in American political history Monday
to drive home his campaign theme that drug abuse is as great a threat as
nuclear war.

A stark new black-and-white Dole television campaign ad uses the famous
image of a little girl picking a daisy -- first used in 1964 by Democrat
Lyndon Johnson, who followed the girl's image with that of a nuclear
mushroom cloud.

``Thirty years ago, the biggest threat to her was nuclear war,'' the
narration says. ``Today the threat is drugs.''

The new commercial was released Monday in Santa Barbara, where Dole is on a
working vacation, and in Washington. Paid for by the Republican National
Committee and authorized by Bob Dole's presidential campaign, it will appear
starting Tuesday in selected markets, including Chicago where the Democrats
are having their nominating convention.

Dole, campaigning near Chicago Sunday, accused President Clinton of
``raising the white flag'' in the war on drugs after a survey last week
found that illegal drug use from 12-17 year-olds had doubled in the past
four years.

In that speech, Dole did not use the nuclear imagery but he did call drug
trafficking the ``moral equivalent of terrorism.''

The new ad, which dissolves from the ``daisy girl'' to harsh images of a
crack pipe, a heroin spoon and a needle stuck in an arm, attacks Clinton's
drug record and concludes ``America deserves better.''

The ad will rotate with another one, released last week as part of a $3.5
million ad buy, on Dole's economic policy and his pledge to slash taxes and
balance the budget.

Dole was in a secluded cottage on the grounds of the luxurious Biltmore
Hotel in Santa Barbara. He had some meetings with advisers, but no public
events scheduled Monday, and his aides said most of his day was devoted to
relaxing and soaking up the sun in the nation's biggest state, with 54
electoral votes.

He has a few campaign events scheduled for later this week, but the plan is
to maintain a fairly low profile during the Chicago convention. Similarly,
Clinton vacationed in Jackson, Wyoming while the Republicans convened in San
Diego to nominate Dole.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Sunday August 25 5:59 PM EDT

Dole Brands Drugs Moral Terrorism, Vows War

PALOS PARK, Il. (Reuter) - Campaigning within shouting distance of Chicago
on the eve of the Democratic convention, Republican presidential candidate
Bob Dole Sunday vowed an all-out war on illegal drugs which he decried as
the ``moral equivalent'' of terrorism.

Harshly attacking the White House for what he called a ''Don't Worry, Be
Happy'' stance on drugs, Dole promised to deploy all resources necessary to
fight drugs -- including the army, the navy, the Coast Guard, the Central
Intelligence Agency and the National Guard.

Citing the study released last week that showed that drug abuse has doubled
since President Clinton took office, Dole blasted what he characterized as a
``Don't Worry, Be Happy'' attitude of the Democratic administration.

``This president has been known not for his eloquence but his silence,'' he
said. ``This administration replaced the unambiguous message of ``Just say
no'' with this message: 'Just say nothing.'''

``We will treat drugs for what they are -- the moral equivalent of
terrorism,'' Dole said. ``The terrorism of drugs destroys our young peole
and hijacks America's future.''

Breaking with a tradition in which candidates do not venture close to their
opponents' nominating conventions, Dole made the speech at a picnic and
rally in a park in affluent suburbs southwest of Chicago, where the
Democratic convention begins Monday. Dole campaigns in Oregon later Sunday,
and starts a working vacation in Santa Barbara, California, on Monday.

In a speech that dwelt far more on stopping drug traffic than on prevention
and education, Dole noted the traditional reluctance to use the military to
confront domestic problems but said drugs come from abroad and are thus not
only a home-grown problem.

He said that if elected he would call on his defense secretary and military
leaders to draw up battle plans for the war on drugs, including contingency
plans for interdiction along the southern U.S. border.

``Now, one would hope that such interdiction by U.S. military forces would
never need to take place. But just as U.S. combat readiness is a deterrent
to those who would challenge us in a war, so will the knowledge that all the
capabilities -- I said all the capabilities -- of our federal government
will be used to reduce the flow of drugs across our border if necessary,''he
said.

In an oblique reference to recent reports that some White House staffers had
used drugs in the past, he said his own stance would be ``zero tolerance''
from the White House on down to every workplace and school in America.

``In the Dole administration we're going to return to what works -- a clear
and forceful policy of zero tolerance. That's zero tolerance. Zero tolerance
for drug sumugglers, zero tolerance for drug pushers. Zero tolerance for
drugs in the workplace and zero tolerance for illegal drugs period. Zero.
Zero. Zero.''

At 6:45 PM -0700 8/26/96, Brian Denny wrote:
>where at BM are you planning on staying?
>vw camp?
>rave camp?
>somewhere else?

You will find most people identifying themselves primarily as a raver (that
is, don't necessarily get/don't care about the Burning Man experience, may
just think that Burning Man is just a big rave) staying at Rave Camp. This
camp is isolated two miles away from the actual Burning Man event to create
a sound-proof safety buffer.

You will find that most all SF Raves people that are more diverse (i.e.
they can tell you about the things that they do in their life of which
raving is probably just one of them) in the Irrational Geographic Mega
Theme Camp, one component of which is the VW Camp.. We will have approx. 18
RV's in this camp... and most of these people are high-tech types.

I don't know where anybody else is staying.

____________________________________________________________________________
 Wayne D. Correia            +1.415.826.6000            FAX +1.415.826.6100

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Burning Man and Excite BSP?
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi All,

I was at my companies, Excite - the search engine, all hands meeting
on Monday when a product manager anounced that he was looking for
some employee volunteers to possibly go to Burning Man with a company
rented truck filled with water bottles to hand out for free at BM
as a promotion. Of course the bottles will have our logo/url on them
but he said there will be no large advertising banners and whoever
wants the water will have to go to our truck to pick it up...it will
not be handed out like flyers. Concerned, I told him that this could
possibly backfire since a positive vibe is something which cannot be
bought, sold, or commercialized. We all know that what makes real
underground parties so special is that positive vibe and what creates
it is UNCONDITIONAL LOVE freely given without concern for ego
gratification or identification.

My purpose in this post is not to start a flame war but to ask for
your valued opinions on our product manager's idea (good or bad) ?
Personally, I don't think it would be a good idea for the reasons
stated above.

Thank you all for your input and I'll gladly forward your constructive
criticism to our product manager!!

Peace and UNCONDITIONAL LOVE always,
John

> Note:  I am NOT flaming in any way, shape, or form.
> 
> It just saddens me to see that to some people the party is a measure of  how >good the drugs are or if they are on drugs at all.  That is an  attitude I'd >worry about.  I guess to each his own.  I am the first to  admit to the >relationship between raves and drugs and don't frown upon  it.  It is just >something I feel that one needs to evaluate.  Why do you  go?  What do you >want to get out of it?  I know the drug aspect is low on  my hierarchy of >reasons why I rave.   I personally don't need substances to  dictate whether I >have a good time or not nor whether I decide to stay or not.
> The people and the music do that for me.  I've heard the comment that  "this >party isn't that great, but maybe if I do E it will make it better."
> That just isn't what I think about raving, but that's just me....
> Hmmm... maybe I'm being "holier-than-thou".  I dunno. :\
> 
> 
> -KaySEE

No, youre not being "holier than thou". Actually that night I spent a
lot of time thinking about exactly what you bring up. Now, understand
that I don't go to raves just for the drugs. But youre right, that night
I was not having a very cool time untill the E kicked in. Partially it
was because I thought I just blew $20. But I just kept thinking: "So is
this it? The only way I am going to enjoy myself at parties is if I'm on
something?" It scares me. I can't keep doing this all my life (none of
us I think can really expect to reach a ripe old age and continue our
weekly/biweekly/monthly indulgence of E or other such substances). I
might start getting invloved in promoting parties even if I'm just
handing out flyers. I'll be sober, but I'll feel better because I can
say that I'll have given back to the scene and helped promote it.

I personally believe that Burning Man should remain a sanctuary from such
activties.  Imagine, if you will, the impact of such a give away next year,
and the year after, and the year after.  Undoubtedly the marketing snowball
effect will occur at Burning Man, and has already begun, but why add to the
giant wad of marketing gluttony?  Is it really an effective campaign? Will
people really save their bottles for the precious URL, or even go back home
and say, "Damn, that free water sure was nice, I should go check out their
web site?"  I seriously doubt people will remember where the water came
from in the first place.

Why doesn't EXcite hand out...oh, I don't know...something more soul
searching?  =)  Something more EXy, or something.

Thank you for not selfishly seeing this as an opportunity to get a free
ride to BM, John.

Burning Man attendees are not a target market!  They just want to be freaks
in an environment as free from the corporate world as possible.  We get
that all day, every day, "We deserve a break today?!"

That's my take on...

Thanks John!

Tony




At 10:25 AM -0700 8/27/96, John Kawamoto wrote:
>Hi All,
>
>I was at my companies, Excite - the search engine, all hands meeting
>on Monday when a product manager anounced that he was looking for
>some employee volunteers to possibly go to Burning Man with a company
>rented truck filled with water bottles to hand out for free at BM
>as a promotion. Of course the bottles will have our logo/url on them
>but he said there will be no large advertising banners and whoever
>wants the water will have to go to our truck to pick it up...it will
>not be handed out like flyers. Concerned, I told him that this could
>possibly backfire since a positive vibe is something which cannot be
>bought, sold, or commercialized. We all know that what makes real
>underground parties so special is that positive vibe and what creates
>it is UNCONDITIONAL LOVE freely given without concern for ego
>gratification or identification.
>
>My purpose in this post is not to start a flame war but to ask for
>your valued opinions on our product manager's idea (good or bad) ?
>Personally, I don't think it would be a good idea for the reasons
>stated above.

>criticism to our product manager!!

On Aug 26,  8:06pm, Aryck wrote:
> Subject: Reply on your reply Dutchman
[my original post deleted]
>         You don't smoke do you??? I can't tell you how many times I've heard
> someone say that.

In fact I am a smoker...

> I'm one of those people that do all that crazy stuff like
> flying through the air and landing on soon to be broken body parts.

Aren't you happy that this is (still) legal to do? That you can decide to
take risks while sporting and nobody bothers you about it?

>         But drugs are a diffirent story, you do have a limited time on this
> earth but, would you really want to spend 1/3 of it on drugs, 1/5
> recuperating from the drugs, and the rest living with the aftermath of the
> drug use???

Of course not, I hope I didn't give that impression and it's not how I live
my life. As I said, moderation and diversity in your kicks, be it mountain
climbing or dropping the occasional E is the key. In your original post you
warned about drugs being dangerous, my point was that there are many other
(legal) activities which can be equally harmful, but for which _your_
right to decide to take part in them is accepted in this world. I'm not
trying to say we should all just watch our lives slip by being doped.
I defend your and my right to do with our body/lives whatever we feel
like.

> I just try to persuade people from doing them because eventually
> you'll have to live your real life, and if you spenmd all your time in a
> made up world, you can't give your full attention to making your REAL world
> the best it can be for you and whatever offspring you may have.

You are talking about an extreme situation where a person is fully
occupied with drugs, raving etc. I agree completely with what your saying,
but this was (as I felt it) not the message of your original post, which
just stated (very generally): "drugs are bad". I can assure you (despite
my "virtual name" on this list that I lead a very happy and satisfying
real life, in a very real world. And to be clear, I have been in a
phase that you describe, living from one rave to another (while still
getting my PhD, mind you) and my guess is lots of people go through
such a stage. It's very educating, about yourself, your friends and
the world and usually last only for a few years at most, after which
other things (in the real world) need your undivided attention.

> It's cool sometimes, but realize that you can't always live like that.

Again, I agree. But let's say your hobby of choice is mountainclimbing
or car racing, you start a family, have kids etc. realizing that you
could get killed in an accident while enjoying yourself. What to do?
We all take risks and I fail to see the difference between _moderate_
drug use and some sports and other activities.

> I don't mean to start an argument, I'm just venting my thoughts.
> Nothing wrong with voicing yer opinion.
>
> Aryck

Precisely, and I hope I didn't give you the impression that I am flaming
you, I just wanted to clarify my point of view. I think that in the end
we agree on most of this issue.

Now I got to get back to my precious crack pipe... (just kidding!),

The Frying Dutchman







--

> maybe big drug cartels should start contributing to the republican campaign
> fund. bet we'd have a complete reversal of opinion then. hmm...

They already are, and their profits are directly linked to a continuing
"war on drugs" policy. It's a policy that ensures maximum profits for
both the lawmakers and the lawbreakers, and it's the people in the
middle that are getting shut out.  The Mafia, especially the  Cuban
Mafia have been been a strong supporter of Republicans due to their
traditional anti-castro/anti-communist stance. You see, they're still
pissed off about having all their casinos and US-run businesses
nationalized by Castro some 30 years ago... But they've been gainfully
employed in the last 20 years by importing cocaine from south/central
america, and now heroin too. Remember that the Mafia rose to power
during prohibition because they were making huge profits in
distributing and making illegal alchohol.

The other group that are big republican supporters are police, prison
guards, prison commissary, and prison construction companies. The
employees of this "sector" make up one of the most powerful
pro-republican political action committees in the US, and they have
everything to gain by ensuring that 1 in 4 black/latino males are
incarcerated for drug-related offenses (since there are no other inner
city status-job programs for black/latino youths).

And of course, it is well known that the CIA helped set up the heroin
importation business in the US in the early 70's as a means by which
they enabled various Thai/Laos/Cambodia "warlords" to amass power in a 
supposed "fight against communism" in Vietnam and the rest of Southeast
Asia. The CIA again used money from the illegal drug trade to finance
"underground" anti-communist operations happened again in the 80's -- 
the rise of cocaine abuse in the US can be directly attributed to the
CIA's use of cocaine sales to buy weapons for the contras in another
covert fight against the communists in South and Central America (since
congress wasn't about to give money to the contras -- c.f. Olliver
North and the Iran/Contra affair). George Bush, as head of the CIA, set
up Noriega's government in Panama as the main conduit for cocaine trade
in the late 70's, and this continued on until Noriega grew too insolent
and powerful with our help; so Bush had to "invade" Panama and capture
Noriega as a drug dealer in the late 80's to keep him from telling us
the real deal.

So when you hear the republicans ranting about how the US and 
Reagan/Bush were central to the downfall of communism, please consider
that this was a Pyrrhic victory at best because we now have a nation at
war with itself over Crack/Coke/Heroin as our addictions financed this
supposed downfall.

Prohibition is big business. Drug importers can make massive profits
due to the clandestine and risky nature of their business, which
requires lots of political side-taking (bribes and high-level contacts)
to ensure that their business remains unfettered, and that their
competition gets caught. Those that make the money off the bribes have
everything to gain. ANd of course, it is keeping a lot of police and
prison officals employed.  It's simply good business all around and
that's the #1 goal of the republicans. All that "christian morals" and
"family values" stuff is just a useful whitewash for what is really
going on, as the other big drug business the Republicans support is 
"christianity" -- this "opiate of the masses" allows people's
attentions to remain misdirected at false threats and evils -- enabling
all this heinous shit to happen right under everybody's noses w/o much
popular dissent. After all, our main objection to "communism" that
rallied Amerikkkans to fight it was their supposed "godlessness."

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

The ever-lovely Kaysee wrote:

>It just saddens me to see that to some people the party is a measure of 
>how good the drugs are or if they are on drugs at all. ...
>...I personally don't need substances to 
>dictate whether I have a good time or not nor whether I decide to stay or not.
>The people and the music do that for me.

BINGO!  It's the same attitude you see at a club.  Someone isn't having a 
good time, so they order another beer.  And another.  Until they're lost in 
the haze and wouldn't know if they were having a good time or just a drunken 
time.  The PEOPLE and the MUSIC do it for me.  And often, even if the music 
isn't quite there, the people make it right.  No drug is going to replace 
that.  I'm not saying I'm innocent here, but for myself, I've had just as 
good a time without as I have with.

S

     moral of the story don't take water from people with a gold tooth, or

     rave, let em go... just no fussin and fighting.  I think we all need 
     to take a deep breath and let go a little.
     
     As for the big promoted raves, if it wasn't for this list I would 
     never know about the small ones (thanks for this list BTW!), and I'd 
     be stuck going to the big ones.  I like the small ones more because 
     it's more like an intimate party and less like a concert or other 
     super size event (kinda that "I love the friends I have gathered on 
     this thin raft" feeling).
     
     I've been to great, peaceful parties thrown by people who obviously 
     run in gangs, and I've gotten my ass kicked in Venice by "mellow peace 
     loving" rastafarians.  How far is this shit going to go on before 
     somebody starts throwing all white rich kid raves?
     
     Relax, think about why you go, and decide.  If you want to split a 
     ride let me know.  If you need help, let me know.  If you're in 
     trouble and I can help, let me know.  Raving is about letting go of 
     that so and so looks like this and that bullshit.  Walk up to the next 
     person that freaks you out at a rave, and say hello and smile.  See 
     them smile back?  That's vibe.  Do it again.  Lay it down.  Spread it 
     wide.  Not a DJ, not the decorations, not the venue.  Let go of your 
     rage, there's a beautiful person inside.  
     
     Peace,
     AndyW
     the fat gangsta chick with a gold tooth and a dosed water bottle

[ to sfraves list ]

 Just being a worry-wart here : I gave/sold my two BM tickets to two
folks here on SFRaves. I made sure to give them a signed letter from
me, stating that I had transfered my registration tickets to these
two guys ,a nd if there was any problem, I could be reached at 
phone number so-and-so.

 Maybe a little overkill, but when I asked about having someone else
use my tickets , the BM rep on the phone told me that , as a minimum,
the BM gatekeepers will want the person(s) holding the tickets to know
the name of the person the tickets were purchased by. The tickets
are numbered, and mine were not in consecutive order.

 SO - if you're usingsomeone else's ticket to get into Burning Man, make 
sure you know what name they used to order the tickets! Or, you might 
have to pay $40 at the gate!

 Your alarm for the day ...

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

All drugs are bad when not done in moderation.  Also, all drugs are
different, so to group them together and say "Bad drugs! Bad!" is
like saying, "Isuzu Troopers have a tendency to roll over, therefore all
vehicles have a tendency to roll over."  Some vehicles are easier to roll
than others, but anyone can roll any car if they don't drive moderately.

     Hey...
     
     I went to Elevation in LA too (I wasn't going to blab, but now that 
     you brought it up)... holy fuck that was live.  I was the guy who 
     showed up at 4:00 am with the teddy bear stuffed in his pants truckin 
     his ass off!  We have to do more of those!!!!  ...and I question that 
     whole no E in LA comment too ;)  It was soo totally fun... We need to 
     put that sense of adventure back every chance we get!!!  Too fun 
     driving Cruchman's car through the most fucked up dirt roads I've ever 
     seen (did everybody make that wrong turn?) Driving by the forest fire, 
     with the moon stained red (erieee)..  and finally almost giving up, 
     and right as we're standing there hearing Boom boom boom whispering 
     through the canyon.  Running through the blackness to find the source. 
      It was the morning of my best friends birthday and we were together.  
     Coming to a clearing and finding these gorgeous folks dancing and 
     standing around meeting and greeting... DJ going off on trancey ass 
     house ... people looking out for each other... meeting everybody... 
     had to jet because a newbie we brought freaked out (it was a bit over 
     the top for a first rave)... too much, can't wait, my birthday is the 
     20th of september... how come there's no party ( I could throw my 
     own.. mmm?) ... I love this community.
     
     All hail VIBE!!!  It WAS off the scale.  Energy, love, and the this 
     night could go on forever feeling.  Can't frame it, can't put it up, 
     just remember...
     
     Long live the underground.... everywhere.
     
     AndyW
     
     P.S.       As for those asking about the Blitzkrieg event, the name is 
     Ron D. Core, and the crew is Dr. Freeclouds, one of the most awesome 
     promotion crews/record stores there are (even though I'm not into 
     hardcore/gabber).  I don't think he needs his ass kicked, but if you 
     agree that that was a bad name for an event, you can visit at:
     
     http://www.drfreeclouds.com
     
     I hope you weren't serious about that... there are better ways to 
     change a mind that bashing it in.  I think that's why we have a 
     problem with the term Blitzkreig in the first place.  I'm sure he'll 
     understand if you take your time to explain it.  Not everybody 
     understands how severe WWII was (most of my family lived through it in 
     Poland, where the Blitz was most deadly), and how close to home it is 
     for a lot of us.

Hey,

So not much is being mentioned about the non-burning man ravers.  I really
don't think MEGGA BUZZ is the only thang is going on.. (But I could be
wrong...) 
What else is going on during this three day Labour day weekend.  I think that
Spundae has a traditional labor day sunday biggie-type clubbish thing.  What
about this Friday'n'Saturday???

Just curious,

Adam

Interesting piece in todays SUCK on the current state of audio on the web -
thought you folks might dig it.  Also, if anyone has any 1200s they would
like to sell, please contact me privately.

thanks



White Riot 
Remember the whole concept of "noise pollution" from the '70s? 
It's not really a problem anymore, thanks to the insulation and isolation Sony 
introduced with the Walkman in 1981. Today there are extensive lines of
personal 
noise-cancellation products, which generate an equal and opposite sound wave
for every unwanted burp, fart, and squeal the modern age can hurl at you. If
you'll just slip these luxuriant headphones on, you'll be whisked away into
an Elysium of soundlessness. Nonsense, we say. Never mind the Quiet Zone
2000. Let's have some rigorous hardware handshaking. 

For some time we've been searching for a plug-in, add-on, extension, or
preference file that would allow that pure rush of information - the white
noise you hear when your modem connects - to play in the background
throughout the workday: ambient music for the info age, Muzak for the
digerati. Instead, a handful of modem manufacturers actually have the nerve
to offer silent dial-up. Actually, the coding for silence was a cinch,
easily predating the invention of the modem back in 1963. For some reason -
apparently there were more pressing concerns - it took thirty years for
manufacturers to respond to the simple question, "Does it have to make that
godawful sound?" Whatever. 

So far, the underwhelming success of online audio has been entertaining to
everyone outside the entertainment industry. Despite the hype, there was no
real reason to fear that RealAudio or TrueSpeech would compete with, say,
the Delco in the dash of your ratty Ford Fiesta. The excitement of streamed
audio quickly gave way to the same old dry hump we've grown accustomed to:
chronic downloads of .aiff, .au, .mpeg,  and .wav files. But last week, an
upstart California firm announced the imminent release of their
audio-streaming server,  in collaboration with Dolby Laboratories (the same
people who brought you the ubiquitous but not-very-useful-after-all  Dolby
Noise Reduction). Liquid Audio, they claim, will be the first real
breakthrough in quality streaming, though they tactfully avoid the one word
that would have had us shaking our leg: "stereo." 

Still, they managed to raise a few eyebrows by asserting that such a
breakthrough - when or if it ever materializes - will do wonders for the
music industry by making quality, seamless sound available on the Web. The
kicker is their claim that this 
technology will be a real comfort to musicians, labels, and publishers who
are already 
royally pissed at the quantity - never mind the quality - of unlicensed,
uncredited, and unapproved online copies of their heavily copyrighted audio. 

Whether it's noise gates, compression, and streaming, or Clipper chips,
SurfWatch, and 
Terms of Service, it's clear the online industry is concentrating on its
filters in an effort to provide some kind of guarantee on content quality.
We're here to say, "Filters be damned!"  Give us a straight shot of the real
thing. If Huxley, Leary,  Alpert, and the gang considered the unstupefied
human mind short of a trickle valve, a door of perception waiting to be
flung open, we say turn on the firehoses. 

We can only hope that cable modems will come with audio monitors that'll
reproduce the 
blast of six-figure bps in surround-sound. Who cares about sheafs of online
newspapers and new media hacks? With their reheated news clips and metamedia
punditry, who knows what they're actually gibbering about anyway? 

Like any moron raised on late-twentieth-century radio, it's not like we're
listening to the words. In fact, we can barely hear them above that annoying
ringing in our ears - is that the modem connecting or the siren call of
tinnitus? What difference does it make? It's an incurable condition either way. 

                         
                         
-----courtesy of E. L. Skinner

> For some time we've been searching for a plug-in, add-on, extension, or
> preference file that would allow that pure rush of information - the white
> noise you hear when your modem connects - to play in the background
> throughout the workday: ambient music for the info age, Muzak for the
> digerati.

I wrote something like this once. A script in Lisp that would grab all
AU format audio files from web pages that could be found on the web,
then download as many as it could in parallel and start playing as many
as it could in parallel as soon as  they were done downloading. It
would do this until you stopped it or the machine crashed, whichever
came first. In terms of load, it pretty much rendered an SGI
workstation completely inoperable -- you'd have to power cycle the
machine as it stopped noticing keyboard input after a while. Then
again, this was the same keyboard/workstation that Marc Andreesen had
spilled beer on back before he sold out. I think the machine was cursed.

Anyways, the audio was very, very noisy. It was cool to hear occasional
recognizable snippets of ren and stimpy (you eeeeediot!) flow by, mixed
in with all the other internet cacophony. It was of course completely
random, playback determined by what audio file would allow itself to be
could be found first, which backbone was fastest, and the overall load
on the internet. Since this was back in '94, of course, there wasn't 
as much crap out on the web as there is now. And the internet wasn't as
slow due to all the lame advertizing crap people are filling their lame
web pages with. After all, we all know the internet was built solely
for the purpose of playing back all the audio files you can find on it
at the same time, and not for making money or commerce.

Anyways, I let this beast run over a long lunchtime back back when "my"
company was still a startup, just to annoy the hell out of people (or
was it art, i'm not sure). I can't do stuff like that now as our new
masters would probably figure out a way to fire me for abusing the
internet...

==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

             <199608271827.LAA03016@netcom8.netcom.com>

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>

Precedence: bulk


Some people asked where you can learn about information that is
currently politically censored by the government and corporate
amerikkka. There's tons of books out there on the CIA, vietnam war, 
military industrial complex, etc. that you can find that report on
these. they may either be true, false, or embellished. I don't have any
names I can quote off the top of my head right now.

More important are the sorts of media-deconstructions that show how
you've been lied to in the press and TV news, e.g the award winning 
documentary "The Panama Deception" done by some public broadcasting
syndicate back in the early 90's. Also Noam Chomsky's "Manufacturing
Consent" which can be rented in many video stores (e.g. Tower). These
should be required viewing before submitting yourself to the televised
brainwashing of the Republican or Democratic National Conventions.

On the radio, there's a weekly program in the late  afternoon (4-5PM)
on National Public Radio syndicate hosted by Jerry Brown (88.5 FM, I
think) -- I forgot the name of the show, I think it's something like
"To the COntrary". I listen to this show occasionally and it is very
interesting. Last time I listened in there was a very good, 
eye-opening interview with Gore Vidal on the lies inherent in our
moribund two-party system, and the hopelessness of our future as
Americans unless there is a serious revolution that takes down our
current corrupt government.

On the more conspiracy-theory end of things, is Dave Emory's show on
Sunday 7PM-10PM on 89.7 KFJC. SOme of the stuff he says sounds totally
outrageous, and some of it is. I remember hearing about the
Iran/Contra/Ollie-North/CIA-drug-running stuff on this show back in the
mid-late 80's and early 90's, well before it was ever mentioned in the
mainstream press.  Everybody was dismissing this as conspiracy theorist
paranoia, and it was so out there that it sounded very outlandish to me
as well. The eye-opener happened when, a few year later (after Reagan
had come and gone, and Bush was in power), articles on the exact same
things that Dave Emory had been ranting about suddely began surfacing
in the main stream press (usually hidden deep inside the paper, rarely
on the first page). Still, you'd barely hear a squeak about it on the
TV news, other than the Ollie North hearings which totally obfuscated
what actually happened in the Iran/Contra affair into a psychodrama of
a courageous ex-marine who was proudly serving his country "right or
wrong".) People simply failed to notice how they had been manipulated
to keep supporting the corrupt Reagan presidency, as he heroically took
credit for freeing the US hostages in Iran, something that Carter had
failed to do with all his diplomacy. What people didn't want to hear
was that the CIA had done a deal with the Iranians to hold on to the
hostages until after Reagan was elected, at which point they magically
gave back the hostages, in trade for arms they needed to fight a war
with Iraq. This was financed by cocaine trade money funneled by the CIA
in order to hide that (and US covert support for the contras) from
congress. People didn't want to hear that Bush as VP and CIA director,
had set this up, and now he was president, as this proved that the
fundamental "balance of power" inherent in the design of the US govt.
had been subverted.

After all, the linkages between Iran/Contra/Reagan/Bush/CIA/drugs was
the third fundamental turning point in showing most of us that the USA
was neither constitutional or democratic. The second being Nixon's
resignation after watergate. The first loss of innocense being the
assasination of Kennedy by Republican Cuban Mafiosis who found Johnson,
and later Nixon to be much better aligned with their anti-communist
anti-castro, pro-defense, big business stance. (this is alluded to in
Oliver Stone's melodramatic portrayals of standard conspiracy theory
dogma in the movies "JFK" and "Nixon". He unfortunately did a great
disservice to the hard investigative work of all the conspiracy
journalists by making it seem so tidy and unbelievable).

Finally, for articles that aren't censored by Corporate Amerikkka,
check out the Utne Reader (which thanks to my girlfriend's subscription
I now read much more regularly) or the NorthCoast Express. Feel free to
read ONLY the "people" and "fluff" sections of USA Today, Time,
Newsweek, Wired, Business Week, Washington Post, New Yor Times,
Chronicle, etc. for information that hasn't been filtered and censored
to have the appropriate political spin of the day. But they're a joke
w/r/t  the news or unbiased opinions on public policy. THese sources
are controlled by the same powers that empower the US government
(ABC/NBC/Time-Warner/Westinghouse/General-ELectric) and they're
inherently biased to spin reality into popular consensus that
translates into political and corporate profits.

Want to do something about it?-- argue with people spouting crap like
"Reagan/Bush was a true american hero", "the republicans are
responsible for maintaining the moral and economic interests of this
nation." At the same time, realize that Bill Clinton ain't all that
either. He's really no better than the republicans and is available for
sale to the highest bidder.

Me? I'm voting for Ralph Nader and the Green Party. He's the only
person who in the last 30 years has been consistently pro-people, a
staunch advocate of consumer's rights and social responsibility.
Meanwhile,  both the Democrats and the Republicans have been
consistently pro corporate-america, anti-environment, anti-people --
their only concern is ensuring an unimpeded free-flow of dollars into
corporate and political coffers. The rest of their messages about "the
dream of america" is just a bunch of crap they use to con and dupe
people into voting for them.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Aug 27 16:22:09 1996

Niels Wrote:
> Some people asked where you can learn about information that is
> currently politically censored by the government and corporate
> amerikkka. There's tons of books out there on the CIA, vietnam war, 
> military industrial complex, etc. that you can find that report on
> these. they may either be true, false, or embellished. I don't have any
> names I can quote off the top of my head right now.

A good book i've just read is
   _Ruses for War: American Interventionalism Since World War II_
which is a moderate, broadly-researched book on wars. And how the CIA
misleads the president and the media about them, the president misleads
congress about them, and the media misleads the public about them. Very
scary stuff, and highly recommended. I can dig up more details (like
the author's name :) if anyone's interested.

Jeremy

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Aug 27 16:32:37 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id QAA03505; Tue, 27 Aug 1996 16:32:37 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from mom.hooked.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with ESMTP id QAA03498; Tue, 27 Aug 1996 16:32:32 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from fish.hooked.net (moonpup@fish.hooked.net [206.80.6.48]) by mom.hooked.net (8.7.4/8.7.3) with ESMTP id QAA26188 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 27 Aug 1996 16:35:38 -0700 (PDT)
From: Milton Cecil <moonpup@hooked.net>
Received: (from moonpup@localhost) by fish.hooked.net (8.7.3/8.7.3) id QAA08686; Tue, 27 Aug 1996 16:38:41 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Tue, 27 Aug 1996 16:38:41 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <199608272338.QAA08686@fish.hooked.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: grass is always greener.....(unlike the british skunk)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

In light of the tone of the previous E-mail I sent, I will now communicate
on a more positive note..........London was the shit........awsome vibe,
many sound sytems, many different directions of music to choose from, and
many many cool people.... 
 
I have to say in 4 months I heard no-one (not one single person) dis anyone
elses party, or analyze (or is that anal-ize) what the scene should, could,
or would be......if only etc........nor discuss incessently the pro's and
con's of drugs vs. no drugs, musical styles vs. musical styles, or whatever
other dribble I see written from time to time (all too ofton) here on SFR.
(sorry, I guess thats a flame....huh) 
 
It was a whole new experience, one I'm sure I will miss......I reckon I can
only speak for my-self, when I say we have a lot to learn in the Bay Area
about co-operation harmony, and  imagination. 
 
It seems that we (including me at times).......love to TALK & BITCH about
whats wrong, and what we ought to do to change the direction etc..... I
only hope that some of you could see what harmony there is amongst the many
different rigs (sound systems) and how well the community works together to
overcome the current legal status (new laws pertaining to raves and
clubbers in general).......all I can say is.....I was inspired by the
attitude of the average party go'er (no not party goa).  
 
I saw and heard of the most insane concepts, very inventive and at the same
time sticking it to the police and government........for instance..... 
 
there was a huge party north of London, and every-one had to go in cars up
the motorway (freeway) to get there. Now the police got word of the party,
and set up a road block to stop the people from attending, and it created a
traffic jam that went for miles...... 
 
......so while they were stuck on the freeway, they dug up a portion of the
road and planted a couple of trees in the middle of the
highway.........awsome stuff...... 
 
they also have major street parties called "reclaim the streets" where they
meet in force and create many clever diversionary tacticts, and before you
know it they have overtaken a neighborhood and have a massive party before
the police know what hit em.............. and by then it's to late for the
bill (thats english for fuzz) to react or stop it.........If they tried,
they know the people will probably riot.........or so they think!!! 
 
It's these kinds of idea's that are inspirational to me, and I find the
British scene to be more mature, more inventive, more creative, and more
established.........we could learn from our distant older cousins.........(
I swear that is not a dis of our Bay Area....... just an insight of
Britain's scene) 
 
It's now no suprise to me that the theory that you have to be a british DJ
to be succesful, means something more than just a theory........they
brought with them a vibe we lacked here in 1990, and without their
influence, DJ's like me would'nt have been inspired and been as successful
as I have. (and it has grown to include many other U.S  DJ's in the mix
now)...........Those British DJ's who have had success here, did so because
of  an understanding of a vibe and attitude that was learned in the U.K in
the late 80's and early 90"s and they brought it here, it is because they
came from an environment where creativity, the musical environment, a
childlike imagination, and the state of the nation's economy gave rise to a
nation of house groovers and shakers. 
 
An additional factor that helps the British scene thrive, is that most
party goers are broke, and unlike America where I feel alot of woman looks
at you as a comodity (security, job, house, car  etc...) everyone just
faces the fact there all broke and gets on with it.......if you meet
someone, you fall in love, you live together, and you deal with the issues
of life together.  Money is not as big an issue, as it seems to be here.
It's about a persons vibe, and when an entire nation (generally speaking)
has that attitude, it helps to create a scene that will thrive for many
years to come. 
 
Some other basic differences are the volume of drugs and alchahol that are
consumed. here, I find that at a night club you will have about a 50-75% of
people drinking. where as in the U.K 98% are drinkers. In an underground
environment here, you will find very few alchahol drinkers, as they tend to
do drugs, (most commonly an E instead of drinking.), where as at an
underground in the U.K, people are poppin E's like there goin out of style,
in addition to drinking up a storm........it's completely mental. 
 
One of the elements I have to say we have the upper hand on, is the
consumption of cigarettes. In the U.K it's 99%, but here only about 40%. I
attribute that to healthier attitudes here, as well as the attitude that in
the U.K, the future is bleak, so have another drink, smoke a fag
(cigarette), pop another "pill" and roll another spliff. 
 
One of the most glaring differences, is the "Festival" attitude. While we
have Burning Man and an occaisional other Festy, Britain is innundated with
massive Festivals all summer long.......I went to a festival in Normandy,
France, and about 5,000 people showed up, and it was considered a failure,
where-as here a festival of 5,000 would be a good turnout. 
It is not un-common to get 35,000 people at a festy in the U.K, I have
heard estimates that next years Glastonberry festival will draw upwards of
300,000 people (no thats not a typo). 
 
All in all, I have been to good parties here and good parties there, I have
attended crap parties here, and crap parties there........I've heard good
and bad music both here and there, it's all really rather personal (based
on your own musical tastes). I'm not even sure I can explain why I feel the
U.K has it goin on, I think it's just a matter of fact, that the U.K. party
scene has had longer to devope and mature, and the average age of the club
goer in the U.K reaches into the late 20's and mid 30's (and the rest),
whereas here I run into lots of people in their teens and early 20's. 
Certainly being 37, I feel that I have more in common with an older crowd,
as the conversation gets deeper.  We here should talk about more than
drugs, music, clubs, & sex, and leave the debating to the polititions.  
 
well I'll have more to say on further postings, until then, I gotta get
some sleep.............. ...........something I need in the U.K or here in
California, it seems that wher-ever you go, some things remain the same. 
                                                                           
        MOONPUP.....wish you were here... 
 
 
 
 
 
 

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Aug 27 16:36:27 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id QAA03755; Tue, 27 Aug 1996 16:36:27 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with ESMTP id QAA03741; Tue, 27 Aug 1996 16:36:22 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from uclink2.berkeley.edu (uclink2.berkeley.edu [128.32.136.72]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.5/8.6.12) with ESMTP id QAA01590; Tue, 27 Aug 1996 16:36:20 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from localhost (sidewalk@localhost) by uclink2.berkeley.edu (8.7.5/8.6.12) with SMTP id QAA02078; Tue, 27 Aug 1996 16:31:14 -0700
Date: Tue, 27 Aug 1996 16:31:14 -0700 (PDT)
From: Timothy McIntyre <sidewalk@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
Reply-To: Timothy McIntyre <sidewalk@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
To: John Kawamoto <jkawamoto@excite.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Burning Man and Excite BSP?
In-Reply-To: <32232F7E.37B9@excite.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.ULT.3.93.960827121521.10369A-100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



Well, just remember that Burning Man is not a rave: that seems to be
a pretty big misconception floating around, and a lot of people are 
applying rave ideals (i.e., no corporatism, keep it underground) to the
Burning Man festival.  Indeed, there will be a rave camp, where I would
bet that logo-splashed water bottles might not be so welcome, but water
giveaway is certainly a nice thought.
	Burning Man, according to a quote from its original
founder, has quite a lot to do with two simple things: temporary
community, and all the issues that that concept raises, and dada-ism,
which is the artistic movement centered around all things absurd.  

  Interestingly, dada-ism is a pretty big tent, since nearly anything can 
be justified as absurd.  (i.e., "what do you mean you don't want our water 
bottles here?  they're just being distributed as an artistic statement!")
So in a way, it's hard to say that anything doesn't belong at burning man,
given the fact that the festival is held beneath a dada-ist umbrella.
It's supposed to be silly and nonsensical; and subverting commercialism
is almost always a humorous thing.  For example, the rock band U2's last
tour dealt with nonsensical themes, like subverting corporatism and 
exploring its ironies.  I'll bet that there will be a lot of that at
Burning Man this year, given the fact that they're expecting 10,000
people supposedly.  Anyways, my point is to just remember that BMan will
be weird and wonderful, and I hope that it stays inclusionary.
Sorry to ramble like that, by the way! 

see y'all in Black Rock City,
Timothy





_______________________
Welcome to UCLink2
UC Berkeley's Electronic Information Exchange


connected to uclink2.Berkeley.EDU


Welcome to UCLink2 
UC Berkeley's Electronic Information Exchange




On Tue, 27 Aug 1996, John Kawamoto wrote:

> Hi All,
> 
> I was at my companies, Excite - the search engine, all hands meeting
> on Monday when a product manager anounced that he was looking for
> some employee volunteers to possibly go to Burning Man with a company
> rented truck filled with water bottles to hand out for free at BM
> as a promotion. Of course the bottles will have our logo/url on them
> but he said there will be no large advertising banners and whoever
> wants the water will have to go to our truck to pick it up...it will
> not be handed out like flyers. Concerned, I told him that this could
> possibly backfire since a positive vibe is something which cannot be
> bought, sold, or commercialized. We all know that what makes real
> underground parties so special is that positive vibe and what creates
> it is UNCONDITIONAL LOVE freely given without concern for ego
> gratification or identification.
> 
> My purpose in this post is not to start a flame war but to ask for
> your valued opinions on our product manager's idea (good or bad) ?
> Personally, I don't think it would be a good idea for the reasons
> stated above.
> 
> Thank you all for your input and I'll gladly forward your constructive
> criticism to our product manager!!
> 
> Peace and UNCONDITIONAL LOVE always,
> John
>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Aug 27 16:51:10 1996

and no other co-op parties, which means that the Cal rager of the week-end
