From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Aug 27 17:45:50 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id RAA10466; Tue, 27 Aug 1996 17:45:50 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from mom.hooked.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with ESMTP id RAA10454; Tue, 27 Aug 1996 17:45:47 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from fish.hooked.net (moonpup@fish.hooked.net [206.80.6.48]) by mom.hooked.net (8.7.4/8.7.3) with ESMTP id RAA10139 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 27 Aug 1996 17:48:52 -0700 (PDT)
From: Milton Cecil <moonpup@hooked.net>
Received: (from moonpup@localhost) by fish.hooked.net (8.7.3/8.7.3) id RAA11650; Tue, 27 Aug 1996 17:51:56 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Tue, 27 Aug 1996 17:51:56 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <199608280051.RAA11650@fish.hooked.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: grass is always greener.....(unlike the british skunk)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

In light of the tone of the previous E-mail I sent, I will now communicate
on a more positive note..........London was the shit........awsome vibe,
many sound sytems, many different directions of music to choose from, and
many many cool people.... 
 
I have to say in 4 months I heard no-one (not one single person) dis anyone
elses party, or analyze (or is that anal-ize) what the scene should, could,
or would be......if only etc........nor discuss incessently the pro's and
con's of drugs vs. no drugs, musical styles vs. musical styles, or whatever
other dribble I see written from time to time (all too ofton) here on SFR.
(sorry, I guess thats a flame....huh) 
 
It was a whole new experience, one I'm sure I will miss......I reckon I can
only speak for my-self, when I say we have a lot to learn in the Bay Area
about co-operation harmony, and  imagination. 
 
It seems that we (including me at times).......love to TALK & BITCH about
whats wrong, and what we ought to do to change the direction etc..... I
only hope that some of you could see what harmony there is amongst the many
different rigs (sound systems) and how well the community works together to
overcome the current legal status (new laws pertaining to raves and
clubbers in general).......all I can say is.....I was inspired by the
attitude of the average party go'er (no not party goa).  
 
I saw and heard of the most insane concepts, very inventive and at the same
time sticking it to the police and government........for instance..... 
 
there was a huge party north of London, and every-one had to go in cars up
the motorway (freeway) to get there. Now the police got word of the party,
and set up a road block to stop the people from attending, and it created a
traffic jam that went for miles...... 
 
......so while they were stuck on the freeway, they dug up a portion of the
road and planted a couple of trees in the middle of the
highway.........awsome stuff...... 
 
they also have major street parties called "reclaim the streets" where they
meet in force and create many clever diversionary tacticts, and before you
know it they have overtaken a neighborhood and have a massive party before
the police know what hit em.............. and by then it's to late for the
bill (thats english for fuzz) to react or stop it.........If they tried,
they know the people will probably riot.........or so they think!!! 
 
It's these kinds of idea's that are inspirational to me, and I find the
British scene to be more mature, more inventive, more creative, and more
established.........we could learn from our distant older cousins.........(
I swear that is not a dis of our Bay Area....... just an insight of
Britain's scene) 
 
It's now no suprise to me that the theory that you have to be a british DJ
to be succesful, means something more than just a theory........they
brought with them a vibe we lacked here in 1990, and without their
influence, DJ's like me would'nt have been inspired and been as successful
as I have. (and it has grown to include many other U.S  DJ's in the mix
now)...........Those British DJ's who have had success here, did so because
of  an understanding of a vibe and attitude that was learned in the U.K in
the late 80's and early 90"s and they brought it here, it is because they
came from an environment where creativity, the musical environment, a
childlike imagination, and the state of the nation's economy gave rise to a
nation of house groovers and shakers. 
 
An additional factor that helps the British scene thrive, is that most
party goers are broke, and unlike America where I feel alot of woman looks
at you as a comodity (security, job, house, car  etc...) everyone just
faces the fact there all broke and gets on with it.......if you meet
someone, you fall in love, you live together, and you deal with the issues
of life together.  Money is not as big an issue, as it seems to be here.
It's about a persons vibe, and when an entire nation (generally speaking)
has that attitude, it helps to create a scene that will thrive for many
years to come. 
 
Some other basic differences are the volume of drugs and alchahol that are
consumed. here, I find that at a night club you will have about a 50-75% of
people drinking. where as in the U.K 98% are drinkers. In an underground
environment here, you will find very few alchahol drinkers, as they tend to
do drugs, (most commonly an E instead of drinking.), where as at an
underground in the U.K, people are poppin E's like there goin out of style,
in addition to drinking up a storm........it's completely mental. 
 
One of the elements I have to say we have the upper hand on, is the
consumption of cigarettes. In the U.K it's 99%, but here only about 40%. I
attribute that to healthier attitudes here, as well as the attitude that in
the U.K, the future is bleak, so have another drink, smoke a fag
(cigarette), pop another "pill" and roll another spliff. 
 
One of the most glaring differences, is the "Festival" attitude. While we
have Burning Man and an occaisional other Festy, Britain is innundated with
massive Festivals all summer long.......I went to a festival in Normandy,
France, and about 5,000 people showed up, and it was considered a failure,
where-as here a festival of 5,000 would be a good turnout. 
It is not un-common to get 35,000 people at a festy in the U.K, I have
heard estimates that next years Glastonberry festival will draw upwards of
300,000 people (no thats not a typo). 
 
All in all, I have been to good parties here and good parties there, I have
attended crap parties here, and crap parties there........I've heard good
and bad music both here and there, it's all really rather personal (based
on your own musical tastes). I'm not even sure I can explain why I feel the
U.K has it goin on, I think it's just a matter of fact, that the U.K. party
scene has had longer to devope and mature, and the average age of the club
goer in the U.K reaches into the late 20's and mid 30's (and the rest),
whereas here I run into lots of people in their teens and early 20's. 
Certainly being 37, I feel that I have more in common with an older crowd,
as the conversation gets deeper.  We here should talk about more than
drugs, music, clubs, & sex, and leave the debating to the polititions.  
 
well I'll have more to say on further postings, until then, I gotta get
some sleep.............. ...........something I need in the U.K or here in
California, it seems that wher-ever you go, some things remain the same. 
                                                                           
        MOONPUP.....wish you were here...

>> I think Niels hit the nail on the head with his remarks about drugs  ie:  E.
>> Drugs are NOT glamorous and they are very dangerous and have caused a >>great
>> deal of harm.
>Perhaps even more dangerous are generalizations.

yes. it is the _abuse_ of drugs that is problematic.
i would argue with anyone who said that "drugs are dangerous, period" - as
someone who might not be alive today if it hadn't been for a certain
perscription drug. and yes, it is a drug, even though it comes over the
counter - legality of a substance has no relation to it's safety. there are
many legal drugs that are dangerous, there are many illegal drugs that are
not, and the reverse.
leading to..

>Agreed, it's always good to think about what exactly it is you're doing.
know what you are doing, so you can do it responsibly with regards to your
health; mentally, physically, and spiritually.
-brendan-

Hello,

On Tue, 27 Aug 96 15:44:07 -0700, "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
wrote:
>Me? I'm voting for Ralph Nader and the Green Party. He's the only
>person who in the last 30 years has been consistently pro-people, a
>staunch advocate of consumer's rights and social responsibility.

Well, I respect this latest posting a lot more than the "the sky is
falling because of the Republicans" posts from a year or so ago.

However, if one were to vote for a small party simply because of their
stand on the issues, it seems pretty clear that the Libertarian Party
most closely represents the viewpoints and interests of ravers.

Whereas consumerism and social responsibility are laudable goals, the
methods of the Naderites have always been LAWS.

LAW means:

1 - Someone decides what is right and what is wrong.
2 - The police put you in jail if that "someone" doesn't like what you
are doing.

This seems to me to describe the history of raves pretty well.

No, I am certainly not proposing an*rchy, however, I do feel that, to
quote Thomas Jefferson "That government governs best that governs
least".

The Libertarian Party believes this, in fact, their platform includes
legalising every action that doesn't have a victim.

Beyond that, their principle is to only allow the least government
necessary to provide an orderly society, which then provides the most
freedom.

PS   To me, the only politician who has any personal integrity is
Jerry Brown (unfortunately, I don't always agree with him).

PPS  If one views Werner Herzog's documentary of the Iraqi occupation
of Kuwait, called "Lessons of Darkness", or the British documentary
about the Iraqi military occupation of the Marsh People in southern
Iraqi, both of which were environmental disasters; one gets the
impression that the only problem with arming Iran against Iraq was
that they didn't arm Iran enough.


Be seeing you,

Ken                           <*>
kstuart@mail.telis.org

I have held my toungue on Burning Man.  I did post a story, which I had
hoped would relevate an epiphany with some.  Clearly, it did not.  While
many unsuspecting individuals are clamoring to go to their first BM, excited
by the aspect of a large rave, I feel they know or understand little about
what Burning Man is really all about.  It is not a rave, but rather a
celebration of death.  It is purely negative.  It disgusts me.  Do those who
are so excited about going not realize what BM is REALLY about??!!??  

I have read many of outraged posts about partys sporting insulting names
like BlitzKrieg.  But I wonder, why does no one seem insulted by the THEME
of Burning Man?  I, for one, am insulted.  Sicked, actually, that our
society celebrates the supposed death of Love/Life/Spirit and galvanizes
together only to rally support for forces which seek only to destroy Life.
BM is not about renewal.  It is not about Love.  Burning Man is about fear,
confusion and death.  It is about being lulled to sleep and living in hate
and pain and isolation.  It is about NOT learning from mistakes made in the
past, nor is it about trying to reconcile any opportunity for rebirth.

This, my family, is my opinion.  I'm not scared to tell you all how I feel.
Burning Man is a blatant astrocity, it is something for which I will offer
no hope.  Those who attend are blinding themselves.  This is their choice.
Thank you for allowing me to express myself here, even though some of you
might not understand from where it is I come from.  
  

Love in LIFE!

Troy J.

> someone who might not be alive today if it hadn't been for a certain
> perscription drug. and yes, it is a drug, even though it comes over the
> counter - legality of a substance has no relation to it's safety. there are
> many legal drugs that are dangerous, there are many illegal drugs that are
> not, and the reverse.

dangerous.  Moderation is maturity.  Pavlovian reactions like 
automatically saying, "Ooh, drugs, bad... Baaaahhhd" is bleating like a 
sheep in the herd, well versed on the latest media propaganda.  "Just say 
no."

Benjamin

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Aug 27 21:56:01 1996

             <3225b8b2.551370134@mail.campus.mci.net> 
Date: Tue, 27 Aug 96 21:55:46 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>

Precedence: bulk


> Well, I respect this latest posting a lot more than the "the sky is
> falling because of the Republicans" posts from a year or so ago.

I really haven't changed that much. I think the difference is that the
sky has fallen, and people are beginning to give the republican
congress the respect it deserves, i.e. the same as you'd give to a used
car salesman. I do blame republicans for a lot of evils, but democrats
are just as guilty. THe two party system is not democratic, does not
represent the will of the people.

> However, if one were to vote for a small party simply because of their
> stand on the issues, it seems pretty clear that the Libertarian Party
> most closely represents the viewpoints and interests of ravers.

I don't think so. At least personally, I see the libertarians and
republicans as greed-based ideologies.

I disagree with the libertarian party, as I do feel we need laws to 
limit people's inherent greediness and power-seeking tendencies. I
might prefer to see people organize in smaller autonomous groups that
could decide on what laws they want to impose, with free movement
between groups, etc. At the same time, if a group decides they want to
pollute another group's river, or enslave certain members of their
society, or prevent the free flow of people/goods/information across
group borders, then clearly a larger structure needs to impose itself
to ensure the good of the whole.

This doesn't mean that we need to maintain the current national versus
state governments, but since it's what we got, it's best to go with
that. (revolutions tend to "throw the baby out with the bathwater"
and typically result in more suffering than the status quo).

The best way to succeed, IMHO, is to have laws which don't take morals
or religion into account, as these are variable and can't be dictated.
What doesn't vary is people's relation with each other,  and our place
on this earth. To this end, I think we need laws that always ensure we
put nature above man, people above profit. Libertarians believe that
people have a inaliable right to profit, while ignoring the zero sum
nature of profit (profit only comes at someone's expense). I believe
that greed/profit is one of the most evil things on earth and needs to
be opposed with extreme force. People do not have a right to make
money, businesses do not have an inalienable right to exist or do
business. The ability to make money is a privilege, and not a right.
This privilege should be taken away from you if your profit motives
comes at the expense of workers, customers, people, nature, etc.
Basically, we value money in this country far too much -- it's the only
thing that actually matters and this is why our society is falling
apart. We need to change this sick attitude if we want to survive and
pass on a  healthy and happy world onto our children.

I am also opposed to "progress" as an end in itself. This seems to be 
something that libertartians are obsessed with unfettering progress. I
think we are progressing far too fast, far too fast for us to
understand what our progress is doing to us, too fast to introspect on
whether we need all the blessings of consumer society. A biological
organism that suffers from extreme and unchecked progress is called
cancerous. We are building a cancerous, self-destroying, self-consuming
society by focussing on progress, profit, and change as an end in
itself. THey should be a means to and end, and that end is global
survival of all people, all plants, all animals in harmony.

That's what I believe. Your mileage may vary.

> PS   To me, the only politician who has any personal integrity is
> Jerry Brown (unfortunately, I don't always agree with him).

I agree with you on this. THat's why I like his show on NPR as well.
He's a pretty "green" libertarian. Some would just say he's a liberal.

>Iraqi, both of which were environmental disasters; one gets the
>impression that the only problem with arming Iran against Iraq was
>that they didn't arm Iran enough.

There's a much deeper history here. You see, the USA originally
supported the despotic government in Iran, namely the Shah of Iran, who
we've been arming and helping stay in power since the 50's via a police
state that we're 100% responsible for setting up. The  muslim
fundamentalist overthrow of the Shah happened as a popular reaction to
the USA's support of a very ruthless, unpopular government in Iran. So
then we (or rather, the CIA) started giving Saddam Hussein lots of
armaments and financial support so that he could build up his own
dictatorial police state in the hopes that he would lead the fight
against our new enemies, the popular Iranian/Muslim fundamentalist
government. But then Saddam Hussein got a little too powerful and
started thinking on his own, using the army/navy/air-force we helped
set up, train, fund, etc to intervene in the region. The invasion of
Kuwait was a simple pretext by which we could reign in "our man" who
had become a force unto himself... thus our "blitzkrieg" against
Iraq. I can't blame Saddam, because we made him who he is. 
It's really the same exact story that played out in Panama with Noriega.
We made Noriega who he is, and then we shut him down when he
stopped following our orders. 

The moral of this story is that the USA should not intervene in the
affairs of other governments. Most every country in the world hates the
USA for the henous shit we've been perpetrating after world war II. If
you travel outside the US, you'll begin to get an idea of how horrible
we actually are -- no better, in many ways, than the Nazi's.

==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==

first of all, it is obvious you have never been to a burning man
celebration. 
 
second of all, where did you get so bitter? 
 
third of all are you a catholic or a born again christian?

most exciting and enjoyable experiences of my life. 
 
further more, many a rave could learn a lot from the harmony, creativity,
spirituality, and overall organization, of the BM 
 
and last but not least get the fuck off your pedistal and enjoy life while
you are still alive and healthy, your post is one of the most negative I
have ever had the misfortune to read. I find your opinions of drugs and the
BM to be both offensive and narrow. 
 
I reckon you have been watching too much television.........get out and
live life, and allow us the freedom to enjoy what it is we do to enjoy
life, after all 10,000 people can't be wrong........and besides when did
you ever go and witness the joy of BM. 
 
It's obvious from your previous post about the harms of drugs that you know
very little about life and it's mysteries..........or about our family that
you pretend to say you are a part of............this family that you
condemn is even more special to me than my real family, because I CHOOSE to
make them family, not because I was born into it....trust me you are no
family member.......you have to share and experience and relate to this
family, something I'm afraid you'll never understand. 
 
GET A LIFE and leave us in peace to make our own individual desicions. 
 
I think you are on the wrong internet service, I think you meant to e-mail
the popes address, he may agree with you........try the repuplican e-mail
address, youll find your family  there somewhere!!!!!!!!

On Tue, 27 Aug 1996, Wowser wrote:

> I think Niels hit the nail on the head with his remarks about drugs  ie:  E.
> Drugs are NOT glamorous and they are very dangerous and have caused a great
> deal of harm.  His knowledge of E seems right on and I hope those of you out
> there who mindlessly pop pills into your mouths that some stranger sold you
> at a rave will listen to a few words of wisdom from those who are obviously
> concerned about not only your well-being, but all of ours.

Illicit substances(which is what I believe you are referring to) are 
tools. Use these tools without thought, consideration, and respect, and 
they can harm you. Use them with a little intelligence, and they can open 
the world.

Making blanket statements about a given subject is easy to do, and 
likewise seldom correct.


                                           Black Adder

Do you? Apparently not given your obvious lack of understanding. You make

religions that do not appreciate the *FULL* cycle of life, which includes 
the concept of death. Because *you* fear it, does not make it inherently 
"bad."

> like BlitzKrieg.  But I wonder, why does no one seem insulted by the THEME
> of Burning Man?  I, for one, am insulted.  Sicked, actually, that our

Good. I think that is the whole point(hey BM people, you sickened a 
dogmatist, CONGRATS!)

> together only to rally support for forces which seek only to destroy Life.

> confusion and death.  It is about being lulled to sleep and living in hate
> and pain and isolation.  It is about NOT learning from mistakes made in the

You must have a lot of past experience with BM to make such a

> This, my family, is my opinion.  I'm not scared to tell you all how I feel.

Good. And I am not scared to tell you what an assinine, and ill-informed 
judgement you make on a subject you know little or nothing about.

> Burning Man is a blatant astrocity, it is something for which I will offer
> no hope.  Those who attend are blinding themselves.  This is their choice.
> Thank you for allowing me to express myself here, even though some of you
> might not understand from where it is I come from.  

I think some of us understand all too well where you are coming from, 
thus the harsh responses you are receiving.

> Love in LIFE!

Life is a cycle...learn the *complete* cycle....respect it...cherish it......

                                        Black Adder

On Tue, 27 Aug 1996, Timothy McIntyre wrote:

> 
> 
> Well, just remember that Burning Man is not a rave: that seems to be
> a pretty big misconception floating around, and a lot of people are 
> applying rave ideals (i.e., no corporatism, keep it underground) to the
> Burning Man festival.  Indeed, there will be a rave camp, where I would
> bet that logo-splashed water bottles might not be so welcome, but water
> giveaway is certainly a nice thought.

I will think that if you do just a bit of research, that you will find 
similar opinions regarding commercialism among the earlier attendees.


> 	Burning Man, according to a quote from its original
> founder, has quite a lot to do with two simple things: temporary
> community, and all the issues that that concept raises, and dada-ism,
> which is the artistic movement centered around all things absurd.  
> 
>   Interestingly, dada-ism is a pretty big tent, since nearly anything can 
> be justified as absurd.  (i.e., "what do you mean you don't want our water 
> bottles here?  they're just being distributed as an artistic statement!")

So, how long before the Coors ads? Oh, they were being distributed as an 
artistic statement.....

> So in a way, it's hard to say that anything doesn't belong at burning man,
> given the fact that the festival is held beneath a dada-ist umbrella.
> It's supposed to be silly and nonsensical; and subverting commercialism
> is almost always a humorous thing.  For example, the rock band U2's last
> tour dealt with nonsensical themes, like subverting corporatism and 
> exploring its ironies.  I'll bet that there will be a lot of that at

Hmm U2.... didn't they sue Negativeland for poking fun at them? Poor 
example, choose another....

>example, choose another....

actually, U2's record label sued negativland. from what i read in an
interview with the edge, he thought it was a pretty cool thing negativland
was doing. and i believe the record label has reversed it's decision, and is
allowing negativland to distribute the single. the only problem is now with
casey casem (sp?) who threatens to sue their ass off should they market it.
(incidently, it's a fairly long clip with casey swearing, saying about U2:
"these guys are english and who gives a shit" - or something similar - , etc..)

incidently the single "the letter U and the number 2" is available online, at 
http://sunsite.unc.edu/id/negativland/samples.htm
in .au, mpeg-2, and real-audio! =)
-brendan-

Karen Hardie <pounce@vcn.bc.ca> wrote:
>If you haven't heard it find it RIGHT AWAY!  it's utterly priceless.  :)

Anyone interested can email phin@west.darkside.com for Phineas Narco's
online tape catalog.  He has tapes of the U2 recordings (the original CD,
with the classic "Special Edit" radio mix plus a half dozen other
variations), a lot of mostly unpublished Negativland/Over the Edge stuff,
other improv radio stuff, and lots more in similar vein.  If you feel like
sending away for U2, I highly recommend Over the Edge "The Experience" as
well.  It's a 3-hour live-mixed audiocollage based around a Jimi Hendrix
documentary produced a few years ago.

anarch@scruznet.com

hi all!

have a great time at BM!!!

i'm going to a job interveiw at stanford friday.  please wish me luck!
it's a hella cool job, working for a hella cool scientist.  someone i've
admired for years.  i feel so lucky to have a chance to spend a day in his
lab.

alas, i cannot go to BM.  i have to admit, i was a bit put off when
someone told me that the theme of BM was hell.  but i have since learned
that this isn't quite true.

the origins of BM.. celebration of the end of a bad love affair...seems a
bit negative, i suppose.  but i think that all ends are liberating,
because they mean that you can now make a fresh start.  

i read the tarot cards, and whenver the card of death comes up, i tell
people that it means the END of something and that it signals the
BEGINNING of something else.  so burning down a wooden man is a positive
thing, in my mind.  and remember...the man will be rebuilt to be burned
down again next year!  (i hope)  so even the one who is utterly destroyed
is renewed.  

it's like love.  you end a love affair, but you try again with someone
new, usually.  life is about trying, failing sometimes, and then trying
again.

so everyone have a fabulous time!!!!

love,

Ann

Wayne, that's a low blow. I don't think I agree with Wowser's reasons
for agreeing with me in a different post, even though he did agree with
me. Actually, I might partially agree with him on moral grounds if it
weren't for an inherent christian slant that seems to pervade his
posts. Christianity really gets my goat... errr... I mean it perks
my horns.... errrr... I mean it makes me see red..... ummm... I mean
it makes smoke come out of my ears... Hmmm...

Besides, I wouldn't be caught dead saying "love in life."

W/r/t wowser's post -- why is it when some great christian
pre-renaissance artists depicts a gory portrayal of the sufferings of
hell, it's "ok", but when you have a theme like "a year in hell" it's
not? Perhaps you have to go to hell to understand heaven?? Or at least
choose which side you're on? Shouldn't people have freedom of choice in
this matter? Besides, if there's less people in heaven, then you can
drink more champagne, eat more caviar, and have more angels all to
yourself bending over and showing you their cute little cherub cheeks.

Also, there's lots of celebrations worldwide that are 100% death
related, e.g. Mexican "Day of the Dead" celebrations which have been
folded rather neatly into Christianity, even though they speak back to
Aztec/Indian roots. Do you also have a problem with such celebrations?

On Tue, 27 Aug 1996 blkadder@value.net wrote:

> On Tue, 27 Aug 1996, Timothy McIntyre wrote:
> 
> > 
> > 
> > Well, just remember that Burning Man is not a rave: that seems to be
> > a pretty big misconception floating around, and a lot of people are 
> > applying rave ideals (i.e., no corporatism, keep it underground) to the
> > Burning Man festival.  Indeed, there will be a rave camp, where I would
> > bet that logo-splashed water bottles might not be so welcome, but water
> > giveaway is certainly a nice thought.
> 
> I will think that if you do just a bit of research, that you will find 
> similar opinions regarding commercialism among the earlier attendees.

  Well I'm not really condoning the commercialism here... I was just sort
  of trying to check out what happens when you look at commercialism 
  under the light of dada-ism.  Personally, I'd rather not look at 
  corporate logos over Labor Day weekend, but my point is that if one is
  invoked *cleverly*, then it would be difficult for me to justify 
  scoffing at it, given the fact that dada-ism (and the BM founder is
  clearly a dada-ist) gave such a big push to this event.

> 
> 
> > 	Burning Man, according to a quote from its original
> > founder, has quite a lot to do with two simple things: temporary
> > community, and all the issues that that concept raises, and dada-ism,
> > which is the artistic movement centered around all things absurd.  
> > 
> >   Interestingly, dada-ism is a pretty big tent, since nearly anything can 
> > be justified as absurd.  (i.e., "what do you mean you don't want our water 
> > bottles here?  they're just being distributed as an artistic statement!")
> 
> So, how long before the Coors ads? Oh, they were being distributed as an 
> artistic statement.....

	No no no--the 'artistic statement' bit has to be taken literally 
  and not sarcastically here: sure, if the 'artistic statement' line of
  defense is merely an *excuse* for some company to make its presence
  felt, then that's lame.  But if it is done intelligently and for
  genuinely artistic or declaratory purpose, well, then who am I to
  comment?  But you're right--Satan forbid a big Coors billboard! :)
  (the official BM theme this year is Dante's _Inferno_)


> 
> > So in a way, it's hard to say that anything doesn't belong at burning man,
> > given the fact that the festival is held beneath a dada-ist umbrella.
> > It's supposed to be silly and nonsensical; and subverting commercialism
> > is almost always a humorous thing.  For example, the rock band U2's last
> > tour dealt with nonsensical themes, like subverting corporatism and 
> > exploring its ironies.  I'll bet that there will be a lot of that at
> 
> Hmm U2.... didn't they sue Negativeland for poking fun at them? Poor 
> example, choose another....
>
>
>     						


    Ooooo....nice. I forgot about that.  Oops!  (although that oversight 
  doesn't really invalidate the example.)  Staying with pop music, though,
  another example would be Rolling Stone magazine's decision to run a
  cover photo of Nirvana, with the singer wearing a "Corporate Magazines
  Still Suck" T-Shirt.  [Kurt Cobain had been told not to wear any clothes
  with words on them to the photo shoot, so he showed up wearing the
  T-shirt. The photographer was panicked, fearing that that his editors 
  would be furious with him for not being able to get a good cover shot,
  but the editors got such a kick out of it they cropped the picture to
  emphasize the message, and ran it on their cover.]
  Anyway, I basically meant to say that commercialism at Burning Man is
  far more complicated an issue than commercialism at a massive rave,
  given the weird ideas behind the Burning Man concept.

  pedantically yours,

  Timothy

From: ecto@souliton.com (brad finlay)

Precedence: bulk

At 8:30 PM 8/26/96, Customer Service wrote:
>Bruce,
>John's Hopkins University in Baltimore, renowned as one of the top notch
>med. universities, released a report last fall that E does just what you
>suggested...in monkeys. Reported "brain damage" (their wording) included
>terminal depression! Question is, how much does it take?  Unfortunately, I
>never read the actual medical journal  ( I just saw a snippet in the
>Chron.)  I mean, did these docs dose our little ape friends out of their
>minds every day for  4 weeks?

        Yep, this is from the MAPS (Multidisciplinary Association for
Psychedelic Studies newsletter):

        "The 5 mg/kg dose of MDMA injected in the primates is about 3 times
larger than the typical human dose of 1.7 mg/kg. Dr. Ricaurte has
previously shown that subcutaneous injection of MDMA is roughly twice as
toxic as oral administration (this varies somewhat depending on brain
region), and
that repeated dosing is more toxic than single administration.(6)"

        So, he didn't find severe modifications of the 5-HT (Serotonin)
uptake axons with "recreational" doses of MDMA to the monkeys, so he used
larger doses, subcutaneously (shootin' em up).

        "In order to cause substantial serotonin reductions in multiple
primate brain regions, it was necessary to administer subcutaneous
injections of 5 mg/kg twice daily, four days in a row, for a total of eight
injections. The relevanceof the data from this study to the human
therapeutic or recreational use of MDMA is not clear."

        That's about 45 times the "recreational" human dosage.  (5mg/kg is
3x as neurotoxic x 2 for injecting it x 8 injections) So, i dunno, i mean,
i don't know of anyone who's shooting up 5mg/kg doses of E twice daily for
four days in a row.  Maybe i'm just swinging with the wrong crowd ;)  I
think as well that the linkage between lower primate neurological reactions
and human reactions hasn't been fully worked out, we are somewhat more
complex than monkeys neurologically (i won't get philosophical here ;) so
*as i see it* the findings point to only a few things:
        *In significant, regular dosages* MDMA causes "abnormal" regrowth
of certain neurological pathways (in some areas there is heightened
regrowth, in others there's lesser regrowth). To me, "abnormal" regrowth
doesn't constitute "brain damage."  The link between the regrowth and
impaired or dysfunctional neurological functioning hasn't been established
100%.  In fact (this is totally just me talking from..uhhh...personal
experience) i may venture to say that MDMA's neurological re-patterning may
be beneficial in some ways.  Many researchers thought that serotogenic
depletion would cause anxiety attacks, hostility, depression and impaired
memory function in users, yet many users find just the opposite.
        Here's the URLs for some more info, the second one is the most recent:

        http://www.maps.org/news-letters/v5n3/nih.html

        http://www.maps.org/news-letters/v6n1/06108neu.html

        Here's one other quote from the article:

        "In terms of human use, Dr. Ricaurte was cited as stating that
"people could probably take normal amounts of MDMA three or four times a
year without noticing any neuropsychiatric problems but people who took
seven or eight doses a night could be inviting problems."

        I think that's a fair assesment. ;)

>Bottom line...while E is a beautiful thing and has potential to change the
>way we keep in touch with our emotions and with our fellow humans, I think
>that there is a certain danger in doing it even once a week.  My personal
>theory is that our serotonin levels, which I believe can replenish
>themselves if given the chance, can actually dry up at the source (thus the
>"brain damage") if partying is done in excess.  My advise is, that until we
>know more about the JHU study and what it really means, we ought to ALL
>consider what sort of permanant damage we might be doing to ourselves.  The
>trick, I feel, is to take what we have learned through E and practice a
>opening up "cleaner" doorways to our super-consciousness.  We've all been
>there, and so we know that it exists.   Can we get there on our own?
>Better cautious now than terminally damaged ten years down the road.

        Well said! I think if there's one thing that i've learned about
MDMA (from friends of friends ;) is that when i go and look for something
to fulfill a certain desire (like peace, or feeling love, or whatever) i
realize that it's all within me in the first place.  In that way, i think
that MDMA isn't habit forming, because every time you do it you come closer
and closer to permanently releasing the things that you're trying to 'find'
with the drug, but from within. It's like you have your own permanent
supply of love :) (free, never cut with anything, and you don't hesitate to
share it) ;)
        Also, i think that MDMA as a therapeutic tool is something that
should be examined as well.  Addictions/Behaviours can be self-modified
through "self-metaprogramming" or through a competant therapist (be careful
who you leave your sensorium with though ;).  A friend of a friend told me
that MDMA acts sort of like a backup hard drive that you can use to
rearrange your main root directory and rebuild your desktop ;) (I think
that was the geekiest metaphor i've ever heard) ;)
        Don't take all this stuff i've said about E as gospel truth, i'm no
chem student nor neurologist, but i think that there are certain obvious
facts within the research itself that shows that "brain damage" is unlikely
if one is MODERATE.
        As well, MAPS is a solid, reliable and sound source of a lot of
information.  They have a bit more credibility than something like, say,
High Times.
        But, as with everything: balance and moderation = safety!

        paix, amour et l'ecstasy ;)

                        brad

good morning merry flamethrowers...

insulting and outcasting someone are not good ways to deal with differences...
enough people responded to Troy J. in a way that essentially said "you
stupid bastard, you're not one of us...", and i find that scary.

now i couldn't disagree more strongly with Troy's opinions. but i
understand that he is a human being, entitled to his opinions, and
deserving of my respect...

and what about Unity? making someone feel excluded does not foster love.
and it won't help change someone's opinion.

i may be totally crazy, but my feelings are that PLUR should be something
more than a buzzword, more even than a group of warm feelings that we feel
at parties. PLUR should be a personal and political philosophy (at least it
is for me)... and i'm not seeing that in this discussion.

maybe we should form an sfraves-alter-ego list for getting all our
aggressions out... :)

plurally,
brian

ps      for those of you getting tired of my intervening in your
discussions: i was going to just shut up about it, but the negativity in
this thread got me pretty upset... i promise in the future i won't try to
break up your fights :)

Hello,

On Tue, 27 Aug 96 21:55:46 -0700, "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
wrote:

>Ken wrote:
>> However, if one were to vote for a small party simply because of their
>> stand on the issues, it seems pretty clear that the Libertarian Party
>> most closely represents the viewpoints and interests of ravers.
>
>I don't think so. At least personally, I see the libertarians and
>republicans as greed-based ideologies.
>
>The best way to succeed, IMHO, is to have laws which don't take morals
>or religion into account, as these are variable and can't be dictated.
>What doesn't vary is people's relation with each other,  and our place
>on this earth. To this end, I think we need laws that always ensure we
>put nature above man, people above profit. Libertarians believe that
>people have a inaliable right to profit, while ignoring the zero sum
>nature of profit (profit only comes at someone's expense). I believe
>that greed/profit is one of the most evil things on earth and needs to
>be opposed with extreme force. People do not have a right to make
>money, businesses do not have an inalienable right to exist or do
>business. The ability to make money is a privilege, and not a right.
>This privilege should be taken away from you if your profit motives
>comes at the expense of workers, customers, people, nature, etc.

Once again, the problem with this comes when you try to implement a
system to decide WHEN the profit motive comes at the expense of
others.

You either have:

- People who subjectively decide WHEN to intervene, OR
- A system that decides on the basis of criteria - however, you still
need people who subjectively decide in the first place on WHICH
criteria to use !  :-)

ALL socialist systems require people to decide when a wrong has been
committed against "Nature" or "The People".

BUT, you yourself just stated:

"The best way to succeed, IMHO, is to have laws which don't take
morals or religion into account, as these are variable and can't be
dictated."

and this EXACTLY applies to a system which protects "Nature" or "The
People".

There are millions out there who say that morals and religion are not
variable, but that it is entirely variable where one draws the line
between making a living versus greedily destroying nature and
exploiting people.  Sure the extremes are easy to see, but where does
greed start - $40k per year?  $80k ?  $120k ? $300k ? 

All systems of socialism require someone to decide all these things.

AND what happens time and time again is that the Hitlers and the
Stalins gravitate towards those positions in the government that
decide such things.

This is why communism, an otherwise well meaning philosophy, never
works - because the worst people always spend all their energies
getting into positions of decision and power.

SO, the most freedom is obtained in a system where YOU make all the
decisions.

That system is called the Free Market.   If people want Jeno DJ tapes,
then THEY choose by buying them, and more DJ tapes are made.

In a socialist system, someone else has the power to decide that Jeno
DJ tapes are not healthy for people and nature and to ban them.

In a socialist system, decisions are made by bureaucrats and
lawmakers.

In a free market system, all decisions are made by the People, not by
someone else.   You vote by what you put your money into.

For example, laws are not necessary to protect the environment.  I am
a member of the Rainforest Action Network.   They use my money to
embarass corporations that clear the Rainforest, and have been
successful in convincing them to stop.   If enough people used their
own choice to donate these organizations, these problems could be
overcome without resorting to any laws.


Cheers,

Ken                         <*>
kstuart@mail.telis.org

My favorite CD for 1996 so far = Orbital - "In Sides"

[huge snip]
> This is why communism, an otherwise well meaning philosophy, never
> works - because the worst people always spend all their energies
> getting into positions of decision and power.

And this being a non-communist country, we must have great, beautiful
and well-meaning people in positions of power!

> SO, the most freedom is obtained in a system where YOU make all the
> decisions.

The problem with many western democracies is that people are interpreting
the idea of democracy as meaning that the majority has the right to
tell everybody how to live their lives, instead of leaving everybody
doing their thing as long as they are not causing problems for everybody
else. In America, I'd say the average Joe makes very little decisions
of any importance.

> That system is called the Free Market.   If people want Jeno DJ tapes,
> then THEY choose by buying them, and more DJ tapes are made.
>
> In a socialist system, someone else has the power to decide that Jeno
> DJ tapes are not healthy for people and nature and to ban them.

Pfff, what do you think is happening right now in this free market here?
America is supposedly the ultimate free market and at the same time a
country that attempts to limit personal freedom quite a bit. A Jeno tape
is one thing, gay marriage or medical marihuana another...

> In a socialist system, decisions are made by bureaucrats and
> lawmakers.

Hahaha! So who are making the laws here then???

> In a free market system, all decisions are made by the People, not by
> someone else.   You vote by what you put your money into.

Unless the voting system has become so corrupted that you end up with
only 2 choices, both extremely similar and run by people who's
only interest is to sell themselves and the products of their sponsors
to you. Having a few more (big) political parties in this country
would be an excellent start IMHO.

> For example, laws are not necessary to protect the environment.  I am
> a member of the Rainforest Action Network.   They use my money to
> embarass corporations that clear the Rainforest, and have been
> successful in convincing them to stop. If enough people used their
> own choice to donate these organizations, these problems could be
> overcome without resorting to any laws.

This demonstrates just the ridiculous power of the media in this country,
which to me is probably one of the most frightening aspects of it.
It essentially means that who has the most money will get done what
they want, like the tobacco, prison building and arms lobbies for instance.
And these are probably not run by "the people".

Just my $0.02, no flame intended. I agree communism is going nowhere, but
also think capatalism to the extreme doesn't work. There are systems which
are in the middle (social-democratic) of all that, which can be found in
some places in Europe and which do quite well.

> Burning Man is a blatant astrocity, it is something for which I will offer
> no hope.  Those who attend are blinding themselves.  This is their choice.
> Thank you for allowing me to express myself here, even though some of you
> might not understand from where it is I come from.  
>   
You're right, I might not understand where you're coming from,
but then again I might.  I think you've taken a view of this festival
that clearly differs, even directly clashes with my own... so I thought
I'd just mention what it means to me, and you can decide if we are really
on such opposing sides or not.

Death is a tricky issue, because yes it is the concrete manifestation of
life's worst fear, an end, but I think that one of the most important
points of life is realizing that fears and perspectives that hold us
back and keep us from being free with our life are illusions... that
the infinite spirit driving all things and ourselves is immortal and
invincible, and that these fears of death or of anything else must be
faced head on so that we can learn to move straight through them and
move our life to new directions and realizations.

I view Burning Man as a celebration of the breaking down of fear, that
confrontation with hell, where within we realize just how alive and free
we really are.  We live in a society and reality of many restrictions
and constraints, shaping our spirit into a tightly focused expression
of life that fears it's own demise, but as we go from moment to moment
we learn to lift constraint after constraint and we find that we are
always still here, and usually changed for the better.  

It is not by simply realizing that you're alive and then staying in that
same perspective forever that keeps you alive.  rather, it is by letting
go of what you currently view as your life and moving on to a new view,
which keeps the energy flowing... and that flowing energy is life itself.
stagnant or trapped energy is doomed to die.

> BM is not about renewal.  It is not about Love.  Burning Man is about fear,
> confusion and death.  It is about being lulled to sleep and living in hate
> and pain and isolation.  It is about NOT learning from mistakes made in the
> past, nor is it about trying to reconcile any opportunity for rebirth.

Burning Man is solely about renewal, about rebirth.  It is entirely
about love.  It is only through facing your fear head on, and letting
go of the hate that created it that you learn to love.

Hell is a pretty solid manifestation of all the things we as living
beings fear, and by putting all our fears into the fire and letting them
burn we release the energy trapped within and let it grow into new
forms of life.  Burning Man is a festival where many different kinds
of people come together and let each other express themselves without
anyone trying to judge or condemn anyone for how they are choosing to live.
It is a festival where people try to respect every idea that someone
chooses as their own truth.  It is a festival that challenges you to
stop judging and start living... free and without fear.
It is a festival that challenges you to love life.

That's just my take on it all.

> Love in LIFE!

exactly... 

respectfully,
-john.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Aug 28 12:15:37 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id MAA08040; Wed, 28 Aug 1996 12:15:37 -0700 (PDT)

Date: Wed, 28 Aug 1996 12:13:20 -0700 (PDT)

Subject: Re: The New Nuclear Threat... NRR?
In-Reply-To: <9608281111.ZM8905@laertes.ucsf.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.ULT.3.93.960828115635.7443D-100000@uclink3.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



	O.k. Everyone take a deep breath, count slowly backwards from 10.
It'll all be o.k. 
	There's so much argument going on around here about BM and what it
means. I cut this from Ronald's post and am using it out of context but I
think it makes a good point:

On Wed, 28 Aug 1996, Ronald Knegtel wrote:
> 
> The problem with many western democracies is that people are interpreting
> the idea of democracy as meaning that the majority has the right to
> tell everybody how to live their lives, instead of leaving everybody
> doing their thing as long as they are not causing problems for everybody
> else. In America, I'd say the average Joe makes very little decisions
> of any importance.

	I don't think I'm being overly presumptuous by saying that we're
all more or less responsible individuals who have the ability to make up
our own minds, to define our own lives and gather our own meaning from the
world around us. Arguing over what BM "means" or what a rave is "about" is
like trying to convince someone of what they should get from a piece of
literature. Just because one feels that a rave is not in the "spirit of
raves" does not mean that everyone else will draw the same conclusion from
it. I've found that people infuse events with their own meaning. What this
implies is that even if you consider a rave to have a bad name or a bad
vibe, it does not follow that others will get the same impression. 
	Yes, I agree that a democracy is *not* (or should not) be about a
majority enforcing it's worldview and way of life on a minority. Nor
should a rave scene be about defining what raves should mean to other
people. Take a little personal responsibility and define your life for
yourself. Let others draw meaning as they will. All the flames in the
world won't change ignorance or stupidity.
	There's a difference between supplying knowledge and info (i.e.
posting the hopkins' research report and debating about it) and arguing
about whether people "should" or "ought" to do drugs or go to
lightning-storm parties. 
	There's a fine line between explanation and justification, between
providing information and prescribing courses of action, between accepting
what others do as their own responsibility and trying to change them. 
	I guess what course of action *I'm* trying to prescribe, is that
we don't prescribe courses of action. Be your own person. Make your own
decisions, but make them informed and wise (whatever that means). 


Love and bean-bags,
Stan

	did you ever consider that lsd and color tv arrived for our
consumption about the same time? here comes all this explorative color
pounding and what do we do? we outlaw one and fuck up the other...there
are some basic grounds for outlawing lsd, dmt, stp - it can take a man
permanently out of his mind - but so can picking beets, or turning bolts
for GM, or washing dishes or teaching English I at one of the local
universities. if we outlawed everything that drove men mad, the whole
social structure would drop out - marriage, the war, bus service,
slaughterhouses, beekeeping, surgery, anything you can name. anything can
drive men mad because society is built on false stilts.

				-charles bukowski, _A Bad Trip_

well lets see it only took me 2 days back from London to put my foot in my
mouth....... again...... 
 
I guess I'm just too passionate about my drugs, music and burning man......

 
I just wanted to say to you all that when I say things that appear
offensive and narrow minded, it's not intended that way, I havn't been on a
computer for 4 months, and I forgot my manners......I would like to
apologize publicly to Wowser, and all the people who had to read MY
negative comments. 
 
It's funny how I learn my lessons in life......(over and over) 
 
I guess after a 4 month stint in London, it made me see how different
things can be. 
and I get insensed whan I see someone dis the things in life that give me
freedom of expression, and make my life worth living....I try not to talk
about things I know nothing about, (like politics/religion/etc.....) and I
only talk of what I know.......and I felt at the time Wowser seemed to be
talking of something he does't understand or relate too, and I couldn't see
the reason to dis something that so many of our community seem to take to
heart in........maybe he knows something more about it than I do....maybe
not...... 
 
I can see where I deserve to be flamed for my response to Wowser,
especially my comments about religion etc.....I was out of line....so be it

 
for those of you who see me as just an opinionated guy with a big
mouth....I guess I deserve that......for those of you that have gotten to
know me closely enuff know that I am not being percieved correctly, and
that I try to be genuine and kind, and I am not the kind of person who
would hurt others on purpose. 
 
sometimes I forget that my insensitivity at times like this, can insult and
hurt, and I can only be humbled by the experience. 
 
I will be taking some time off from this flaming nonsense, and just
observing the wars from a distance........I thank those of you who stand
behind me at times like this, and I appreciate the opinions of those that
flame me, believe me it's embarrasing to show my weaknesses in front of 400
plus people, especially when I consider myself to have been growing away
from this kind of public display, (slowly) over the past years or so..... 
 
I too have my dark side, and I allow it to be judged by all those who read
these posts.... 
 
I will now endevour to quietly head off into the burning man, another
lesson learned, and another perspective gained...... 
 
I hope to see some of you there and I hope whatever you do this weekend,
enjoy youself.... 
                                moonpup

Subject: MegaCyber Buzz Carnival

Precedence: bulk

Dear You Guys,

Yesterday someone dropped a message poking fun of the "carnival" raves, and
I came really close to adding a note to that.  After all, it's *so* easy to
make fun of...all you have to do is say MegaCyber Neat Planet Buzz Fest,
Part 3, and suddenly it becomes very funny, who can deny it?
But then I remembered how I used to scrap with my girlfriend about things
like this.  She always used to be protective of the "underground", as if,
"how *dare* these people show up at *our* parties, even start throwing
parties?"

I remember one of the most fascinating things I discovered when I moved to
San Francisco was the sheer size of the parties.  "Jesus, they're throwing
parties in the *civic center*?"  I was astounded that something so cool had
spread to so many people.   Granted, I'd prefer to give foot massages than
go toe-ta-toe with gangstas, but hell, I've been to many of these
G-parties, and I've only been messed with once.  I think that there are
enjoyable aspects of the harder edged parties as well.  At the parties
I've been to like this, I've had a fine time soaking in the attitude, the
swagger, and even the stupid-ass circle dancing.

In an interview about a year ago, Barry Weaver said that people should
chill out on the spiritual thing and just consider that they're dancing and
having a good time. While I have no plans to "chill-out" on the spiritual
thing, I think there is something to be said about just cutting loose,
being a little hard, and showing off in the middle of the circle dancers.
It's all about having a good time, isn't it?  People have good times in
different ways.  Some people are scared to get all soft and huggy, for fear
it will be interpreted as a weakness.  But a gangster at a rave just might
be the first step toward something positive.

There's a whole lotta lovin to learn.  People like us our blessed with this
insight that we can empower and heal ourselves through dance.  But if we
start becoming elitist and hoity-toity about it, aren't we re-creating the
very establishment  we went underground to escape?   House music has a
*very* powerful effect on a human being, and so it's bound to attract a lot
of people, and not everyone is going to be coming from the same point of
view.

The second thing that struck me about SF was that you can actually *choose*
what kind of party to go to.  In many other cities, there is one party per
weekend, if you're lucky.  I don't think there's anything wrong with the
rave scene spreading...in fact it might even be necessary, if we're going
to achieve this critical mass that we've been talking about for so long.
If we're going to change the world folks, we need a big army.  (And we need
to train 'em well).  I guess the kid  who was making fun of the
MegaBuzzCyber Cool carnivals wasn't really objecting to their existence,
but questioning whether or not it'd be worth going to.  Anyway, if you love
house music, doesn't that mean you should love *everything* about house
music?  I dunno.  I lost my point and...


...here comes my boss.


Evolve.

-boomerang



Peter Sandifer
Customer Service

Hey all,

I wondered if any of you out there had experience with sampling sound from
videotape soundtracks. Is it just a cable you plug into your VCR and your
stereo or sampler and off you go? What is the copyright law concerning say,
single sentences or words as spoken by movie charachters on video? I know
lots of records who sampled stuff from movies and I have a hard time
believing all the artists involved pay copyrights to the makers of those
movies...

The Frying Dutchman

>         "In order to cause substantial serotonin reductions in multiple
> primate brain regions, it was necessary to administer subcutaneous
> injections of 5 mg/kg twice daily, four days in a row, for a total of eight
> injections. The relevanceof the data from this study to the human
> therapeutic or recreational use of MDMA is not clear."

sleep did the poor monkeys get?  Did they do a control with something "proven 
safe" like caffeine?  What are the neurological symptoms of sleep deprivation 
anyway?  I hear psychosis is among the psychological symptoms...

other's throats out while the e-monkeys just got a bit down, I can see there 
being some problems with publication...

hello all-

this morning, i realized just how short life is (if you're confused, see my
earlier MATT'S IN THE HOSPITAL message).  i almost was killed this morning,
and i got to thinking, what's so important about my car, my computer, my
guitar, etc?  how am i gonna use them when i'm dead?  what's so important
about making a good paycheck?  how can i spend it after i've been committed
to an institution for going crazy from working too hard?  

i'm sitting on my couch, home from the hospital, still shaken up, but
getting better.  i just thought i would share my experiences with anyone out
there who is a workaholic, and tell them "SLOW DOWN!!!  SLOW DOWN, OR THE
WORLD WILL FIND SOME WAY TO SLOW YOU DOWN, AND YOU MAY NOT LIKE IT!"

so, with that said, i'm gonna take a hot shower.

p.s.  matt's happy go lucky, filled with love posts will return soon, so if
you don't like it, just filter me out entirely.

love to you all, and i hope your day goes well-

matt l


matthew d. p. k. lanier

At 8:22 PM -0000 8/28/96, Randy C Cone wrote:
>So let me guess John; you support Wowser's assesment of BM?

I made no comment about wosers post onne way or another.  WOser and others
had an opinion, and I regard it as such.  I see no need to spout out my
opinion about everything.

>Or are you
>just taking the time out to criticise the reactions to Wowser's post
>without also commenting on Wowser's post.

I made all the comments I cared to make.  I see no need to argue about this
particular opinion.  That is my perrogative, yes?

>
> I thinks that the reason why Wowser recieved such a hostile reaction
>from many people (myself included) was that he attacked something that
>many people here hold dear; the right to gather and party. Two elements
>in life thet you, unless I'm mistaken, also cherish. So whats up John?
>I'm certain you have more insights to share with us.

I'm not so certain about that.  Like I said, I have nothing more to add.

>
> PS I do not agree that Wowser should get off the list. I feel he is
>welcome to share his opinions with us; just as we are welcome (or should
>be) to share ours with him. I do appreciate John's comment's; I'm just
>curious why he is deconstructing the reactions to Wowser rather than
>Wowser's post itself.

Maybe it was one old-timer's way of saying to another to chill out a bit,
in a non-obtrusive(IMO) way.  Maybe it was someone, chosing an example, to
ask everyone to chill a bit.  Maybe I was just taking time out of my very
busy life to add, what I saw as value and a certain perspective to the
entire dialog.

Deconstruction is difficult without an explosive.

Date: Wed, 28 Aug 1996 21:02:12 GMT
Reply-To: kstuart@mail.telis.org
Message-ID: <3225b122.50712686@mail.campus.mci.net>
References: <199608280455.VAA22589@netcom11.netcom.com>  <32267f74.37993050@mail.campus.mci.net> <9608281111.ZM8905@laertes.ucsf.edu>
In-Reply-To: <9608281111.ZM8905@laertes.ucsf.edu>
X-Mailer: Forte Agent .99f/32.275
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello,

On Wed, 28 Aug 1996 11:11:42 -0700, "Ronald Knegtel"
<knegtel@laertes.ucsf.EDU> wrote:
>Ken wrote:
>[huge snip]
>> This is why communism, an otherwise well meaning philosophy, never
>> works - because the worst people always spend all their energies
>> getting into positions of decision and power.
>
>And this being a non-communist country, we must have great, beautiful
>and well-meaning people in positions of power!

You're creating a black-and-white polarity here between "communist"
and "non-communist" countries.   If you read carefully, I said
"communism, a philosophy".

Every country's government is a spectrum between the free market and
socialism/communism.

The reason that we have power-hungry people in our government is
because the government itself is powerful.

If we take away a lot of the government's funding (ie taxes), then we
take away its power and then we take it away as an instrument for just
those power-hungry people that everyone here is against.

I can hear someone say " but that will just leave the corporations to
do whatever they want " and there are three answers to this:

(1) A lot of the power of the corporations comes from their leverage
in the government due to lobbyists, which then gets them legal
exceptions to normal free market forces, which vastly increases their
influence.

(2) One of the few legitimate activities of government is anti-trust
action, ie enforcing existing laws that prevent monopolies and other
corporate actions that go against free market forces.

(3) When anti-trust laws are enforced, individual corporations only
encompass small segments of the economy - unlike the government which
has power over every aspect of your life.

>
>> SO, the most freedom is obtained in a system where YOU make all the
>> decisions.
>
>The problem with many western democracies is that people are interpreting
>the idea of democracy as meaning that the majority has the right to
>tell everybody how to live their lives, instead of leaving everybody
>doing their thing as long as they are not causing problems for everybody
>else. In America, I'd say the average Joe makes very little decisions
>of any importance.

You seem to be misunderstanding what I am saying.  The effect of
democracy in the polling place is nothing compared to the decisions
made by average Joe in what he is going to do with his time and money.
Every time he chooses between watching a TV show or going to
"Harmony", between buying a six-pack of beer or the new Orbital CD, he
makes a decision.

In a socialist system, decisions are made for you by other people who
think that they have your best interests at heart.   Didn't you think
you were getting rid of that when you moved out at 18?

>> That system is called the Free Market.   If people want Jeno DJ tapes,
>> then THEY choose by buying them, and more DJ tapes are made.
>>
>> In a socialist system, someone else has the power to decide that Jeno
>> DJ tapes are not healthy for people and nature and to ban them.
>
>Pfff, what do you think is happening right now in this free market here?
>America is supposedly the ultimate free market and at the same time a
>country that attempts to limit personal freedom quite a bit. A Jeno tape
>is one thing, gay marriage or medical marihuana another...

Exactly... except that America is not the ultimate free market.  Over
the last 30 years, the government has had more and more influence, and
your free market choices are less and less.   For example, Hong Kong
has more of a free market than we do.

As far as the other choices you mentioned above, the Libertarian Party
(which was the subject of the post you are replying to) is in favor of
allowing you to do all those things (in fact their platform dispenses
with the word "medical" above).

>> In a socialist system, decisions are made by bureaucrats and
>> lawmakers.
>
>Hahaha! So who are making the laws here then???

Exactly.   Our current government has become too socialist.

>
>> For example, laws are not necessary to protect the environment.  I am
>> a member of the Rainforest Action Network.   They use my money to
>> embarass corporations that clear the Rainforest, and have been
>> successful in convincing them to stop. If enough people used their
>> own choice to donate these organizations, these problems could be
>> overcome without resorting to any laws.
>
>This demonstrates just the ridiculous power of the media in this country,
>which to me is probably one of the most frightening aspects of it.
>It essentially means that who has the most money will get done what
>they want, like the tobacco, prison building and arms lobbies for instance.
>And these are probably not run by "the people".

But if your tax money is returned to you, you can give it to people
like the Rainforest Action Network.   The amount of tax money
currently collected by the government is so vast, that if private
groups like RAN had access to it, they could do a MUCH better job of
protecting the environment than the apathetic government bureaucrats
could ever do.

Paying taxes is equivalent to flushing your money.   Whatever your
concern is, a private action group that is enthusiastic and motivated
can always do a better job of it than the government.


Cheers,

Ken                         <*>
kstuart@mail.telis.org

My favorite CD for 1996 so far = Orbital - "In Sides"

sound system from an actual sound company like JK or Santa Cruz Sound, 
etc. It would only cost a minimal amount, and might be the best idea. 
But if any of you know of anyone with a system, please speak up!

voicemail, to organize a phonelist. If you want to help call 
(415)263-4885. Leave your name, and phone number, even a pager number 
if you have one! Also leave any spaces (locations) you might know of.

spaces or info about what space we will decide upon.

Troy, yes Burning Man is about death.  But without death there is no
regeneration.  It takes the death of animals, vegetables, trees and many
other things to sustain your life.  Is your life what you would consider
sickening or "bad" because it asks for death every day?  When people throw
out aspects of themselves that are no longer healthy or useful and "burn"
them with the  effigy on Sunday night, they are making room for positive
change and rebirth.  I know I will "burning" and mid-wifing many things
that evening. I believe that is a very sad state that our culture cannot
embrace the dark as well as the light.  In the dark we learn about our
fears and the things we allow to limit ourselves.  I think "burning" and
destroying symbolically is alot more healthy and positive then having to
resort to Prozac don't you?

Melissa  

	

	**************************************************************	
	Go to the mountains and the oceans and the forest, go naked in 
	the summertime that you may regain the old joy and love gladly 
	and freely under the stars.

						-John Whiteside Parson
	**************************************************************

********Begin =
babbel*******************************************************************=

Not to be nit picking, but.... I believe the show Niels is referring to =
is called We The People, Its Jerry Brown's daily show on KPFA 94.1.

Hello happy ravers, and unhappy uh.... flamers. As a newbie to this list =
I've been trying to hold my tongue for the obligatory week before =
posting, but holding my tongue "Mah me thoun lahk pith" when I talk :)   =
 Ofcourse I sound even worse with my foot in my mouth.
=09
	I think I'm going to have a ball at the next few parties trying to =
match the posts I've been reading to all the familiar faces.
=09
	Regarding the great E-debate, I've read PHIKAL cover to cover and I =
highly (no pun intended) recommend it for its wealth of  unbiased (sort =
of) knowledge concerning psycho-active compounds, the "fictional" book =
at the beginning was great reading as well.=20

I've also read everything else I can find on the subject. Everything =
else I've come across has been slanted badly for or against, and both =
sides twist the numbers.=20

One thing that is clear, is that eventhough this compound (mdma) has =
been around for ages, there hasn't been enough information made public =
for accurate assessments of the long term effects of standard =
recreational doses over long periods of time. (long sentence.Ughh.)

	The findings of brain damage in lab animals that I have come across =
(the findings, not the animals) all describe absurdly high doses at very =
short intervals. Conspicuously absent from the data of most of these =
studies is a control group. This tells me that either the researchers, =
or those presenting the data, are trying to draw conclusions that the =
data won't support.	=20

	Ok, I could talk for days on the subject, but I type rreeeaaalll =
sloooww. I'm not defending the use of E, I feel most of us are capable =
of making that decision on our own, but its so hard to get any unbiased =
information.

		Peace, love, knowledge and all that good stuff
					Chris
****DISCLAIMER****
If any of the above is incoherent I apologize, I'm on my 6th cup of =
coffee.

Hello,

On Thu, 29 Aug 1996 01:56:11 +0200 (MET DST), Sune Alexandersen
<balexand@online.no> wrote:
>I`m having trouble with which posts that are sfraves and which are not..
>
>Why don`t we all add a SFRAVES in the subject-line??
>(I`m using Eudora, but does anyone know of another mailer, that displays the
>sender in the _in_ box???)

If you get "Agent" a great combined news&mail reader, then it will
separate your e-mail according to ANY criteria you devise (for example
you can have it look for "sfraves" in the To, CC, From and Sender
headers).   Then it puts all your e-mail into separate folders based
on these criteria.   For example, all my sfraves mailing list mail
goes into an "sfraves" folder automatically - BUT it doesn't have to
be mailing list mail, it can look for e-mail from specific friends and
do the same.  Anything that doesn't meet any criteria goes into
"inbox" folder.

It does cost something like $30-$40, but they provide excellent
technical support and frequent updates with great new features.

Check it out at:

http://www.forteinc.com/agent/index.html


Cheers,

Ken                         <*>
kstuart@mail.telis.org

My favorite CD for 1996 so far = Orbital - "In Sides"

I'm just venting here-

A few months ago theron was discussing his new tape he had made.  Some of
you know him and can probably relate or let him know of my anger.
May it was and a few sfravers also comented on how good the tape was.  Well
I thought i would be good and contribute and purchased a tape.  I
corresponded with Theron and he sent me this:


thanx for your interest in my mix. you can get it directly from me by sendin=
g
$10 and your address to:

theron kagnoff
2000 broadway #1004
SF,CA 94115

it's 16 new goa/psychedelic trance trax beatmixed and blended by yours
truely. i'm quite pleased w/it and it sounds like others are fond of it as
well. most of the trax on it i review in the latest xlr8r magazine.

enjoy!
-theron

Well I did and nothing happened.  A few months went by and no tape but the
check was never cashed.  I figured it was lost in the snail mail.  No use
in canceling a 10 dollar check cuz it costs 10 dollars to do it.  No big
deal right.  Well a few weeks ago I get my bank statement and my check is
deposited to Theron Kagnoff.  Hmm ok well I figured he would NOW send me
his tape.  No TAPE!
I emailed him but his email is out of service and I am out of 10 buckes or
a "was-gonna-be-fresh" mixed tape by theron.

If any one knows him please drop him a line and see if he can send me the
tape, or my 10 bucks.  If that doesn't happen tell him a BIG FUCK YOU!!!!

No Peace.  No Unity.  No Love.  NO RESPECT!!!!

Austin

At 05:54 PM 8/28/96 -0700, you wrote:
>Troy, yes Burning Man is about death.  But without death there is no
>regeneration.  It takes the death of animals, vegetables, trees and many
>other things to sustain your life.  Is your life what you would consider
>sickening or "bad" because it asks for death every day?  When people throw
>out aspects of themselves that are no longer healthy or useful and "burn"
>them with the  effigy on Sunday night, they are making room for positive
>change and rebirth.  I know I will "burning" and mid-wifing many things
>that evening. I believe that is a very sad state that our culture cannot
>embrace the dark as well as the light.  In the dark we learn about our
>fears and the things we allow to limit ourselves.  I think "burning" and
>destroying symbolically is alot more healthy and positive then having to
>resort to Prozac don't you?
>
>Melissa  
>

I am not talking about physical death, Melissa.  That was the point.  Within
each of us IMO there is not found both darkness and light, but rather a
struggle to break free from one into the other. I know I may well be in the
minority here to think such, but this is my freedom and my right to do so.
I do not beleive in the yin/yang.  Rather, I beleive we are the line which
is found in the middle; and in this world, in our short existances here, is
where we are given the opportunity to seek out a rebirth.  This rebirth can
be into Life or into death.  Preferably from the dark and into the light,
for this also breaking free from death into LIFE.  This has nothing to do
with religion, but everything to do with the human soul.  Surrendering
onesself over to legions of dark things and abandoning conscious thought in
the name of self-discovery is utterly the biggest deception I know of IMO.

There was talk of boycotting the BlitzKrieg rave in LA because of the name
and what it meant to people.  Many people voiced their opinons about how
dreadful and inappropriate that name was.  BM is not about rebirth, it is
about celebration of permanent death and about surrendering to utter lies.
THIS is my opinon.  This is how I see the world.  I am free to do so.
  

Troy J.

Even though I'm not going to BM - I finally feel compelled to say
something about "your" interpretation of BM.... I know the people who
created the BM ceremony (and suspect that you don't)... and I can tell
you that they have no such intention as you ascribe to them... but
if truth be told they have NO INTENTION AT ALL....

  The BM ceremony is a ceremony without any overt purpose - the creators
of this ceremony were adamant that they DO NOT want to impose any
reason or dogma to the burn... it's about personal interpretations and
values... each person is free to make their own... or none at all...
Thus, you are free to your personal interpretation of it just as everyone
else... BUT where you make a mistake is applying your own personal dogma
to everyone else - the creators of BM are not responsible for your negative
interpretation of their symbol - you are. You are trying to make a general
symbol an ABSOLUTE symbol which is the exact reason that Christianity has
become so corrupt and valueless to so many people.... but that is another
story. Just quit trying to tell everyone else YOUR TRUTH as if it is THE
TRUTH... it hasn't worked in the past and it doesn't work now...

Mike

StEvEo's 1st ANNUAL HUMAN CARCOPHONIC ORCHESTRA!

Saturday eve (round bout 8:30pm(look for the flyer on the main message board
in town) on the playa, we'll be conducting an experiment in sound. The basic
idea is this: A large goup of people making lots of noises (chants, favorite
rave choruses, operatic singing, grunts, doo-wops, zerberts, etc.)
It would be nice to have a couple didges and and drums, but primarily human
noises. It will be "chaotic freestyle" for the most part but we might try
"conducting" a few volleys with several people on similiar rhythms. Please,
if you have any interest in tribal sounds and communal harmony, come by and
support this seemingly loopy idea of mine! Thanks,
-StEvEo
P.S. Remember to look for the superbly designed HUMAN CARCOPHONIC ORCHESTRA
poster, it will have our location and time.
