just some obsolete thoughts from my side.
what i like about wowser is that he seems to be a considered guy and he 
really *tries*. 
i never found myself agreeing with him in any way, but i sorta like his 
attitude. he really really is a couraged and humble fighter for the Lord, 
not being afraid of inconvenience nor giving shit on his reputation.
i think thats gorgeous.

i can live quite well with that kind of people, as i can with the ones 
that aren't up for saving the world but just wanna party.
the thing i kinda dislike is what sometimes comes through 
on the list here, people behaving like their partying and doing drugs was 
the way to save the world. you know i strongly suspect saving the world would 
be way more painful than dosing everybody with ecstasy and doesn't have much 
to do with just going with the ceaseless flow of fun events throughout the 
year in a happy daze.

concerning the arguments you found to kick wowsers little butt - i think 
they are not worth the figurative paper you typed them on.

the fact that something is well organized and creatively done alone doesnt 
make it good and supportable in any way.

10000 people can very well be wrong. just imagine that being said about 
the third reich or something (not that i'm making comparisons, god forbid).

some people putting effort into organizing something is no reason to 
appreciate it. 
..ohhh, i put so much effort into preparing that little baby coffin and 
sprinkling blood all over the altar...
(not that i'm making comparisons again)
  
' get a life and leave us in peace to make our own individual decisions ' -
you would say that to jesus too, would you,  
you wicked, wicked faithless little snob you :)

anyway i'm happy to notice raveland is nothing more than any normal 
amusement park and this list doesn't contain more plur than any arbitray 
24 hour nautilus, because thats something i always suspected and 
thats something i can *relate* to.
ulrike

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ronald Knegtel wrote:
> 
> Hey all,
> 
> I wondered if any of you out there had experience with sampling sound from
> videotape soundtracks. Is it just a cable you plug into your VCR and your
> stereo or sampler and off you go? What is the copyright law concerning say,
> single sentences or words as spoken by movie charachters on video? I know
> lots of records who sampled stuff from movies and I have a hard time
> believing all the artists involved pay copyrights to the makers of those
> movies...
> 
> The Frying Dutchman

Umm... Tough question. I think that copyright law is some thing like 15 years must pass until 
something is considered "Public Domain". This means that you can use OLD material that has 
been coprighted once this time limit passes. Unless of course the owner of the copyright 
applies for an extension, Which I belive is possible. IMHO, if it's a snippet you're 
capturing from some obscure SciFi movie for a track you're going to play live at a party, no 
one is going to care. If on the other hand, you're U2 (sorry), You'd definitely have to get 
the owners ok.

I had always thought that this was part of the reason that "White Labels" were made. If you 
has a killer track with some funky samples, which were some one elses, you put it on a White 
Label so no one knows who to sue )>.

Any one care to give us a "White Label" history lesson?

If you're using a sampler you'll most likely need 1/4in to RCA cables. Every VCR I've ever 
seen has RCA plugs on the back. HI-Fi VCR's will output in <STEREO> but older ones are mono. 
Mono is usually adquate though.

PLUR, gav
eona
aviv
cete
e y

> but love is the sky and i am for you
> just so long and long enough
>               - e.e. cummings

It is a great .sig. BTW, I did not know where it came from till I saw 
your .sig, but there's a sample of a girl saying "I am for you" in a 
track by Paradise 3001 called "When the magnetic flow fails". It's on 
their Sunspots cd/record. It's really trippy (for lack of a better 
word).

gav

heya.....thinking about Wowser and possibily joining a 24 hour Nautilus gym,
and "hey you get off of my cloud"......don't you just the love the smell of
poetry in the morning??? No, I think I quoted that wrong from Apocalypse
Now.  But, there has been so much flaming going on recently.  I guess most
people were just getting "fired up" for going to Burning Man......Maybe we
need to remember not to play with matches....

uh?? Maybe we need to remember what Voltaire said about PLUR,...."I may not
agree with you, but I will defend until the death your right to say it..."
This from a guy who spent most of his life as a professional pariah. When we
really "flame" someone, it's the same as burning them at the stake as some
kind of heretic or witch. The truth is, we only have as much freedom as we
are willing to allow someone else.....I am afraid that if we allowed some
people on this list to be in charge of the world or this list, it would be
the smell of napalm morning.....sulphur,sulphur, everywhere.....and such a
lot of stink!!!! 

                              thoughts from a burnt man...SpinSilver

Ulrike,

        Please remember that not all of us are like the loudest "voices" on
this list.  There are many within this community who truly believe that our
unconditional love and positivity is a valuable inspirational force, and we
hope that it will help us to take the reins and steer this world away from
the brink of disaster toward which it is very likely headed.
        For my part, I love every person, with my whole being.  That
doesn't mean I LIKE everyone, but I wish to continue to radiate light and
joy, and dose the world with my love, always to be kind and considerate of
others.  I don't know how many people pick up on this, but it's the most
important thing in my life, and I do hope it's appreciated.
        I've found people through this list who are of a like mind-set, to
varying degrees.  I hope that you will make it over here soon, and
experience firsthand what I'm describing.  I, we, await you with open
hearts.

Love,
Eric

[ to sfraves ]

 This may be poor timing on my part ( with so many folks going out of
the area and away from their terminals for Burning Man ), but I was 
hoping to get some experienced answers -

 I'd like to explore the playing of MIDI instruments and sound samples
with my Mac. So, if anyone is making music with a Macintosh computer,
please give me the benefit of your wisdom:

1. What sequencer software would you recommend? It must be able to
   sequence MIDI events and the playback of sound samples.

2. What MIDI interface is good/bad?

3. The only sample playback card I know of for the Mac is SampleCell.
   Are there other and/or cheaper alternatives?

Equipment: I have an old Mac II w/accelerator , NuBus expansion slots,
           not PCI. I already have some sound manipulation software.

 Thanks for reading this!

>>  chocolate.

>>  4)      You can safely have chocolate while you are driving.
>>  5)      You can make chocolate last as long as you want it to.
>>  6)      You can have chocolate even in front of your mother.
>>  7)      If you bite the nuts too hard the chocolate won't mind.
>>  8)      Two people of the same sex can have chocolate without being
>>  called nasty names.
>>  9)      The word "commitment" doesn't scare off chocolate.
>>  10)     You can have chocolate on top of your workbench/desk during
>>  working hours without upsetting your co-workers.
>>  11)     You can ask a stranger for chocolate without getting your face
>>  slapped.
>>  12)     You don't get hairs in your mouth with chocolate.
>>  13)     With chocolate there's no need to fake it.
>>  14)     Chocolate doesn't make you pregnant.
>>  15)     You can have chocolate at any time of the month.
>>  16)     Good chocolate is easy to find.
>>  17)     You can have as many kinds of chocolate as you can handle.
>>  18)     You are never too young or too old for chocolate.
>>  19)     When you have chocolate it does not keep your neighbors awake.
>>  20)     With chocolate size doesn't matter.

On Aug 29, 12:43pm, Ulrike Laitko wrote:
> Subject: Re: shutup unless you understand the storyline
[snip]
> what i like about wowser is that he seems to be a considered guy and he
> really *tries*.
> i never found myself agreeing with him in any way, but i sorta like his
> attitude. he really really is a couraged and humble fighter for the Lord,
> not being afraid of inconvenience nor giving shit on his reputation.
> i think thats gorgeous.

In my book that would describe a fanatic. A type of person I don't really
find gorgeous. And the only thing he is *trying* is to put his particular
set of values upon us.

> i can live quite well with that kind of people, as i can with the ones
> that aren't up for saving the world but just wanna party.

There are different ways of saving the world. And the discussion was not
about saving the world versus wanting to party. It was Wowser claiming
that BM is an evil event and other claiming he had no idea what BM
was really about, or put differently, BM not being an evil event which
will send its attendees eventually straight to hell but rather a celebration
of community and a place for people to get together and exchange ideas.
Or something like that.

> the thing i kinda dislike is what sometimes comes through
> on the list here, people behaving like their partying and doing drugs was
> the way to save the world.

Are you on the same sfraves list as I am? I can't remember anybody stating
that, except for the occasional post every now and then in which somebody
suggests that some people might lighten up a bit if they would indulge
into some mind altering chemicals. I don't think people on this list are
so naive.

> you know i strongly suspect saving the world would
> be way more painful than dosing everybody with ecstasy and doesn't have much
> to do with just going with the ceaseless flow of fun events throughout the
> year in a happy daze.

Who said that? It's not about saving the world, the original discussion
was about Wowser claiming that BM was a bad thing to attend.

> concerning the arguments you found to kick wowsers little butt - i think
> they are not worth the figurative paper you typed them on.

Hahaha, although I haven't been involved in this discussion until now
I would say Wowser's arguments are about as meaningful as those of his
opponents. He says BM is evil and bad for us. Period. Just because he
thinks so and without delivering real argumentation except that anything
which has to with the darker sides of life must be evil. His opponents simply
claimed that they had a different opinion on that issue and that he
may not have a good idea what BM is about.

> the fact that something is well organized and creatively done alone doesnt
> make it good and supportable in any way.
> some people putting effort into organizing something is no reason to
> appreciate it.

Agreed, but people have also explained their opinions about relation
between dark and light, that there is no life without death and that each
ending can be a new beginning. Wowsers response was "that's not the way
I see it".

> ' get a life and leave us in peace to make our own individual decisions ' -
> you would say that to jesus too, would you,

Next time he comes around, yes. It's been ~2000 years now...

> you wicked, wicked faithless little snob you :)

You're flattering me! ;)

> anyway i'm happy to notice raveland is nothing more than any normal
> amusement park and this list doesn't contain more plur than any arbitray
> 24 hour nautilus, because thats something i always suspected and
> thats something i can *relate* to.

I would say the plur on this list is somewhat higher than sampled on
average around us. People, however, get easily irritated by Bible
thumping folks, who, without other arguments than a 2000 year old book,
try to determine what's wrong or right for others to do. Christianity
has had its 2000 years to impregnate people with fear and lies, stood
at the beginning of the Inquisition and progroms against Jews and
essentially still tries to force its message down our throats instead
of just offering it for us to consider. I think that gives us the right
to put a few cynical remarks in a lousy E-mail sometimes...

The Frying Dutchman

> ulrike
>-- End of excerpt from Ulrike Laitko

WHOAA!...I have been moving for the last two weeks an my computer has been
in a box....I never realised how much I would miss being on line and
reading all of these posts and being a part of sfraves! :-) well...I
actually went to one of those 5 minutes on line for a quarter boxes at a
cafe, last week when I sent a really hurried post regarding OPEN, sorry
for the brevity and any confusion that may have caused! 5 minutes is not
enough time to read and reply to all you guys!
	Well I went to OPEN with two rave virgins and anothert of my best
friends, after finding the spot way out in some east bay roller
rink...sheesh...we wnt in and basically we all had a blast...the
"butterfly room" was somewhat of a joke...although really cool, for all
the hype I was kinda dissapointed, Other things I noted were many younger
people around...one image that sticks with me is a teenage girl, dressed
up complete with teddy bear, pig taiils and a pacifier in one hand...and a
cigarette in the other...sheesh!
	There was a really rad jungle set done in the ambient rom around
3-4 am, from an amatuer perspective seemed quite technical with scratching
and stuff really neat. One last note...the life of a cup at this rave was
very short lived...the little cup was hardly noticed :-(
	But all in all we had a great time and enjoyed eachothers company
and danced alot and had fun which is what really matters anyway...peace
and love to all of you!
tr

X-Sender: epaul@macpo-1
Message-Id: <v02130500ae4be1ce29d6@[146.225.54.11]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 1996 17:24:58 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: epaul@Synopsys.COM (Eric P. Peterson)
Subject: Ultra-brief Open review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Venue: Remote, but not too remote ;)  Roomy :)  A little too much delay in
sound from corner to corner, though, as speakers were placed in each.
There were groups dancing in each corner, in front of the dj, and all
throughout, and still there was room to move around :)
Dance/chill area separation: insufficient to separate sound :(
Air: not hot OR smoky :)
Lighting: Impressive; radiating lights above turntables, a clear plastic
person with blinking colored lights inside suspended from the ceiling.  A
couple house lights on made the place to lit up, though :|
Music: Wonderful and dancy throughout, only one near-trainwreck, well
recovered.  Dj Trance was in rare form, and Moshe was a madman with his
scratching frenzy in the chill area! :D
VIBE: Not intense, but very pleasant and positive.  Friendly people.  Hare
Krishnas were cool.  The crew were enthusiastic.
Features: Free massage was excellent!  The butterflies were beautiful, but
it was just a glass case.  I was hoping for something more interactive, but
that might have gotten out of hand...
This was the first party in a long time where I didn't know at least 1/3 of
the people.  It was refreshing, but I missed everyone who wasn't there.  We
got to bring in water :)  I left my candy bag unattended in both areas, and
it was unmolested the whole party through :D
Overall: I greatly enjoyed the party!  Excellent job on the part of the
Nexus crew; I hope to attend their events again.

Peace,
Eric



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Aug 29 18:20:11 1996

Date: Thu, 29 Aug 96 18:20:59 PST
From: "Ciaran O'Hara" <Ciaran.O'Hara@CCMAIL.AirTouch.COM>
Message-Id: <9607298413.AA841368098@CCMAIL.AIRTOUCH.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: NRR : Old lady's riches (longish)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
        A lttle NRR humor. Anyone else still at work ?
     
A little old lady walked into the head branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank 
holding a large paper bag in her hand.  She told the young man at the 
window that she wished to take the $3 million she had in the bag and open 
an account with the bank.
     
She said that first, though, she wished to meet the president of Chase 
Manhattan Bank due to the amount of money involved.  The teller seemed 
to think that was a reasonable request and after opening the paper
bad and seeing the bundles of $1000 bills which amounted to right around $3 
million, telephoned the bank's secretary to obtain an appointment for the 
lady.  The lady was escorted upstairs and ushered into the president's 
office.
     
Introductions were made and she stated that she would like to get to know 
the people she did business with on a more personal level.  The bank 
president then asked her where she came into such large amount of money. 
"Was it an inheritance?" he asked.  "No." she answered. 
"Was it from playing the stock market?"  "No", she replied. 
He was quiet for a minute, trying to think of where this little old lady 
could possibly come into $3 million.
     
"I bet." she stated.
     
"You bet?" repeated the bank president.  "As in horses?" 
"No." she replied, "I bet people."
     
Seeing his confusion, she explained that she just bets different things
with people.  All of a sudden she said, "I'll bet you $25,000.00 that by 10:00 
o'clock tomorrow morning, your balls will be square."  The bank president 
figured she must be off her rocker and decided to take her up on the bet.
He didn't see how he could lose..  For the rest of the day, the bank 
president was very careful.  He decided to stay home that evening and take 
no chances; there was $25,000.00 at stake.
     
When he got up in the morning and took his shower, he checked his balls to 
make sure everything was okay.  There was no difference; they looked the 
same as they always had.  He went to work and waited for the little old
lady to come in at 10:00 o'clock, humming as he went.  He knew this would be a 
good day' how often do you get handed $25,000.00 for doing nothing.
     
At 10:00 o'clock sharp, the little old lady was shown into his office.
With her was a younger man.  When he inquired as to the man's purpose for being 
there, she informed him that he was her lawyer and she always took him
along when there was this much money involved.  "Well," she asked, "what 
about our bet?"
     
"I don't know how to tell you this," he replied, "but I am the same as 
I've always been only $25,000.00 richer."
     
The lady seemed to accept this, but requested that she be able to see for 
herself.  The bank president thought this was reasonable and dropped his 
trousers.  She instructed him to bend over and then grabbed a hold of his 
balls with both her hands.  Sure enough, everything was fine.
     
The bank president then looked up and saw her lawyer standing across the 
room banging his head against the wall.
     
"What's wrong with him?"  he inquired.  "Oh him," she replied, "I bet him 
$100,000.00 that by 10:00 o'clock this morning that I'd have the president 
of Chase Manhattan Bank by the balls."
     
     
     Ciaran

Hello All!

I was at my companie's (Excite - the search engine) weekly Monday 
all-hands meeting today when one of the product managers anounced 
that he was looking for some volunteers from Excite to POSSIBLY go
to Burning Man with a company supplied rental truck filled with 
water bottles to hand out for free at BM...of course the bottles
will have our logo/url on them. Concerned, I warned the product manager
that this BSP could possibly backfire noting that what makes real
underground parties so special is that positive vibe which is some-
thing that cannot be bought, sold or commercialized. We all know 
that it's unconditional love given freely with no IDENTIFICATION or
GRATIFICATION of one's ego is what creates the vibe. 

My intention in this post is not to start a flame war but to ask for 
your valued opinion on this product manager's idea. He has said that
it would just be made available for the taking, out of the back of a
truck and would not have banners posted all over the place. Also,
the water would not be passed out intentionally, like flyers, but 
people would have to go to the truck to get it. 

Personally I don't think it's a good promotional idea for the reasons
stated above...I will gladly forward your opinions to him.

Peace and UNCONDITIONAL LOVE always,
John

At 09:15 PM 8/27/96 -0700, Wowser <tuskluv@lewiston.com> wrote:

>I have held my toungue on Burning Man.  I did post a story, which I had
>hoped would relevate an epiphany with some.  Clearly, it did not.  While
>many unsuspecting individuals are clamoring to go to their first BM, excited
>by the aspect of a large rave, I feel they know or understand little about
>what Burning Man is really all about.  It is not a rave, but rather a
>celebration of death.  It is purely negative.  It disgusts me.  Do those who
>are so excited about going not realize what BM is REALLY about??!!??  
>
>I have read many of outraged posts about partys sporting insulting names
>like BlitzKrieg.  But I wonder, why does no one seem insulted by the THEME
>of Burning Man?  I, for one, am insulted.  Sicked, actually, that our
>society celebrates the supposed death of Love/Life/Spirit and galvanizes
>together only to rally support for forces which seek only to destroy Life.
>BM is not about renewal.  It is not about Love.  Burning Man is about fear,
>confusion and death.  It is about being lulled to sleep and living in hate
>and pain and isolation.  It is about NOT learning from mistakes made in the
>past, nor is it about trying to reconcile any opportunity for rebirth.
>
>This, my family, is my opinion.  I'm not scared to tell you all how I feel.
>Burning Man is a blatant astrocity, it is something for which I will offer
>no hope.  Those who attend are blinding themselves.  This is their choice.
>Thank you for allowing me to express myself here, even though some of you
>might not understand from where it is I come from.  
>  
>
>Love in LIFE!
>
>Troy J.
>
> 
>
>

Ronald Ross.
NASA, not Mussorgsky....... 
ronald@thistle.org
ke6jab.

From: Dave Bayer <dlb@OCF.Berkeley.EDU>

To: "\\SFRaves\\" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Burning stuff and rebirth and love
Message-ID: <Pine.APO.3.91.960828180703.3851A-100000@locusts.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
ReSent-Date: Thu, 29 Aug 1996 18:37:21 -0700 (PDT)
ReSent-From: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>
ReSent-To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
ReSent-Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.960829183721.10179S@taz.hyperreal.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

So there is this thread about love and how burning man is not about love 
or renewal or rebirth or putting a lot of energy into something 
completely useless and futile because at the end of the day everything is 
completely useless and futile but you might as well do something 
completely useless and futile that is fun or what have you. Then there is 
this question about whether that involves love. And then there seems to 
be loads of people saying it is all about love or it is devoid of love 
which makes me wonder if these people have the same idea of love and I 
doubt they do.
	So, let me inject something a thought here. To some, like myself, 
love has nothing to do with playing with fuzzy animals and depending on 
support from those "loved" ones or lying around in big cuddle piles (all 
of which can be nice) or whatever else I have seen "love" described as or 
when I have been a part, have had people tell me that they just love me. 
That's nice, but I hope it's not because I chose to wave around a stuff 
animal and merely smile. And if these are things that make up an event 
that is "filled with love" then I agree, Burning Man is pretty devoid of 
love.
	To me, the greatest love comes from those people who let me be 
who I am at the moment, and who aren't going to start placing all kinds 
of conditions on how I interact with them. They are people who are not 
going to let me ask too much of them or let me lull myself into some 
whinging state in which I cannot deal with my own shit on a day to day 
basis. They are the people who take responsiblity for themselves and let 
those around them do the same. And I have found burning man to be a 
ffestival full of these people.
	So before going out and yelling about how this place is evil and 
how people should not go, why not let them go and decide for themselves 
whether they think it is evil, whether they enjoy the saracasm of the 
events or whatever they find in them? Why not let them go out and look at 
themselves and see if they are how they want to be, or if they might 
learn to more how they want to be out on the playa? Saying something 
about your feelings on the subject is your right and often leads to 
discussion that might let you see someone's views, buyt some of this 
thread seems like I-know-what-is-best-for-everyone, and I for one, don't 
like other people demanding to live my life for me. Please let me make my 
own mistakes because, to a certain degree, it is the best way I learn...

dave

     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" Beats and
       atmospherics w/DJ Seth. KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

From: Milton Cecil <moonpup@hooked.net>
Received: (from moonpup@localhost) by bass.hooked.net (8.7.3/8.7.3) id VAA10841; Thu, 29 Aug 1996 21:05:58 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Thu, 29 Aug 1996 21:05:58 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <199608300405.VAA10841@bass.hooked.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: conceptual BM jargin
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I hate to be so blunt, shallow, and mindless, in that I truly don't
understand exactly what burning man is meant to be or mean, but it's
interesting to see people offer all these great birth/death concepts, and
other really deep thoughts in regard to what burning man means, and I'm
sure that there were some spiritual agendas that the promoters had in mind
when they began the concept many years ago. 
 
I actually feel that I don't fully understand how deep the concepts and
reasons for BM are, although I have more insight now about it than I did 2
days ago, and from what I am starting to realize is that it means different
things to different people. 
 
After being in the UK all summer and attending a few festivals and seeing
the rave element in it's grandest scheme, I have a huge respect for BM
because it INCLUDES a rave area in it's concept as well as all the other
elements it has to offer.  
 
What makes it my favorite event to attend is that it is all inclusive, and
not just about one concept (like rave).  While the festivals in Europe
cater primarily to a rave element and audience, the BM offers one a chance
to see and hear and participate in many different perspectives of life well
beyond just raving. (excuse me for using the word "rave", but it does help
to make the point.) 
 
It is this element of BM that turned me on so much last year (my first BM),
in addition to the fact that they offered a rave camp and besides, I got to
hang out and be with some of my favorite people in the world.  
 
My parents were hippies and musicians when I was a child, and I hung out at
hippie communes, jazz festivals, nudist colonies (yes I was around in the
60's and 70's) and had many different perspectives and experiences to help
mold me into the cyber hippie freak that I consider myself now. DJing in
the 90's and playing many different styles of music, (not just house,
trance, techno, or triphop etc...) is just another perspective to help make
me even more varied and diversified as an individual. 
 
It is the very mixture of hippy/cyber/rasta/gay and whatever other elements
etc, and the variety of people that are extremely varied in life, age,
backgrounds, race, and beliefs, etc... that gives me a feeling that this is
an open minded and futuristic place, while at the same time has basic
humanistic values that trancend time, race, sex, and values. and gives me a
feeling of being a child back in the 60's. 
 
I remember last year I was astonished that some ravers hung out in the rave
camp only, and never even walked over and checked out the BM camp. I felt
what a shame to close yourself off to such a glorious experience, just
because you are so into raving, that you could'nt explore the elements of
BM beyond just your interests. 
 
 
 
(here comes the really shallow and mindless part). I truly have to say that
one of the main reasons I attend BM is that I get to do lots of drugs, get
naked (legally), and in general just be as wild & free as I can possibly
be. This world is far too uptight and rigid, and we rarely get a chance to
release the kind of emotions and energy that BM offers. 
 
This summer I went to a festival in France and I saw 2 girls (excuse
me.....women), that were topless and rolling around in the mud. I had to
approach and ask if they had ever heard of BM, they had not so I began to
tell them about the mud people at last years event. as I began to explain
it I decided to join them, and so I got naked and took a running start and
literally dove in with them.  
 
Now at last years BM I thought wow, I could'nt possibly roll around naked
in mud (well I could roll around naked, just not neccesarily in mud), I
thought who wants to get that dirty with no showers around etc....., but
aftrer rolling in the mud with my new friends, I realized the irony of the
situation was that once I got totally covered in mud like that, nothing the
rest of the weekend could affect me. I did'nt need to worry about sitting
in the dirt fields where the cow's shit, or walking through a stream bare
foot and getting my feet dirty, or getting dirty climbing a tree, etc....
The fact that I had already gotten completely covered from head to toe in
mud, meant that I'd already been there, and so it gave me a sense of
freedom I had never felt before. 
 
well anyway I hope this helps to clarify my position on why I am so
emotional about the BM event. It has helped to give me more freedom than I
could ever find before. (and without even fully understanding the true
spiritual elements) 
 
so don't be suprized if you see me leading the charge at mudhenge 
 
I would just like to add one last observation, and that is that I think
anyone who has ever thrown an event, or plans to in the future could learn
a great deal from the organizers of BM. they have captured an ora,
imagination and feeling that trancends beyond anything I've witnesses
before. In addition they have the backing of the local authorities because
they approach all aspects of it with dignity, respect, and care. 
 
I hope to see as many of you out there as I can possibly can.........I
can't wait

Not to forget the cool Egyptian motifs - pyramids, sphinx's, etc
which added a nice touch, I thought!

Very young crowd. And the famous juice bar, where I had the pleasure
of meeting Raven for the first time, hi Raven! (Hope you had fun at
BM!).

But I had to leave early as I was saving my energy for crewing at
Hallucination the following night! (hi Ran, Steve, Brendon the 
firestarter, etc!).

- Martin

> 
> Venue: Remote, but not too remote ;)  Roomy :)  A little too much delay in
> sound from corner to corner, though, as speakers were placed in each.
> There were groups dancing in each corner, in front of the dj, and all
> throughout, and still there was room to move around :)
> Dance/chill area separation: insufficient to separate sound :(
> Air: not hot OR smoky :)
> Lighting: Impressive; radiating lights above turntables, a clear plastic
> person with blinking colored lights inside suspended from the ceiling.  A
> couple house lights on made the place to lit up, though :|
> Music: Wonderful and dancy throughout, only one near-trainwreck, well
> recovered.  Dj Trance was in rare form, and Moshe was a madman with his
> scratching frenzy in the chill area! :D
> VIBE: Not intense, but very pleasant and positive.  Friendly people.  Hare
> Krishnas were cool.  The crew were enthusiastic.
> Features: Free massage was excellent!  The butterflies were beautiful, but
> it was just a glass case.  I was hoping for something more interactive, but
> that might have gotten out of hand...
> This was the first party in a long time where I didn't know at least 1/3 of
> the people.  It was refreshing, but I missed everyone who wasn't there.  We
> got to bring in water :)  I left my candy bag unattended in both areas, and
> it was unmolested the whole party through :D
> Overall: I greatly enjoyed the party!  Excellent job on the part of the
> Nexus crew; I hope to attend their events again.
> 
> Peace,
> Eric
> 
>

Re: Burning Man, etc.

Eric P. Peterson wrote:
> [moonpup gave his point of view on Burning Man]
> Thank you, moonpup!  I thought I didn't understand the concept of BM
> either, and that was a large part of my decision not to go.  It appears
> (from your observation and others') that Burning Man is all about freedom
> and release.

I've seen a lot of talk about the MEANING of Burning Man, and I've not
said anything until now.  When I went last year, somebody who had gone
before had the sense to tell me that there is NO real meaning.  It is
what it is and also what you make of it.  It's whatever you want it to
be.

So last year I pondered a bit (during the eight hour car trip), and
decided that for me, the Burning of the Man was going to represent the
burning of a lot of behaviors and traits in me that I didn't like.  Last
summer was a very introspective summer for me, and I learned a lot about
myself.  I had become very intimate with the monsters, demons, and
angels that make up my personality.  Burning Man last year was the
culmination of those thoughts and experiences, and during the actual
ritual I worked hard to burn the demons and free the angels.

This year, frankly, I haven't thought about it much.  I've been so busy
with my daily life that it's only been until last night that I realized
it's almost upon me.  Today, I finish packing and wait for my ride and
start thinking about the meaning of B.M. for me THIS YEAR.  I have no
answers yet, but I can tell you that it is NOT solely a RAVE for me,
although I probably will.

When I'm there I draw on the spiritual energy of the place.  Think about
it: it is a prehistoric lakebed.  The place is OLD, VERY OLD, and there
is some STRONG energy there.  You can feel the energy, and with a little
work you can tap into it.

One other note: the theme of being free is very prevalent.  There's
something very special about going to a place where there really no laws
and nobody really cares about what you're doing or why you are the way
you are.  Everybody is accepted as is.

HERE'S A GOOD STORY FROM LAST YEAR TO ILLUSTRATE:

My friend C. and I were near the man after he had been burned.  I was
dancing around the fire, but C. was about twenty feet away, in the
moonlit darkness.  It was a while before I noticed about seven cops
(local, state, I can't remember) standing away from the fire, watching. 
I was a little weirded out, but I ignored them.  My friend C. was
smoking a cigarette, a little behind and to the side of them, also
watching the fire.

After a while the cops turned to go and, as they walked passed him, one
came over and asked him for a cigarette and a light.  C. said sure,
picked up his backpack from the ground, gave the cop a cigarette and a
light.  The other cops had all stopped and were standing around
nonchalantly.  The cop said "Thanks a lot" and then they all turned and
walked away.  They were very cool, he said.

It was at that moment that my friend C. realized he was standing there
stark naked except for his shoes.


Anyway, I leave in a few hours.  Hope you all have a marvelous time
here.  Remember: IT IS WHAT YOU MAKE OF IT.  I think that applies to
more than just life -- uh -- Burning Man, I mean. :-)

pauly

x-radio
http://www-x-radio.com/x-radio/

A pen-pal of mine in Singapore sent this to me.  I think the message could 
be generalized to include any perception altering substance.  You're all so 
beautiful.  I hope you take a moment to consider...

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

DEATH OF AN INNOCENT

I went to a party, Mom, I remembered what you said.
You told me not to drink, Mom, so I drank soda instead.
I really felt proud inside, Mom, the way you said I would.
I didn't drink and drive, Mom, even though the others said I should.

I know I did the right thing, Mom, I know you are always right.
Now the party is finally ending, Mom, as everyone is driving out of sight.
As I got into my car, Mom, I knew I'd get home in one piece.
Because of the way you raised me, so responsible and sweet.

I started to drive away, Mom, but as I pulled out into the road,
the other car didn't see me, Mom, and hit me like a load.
As I lay there on the pavement, Mom, I hear the policeman say,
the other guy is drunk, Mom, and now I'm the one who will pay.

I'm lying here dying, Mom.  I wish you'd get here soon.
How could this happen to me, Mom?  My life just burst like a balloon.
There is blood all around me, Mom, and most of it is mine.
I hear the medic say, Mom, I'll die in a short time.

I just wanted to tell you, Mom, I swear I didn't drink.
It was the others, Mom.  The others didn't think.
He was probably at the same party as I.
The only difference is, he drank and I will die.

Why do people drink, Mom?  It can ruin your whole life.
I'm feeling sharp pains now.  Pains just like a knife.
The guy who hit me is walking, Mom, and I don't think it's fair.
I'm lying here dying and all he can do is stare.

Tell my brother not to cry, Mom.  Tell Daddy to be brave.
And when I go to heaven, Mom, put "Daddy's Girl" on my grave
Someone should have told him, Mom, not to drink and drive.
If only they had told him, Mom, I would still be alive.

My breath is getting shorter, Mom.  I'm becoming very scared.
Please don't cry for me, Mom.  When I needed you, you were always there.
I have one last question, Mom, before I say good bye.
I didn't drink and drive, so why am I the one to die?

************************
Someone took the effort to write this poem.

So please, forward this to as many people as you can.
And see if we can get a chain going around the world that will
make people understand that drinking and driving don't mix.

TOGETHER WE CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE, so please forward this letter
to as many people as you can.

There are plenty of US who have not gone, for one reason or another.  This
is year number two that I had tentative plans and they fell through.  Oh
well, no biggie, hopefully next year, if I still have an SO, then I'll go,
otherwise my ass will be at home next year as well.

For this weekend, I have my son for the duration (very, very cool!!!), so
we'll be doing the city, scamming on wimmin, and doing father and son
stuff.  I would rather be doing this than crackerjacking in the desert.

There is life outside of BM, rave, parties, etc.  I like it all.

Peace & have a good weekend,
John

P.S.  Also there will be a BBQ at my son's godfather's house, so we'll be
cruising by there.  Sultan will get to see his dad get a bit irreverant,
all in all the formula for a great weekend.

Peace.

>      to take a deep breath and let go a little.
>      
>      As for the big promoted raves, if it wasn't for this list I would 
>      never know about the small ones (thanks for this list BTW!), and I'd 
>      be stuck going to the big ones.  I like the small ones more because 
>      it's more like an intimate party and less like a concert or other 
>      super size event (kinda that "I love the friends I have gathered on 
>      this thin raft" feeling).
>      
>      I've been to great, peaceful parties thrown by people who obviously 
>      run in gangs, and I've gotten my ass kicked in Venice by "mellow peace 
>      loving" rastafarians.  How far is this shit going to go on before 
>      somebody starts throwing all white rich kid raves?

>      Relax, think about why you go, and decide.  If you want to split a

>      trouble and I can help, let me know.  Raving is about letting go of 
>      that so and so looks like this and that bullshit.  Walk up to the next 
>      person that freaks you out at a rave, and say hello and smile.  See 
>      them smile back?  That's vibe.  Do it again.  Lay it down.  Spread it
